div1.head: Antiphon
div1.p: ANTIPHON: 480 — 411 B.C. Approximate period of extant work, 421 — 411 B.C. Life in Attic Orators, I. 1 — 17.

Style. Antiphon, the earliest forensic speech-writer (logogra/fos), represents that early style of Attic prose composition which Dionysius (de comp. verb. 22 — 24) calls the ‘austere’ or ‘rugged’ (au)sthra\ a(rmoni/a), as distinguished from the ‘smooth’ (glafura/) of Isokrates, and the ‘middle’ (me/sh) of Demosthenes. Its leading characteristics are (1) dignity: ‘the movement of the whole is to be slow and majestic, impressing by its weight and grandeur, not charming by its life and flow’: (2) reliance on contrasts of single words: e.g. gnwristai/ — dikastai/ — docastai/ — kritai/, Antiph. De Caed. Her. § 94: (3) bold, but not florid, imagery: e.g. e)pi\ th=| e)mautou= a)paidi/a| zw=n e)/ti katoruxqh/somai, Tetr. II. B § 10: (4) sparing use of the ‘figures of thought’, sxh/mata dianoi/as, — as irony, rhetorical question, etc.: see Attic Orators, I. 29: (5) predominance of direct appeals to feeling (pathos) over subtle expression of character (êthos): (6) in the structure of sentences, the transition from a ‘continuous’ style, le/cis ei)rome/nh, in which clauses are simply strung together, to a periodic style, le/cis katestramme/nh.

Thucydides belongs to the same stage of Attic prose as Antiphon, differing from him principally in (1) a more pregnant brevity: (2) a tendency to peculiar arrangements of words, caused by desire of emphasis on the key-note of the thought: e.g. Thuc. v. 91, e)pi\ swthri/a| nu=n tou\s lo/gous e)rou=men th=s u(mete/ras po/lews, instead of e)pi\ swt. th=s u(met. po/l.: (3) a tendency to bring a greater number of clauses within the compass of a single sentence, in order that the whole of a complex thought may be seen at one view. — See Attic Orators, I. 18 — 44. On Antiphon's Works in general, ib. 45 — 70.

div2.head: *tetralogi/a2 speech 2
div2.p: The Tetralogies have this special interest, that they represent rhetoric in its transition from the technical to the practical stage, from the schools to the lawcourts and the ecclesia. Antiphon stood between the sophists who preceded and the orators who followed him as the first Athenian who was at once a theorist of rhetoric and a master of practical eloquence. The Tetralogies hold a corresponding place between merely ornamental exercises and real orations. Each of them forms a set of four speeches, supposed to be spoken in a trial for homicide. The accuser states his charge, and the defendant replies; the accuser then speaks again, and the defendant follows with a second reply. The imaginary case is in each instance sketched as lightly as possible; details are dispensed with; only the essential frame-work for discussion is supplied. Hence, in these skeleton-speeches, the structure and anatomy of the argument stand forth in naked clearness, stripped of everything accidental, and showing in bold relief the organic lines of a rhetorical pleader's thought. — Attic Orators, I. 45 f. The Tetralogies are distinguished by their practical character from the ‘displays’ of the sophists as well as from the ‘declamations’ of the Augustan age.

The subject of the Second Tetralogy is the death of a boy accidentally struck by a javelin while watching a youth practising at the gymnasium. The boy's father accuses the youth — whose father defends him — of accidental homicide; and the case comes before the court of the Palladion. In order to understand the issues raised, it is necessary to keep in mind the Greek view of accidental homicide. This view was mainly a religious one. The death was a pollution. Some person, or thing, must be answerable for that pollution, and must be banished from the State, which would else remain defiled. In a case like the supposed one, three hypotheses were possible: — that the cause of the impurity had been the thrower, the person struck, or the missile. There was a special court — that held at the Prutaneion — for the trial of inanimate things which had caused death. Here, however, the question is only of living agents. The judges have nothing whatever to do with the question as to how far either was morally to blame. The question is simply which of them is to be considered as, in fact, the author or cause of the death.

The accuser's first speech consists only of a few sentences, in which he says that the facts admit of no doubt. A homicide has been committed, though an involuntary one. The penalty demanded is the banishment of the accused, in order that Athens may not be polluted by his presence (mh\ periora=n a(/pasan th\n po/lin u(po\ tou/tou miainome/nhn § 2). It is expressed by the phrase ei)/rgein w(=n o( no/mos ei)/rgei ib. and g. § 11. The
condemned person remained in exile until the relatives of the deceased gave their consent to his return (e(/ws a)\n ai)de/shtai/ tis tw=n e)n ge/nei tou= peponqo/tos: cp. Dem. or. XXXVII. Adv. Pantaen. § 59, or. XLIII. Adv. Macart. § 57): the usual statement that the term was limited to a year (a)peniautismo/s) needs confirmation, at least for Athens. See K. F. Hermann, Antiq. I. § 104. 11.

div3.p: a)pra/gmonas a)pra/gmwn, the man ‘of quiet life’, who keeps out of law-suits and politics: h(su/xios, the man ‘of peaceful disposition’. In regard to law-suits, the Athenian a)pra/gmwn stood in favourable contrast with the sukofa/nths, but in politics he was despised: Thuc. II. 40, to\n mhde\n tw=nde (tw=n politikw=n) mete/xonta ou)k a)pra/gmona a)lla\ a)xrei=on nomi/zomen.
tolma=n ta/ te a)/lla=ta/ te a)/lla tolma=n. For te misplaced, cp. Thuc. IV. 10, h)\n e)qe/lwme/n te mei=nai kai\ mh\ kataprodou=nai.

th
 a)kri/beian ‘the exact truth’. Thuc. I. 22, xalepo
 h)=n diamnhmoneu=sai th
 a)kri/beian au)th
 tw=n lexqe/ntwn, ‘the exact form’.
kai\ au)to/s ‘myself also’: — alluding to the accuser's previous appeal (a. § 2), u(ma=s de\ a)ciw= e)leou=ntas, k.t.l.

a)kribe/steron ‘with more subtlety’ — referring especially to the distinction which he proceeds to draw between pra/ktores tw=n a)kousi/wn and tw=n paqhma/twn ai)/tioi (§ 6). The accuser, in his second speech (g. § 3), says, mh\ e)/rga fanera\ u(po\ ponhra=s lo/gwn a)kribei/as (‘a quibbling subtlety’) peisqe/ntes yeudh= th\n a)lh/qeian tw=n praxqe/ntwn h(gh/shsqe.

mh\...th\n kri/sin poih/sasqai With the vulg., mh\ dia\ ta\s proeirhme/nas tu/xas a)podecame/nous, k.t.l., we can only render: ‘I ask you to entertain my defence, and not to give your judgment — under the influence of those mischances to which I have referred — on grounds of opinion rather than of fact’. But the position of a)podecame/nous...a)pologi/an, inserted between mh/ and poih/sasqai, is then intolerable. Blass conjectures i)/sa tai=s proeirhme/nais tu/xais: i.e. ‘I beg you not to receive my defence in the spirit — not to view them in the light — of the mischances’, etc. The objections are (1) the phrase i)/sa tai=s... tu/xais, which surely will not yield such a sense: (2) the necessarily favourable sense of a)podecame/nous. I propose, retaining dia\...ta\s tu/xas, to insert h(=tto/n ti before a)podecame/nous: ‘I beg you not to entertain my defence the less favourably on account of the mischances to which I have referred’. See p. 55, § 8, for another instance in which h(=tton seems to have dropped out. — An alternative remedy would be
to change a)podecame/nous for some partic. of opposite meaning (‘having rejected’); but neither a)podokima/santas nor a)pwsame/nous is palaeographically probable.
pro\s tw=n le/gein dun ‘is on the side of’, ‘favours’, those who can speak. Eur. Alc. 57, pro\s tw=n e)xo/ntwn, *foi=be, to\n no/mon ti/qhs, ‘for the rich’ — in their interest.

para\ gnw/mhn tou/twn ‘The result has completely disappointed these expectations’:=para\ tau=ta a(\ h)/lpizon, the genitive tou/twn depending on the idea of contrariety implied in para\ gnw/mhn, as if he had written sumbe/bhke/ moi e)nanti/a tou/twn.
meira/kion usu. denotes the age from about 14 to 18: pai=s is younger. Xen. Symp. IV. 17, w(/sper ge pai=s gi/gnetai kalo/s, ou(/tw kai\ meira/kion kai\ a)nh\r kai\ presbu/ths.

ou)x u(/brei ou)de\ a)kolasi/a| ‘insolence or wantonness’. The essence of u(/bris is that it indulges the sense of power by humiliating another: a)kolasi/a does what it likes at the moment, without thinking of others. Aristotle distinguishes three ei)/dh of o)ligwri/a (slight esteem), — viz. katafro/nhsis (contempt), e)phreasmo/s (active spite), u(/bris, outrage (Rhet. II. 2), — the point of e)phreasmo/s being that it vexes the other, and of u(/bris that it dishonours him. Arist. makes a)kolasi/a the u(perbolh\ peri\ h(dona\s kai\ lu/pas, — the meso/ths being swfrosu/nh. The accuser, in his reply, attributes a)kolasi/a to the youth (g. § 6).

e)n tw=| gumnasi/w| The palai/stra, the school of wrestling and boxing, is often mentioned in connection with the didaskalei=on as a place of training for boys: cp. Theophr. Char. VII. The gumna/sion was a more general resort, including grounds for running and archery, baths, and (as here) a range for javelin practice. Plato recommends that a boy should begin at six years of age to learn riding, and the us of the bow, javelin and sling: ‘letters’ he postpones to the age of ten (Legg. VII. 794 C).
a)kousi/ous ai)ti/as ‘charges arising from an involuntary act’. A harsh phrase: but the conj. a)nosi/ous seems weak.

mh\ foneu=sin ei)=nai Notice the simple mh/, where mh\ ou) would be regular. Cp. Soph. Phil. 349, ou) polu\n | xro/non m' e)pe/sxon mh/ me naustolei=n taxu/. So Trach. 226. This is more frequent with to\ mh/, e.g. O. T. 1387: Xen. Cyr. v. 1. 25, ti/s sou= a)pelei/fqh to\ mh/ soi a)kolouqei=n; Her. I. 209, ou)k w)=n e)/sti mhxanh\...ou)demi/a to\ mh\ kei=non e)pibouleu/ein e)moi/.
<o( me\n e)kwlu/qh>] Cp. § 7, e)/paqe...diakwluqei\s tou= skopou= tuxei=n.

ei)/per...a)poqanw/n ‘As to the boy, if it has been proved to you that he was not struck while he stood still (e(stw/s), it is still more manifest that, since he came of his own accord into the course of the javelin, he was killed through his own error’. mh/ and not ou) before blhqei/s because it depends on ei)/per: but ou) would have been admissible here, owing to the emphasis on the negative fact. Cp. on De Caed. Her. § 14. — u(pelqw\n...dhlou=tai...a)poqanw/n. Since, or because, he came,... it is clear that he died: =to\ u(pelqei=n au)to\n dhloi= o(/ti...a)pe/qane. So we might have, a)melh/sas dh=lo/s e)stin a(martw/n, ‘it is clear that he erred by carelessness’. The argument is: ‘If he voluntarily left a safe place, he alone is answerable for the consequences’. In e)/ti safeste/rws the comparative is merely rhetorical: — It must be, if possible, more obvious still, etc. Note the alternative forms safeste/rws, safe/steron (§ 6): cp. Isocr. Panegyr. § 193.

w(=n a)\n e)pinoh/swsi/ ti dra=sai The proper construction would have been simply a(marta/nontes w(=n (=tou/twn a(/) a)\n e)pinoh/swsi, failing in the designs which they may have formed. But to this ti dra=sai is added, as if, instead of a(marta/nontes, such a word as kwluqe/ntes had preceded: failing to execute some part of their designs. The redundancy was suggested by the antithesis between planning and doing: cp. Thuc. v. 13, ou)k a)cio/xrewn au)tw=n o)/ntwn dra=n ti w(=n ka)kei=nos e)peno/ei.

a)peirhme/non...prostetagme/non Accus. absol.: prostetagme/non also in Plat. Legg. X. 902 D. So de/on — e)co/n — pare/xon — parasxo/n — prosh=kon — ei)rhme/non — dedogme/non — gegramme/non — prostaxqe/n, k.t.l. Goodwin § 110. 2.
e)cemele/ta ‘was carefully practising’. Plat. Hipp. mai. 286 D, a)kou/sas kai\ maqw\n kai\ e)kmeleth/sas (having perfected my skill) pa/lin i)e/nai e)pi\ to\n e)rwth/santa.

e)n gumnazome/nois i.e. not among those who were practising athletic exercises (where the risk of an ccident would have been greater), but ‘in the rank’ (ta/cis) of the javelin-throwers, who had a special part of the gymnasium reserved for them.

tetimwrhme/nos e(auto/n Cp. De Caed. Her. § 21, to\n plou=n pepoihme/nos. So Thuc. III. 67, tetimwrhme/noi, ‘having taken vengeance’: but in Thuc. VII. 77 it is passive, a)poxrw/ntws h)/dh tetimwrh/meqa, ‘we have been punished’: and so VI. 60, e)tetimw/rhnto. So e.g. memimhme/nos, e)ntequmhme/nos, e)skemme/nos, h)|tiame/nos, kekthme/nos, can be either midd. or pass.

ou) sunhdome/nwn ou)de\ suneq The use of sun- in the first pair of compounds is incorrect: the meaning is, ou)k e)pixairo/ntwn ou)d' e)qelo/ntwn: but the form of the first clause is assimilated to that of the second. Cp. Thuc. I. 142 § 2,
h( e)pitei/xisis...h(mw=n a)ntepiteteixisme/nwn, ‘when our city (Athens) is a counter-fortress to theirs’, as Shilleto takes it: the e)pi/ in a)ntepit. losing its proper force (‘on hostile soil’), and being merely in rhetorical symmetry with e)pitei/xisis. — h(mw=n] = tou=de me\n tou= nhpi/ou, e)mou= de\ tou= ghraiou=, § 11. More boldly below, § 9, w(s fone/a me diw/kei.
mhde\ a)kousi/ws ‘not even involuntarily’: i.e. the boy himself was ai)/tios tou= paqh/matos, § 6.

a)poluo/menos de/...e)sme/n The anacolouthon is caused by the speaker's thought passing, as the sentence goes on, from the charge of which the son is really innocent to the consequences for both father and son, if he is condemned.

tw=n e)pithdeuma/twn ‘our aims in life’. Cp. § 3, tau=ta paideu/wn to
 ui(o
 e)c w(=n ma/lista to\ koino
 w)felei=tai. — e)pith/deuma, a practice founded on a principle, Thuc. I. 32, 37.
ou(=to/s te ga/r [I say "we,"] for both he, etc.

e)pi/ te ga/r] e)pi/ before diafqora=| might mean ‘after’: but it is better to take it, both with diafqora=| and with a)paidi/a|, as denoting the condition. ‘If he is to perish’...‘if I am to be left childless’.

zw=n...katoruxqh/somai The accuser, in his second speech, appropriates the metaphor (g. § 12), zw=ntes katorwru/gmeqa u(p' au)tou=. This is characteristic of the Tetralogies (cp. b. § 2 and g. § 3, ei)s to\n u(me/teron e)/leon katapefeugw/s), which are repertories of points and topics, not examples of finished form.
ghraiou= A poetical word, used by Herod.; also once by Thuc. VI. 54, *peisistra/tou...ghraiou= teleuth/santos: but not in later Attic prose.
sumfe/rein Xen. Cyr. IV. 3 § 13, e)kei=no de\ ou)xi\ eu)pete/s, to\ o(/ ti a)\n de/h| o(/plon fe/rein, to\n i(/ppon tou=to sumfe/rein; (help to carry it.)

div2.head: *tetralogi/a3 speech 1
div2.p: — An elderly man having died of blows received in a quarrel, the youth who had dealt them is accused of murder before the Areiopagus. The accuser's first address expresses in a striking form the religious view of homicide as a defilement. See Attic Orators, I. 55.

div3.p: tou\s prw/tous genome/nous Cp. Hes. Op. 109, xru/seon me\n prw/tista ge/nos mero/pwn a)nqrw/pwn | a)qa/natoi poi/hsan... karpo\n d' e)/fere zei/dwros a)/roura | au)toma/th pollo/n te kai\ a)/fqonon.

tw=n a)lithri/wn ‘avenging spirits’. The gods under whose protection the murdered person stood, and to whom his spirit turns for vengeance — oi( tw=n a)poqano/ntwn prostro/paioi
(§ 4) — become a)lith/rioi, punishers of sin, in relation to the murderer. The commoner sense of a)lith/rios is ‘sinful’, with a genit. of the god offended or the place polluted (e.g. qew=n, *(ella/dos): for the double meaning, cp. a)la/stwr, mia/stwr, prostro/paios, a)fi/ktwr, prosi/ktwr.
ou) prosh=kon ‘gratuitous’: strictly ‘alien’, — not arising from their own sin. From another point of view, ‘selfinflicted’ woes are oi)kei=a pa/qh, Soph. Ai. 260.

ou) timwrou=ntes (1) timwrei=n tina/ tini, to punish A for B's satisfaction: (2) timwrei=sqai/ tina/ tini, to revenge oneself on A for wronging B. The accus. is more often omitted with timwrei=n, the dat. with timwrei=sqai.

toi=s e)pitimi/ois A word of poetical cast, like many which the older prose writers used: see Attic Orators, I. 20. Soph. El. 1382, ta)piti/mia th=s dussebei/as. Lycurg. In Leocr. § 4, ta\ e)k tw=n no/mwn e)piti/mia.
kai\ tou= u(mete/rou a(mart. u(pai/tioi ‘responsible for your offence also’. u(pai/tios is not ‘accessory’, like metai/tios or parai/tios opposed to panai/tios, but ‘under’, ‘liable to, ai)ti/a’.
u(/brei kai\ a)kolasi/a| Cp. note on Tetr. *b. b. § 3.

tw=n geraiote/rwn As ta\ tw=n g. no/mima could not mean ‘the privileges of elders’, we can only render ‘the institutions of our ancestors’. But it may be suspected that the text is corrupt, and that the to\n geraio/teron of N points to this. The contention is that he would in any case have been guilty of homicide; but that the offence has been aggravated by violence to a man so much older than himself. After to\n geraio/teron, tu/yas or a similar participle may have fallen out.
a(martei=n ‘to miss’: Andoc. De Myst. § 20, duoi=n toi=n megi/stoin kakoi=n ou)k h)=n au)tw=| a(martei=n. Cp. dikaiou=sqai, ‘to get one's due’, to be punished, Thuc. III. 40.
timwrei=sqai Middle, ‘to punish Cp. Tetr. *g. d. § 11, to\n de\ miaro\n tw=| xro/nw| a)podo/ntes fh=nai toi=s e)/ggista timwrei=sqai u(polei/pete.

th\n bouleu/sasan yuxh/n Cp. Andoc. De Reditu § 24, where he argues that not his sw=ma but his gnw/mh was answerable for his deeds: h( de\ gnw/mh a)nti\ th=s prote/ras e(te/ra nuni\ pare/sthken. Here, as there, the sinning mind is personified. In Thuc. yuxh/ is nearly always ‘the breath of life’ in a physical sense: once, in II. 40 § 3, kra/tistoi th\n yuxh/n = eu)yuxo/tatoi, of moral courage.

div2.p:
Herodes, an Athenian citizen, had settled at Mytilene in 424 B.C., after the
revolt and reduction of that town. He was one of the cleruchs among whom its territory was apportioned, but not otherwise wealthy. Having occasion to make a voyage to Aenos on the coast of Thrace, to receive the ransom of some Thracian captives who were in his hands, he sailed from Mytilene with the accused, — a young man whose father, a citizen of Mytilene, lived chiefly at Aenos. Herodes and his companion were driven by a storm to put in at Methymna on the north-west coast of Lesbos; and there, as the weather was wet, exchanged their open vessel for another which was decked. After they had been drinking on board together, Herodes went ashore at night, and was never seen again.

The accused, after making every inquiry for him, went on to Aenos in the open vessel; while the decked vessel, into which they had moved at Methymna, returned to Mytilene. On reaching the latter place again, the defendant was charged by the relatives of Herodes with having murdered him at the instigation of Lycînus, an Athenian living at Mytilene, who had been on bad terms with the deceased. They rested their charge principally on three grounds. First, that the sole companion of the missing man must naturally be considered accountable for his disappearance. Secondly, that a slave had confessed under torture to having assisted the defendant in the murder. Thirdly, that on board the vessel which returned from Methymna had been found a letter in which the defendant announced to Lycînus the accomplishment of the murder.

It was necessary that the trial should take place at Athens, whither all subject-allies were compelled to bring their criminal causes. The ordinary course would have been to have laid an indictment for murder (grafh\ fo/nou) before the Areiopagus. Instead, however, of doing this the relatives of Herodes laid an information against the accused as a ‘malefactor’ (kakou=rgos). He was accordingly to be tried by an ordinary dikastery under the presidency of the Eleven. ‘Malefactor’, at Athens, ordinarily meant a thief, a housebreaker, a kidnapper, or criminal of the like class; but the term was, of course, applicable to murder, especially if accompanied by robbery. Date about 417 B.C. See Attic Orators, I. 55 ff.

div3.head: 1. Narrative: §§ 1 — 30.
div3.p: e)boulo/mhn Without a)/n, — of that which one wishes were now true, but which is not so: Ar. Ran. 866, e)boulo/mhn me\n ou)k e)ri/zein e)nqa/de, ‘I could have wished that I was not’... Cp. the use of e)/dei, w)/felon, etc., with infin.: Goodwin § 49. 3. c.
tou= me/n...tou= de/] tou= me/n=th=s te sumfora=s kai\ tw=n kakw=n, adversity: tou= de/=th=s duna/mews tou= le/gein kai\ th=s e)mpeiri/as tw=n pragma/twn, — the power of self-defence.

ou(= me\n ga/r ‘In circumstances where I was forced to suffer personal ill-usage on the charge falsely brought, legal experience did not come to my rescue; and here, when I must save myself by help of the truth, and by a narrative of the facts, I am embarrassed by my incapacity for speaking’. kakopaqei=n, because he had been imprisoned, bail being refused: see § 17.

e)ntauqoi= So § 10, e)ntauqoi= pepoih/kasi th\n kri/sin, ‘they have brought the trial hither’. Here, too, the idea of motion can be elicited from w)fe/lhsen as=e)boh/qhsen. In Soph. Phil. 481, e)mbalou= m' ...o(/poi | h(/kista me/llw...a)lgunei=n, o(/poi=e)kei=se o(/pou. In Ar. Lys. 526, poi= xrh=n a)namei=nai = me/xri ti/nos xro/nou; Cp. Pors. on Eur. Hec. 1062.

a)/pistoi g. toi=s a)l.] ‘have been disbelieved because they told the truth’: toi=s a)lhqe/sin, a somewhat harsh instrumental dative, ‘by the truth’,=tw=| ta\ a)lhqh= le/gein. — dhlw=sai au)ta/, to prove, establish their story, which, though really true, seemed improbable.

e)pi\ toi=s tw=n kathg. lo/g.] ‘dependent upon’. au)ta\ ta\ e)/rga, ‘the actual facts’: h( a)lh/qeia tw=n pragma/twn, ‘the true version’ of the story. Cp. Tetr. *b. b. § 2, h( do/ca tw=n praxqe/ntwn, opposed to h( a)lh/qeia.

ou)x a(/per...a)kroa=sqai Our idiom requires, ou)x a(/per oi( polloi\ ai)tou=ntai, a)kroa=sqai au)tw=n. Cp. Plat. Gorg. 522 A, peinh=n kai\ diyh=n a)nagka/zwn, ou)x w(/sper e)gw\ polla\ kai\ h(de/a kai\ pantodapa\ eu)w/xoun u(ma=s: i.e. ou)x w(/sper e)gw\ e)poi/oun, eu)wxw=n.

ta/de de/ Note de/, where (after ou)x a(/per, k.t.l.) later prose would usu. have a)lla/: cp. Thuc. IV. 86, ou)k e)pi\ kakw=|, e)p' e)leuqerw/sei de/. Soph. Ant. 84, promhnu/sh|s ge mhdeni\...|... krufh= de\ keu=qe. So ou)de/=a)ll' ou), Il. XXIV. 25.

a)lhqei/a|...ei)rh=sqai ‘that it has the force of truth, not of rhetorical art’. The proposed insertion of eu)= before ei)rh=sqai seems to weaken the sense. a)lhqei/a|, deino/thti, instrumental dat., like toi=s a)lhqe/sin in § 3: by means of, in the strength of.

kai/ pou/ ti kai\ e)cam The first kai/=‘also’: i.e. as he is in peril, so will he be nervous: the second kai/=‘e'en’, ‘actually’, belonging to e)camartei=n: pou=‘I suppose’, rather than ‘at some point’. The very fact that a man's life is at stake makes it almost certain that he will commit some indiscretion.

diapra/sswntai...o)rqoume/nous ‘But when they are
seeking (present) to effect some object without risks, they are more successful (as speakers)’. Cp. Soph. Ant. 675, tw=n d' o)rqoume/nwn, ‘of the prosperous’.
e)n tw=| u(met. dik.] ‘A part of your duty no less than of my right’: i.e. compatible with the h(liastiko\s o(/rkos taken by the dikasts.

ou) tw=| feu/gein a)/n ‘Not on the chance of eluding the judgment of the Athenian people’. tw=| feu/gein is a dat. expressing the motive as a circumstance of the action, like eu)noi/a| e)/praca, I acted with (or from) good will: as we might say, ‘I do not urge this by way of possibly escaping’. feu/gein a)/n, the oblique of feu/goimi a)/n, not of e)/feugon a)/n. — to\ plh=qos to\ u(me/teron, the judges as representing to\n dh=mon to\n *)aqhnai=on: a regular mode of respectful address: so Andoc. Myst. § 135, to\ plh=qos tw=n *)aqhnai/wn.

ka)\n a)nwmo/tois k.t.l. ‘I would commit my life to your decision even if you were bound by no oath, and were to decide on no basis of law’: kai\ mh\ kata\ no/mon mhde/na with diayhfi/sasqai. — e(/neka/ ge tou= pisteu/ein, ‘so far as concerns’, etc.
paranomi/a ‘illegal conduct’, often also in a general sense of anti-republican licence; ou) dhmotikh\ paranomi/a (of Alcibiades) Thuc. VI. 28.

kakou=rgos On the strength of the information (e)/ndeicis kakourgi/as) laid against him, he was arrested by the Eleven (a)pagwgh/n, § 9: a)ph/xqhn, § 85). The same summary procedure (instead of the ordinary grafh\ fo/nou) was taken against the murderers of Phrynichus in 411 B.C. (Lycurg. In Leocr. § 12) and against Agoratus (Lys. In Agorat. § 85). The speaker here seems to have been treated harshly, but not, as he alleges, illegally.

fasi\ de\ au)= They argue that the general term kakourgi/a includes to\ a)poktei/nein as well as to\ i(erosulei=n, etc.: he admits this, but argues that these greater kakourgh/mata should be tried under the laws special to each. The emendation fasi\ de\ au)to/ ge to\ a)poktei/nein, with w(/sper inserted before kai\ to\ i(erosulei=n, is needless, and suggests a contrast, which has no point here, between accidental homicide and deliberate murder.

e)n th=| a)gora=| The prosecutor in a case of fo/nos gave the accused formal notice (pro/rrhsis) to keep away from all public places: see below § 88. Several law-courts were situated in the market-place: Lys. or. 19, § 55, e)ggu\s oi)kw=n th=s a)gora=s ou)/te pro\s dikasthri/w| ou)/te pro\s bouleuthri/w| w)/fqhn ou)depw/pote. (though I live near)

a(/panta ta\ dikasth/ria viz. (1) the Areiopagus, (2) to\ e)pi\ *palladi/w|, for accidental homicide, (3) to\ e)n *freattoi=, when a man already banished for an accidental homicide is tried anew for murder, (4) to\ e)pi\ *delfini/w|, for homicide where justification is pleaded, (5) to\ e)pi\ *prutanei/w|, when an inanimate object had caused death. In the last four courts the e)fe/tai judged. Cp. Hermann Antiq. I. § 104.

tou=to de\ de/on se The apodosis would probably have been a)nw/motos me/n...kathgorei=s, at the beginning of § 12: but owing to the length of the sentence the construction is interrupted, and § 12 begins with a(\ (instead of tau=ta) su\ parelqw/n.
a)nw/motos me/n The usual prowmosi/a can scarcely have been dispensed with in cases of a)pagwgh/. The expression is rhetorical: ‘you have not taken the solemn oath of the Areiopagus’.

a(ptome/nous tw=n sfagi/wn ‘with hand laid upon the sacrifice’. Dem. In Aristocr. § 67, prw=ton me\n diomei=tai kat' e)cwlei/as au(tou= kai\ ge/nous kai\ oi)ki/as...sta\s e)pi\ tw=n tomi/wn kaprou= kai\ kriou= kai\ tau/rou, kai\ tou/twn e)sfagme/nwn u(f) w(=n dei= kai\ e)n ai(=s h(me/rais kaqh/kei.

<tou=to me\n>...tou=to d'] ‘in the first place’...‘in the next place’. The accuser says that the accused would have fled, if he had not been arrested. The accused replies that he would have had no motive for secret flight. He could have left Attica openly, either (1) before the proceedings began, in which case judgment would have gone by default: or (2) after the proceedings had begun, and when he had made his first speech in court, — in which case he would have accepted the penalty of exile.

i)/son h)=n moi ‘It was as good for me’ not to come: ‘I might as well not have come’. Blass inserts ei)=nai after o)flei=n, rendering aequum erat licere mihi: but the sense is, ‘I might as well have incurred judgment by default’.

th\n prote/ran sc. a)pologi/an: his first speech, in reply to the first speech of the accuser. In a trial which ran its full course, the accuser and the accused would each speak a second time. Dem. In Aristocr. § 69, to\n pro/teron d' e)/cestin ei)po/nta lo/gon metasth=nai. This voluntary withdrawal is expressed in Tetr. *g. d. § 1 by u(pape/sth.
a)rxaiota/tois Isocr. Panegyr. § 40, oi( ga\r e)n a)rxh=| peri\ tw=n fonikw=n e)gkale/santes...e)n toi=s no/mois toi=s h(mete/rois ta\s kri/seis e)poih/santo peri\ au)tw=n.

h)\ ou)/] ou)/, and not mh/, in the second clause, because there is an emphasis on the fact that he does not state the case
correctly. He seeks to lead you into an abstract speculation (ei) kalw=s kei=ntai h)\ mh/): you must draw a practical conclusion. Cp. Soph. Ai. 7, o(/pws i)/dh|s | ei)/t' e)/ndon ei)/t' ou)k e)/ndon.

ou)dei\s pw/pote Grote (v. 498) is with those who deny that Ephialtes took away the jurisdiction of the Areiopagus in homicide. In Lys. or. I. De Caed. Erat. § 30, w(=| kai\ pa/trio/n e)sti kai\ e)f' u(mw=n a)pode/dotai tou= fo/nou ta\s di/kas dika/zein, a)pode/dotai is not ‘it has been given back’, but ‘it is assigned’.

kai\ tau=ta parelqw/n Cp. § 12 a(\ su\ parelqw/n, § 11 su\ de\ tou=to me\n parelqw/n, k.t.l. Better here, then, ‘and having disregarded these ordinances’: rather than: ‘and, what is more, you have come forward’, etc.

w(s kai\ toi=s to/te dikastai=s, k.t.l. ‘as if, in fact, you meant to dispute the previous verdict’. oi( to/te dikastai/ are the judges who are now trying the case, but who, at the time denoted by a)pisth/swn, will be ‘the former judges’, whose verdict he will then seek to upset. It seems unnecessary to conjecture toi=sde toi=s or toi=s e)nqa/de.
mhde\ ple/on...mhd' ‘even if I am acquitted (so far from being finally saved) I am not even benefited’.
e)/ti de\ ma/l' e)de/qhn ‘Moreover, I was actually imprisoned’. ma/la is not=‘rigorously’, but merely gives a certain colloquial emphasis, ‘I can assure you’.

e)gguhta\s trei=s Dem. In Timocr. § 144 (from the oath of the bouleutai/), ou)de\ dh/sw *)aqhnai/wn ou)de/na o(\s a)\n e)gguhta\s trei=s kaqisth=| to\ au)to\ te/los telou=ntas (i.e. three i(ppei=s if he were a i(ppeu/s, etc.). The only exception was when the accused was charged with prodosi/a th=s po/lews or kata/lusis tou= dh/mou: and the object, Demosth. says, was to prevent malicious collusion among the r(h/tores in the boulh/.
oi( e)pimelhtai\ tw=n k.=oi( e(/ndeka, by whom the arrest on the e)/ndeicis kakourgi/as was made. Herm. Antiq. I. § 139. 13.
e)moi\ mo/nw| e)pe/lipe ‘failed in my case only’. The simple dat. gives this sense without the addition of e)p) proposed by Reiske. Baiter, needlessly, e)ne/lipe.

tou/s te fi/lous Cp. Dem. In Timocr. § 145, i(/na mh\ dia\ to\ dede/sqai xei=ron a)nagka/zointo a)gwni/zesqai h)\ kei) panta/pasin a)para/skeuoi ei)=en: where xei=ron, ‘at greater disadyantage’, means that the disgrace of their imprisonment would estrange their supporters.

polloi=s e)lasswqei/s, k.t.l. ‘placed at a disadvantage in respect to many points of your law and of justice’: because he had been accused as a kakou=rgos, and bail had been
refused. Cp. e)lassou/menoi, ‘suffering a disadvantage’, ‘exacting less than our due’, Thuc. I. 77: Dem. De Cor. § 3, polla\ me
 ou)=n e)/gwg' e)lattou=mai kata\ toutoni\ to
 a)gw=na *ai)sxi/nou. — e)lasswqei\s is Dobree's correction (supported by N) of the vulgate swqei\s a)/n, which could only mean, ‘when I might (justly) be acquitted’, ‘though entitled to acquittal’,=o(/te swqei/hn a)
 (ei) tw=n dikai/wn tu/xoimi). Cp. Xen. Mem. IV. 4. 4, r(a|di/ws a)
 a)feqei/s [=o(/te a)fei/qh a)
]...proei/leto a)poqanei=n. But, though grammatically possible, swqei\s a)/n ill suits the context.

*ai)=non a town on the coast of Thrace, on the promontory S.E. of the lake Stentoris at the mouth of the Hebrus: about 100 miles N. of Lesbos. It is named by Thuc. VII. 57 as one of three Aeolic places (Methymna and Tenedos being the others) which helped Athens against Sicily.
*qra|ci/n Her. v. 6 says of the Thracians, pwleu=si ta\ te/kna e)p' e)cagwgh=| (as slaves). *qra=|tta, a Thracian dou/lh, Theoph. Char. XXVIII.
h(...pro/fasis the (real) occasion: cp. Thuc. I. 23, th\n a)lhqesta/thn pro/fasin. But below § 26 h( pro/fasis is the (false) pretext. pro/fasis is a cause alleged — truly or untruly.

th=s *mhqumnai/as *mhqu/mnh (Molivo) on N.W. coast of Lesbos. Thuc. III. 2, *le/sbos plh\n *mhqu/mnhs a)pe/sth. The land of Methymna was not confiscated by Athens after the revolt (III. 50): and in VII. 57 its people are fo/rw| ou)x u(ph/kooi — an exemption shared in 415 B.C. only by Chios (VI. 85).
[to\n *(hrw/dhn A manifest gloss, which a comma after au)to\n fails to make tolerable.
pepoihme/nos Cp. Tetr. *b. b. § 8, tetimwrhme/nos.

e)gi/gneto ‘This, too, followed (imperf.) of necessity’: but e)ge/neto, ‘took place’, — of the same thing viewed, not as a consequence, but as an independent occurrence at a given moment in past time.
tau=t' ‘all this’: the mete/kbasis and its circumstances.

h)\ kai\ u(p' e)mou= The kai/ is redundant, and can be expressed only if we say ‘by me on my part’: but the Greek love of balanced contrast borrows it from the form, e)zhtei=to ou) mo/non u(po\ tw=n a)/llwn a)lla\ kai\ u(p' e)mou=. So Soph. El. 1146, O. C. 53, Ant. 927.

ei)/s te th\n *mit The te after ei)s corresponds with the kai/ before a)/llou (‘both — and’, i.e. ‘not only — but’): the clause kai\ t. e). g. e)pe/mpeto explains e)gw\ ai)/tios h)=n p.: ‘Not only was I the cause of a messenger being sent, — that is, it was on my
suggestion that it was proposed to send him (imperf.), — but’ etc.
e)/pempon ‘offered to send’. Aeschin. In Ctes. § 83, *(alo/nnhson e)di/dou: o( de\ a)phgo/reue mh\ lamba/nein: so e)/peiqon.
plou=s...e)gi/gneto ‘The weather favoured our voyage’: Thuc. I. 137, mhde/na e)kbh=nai e)k th=s new\s me/xri plou=s ge/nhtai.

e)pedh/moun ‘was still in the country’ — i.e. in Lesbos, before he had sailed for the coast of Thrace. Reiske wrongly, ‘Athenis adhuc versabar’ — supposing the speaker to have gone there from Aenos, before returning to Lesbos.
e)n me\n th=| gh=| The me/n is taken up by o(/pws d' h)fani/sqh: he had certainly been killed on land, they said, but how the body had disappeared, they could not tell.

a)\n e)du/nato The imperf. with a)/n might mean either (1) he would not now be able [as in fact he is]: or (2) he would not, at the supposed past time, have been able: the imperf. differing here from the aor. in expressing the man's state, and not merely his ability for a certain act at a certain moment. ‘He probably would not have been in a condition to control his own movements’.
o)pth/r A poet. word, used by Xen. in this sense, Cyr. IV. 6. 17.

ka)=|t' e)gw/ ‘Nevertheless, I concede [I will take for granted] the assertion of the prosecutors, — parexo/menos, although I bring witnesses’, etc. ei)=ta,=after all that I have proved: cp. Plat. Prot. 327 C.

mh\ o(mologou=sin a)poqanei=n Franke would write o(mol. mh\ a)poq., but the unusual order arises from the eager stress on the negative. Thuc. VI. 18, ou) mo/non e)pio/nta tis a)mu/netai, a)lla\ kai\ mh\ o(/pws e)/peisi prokatalamba/nei, i.e. o(/pws mh\ e)/peisi.
ti ai(=ma is a certain correction of the vulg. to\ ai(=ma. For the position of ti cp. Dem. Phil. III. § 47, e)/sti toi/nun tis eu)hqh\s lo/gos: Soph. Ai. 468, kai\ drw=n ti xrhsto/n.
ou)k e)nexw/rei ‘But when they found that this theory was inadmissible’.
a)potrapo/menoi...sullabo/ntes e)bas.] The second part. belongs more closely to the verb: cp. Plat. Phaed. p. 70A, (h( yuxh\) diaskedasqei=sa oi)/xhtai diaptome/nh.
flau=ron ‘compromising’.

div3.head: 2. Peroration: §§ 81 — 96.
div3.p: tekmhri/wn...shmei/ois Arist.'s distinction between the conclusive tekmh/rion and the fallible shmei=on is not clearly drawn by earlier writers, though tekmh/rion often=‘a proof’. Antiphon, frag. XXIII. 2 (Sauppe), ta\ parw|xhme/na shmei/ois pistw=sai ta\ de\ me/llonta tekmhri/ois, — where shmei=a=indications furnished by facts, tekmh/ria=grounds of conjecture: and so Andoc. De Pace § 2, peri\ tw=n mello/ntwn. Here, however, tekmh/ria are rather positive proofs: shmei=a, signs.
tou\s kindu/nous ‘their appointed dangers’.
mh\ kaqaroi/ sc. o)/ntes. Xen. Cyr. III. 1. 16, ti/ xrh/sait' a)/n tis i)sxurw=| h)\ a)ndrei/w|, mh\ sw/froni;

suneisba/ntes Xen. Cyr. VIII. 1. 25, w(/sper oi( plei=n ai(rou/menoi meta\ tw=n eu)sebw=n ma=llon h)\ meta\ tw=n h)sebhke/nai ti dokou/ntwn. Cp. Aesch. Theb. 597 — 600: Hor. Carm. III. 2. 26: Eur. El. 1354.

diakwlu/ontes...mh\ gi/gnesqai Xen. Anab. II. 3. 3, quome/nw| i)e/nai e)pi\ basile/a ou)k e)gi/gneto ta\ i(era/, opp. to kala\ h(mi=n ta\ i(era\ h)=n. The pollution incurred by the slaying of the Persian heralds hindered the sacrifices at Sparta from being favourable until the mh=nis of Talthybius had been appeased, Her. VII. 134.
tekmh/ria...th=s ai)ti/as, o(/ti, k.t.l. ‘evidence concerning the charge (against me), showing that these men are accusing me falsely’.
oi)=mai de\ kai\ u(mw=n Dobree's emendation, de/omai de\ kai\ u(mw=n, is the simplest, but gives less point than oi)=mai de\ kai\ <pro\s> u(mw=n <ei)=nai> a)poy.

kaq' ou(\s me\n a)ph/xqhn ‘I am not liable to the laws under which I was arrested, while as to the acts with which I am charged, I can still be brought to trial in the legal form’. He was arrested for kakourgi/a: if that means fo/nos, he can still be tried for it by a grafh\ fo/nou: if it means anything else, he is innocent.

ei) de\ du/o e)c e(no/s ‘If two trials have been made out of one, the fault is not mine, but that of the accusers. When, however, my worst enemies have left me the chance of a second trial, surely you, the impartial awarders of justice, will never pronounce on the present issue a premature verdict of murder’. In ei) gege/nhsqon, pepoih/kasin he assumes that he will be acquitted now, and tried again. For the form of the sentence, ou) dh/ pou, k.t.l., cp. Plat. Gorg. 512A, logi/zetai ou)=n o(/ti ou)k, ei) me/n tis, k.t.l.

do/te ti kai\ tw=| xro/nw| ‘Leave some scope for that
other witness — Time’. Cp. Hor. Sat. II. 2. 94, Das aliquid famae.

h)ci/oun me/n ‘I should certainly desire, judges, that in such cases [of alleged murder] the sentence (th\n di/khn) should be in accordance with the laws, [i.e. that death should be inflicted if deserved,] but that the investigation should, in every possible instance, be regulated by justice’ (to\ di/kaion). Sauppe inserts tou/tous (sc. tou\s no/mous) before to\ di/kaion, thus weakening, I think, the antithesis between ‘the laws’ as the standard of punishment, and ‘justice’ as the canon of inquiry. — h)ci/oun like e)boulo/mhn, § 1, note.
xrh=sqai th=| di/kh| ‘abide by the sentence’.

ou)/te th\n di/khn, k.t.l. ‘No one would dare, through confidence in his own innocence, to contravene the sentence when once pronounced, or, if conscious of his guilt, to rebel against the law’. For a true antithesis, the italicised phrases should express opposite notions: but they are, in fact, merely different forms of the same notion. Cp. note on Lysias Pro Mantitheo, § 13 (p. 60) h(goume/nous...nomi/zontas.

a)na/gkh de\...o( timwrh/swn ‘A man must yield, not only to the actual truth (au)tou= tou= a)lhqou=s), but also to a verdict which contravenes the truth, — especially if there be no one to support his cause’.

diwmosi/ai — to/mia — prorrh/seis Oaths taken by the parties to a trial — the sacrifices on which they swear [see § 12] — the notices to the accused [§ 10]. For pro/rrhsis see Plat. Legg. 873 A, prorrh/seis — ta\s peri\ tou= tw=n nomi/mwn ei)/rgesqai. [Dem.] In Neaer. § 9, proei=pen au)tw=| e)pi\ *palladi/w| fo/nou.
h)\ [kai\] e)pi\ toi=s a)/ll.] Cp. § 23. If the sentence were negative (ou) diafe/ronta, k.t.l.), kai/ might stand: as it is, we must surely omit it.
ou)k i)/son e)sti/ ‘It is less serious that the prosecutor should accuse wrongly than that you, the judges, should decide wrongly’.
ou)k e)/xei te/los ‘achieves no result: the result depends (e)n) on you and on the trial’.
diomosame/nous ‘when they have first taken the usual oath’ (made in grafai\ fo/nou), and not merely the ordinary diwmosi/a of parties to a law-suit. Cp. § 12.
ka)kei= in the other trial also.
xrh=sqai sc. e)moi/: ‘to do what you please with me’.
metagnou\s ga/r sc. tis: cp. Hes. Op. 12, th\n me/n ken e)painh/seie noh/sas. Cobet's a)/n tis to\ gegono\s e)panorqw/saito is more ingenious than probable.

h)/dh de/ tisin Alluding to the debate (427 B.C.) in the Athenian ecclesia on the fate of Mytilene, when Cleon's proposal of a massacre was first carried and afterwards rescinded — about ten years before the probable date of this speech. — kai\ meteme/lhsen, ‘have actually repented’.

paraxrh=ma i.e. while the purpose is still clearly present to his mind. From another point of view, an interval between the planning and the execution might be urged as heightening the deliberate character of the act: but here the contrast is merely between e(kou/sion and a)kou/sion.

th
 i)/shn ge du/namin e)/xei, o(/stis=i)/son du/natai, ei)/te tis...ei)/te. Cp. Thuc. VI. 14, no/mize to\ kalw=s a)/rcai tou=t' ei)=nai, o(\s a)
 th
 patri/da w)felh/sh|.
nu=n de\ pisteu/wn The parenthesis beginning at e)n ga\r tw=| toiou/tw| interrupts the constr., which is resumed by e)gw\ d' e)mautw=|, k.t.l., h(/kw ei)s u(ma=s. Cp. §§ 11, 12.
suneido/ti...cuneide/nai The mss. of Antiphon fluctuate between su/n and cu/n: the latter recurs in § 78 of this speech, cumbo/lwn, and in § 87, cuneidw/s.

th\n timwri/an...tau/thn ‘that this had come upon her as the punishment’. Cp. Lys. In Agor. § 30, h( de\ a)rxh\ au(/th... e)ge/neto, ‘this became the beginning’. The pronoun, which might have been neuter (tou=to), is assimilated to the gender of the noun. See my n. on Soph. O. C. 88. In this construction the definite article is not usually added to the noun, but is, of course, quite admissible. It is unwarrantable, therefore, to delete th\n here.

tou=to me\n ga/r ‘For on the one hand, if you listen to me’ — the correl. clause, tou=to de/, tou= tou/tois, being compressed into tou= de\ tou/tois. This is better than to understand, ‘if you listen to me in this matter’.

gnwristai/, k.t.l. ‘On the present occasion, then, take a survey of the case; on the next, sit in judgment on the witnesses; form now an opinion, but defer a decision, on the facts’. Cp. Thuc. VI. 87, mh/q' w(s dikastai\...tw=n h(mi=n poioume/nwn, mh/q' w(s swfronistai/. See introductory note on Antiphon's style.
ou)/te...parei/s ‘with due regard to your conscience as well as to my own right’: cp. § 7.

div2.p:
] The speech On the Choreutes relates to the death of Diodotus, a boy who was in training as member of a chorus to be produced at the Thargelia, and who was poisoned by a draught given to him to improve
his voice. The accused is the choregus, an Athenian citizen, who discharged that office for his own and another trible, and at whose house the chorus received their lessons. The accuser, Philocrates, brother of the deceased Diodotus, laid an information for poisoning before the Archon Basileus; and, after some delay, the case came before the Areiopagus. It was not contended that the accused had intended to murder the boy, but only that he had ordered to be administered to him the draught which caused his death. According to Athenian law this was, however, a capital offence. The present speech is the second made by the defendant, and the last, therefore, of the trial. Its date may probably be placed about 412 B.C.: see Attic Orators, I. 62. — A short extract is given here as illustrating the greater ease and freedom of Antiphon's later style, which is already beginning to emancipate itself from the stiffness of the au)sthra\ a(rmoni/a.

div3.head: Narrative: §§ 11 — 15.
div3.p: ei)s *qargh/lia...*dionusi/ois The second day of the Thargelia was celebrated by a procession and a musical contest (a)gw/n) between choruses of boys: Herm. Ant. II. § 60. 21. At the Dionysia the chorus would have been dramatic.
ou)/te zhmiw/sas k.t.l. ‘Without fining any man [the last resort], without extorting pledges [from the parent who demurred to sending his son], without (even) incurring any dislike’.

a)ll) w(/sper a)/n...e)/pempon ‘But, just as if the business in hand were most agreeable and advantageous to both parties, I made my demand or request, while the parents sent their sons without compulsion, — indeed, with good will’. The full construction would be: a)ll) (ou(/tw e)gi/gneto) w(/sper a)\n e)gi/gneto (ei) h(/dista k.t.l. e)gi/gneto): and the clause ou(/tw e)gi/gneto is represented by e)gw\ me\n e)ke/leuon, k.t.l.

h)|tou/mhn So Bekk. for ms. h(gou/mhn, which could mean only ‘I conducted the levy’ (sc. th=s sullogh=s). e)ke/leuon = ‘I invited’ (the official invitation being equivalent to a command: cp. Fr. inviter): h)|tou/mhn softens this down, ‘or rather, I made a personal request’: corresponding to the gradation of e(ko/ntes — boulo/menoi.

pra/gmata ‘for I happened to be engaged in cases against Ariston and Philînus, and was anxious to lose no time after the impeachment (ei)sh/ggeila) in making a due and formal statement to the Council and to the Athenian public’. Philînus and two other persons had been charged by the speaker with
embezzling public monies, as appears from §§ 21, 55. Antiphon wrote a speech kata\ *fili/nou (Attic Orators, I. 63 note).
ei)/ ti de/oi tw=| xorw=| Cp. Eur. Suppl. 594, e(\n dei= mo/non moi. Usually dei= moi/ tinos, more rarely dei= me/ tinos.

sulle/gein ‘to conduct the levy and act as steward of the tribe on each occasion’, — e(ka/stote, whenever it was called upon to contribute a chorus to a public festival. The e)pimelhtai\ tw=n fulw=n were responsible to the Archon for the appointment of the choregi: cp. Dem. In Mid. § 13. Herm. Ant. I. § 149. 8. By th\n fulh\n sulle/gein below is meant to levy (such a contribution) in the tribe. sullogei=s, at Athens, were esp. those who called in property confiscated to the State: Herm. Ant. I. § 151. 4.
ei)/ ti yeu/domai profa/sews e(/neka ‘If any part of this statement is false, or made for effect’.
tou= o(rkwtou= The officer of the court who tenders the oath. See De Caed. Her. § 12.
tau=ta sfo/dra le/gw ‘insist upon this point’=peri\ tou/twn i)sxuri/zomai. Reiske inserts ou(/tw before sfo/dra.
plh/n ge th=s tu/xhs lit., ‘putting Fortune out of the question’: i.e. ‘unless Fortune so ordain it’, (viz. that I should bring another person into peril).

div1.head: Andocides
div1.p: ANDOCIDES: born about 440 B.C.: died later than 390 B.C. Approximate period of extant work, 410 — 390 B.C. Life in Attic Orators, I. 71 — 87.

Style. Andocides is less a rhetorical artist than a vigorous speaker of quick native wit. The ancient criticism of oratory tended to regard it too much from the reader's point of view, and too little from the hearer's. This was unfavourable to Andocides. He is declared by Hermogenes (170 A.D. peri\ i)d. B. xi.) to be wanting in the distinctive excellences of practical oratory, deliberative and forensic. His diction is plain (a)felh/s), though not with the studied plainness of Lysias. He is sparing in the use of the rhetorical figures of language (sxh/mata le/cews), such as antithesis, parallelism between the forms of the two sentences (pari/swsis), or assonance (paromoi/wsis): though he uses largely the figures of thought (sxh/mata
dianoi/as), such as rhetorical question. In the arrangement of subject-matter he is simple and inartificial (a(plou=s — a)kata/skeuos). His strength lies in narrative, diversified by anecdote and enlivened by graphic description — sometimes by touches of true dramatic power. In addition to these literary merits, his speeches are of great historical value for the years 415 — 390 B.C. — See Attic Orators, I. 88 — 108. On the Works of Andocides in general, ib. 109 — 141.

div2.p: ] Spoken before the Athenian Ecclesia not later than the summer of 410 B.C. [See Attic Orators, I. 109. Andoc. lays stress on the service which he has rendered to Athens by securing a supply of corn from Cyprus: but the battle of Cyzicus in 410 B.C. was followed by the re-opening of the corn-trade between the Euxine and Athens: Xen. H. I. 1. 35. The benefit for which Andoc. claims credit would have been of little importance had it been conferred later than the middle of the year 410.] The object of the speech is to procure the removal of certain disabilities under which he was alleged to lie. His disclosures in 415 B.C. were made under a guarantee of immunity from penalties. But the decree of Isotimides, passed soon afterwards, excluded from the market-place and from temples all ‘who had committed impiety and who had confessed it’; and his enemies maintained that this decree applied to him. The appeal was unsuccessful. He returned to Athens only after the general amnesty of 403 B.C. Having first deprecated the resentment felt against him for having denounced the mutilators of the Hermae in 415 B.C. (§§ 1 — 9), he proceeds, in the following passage, to speak of his life in exile — his services to the army at Samos in 411 B.C. — his return to Athens during the rule of the Four Hundred — and his imprisonment at the instance of Peisander.

div3.p: to/t' au)to\s gnou/s In 415 B.C., when he had denounced certain persons as concerned in the mutilation of the Hermae. au)to/s: he himself felt the misery of his position as keenly as those who condemn him.

paranoi/a| — a)na/gkh| So in § 7 he says that he had acted neo/thti/ te kai\ a)noi/a|. In this speech Andoc. distinctly implies that he was concerned in the sacrilege: this was his ‘madness’: the a)na/gkh was the necessity of denouncing the guilty, or else allowing the innocent to perish. In the De Mysteriis (see next Extract), speaking 11 years later, he protests his own entire innocence. (Cp. Attic Orators, I. 113.)

pra/ttein...o)fq.] ‘To live a life and choose an abode in which I should be as far as possible out of your sight’: o(/pou, as relative to toiau=ta no less than to e)kei=,=e)n oi(=s, or a(\ pra/ttwn. — o(/pou me/lloimi, oblique for o(/pou a(\n me/llw.

e)kei/nhs...deuri/ ‘A longing for that civic and social life with you in Athens (e)kei/nhs), from which I passed into this exile’ (deuri/). He is speaking at Athens; but the words describe his feeling in banishment. The vividness is characteristic of Andocides.
e)k de\ tou/tou ‘from that moment’ — which the con text fixes to 411 B.C.
tw=n tetrakosi/wn The Four Hundred were in power from March to June, 411 B.C. For the details of the Revolution, see the life of Antiphon in the Attic Orators, I. 7 f.

dido/ntos *te/mnesqai Archelaus, king of Macedon (413 — 399 B.C.), had given Andoc. leave to cut down and export timber for oar-spars. Macedonia was the great timber-market of Greece (Xen. Hellen. VI. 1. 11). See my note on Theophrastus Char. XXIII (=VI. p. 195), where the a)lazw/n boasts that Antipater has offered him ‘the privilege of exporting timber free of duty’ (e)cagwgh\ cu/lwn a)telh/s).
pe/nte draxmw=n gen. of price: ‘at the rate of five drachmas’ (for each kwpeu/s).
o(/sou e)moi\ kate/sthsan] o(/sou, not o(/son: ‘the sum in which they stood me’ — the cost-price.
e)ni/khsan Referring to the Athenian victory at Cynossema in 411, and perh. also to that at Cyzicus in 410 B.C.
t. th=s ai)ti/as ‘this merit’ or ‘credit’. Cp. Aesch. Theb. 4, ei) me\n ga\r eu)= pra/caimen, ai)ti/a qeou=.

ei) ga/r, k.t.l. ‘For if the supplies had not been imported for the army at that time, the prospect before them was not a chance of saving Athens, but a risk of losing their own lives’. ki/ndunos h)=n is equivalent to an apodosis with a)/n and aor. indic. (as ei)ko/tws ou)k a)\n e)/swsan). Cp. Thuc. III. 74, h( po/lis e)kindu/neuse pa=sa diafqarh=nai, ei) a)/nemos e)pege/neto. Cp. Aeschin. Ctes. § 123 (where e)kinduneu/samen a)/n is a v. l.).

h)\ peri\ tou= mhde\ au)tou\s swqh=nai] ki/ndunos peri\ tou= sw=sai, a risk in which the saving of Athens was the thing at stake: ki/ndunos peri\ tou= mhde\ au)tou\s swqh=nai=ki/ndunos mh\ ou)d' au)toi\ swqei=en, a risk lest not even they themselves should be saved. Hence the mhde/: the form peri\ tou= swqh=nai being adopted merely for the sake of symmetry with peri\ tou= sw=sai.

ou)k o)li/gw|, k.t.l. ‘The situation there (e)ntau=qa, with regard to the army at Samos) proved to be very different from what I had supposed’: i.e. the relations of the army at Samos with the Four Hundred at Athens were such that the latter received Andoc. not as a friend but as a foe. e)/xonta with ou)k o)li/gw| moi para\ gnw/mhn,=pa/nu a)/llws e)/xonta h)\ w(s u(pe/labon.

oi( e)pi\ stratia=s o)/ntes ‘those upon service’, ‘the army abroad’: cp. Plat. Phaedr. 260 B, oi)/koi kai\ e)pi\ stratei/as, domi militiaeque. stratei/as is a v. l., but stratia/ (see L. and S. s.v.) sometimes=stratei/a. The army at Samos was the mainstay of the Democracy against the oligarchical Revolution: cp. Attic Orators, I. 9.

th\n e(sti/an — tw=n i(erw=n The hearth of the *bouleuth/rion was called *(esti/a *boulai/a (Aeschin. F. L. § 45). In Andoc. De Myst. § 44, threatened persons e)pi\ th\n e(sti/an e)kaqe/zonto. — tw=n i(erw=n, ‘the sacred precincts’ of the altar.

ei)s...tou\s qeou/s, k.t.l. ‘although it was against the gods that I was said to have sinned, the gods seem to have been more merciful to me than men’: e)/xonta (acc. masc.) o)nei/dh, because he was charged with having profaned the Mysteries and mutilated the Hermae.

ou(= dh/, k.t.l. ‘And then it was’ [at this point in my fortunes] ‘that I most bewailed my fate: I who, at a moment when the People seemed to be in evil plight’ [the Democracy having been overthrown], ‘suffered in their stead, and further, when I was found to have been the People's benefactor, was condemned to new misery on this account’: i.e. Andoc. suffered first as a democrat, and secondly as a patriotic democrat. The antithesis is defective, since the overthrow of the Democracy (kakou=sqai) cannot properly be contrasted with the benefits which it had received from Andoc. — Cp. Thuc. VIII. 68, ta\ tw=n tetrakosi/wn...u(po\ tou= dh/mou e)kakou=to.

*a)pwllu/mhn A corr. suggested by Bekker. a)poloi/mhn might stand if for o(/stis we wrote ei): and this would also account for the now redundant e)gw/. But, considering ei)=xon, I think it more likely that the copyist's eye had wandered to trapoi/mhn.

kai\ e)k tou/twn, k.t.l. ‘even after my escape from these perils, grave as they were’: i.e. undeterred by this warning. We cannot well render, ‘even under these circumstances, grave as they were, when I had escaped’; for a)pallagei/s clearly belongs to the preceding words.

div2.p:
] — Date, 399 B.C. — Andocides had laid information, in 415 B.C., against certain persons
whom he accused of complicity in the mutilation of the Hermae. He did so on the guarantee of impunity (a)/deia) which a special decree of the Assembly had given to all who should inform. Subsequently another decree was passed — known as the decree of Isotimides — that all who had committed impiety, and had confessed it, should be excluded from the market-place and the temples.

Andocides had returned to Athens under the amnesty of 403 B.C. His accusers now (399 B.C.) charge him with having broken the decree of Isotimides by attending the Mysteries and entering the temple at Eleusis. The form of the accusation is an e)/ndeicis a)sebei/as, an ‘information’ charging him with impiety. But, in order to prove that he came under the decree of Isotimides, they had to show that he had committed impiety in 415 B.C.

His speech is to show that he had not done so, either by profaning the Mysteries or by mutilating the Hermae. The Mysteries, from which it takes its title, is only one of its topics. It would be better described as a Defence on a Charge of Impiety. As to the Mysteries, Andoc. Affirms that he neither profaned them himself nor informed against others as having done so (§§ 11 — 33). But his account of the Hermae affair is the most important part of the speech. (Analysis of the whole in the Attic Orators, I. 117.)
1. The Mutilation of the Hermae — Information laid by Teucrus and Diocleides: §§ 34 — 45.

div3.p: tw=n a)naqhma/twn=tw=n *(ermw=n, ‘the images’, as dedicated to the god. Cp. § 62, o( *(ermh=s...o(\n h( *ai)ghi\s (the Aegeid tribe) a)ne/qhke. The *(ermai= were plain four-cornered posts surmounted by a head or bust.

a)/deian eu(ro/menos ‘having obtained special permission’. Teucrus was a me/toikos who had withdrawn to Megara, and had thence sent word to the Athenian Council that he would give information regarding the Mysteries and the Hermae if he received license to do so (ei)/ oi( a)/deian doi=en). Thereupon the Council e)yhfi/sato th\n a)/deian, and sent for him (§ 15). — a)/deia, technical term for the authorisation required by a non-citizen (me/toikos, ce/nos, dou=los) who desired to accuse anyone of an offence against the State, — by an a)/timos before he could exercise any civic right, — or by a citizen who proposed to re-enfranchise an a)/timos.
a)pogra/fei ‘denounces’, in a ‘list’ or ‘return’ (a)pografh/) presented to the *boulh/, which the Ecclesia had invested with plenary powers for the occasion (§ 15, au)tokra/twr).
oi( de\ s. a)pe/qanon Grote (VII. 268) doubts this assertion (cp. Thuc. VI. 53, 60), but it is incidentally confirmed by the statement ascribed to Charmides in § 49. See Attic Orators, I. 122.

tw=n zhthtw=n ‘The Commission of Inquiry’ specially appointed by the Ecclesia. Cp. § 14, h)=sqa zhthth/s, w)= *dio/gnhte, o(/te *puqo/nikos ei)sh/ggeilen e)n tw=| dh/mw| peri\ *)alkibia/dou, ‘impeached A. in the Assembly’.

e)pi\ th=| tou= dh/mou k. ‘with a view to the overthrow of the Commonwealth’. dh/mou kata/lusis, the crime of attempting to subvert the democratical government, — often coupled with the more general prodosi/a th=s po/lews: for each there was a grafh/. Lysias's or. 25 is dh/mou katalu/sews a)pologi/a.

to\ shmei=on kaqe/loi ‘took down the signal’, — displayed from the bouleuth/rion to show that it was time to meet, and taken down when business was about to commence. There was a similar shmei=on for the Ecclesia (Ar. Thesm. 277) and for the law-courts (Vesp. 690).
ei)sagg. ei)s t. b.] ‘lays an impeachment before the Council’.
w(s d' i)/doi, k.t.l. ‘and stated how he had chanced to become an eye-witness of the plot’. w(s here=o(/tw| tro/pw|: below § 40 w(s i)/doi=merely ‘that he had seen’.

a)pofora/n ‘He said that he had a slave at Laurium, and that he had occasion to go for a payment due to him’. a)pofora/, the ‘return’ or ‘profit’ accruing to the master from the labour of his slave. Aeschin. In Timarch. § 97, (shoemaking slaves) w(=n e(/kastos tou/tw| du/) o)bo/lous a)pofora\n e)/fere th=s h(me/ras.

panse/lhnon Plut. Alcib. 20, ei(=s d' au)tw=n (the informers) e)rwtw/menos o(/pws ta\ pro/swpa tw=n e(rmokopidw=n gnwri/seie, kai\ a)pokrina/menos o(/ti pro\s selh/nhn, e)sfa/lh tou= panto/s (made a fatal slip), e(/nhs kai\ ne/as ou)/shs (the new moon) o(/te tau=t' e)dra=to. So Diod. XIII. 2. Grote (VII. 271) rightly treats this part of the story as a later fiction. If Diocleides had made such a blunder, Andoc. would not have failed to note it’. (Cp. Attic Orators, I. 123.)

to\ prop. tou= *d., k.t.l. ‘When he had come to the gateway of Dionysus’ [the entrance to the *lh/naion, the enclosure sacred to Dionysus on the S.E. of the Acropolis], ‘he saw several persons descending from the Odeum’ (of Pericles, close to the Dionysiac Theatre on the E.] ‘into the orchestra’ [the open central space of the Theatre]. ‘Afraid of them, he drew into the shade, and crouched down between the pillar and the column with the bronze statue of the General’ [just inside the
propu/laion, as ei)selqw/n seems to indicate, and covered by its shadow].
a)na\ pe/nte kai\ de/ka ‘in groups of fifteen’.

tou=q' u(pe/qeto...o(/pws ‘Thus, in the first place, judges, he assumed this story — a most extraordinary one — in order, I fancy, that it might rest with him to include in this list any Athenian he pleased, or at pleasure to exempt him’. tou=q' u(pe/qeto, made this (the story of the moonlight scene) the basis of his evidence: deino/t. pr. in appos. with tou=to, ‘a most strange’, ‘an incredible affair’. I now prefer this version to rendering: ‘He made this assumption, viz. that it was in his power’, where o(/pws would=w(s or o(/ti, in sense of ‘that’.
katalamba/nein So below, le/gein. The infins. might=katela/mbanon, e)/legon, but perhaps represent rather the vivid katalamba/nw, le/gw used by Diocleides in his narrative.
e)n tw=| x. kaq.] ‘sitting in his forge’ — he being a xalkeu/s.

to\ *(hfaistei=on The guild of smiths, and perhaps artisans generally, held the annual festival of the xalkei=a to Hephaestus early in Nov. (Pollux VII. 105). The *(hfaistei=on, or temple of H., was on the W. of the Agora, having the Stoa Poecilè just above it (Paus. I. 14. 6). For the custom of taking oaths in a temple, cp. Plat. Prot. 328 C, e)lqw\n ei)s i(ero/n, o)mo/sas, o(/sou a)\n fh=| a)/cia ei)=nai ta\ maqh/mata, tosou=ton kate/qhke.
ou)/koun de/oito ‘Now, he said, he did not desire’ — oblique for ou)/koun de/omai, after a secondary tense (e)/fh in § 39).

kai\ nu=n h(/kein k ‘and said, “Now pray come to the house of L., that you and I may there confer with A. and the other needful persons”.’ Euphemus said: nu=n h(=ke/ moi ei)s th\n *l. oi)ki/an: this becomes, *eu)/fhmos (*dioklei/dhn) nu=n h(/kein oi( e)ke/leuse, and, in the oblique form, e)/fh to\n *eu)/fhmon nu=n h(/kein keleu=sai/ oi(. — oi(=‘to oblige him’ (Euphemus). keleu/ein does not, in Attic prose, take a dat. of the person commanded.

h(/kein...ko/ptein The oblique of h(=kon kai\ dh\ e)/kopton: ‘He said that the next day he was there [h(=kon=I came promptly or punctually], and was in the act of knocking at the door’: kai\ dh/=‘and even now’.

a)=ra/ ge se/, k.t.l. ‘Are you the visitor whom the company here expect? Well, one ought not to reject such friends — and with these words he was gone’. oi(/de — Andocides and the others who were already at the house of Leogoras: se/, Diocleides. Acc. to D.'s story, the father of Andoc. gives him a parting hint not to reject the overtures about to be made to him by the conspirators. — a)pw/llue, ‘sought to ruin’.

o(/ti bouleu/soito ‘that he would think it over’. He
said, bouleu/somai: the fut. opt. here, as always, being the oblique of the fut. ind. after a secondary tense.

kaqomologh/sas, k.t.l. ‘concluded an agreement with us, and gave us pledges on the Acropolis’ (by taking an oath in one of the temples: cp. on § 40). — diayeu/d. — dido/nai, oblique pres. rather than imperf.: ‘fail to keep our word or to pay’: as h(/kein for h(/kw rather than h(=kon.

to\ e)pi\ *skamandri/ou yh/f A yh/fisma forbidding that citizens should be put to the torture. A decree of the *boulh/ (then temporarily invested with plenary powers) could of course suspend this. — Cp. Herm. Ant. I. § 141. 15.

o(/pws mh\...e)/stai This would be regular in an object-clause (as skopw= o(/pws mh\ e)/stai): here, in a final clause, we should expect rather o(/pws mh\ h)=|. But the notion of contriving how the object may be attained is uppermost, and so the clause is virtually an object-clause. Xen. Cyr. II. 1. 21, ou)de\ di' e(\n a)/llo tre/fontai h)\ o(/pws maxou=ntai. Goodwin § 44. 1.
e)pi\ th\n e(sti/an Cp. note on De Red. § 15, p. 222.

e)celqou=sa, k.t.l. ‘The Council, after retiring to a secret conference, had us seized and put in the pillory. Then they summoned the Generals before them’ [a)nakal., up to the bouleuth/rion], ‘and ordered them to proclaim that those Athenians who lived in the city should proceed under arms to the market-place, — those at the Long Walls, to the Theseum, — those in the Peiraeus, to the market-place of Hippodamus; that before dawn the Knights should sound the trumpet-call to the Anakeum; that the Senate should go to the Acropolis, and sleep there; and that the Presidents should sleep in the Rotunda’. — tou\s d' e)n makrw=| tei/xei: cp. Thuc. II. 17, ta/ te makra\ tei/xh w)/|khsan kataneima/menoi kai\ tou= *peiraiw=s ta\ polla/. The sing. here denotes the two main long walls (the ‘Northern’ and the ‘Middle’), with the space enclosed by them, conceived as a district. — *(ippod. a)gora/n, the market-place of the Peiraeus. — *)ana/keion, temple of the Dioscuri (a)/nakes), N.W. of Acropolis. — qo/lw|, a circular building, with dome, near the *bouleuth/rion in the Agora: the Prytanes and grammatei=s dined there, Dem. Fals. Legat. § 249.
e)pi\ toi=s o(ri/ois...e)cest.] ‘had taken the field, and were on the frontier’.

e)dei/pnei ‘was entertained’. The privilege of daily si/thsis e)n *prutanei/w| (Ar. Ran. 764) was given either for a limited period or for life (a)ei/sitos): here the imperf. shows that at least more than one day is meant.

div3.head: 2. The Disclosures of Andocides: §§ 48 — 69.
div3.p: e)peidh\ de/ The apodosis is le/gei pro/s me X. Compare the prison-scene in Lysias, Agorat. §§ 39 f.
o(/ti, *)andoki/dh, k.t.l.] o(/ti redundant before the direct quotation: Xen. Cyr. VII. 3. 3, a)pekri/nato o(/ti, w)= de/spota, k.t.l. Goodwin § 79.
ou)de\n e)deo/mhn ‘I had no wish to speak or to give you pain’. But e)deo/mhn mhde\n le/gein, ‘I wished to say nothing’. Cp. § 40, ou)/koun de/oito, ‘did not desire’.

oi(=s ga\r e)xrw= ‘Your other friends (e)xrw=) and associates (sunh=sqa), except us your relations’. a)/neu, ‘besides’, either= ‘except’ (as here), or ‘in addition to’. Cp. Dem. De Cor. § 89, a)/neu tou= kalh\n do/can e)negkei=n, ‘in addition to bringing you fair fame’. So when Caesar says (Bell. Gall. v. 12) of south Britain, Materia (timber) cuiusque generis ut in Gallia est, praeter fagum atque abietem, some render ‘except’; others, ‘in addition to’.
prw=ton me/n With this series, prw=ton — ei)=ta — e)/peita — e)/ti, cp. Soph. El. 261 — 271, prw=ta — ei)=ta — e)/peita — teleutai=on.

a)nagkai/ous ‘near relations’. suggenei=s is the larger term, including the more distant degrees of kinship: a)nagkai=oi (necessarii) are those to whom one is bound by the first, the closest natural ties; as ta\ a)nagkai=a are those things with which life cannot dispense.

po/tera perii/dw deliberative subj., to which answers h)\ ei)/pw: the tense being, as usu., the aor., since the prospective act will be done once for all, not continued or repeated. But Eur. Ion 758, ei)/pwmen h)\ sigw=men; ‘shall we speak [once for all: aor.]; or keep silence?’ [pres. of the continued act].
a)lit. tw=n qew=n For genit., cp. Aeschin. Ctes. § 157, a)lith/rios th=s *(ella/dos: Thuc. I. 26, to\ a)/gos th=s qea=s.

e)teqnh/kesan In the 3rd pers. pl. of the pluperf. act., -esan, not -eisan, was the Attic form. pareilh/fesan occurs in an inscription of 323 B.C. (Meisterhans, Gramm. d. Attisch. Inschriften, p. 75). In the 3rd pers. sing. of the pluperf., -ei is contracted, of course, from ee, and the post-Attic -eisan in the 3rd pers. plur. was perhaps an instance of false analogy. (Cp. Curtius, Greek Verb, p. 433 Eng. tr.)
ei)=nai tou/twn tw=n a)ndrw=n to belong to their party, to be their confederates. Cp. above, § 41, e(/na au)to\n h(mw=n ei)=nai.
ei) mh/ tis e)rei= The vivid construction, instead of ei) mh/ tis le/coi or ei)/poi, after be/baios h)=n.

a)poqano/ntas Here, as in § 51, the aor. refers, not to those
who had already died (§ 49, oi( me\n au)tw=n teqna=sin), but to those who were threatened with death. It is stronger than a)poqnh/|skontas (cf. a)pollume/nous of the same persons in § 51), just as ‘to see them murdered’ is stronger than ‘to see them being murdered’: the aor. pictures the deed as accomplished while he looks on.

kata\ tw=n e(tai/rwn tw=n e)mautou= ‘against my own associates’. Here, the word e(tai=ros seems to bear a merely social sense, referring to a circle of private friends (cp. § 61 pino/ntwn h(mw=n). On the other hand, the title of a lost speech by Andocides, *pro\s tou\s e(tai/rous, probably indicates the members of the oligarchical e(tairei=ai at Athens (Attic Orators, vol. I. p. 139). For the latter, or political, sense of e(tai=ros, cp. below, p. 138, § 87.
e)logopoi/oun Cp. Thuc. VI., ou)/te o)/nta ou)/te a)\n geno/mena logopoiou=sin. So logopoio/s; of one who spreads fictitious news (Theophrastus, Char. VIII).

e)moi\ ga/r, w)= a)/ndres Andoc. says: — ‘Now, in this trial, judges, nothing is so important for me as that, if acquitted, I should be acquitted with honour: and, further, that the general public (tou\s a)/llous a(/pantas) should understand my whole conduct to have been absolutely free from baseness or cowardice’. He wishes to be pronounced an honourable man (1) by his judges, (2) by oi( a)/lloi a(/pantes. All that would be given by a)lla\ prw=ton me\n u(ma=s, which Blass proposes to insert after kakw=| ei)=nai (see crit. note), is already contained in swqe/nti.

fe/re dh\ — xrh\ ga/r ‘Now consider — for a judge ought to examine the facts by a human standard [a)nqrwpi/nws — making allowance for human infirmity], as if the misfortune had been his own — What would any one of you have done?’ w(/sper a)
 au)to
 o)/nta: i.e. w(/sper a)
 (xrei/h logi/zesqai), au)to
 o)/nta (=ei) au)to\s ei)/h). A simpler form would have been w)/sper a)
 (sc. logi/zoito) au)to\s w)/n.

ei) me
 ga h)=n duoi=n The thought is not completed till the end of § 60, xrh/mata e)la/mbane. Briefly, it is this: — ‘If it had been a question between noble death and shameful life, my conduct might be condemned. But it was really a question between slaying the innocent by my silence, and saving them at the expense of he guilty, by speaking out. Therefore I spoke’. — In the series of clauses, note these points: — (1) All is plain down to tou= kalw=s a)poqanei=n. (2) o(/pou de\ tou/twn begins a protasis which has no formal apodosis. The virtual apodosis comes at § 60, (tau=ta de\ pa/nta skopw=n, ‘considering all these things, I say’) eu(/riskon, ‘I found’ that the least evil was to speak. (3) The protasis begun by o(/pou de\ tou/twn is interrupted by the parenthesis *dioklei/dhs me
 ga/r...u(mi=n a(\ h)/kousa. Then the
consequences of his silence are pursued in e)/ti de\...a)pw/lluon, the long parenthesis having broken the original construction, h)=n siwph/santi me
...a)pollu/nai. (4) The new independent constr. is continued in describing the consequences of his speaking: ei)pw
 de\ ta\ o)/nta, k.t.l. Then at § 60 comes the result, prefaced by the summary, tau=ta de\ pa/nta skopw=n.

o(/pou de\ tou/twn...mh\ ei)po/ntos ‘But here the case was the very reverse: by keeping silence I must have perished ignominiously in my innocence, and must also have permitted the destruction of my father, of my brother-in-law, of all my cousins and relations, whom I and no one else threatened with death, by concealing the guilt of others. The falsehoods of Diocleides had sent them to prison; their only hope of deliverance lay in the Athenians learning the whole truth. I was in danger, therefore, of becoming their murderer, if I failed to tell you what I had heard. I was also in danger of destroying three hundred Athenians, and of involving Athens in the most serious evils. This, then, was the prospect if I were silent’.

kai\ timwrh/sasqai The conjectural insertion before these words of kai\ sw=sai/ te h(ma=s is as needless as the similar insertion in § 56 (where see n.), since the thought is contained in o(\s h(ma=s me\n a)pw/lluen (was seeking to destroy). — e)kei=non follows *dioklei/dhn as it often follows au)to/n, e.g. Plat. Prot. 310 D, a)\n au)tw=|s didw=|s a)rgu/rion kai\ pei/qh|s e)kei=non: see Shilleto on Thuc. I. 132.

ou) ge/noito di' e)me/ Notice the opt. ge/noito preceded by ei)shgh/sato, a)ntei=pon, and followed by e)/peson, k.t.l. — all depending on e)ch/legca o(/ti. The optative has the effect of presenting this particular statement, not simply as a fact, but as a quotation of what was confessed by the conspirators. It is the oblique form of ou)k e)ge/neto di' *)andoki/dhn: ‘I proved the facts, — that E. proposed this plan, etc., and that (as they said) it was I who “hindered the plan from being executed at the time”.’
e)n *kunosa/rgei] to\ *kuno/sarges, a gymnasium, with a sanctuary of Heracles, on the E. side of Athens, near the *diomei/a pu/lh.

th
 klei=n sunetri/bhn ‘broke my collar-bone’: Dem. or. 18 § 67, th
 klei=n kateago/ta. — th
 kefalh
 katea/ghn (a_ in Attic), ‘cut my head’: Ar. Ach. 1180, kai\ th=s kefalh=s kate/age peri\ li/qon pesw/n (partit. genit., — the more usual construction in this phrase).

to\n *(e. to\n para\ to\ *f.] ‘The Hermes by the Phorbanteum’ — the h(rw=|on of Phorbas, perh. the hero of that name worshipped in Rhodes as having banished snakes from the
island (Diod. v. 58), and also famed in myth as a boxer (schol. ad Hom. Il. XXIII. 660, etc.). The idea of para/ with accus., in such general indications of position, is — ‘that which one sees when one goes past’ the place. We may render it ‘by’. para/ with dat., ‘beside’, is more precise.

deina\ e)poi/oun ‘On finding this out, the conspirators were furious that I should know of the deed without having had a hand in it’. The more usual phrase, deino\n poiou=mai/ ti,=‘to regard a thing as monstrous’, ‘to feel indignant at it’. On the other hand, deina\ poiw= (lit., ‘to do dreadful things’), refers to the external manifestation of horror or grief by gestures, cries, etc.: Her. III. 14, klaio/ntwn kai\ deina\ poieu/ntwn ‘weeping, and displaying anguish’: Thuc. v. 42, legome/nwn de\ tou/twn oi( *)aqhnai=oi deina\ e)poi/oun, ‘exclaimed’, ‘raised an outcry’.
di' h(ma=s ob nos proditos. ‘Otherwise our enmity will be more effectual than any friendships that you can make by betraying us’.
au)toi=s...e)kei/nois For e)kei/nois following au)toi=s in reference to the same persons, see note on § 60.

w(s ou)=n...e)kei=noi ‘In support of this statement, I gave up my own slave for the torture, (to prove) that I had been ill’, [imperf., was at the past time in question,] ‘and unable even to leave my bed; and the Presidents received [for examination] the female slaves in the house from which the conspirators set forth to begin their work’. o(/qen=e)k th=s oi)ki/as e)c h(=s.
fra/sas ‘on condition of revealing’.
*fhgou/sion Of the deme of Phegeus near Marathon.

labo/ntes ta\ o(/pla a)p ‘and you yourselves’ (au)toi/, the Athenian citizens generally, as represented by the court) ‘took up your arms and went home’. The order given in the panic had been, tou\s me
 e)n a)/stei oi)kou=ntas i)e/nai ei)s th
 a)gora
 ta\ o(/pla labo/ntas, k.t.l., § 45.

pi/stin tw=n e)n a). a)pistota/thn ‘The most traitorous of all possible compacts’: pi/stin, the pledge given by the conspirators to each other: a)pistota/th, most disloyal to the State. Cp. Aesch. Theb. 1021, tafe/nt' a)ti/mws tou)piti/mion labei=n.
to/te de/ We might expect to/te dh/, tum demum, then and not sooner: but the thought is (pro/teron me\n) sune/kruya, to/te de\ a)pe/gr. Cp. § 34, note on a)pogra/fei.
su\ de/, k.t.l. To the grammateu/s of the Court. ‘Clerk, call the persons themselves who were released by my means’.
me/xri tou/tou ‘They will come up and give evidence for as long as you desire to listen to it’.

III. *p*e*r*i *t*h*s *p*r*o*s *l*a*k*e*d*a*i*m*o*n*i*o*u*s *e*i*r*h*n*h*s. — The speech On the Peace with Lacedaemon belongs to 390 B.C., the fourth year of the Corinthian War. Athens, Boeotia, Corinth and Argos were at this time allied against Sparta. The success of Agesilaus in 391 had led the Athenians, probably in the winter of 391 — 90 B.C., to send plenipotentiaries, among whom was Andocides, to treat for peace at Sparta. According to the terms proposed by the Lacedaemonians, Athens was to retain her Long Walls — rebuilt three years before by Conon — and her fleet; she was also to recover Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros: and Boeotia was to be gratified by the withdrawal of the Spartan garrison from Orchomenus. The plenipotentiaries did not use their powers, but requested that the Athenian ecclesia might have forty days in which to consider these proposals; and returned, accompanied by Spartan envoys, to Athens. It was in the ensuing debate — early in the year 390 — that the speech of Andocides was made. — Attic Orators, I. 83. The genuineness of the speech has been questioned, but without sufficient reason. One passage of it (§§ 3 — 12) was adopted, with slight modifications, by Aeschines (De Fals. Legat. §§ 172 — 176). See Attic Orators, I. 129.

Andoc. first shows that a peace with Sparta is not a danger to the Athenian democracy (§§ 1 — 12). He then argues that there is no good reason for continuing the war, and that the proposed terms are peculiarly advantageous to Athens (§§ 13 — 23). If the Boeotians make peace on their own account, Athens will be left with one weak ally, Corinth, and another of which the policy is thoroughly selfish — Argos (§§ 24 — 27).
§§ 28 — 41 (end). Alliance with Sparta is better than alliance with Argos. — Objections to the Peace answered.

toiou/twn d' e)lp. m.] ‘Committed, as we are, to such prospects, we have to choose between joining the Argives in war against Sparta, and joining the Boeotians in making a peace for the common interest’. t. e)lp. metasx., ‘having become sharers in such hopes’, i.e. having entered into alliance with States which have such objects in view as Argos and Boeotia have respectively. Argos hoped to get Corinth if the war were prolonged (§ 27): Boeotia was likely to make peace on its own account with Sparta (§ 24). — koinh=|: cp. § 27, meta\ pa/ntwn tw=n summa/xwn th\n ei)rh/nhn poioume/nous.

di' h(ma=s au)tou/s for our own sakes, opp. to di' e(te/rous. The
words might also mean ‘through our own exertions’. In De Myst. § 63, di' h(ma=s=‘on account of (betraying) us’.

xrh\ ga\r a)namnhsqe/ntas The partic. here expresses the thought on which the chief stress falls. ‘For if we are to take a prudent decision, we must refresh our memory of the past’. Cp. Her. VIII. 129, e)/ti de\ trei=s (moi=rai) u(po/loipoi h)=san, ta\s dielqo/ntas xrh)=n ei)=nai e)/sw e)n th=| *pallh/nh|, ‘which they must traverse before arriving in Pallenè’. Thuc. I. 20, dra/sante/s ti kai\ kinduneu=sai, i.e. ‘to do something if they must risk their lives’ (and Shilleto's note): IV. 11, ta\s sfete/ras nau=s biazome/nous th\n a)po/basin katagnu/nai, ‘to force the passage, though they must wreck their ships in doing it’.

a(\ h(mi=n e)pre/sbeusen...peiqo/menoi ‘listening to the overtures made to us by Epilycus, on behalf of Amorges, — the slave of the Great King, and an exile’: lit., ‘as to the proposals made us by the envoy E. — in regard to these complying with Amorges’, obeying his wishes. Amorges, son of the satrap Pissuthnes, revolted from Dareius II. [regn. 424 — 405 B.C.] and established himself in Iasus, a sea-board town of Caria. In 412 B.C. the Peloponnesians took Iasus, and delivered Amorges to Tissaphernes: Thuc. VIII. 28: Grote VII. 504, 535.

*surakou/sioi d' In 427 B.C. the chief Ionic cities of Sicily — viz. Leontini, Naxos and Catana — in alliance with the Dorian Camarina, sent an embassy to Athens, with Gorgias at its head, asking aid against Syracuse. This was the occasion of the first Athenian expedition to Sicily in 427 B.C.: a second was sent in 425, and a third in 422. The application of Egesta for help against Selinus led to the great expedition of 415 B.C. Andoc. seems to be thinking of the embassies sent by the Ionic Siceliots, and to imagine that a rival embassy had been sent by Syracuse — which was not the case.
h(mei=s toi/nun ei(lo/m ‘Well, we chose then also’: toi/nun ‘so’, ‘accordingly’, i.e. with our usual perversity.

a)nti\ tou= me/nontes...e)/xein The rule that the subject of the infin. stands in the nominative, if it is identical with the subject of the principal verb, holds good even when the infin. takes the article: Plat. Rep. 526 B, ei)/s ge to\ o)cu/teroi au)toi\ au(tw=n gi/gnesqai pa/ntes e)pidido/asin: Ib. 598 D, e)chpath/qh dia\ to\ au)to\s mh\ oi(=o/s t' ei)=nai episth/mhn...e)ceta/sai.

a)risti/ndhn lit. ‘merit-wise’: ai(rei=sqai a)risti/ndhn (Arist. Pol. II. 11. 3) to choose (magistrates) by merit: so plouti/ndhn. Here the idea is that the best men were chosen out (by destiny) for destruction. ‘Having lost the very flower of our citizens and allies’. Cp. Her. VI. 21, *milh/sioi pa/ntes h(bhdo\n (from the youth upwards — all the adults) a)pekei/ranto ta\s kefala/s.

ai)sx. d. oi( swqe/ntes au)t.] Not a formal anacolouthon: but we can see that the speaker's thought has changed its direction. He began the sentence as if it were to end in some such way as o)li/gous ei)/domen swqe/ntas. Thuc. VII. 87, o)li/goi a)po\ pollw=n e)p' oi)/kou a)peno/sthsan.

u(/steron d' u(p' *)arg.] u(/steron can be justified only if Andoc. refers to the beginning of Athenian intervention (427 — 422 B.C.) in the affairs of Sicily.
