The events noticed here occurred before the Sicilian expedition of 415 B.C. ei)rh/nhs h(mi=n ou)/shs: the Peace of Nicias, 422 B.C. — pleu/santes e)pi\ th\n *lakwnikh/n: an allusion to the expedition against Epidaurus in which the Argives were assisted by the Athenians under Alcibiades (419 B.C., Thuc. v. 52 — 54): e)kkalei=n au)t. to\n qumo/n, because the Spartans retaliated by invading Argos, thus opening the campaign which was closed by the battle of Mantineia (418 B.C.) and an alliance between Argos and Sparta.

e)c ou(= polemh/santes Andoc. regards the aid given by Athens to Argos in 419 B.C. as the origin of the renewed war which ended in the final defeat of Athens. But the Sicilian Expedition came after (not, as he seems to think, before) this event, and it was the result of that expedition which led up to the *dekeleiko\s po/lemos (413 — 404 B.C.).
tou=to u(po/loipon ironical: all that is needed to complete the list of our follies.

*korinqi/wn de\ tou\s n. e)/x.] ‘The Corinthian party which now holds the city’=the war-party, who were in the closest alliance with Argos, as opposed to the Philo-laconian or peace-party led by Pasimêlus. The present rulers of Corinth, Andoc. means, are mere instruments of Argive ambition. See Grote IX. 462 f.
tosau/thn explained by fasi\ ga/r instead of w(/ste fa/nai. Cp. below, p. 69, § 19, line 6.

ta\s tettara/konq' h(m The forty days for which the Athenian plenipotentiaries at Sparta had asked, in order that they might refer the proposed terms to the Athenian Ecclesia. — h(ma=s, the envoys, of whom Andoc. had been one.

th\n a)sf. h(mw=n th=s e)panafora=s ‘The precaution taken by us in making the reference’: cp. Thuc. III. 47, to\ *kle/wnos to\ au)to\ di/kaion kai\ cu/mforon th=s timwri/as, Cleon's view that the punishment is both just and expedient.
lanqa/nonta, k.t.l. ‘must hoodwink and beguile the multitude, if he is to bring them to face dangers’: see note on § 29, a)namnhsqe/ntas.

sth=lai slabs set up in public places inscribed with the
terms of treaties, etc.: kata\ th\n sth/lhn, Ar. Av. 1051, ‘acc. to the compact’: st. ai( pro\s *qhbai/ous, their treaty with Thebes, Dem. Megalop. § 27. — tau=ta de/, ‘in regard to these’ (de/ in apodosis,=‘on the other hand’).
gra/mmata ta\ gegramm ‘the letter of the terms’: cp. § 40.
u(ponoei=n, k.t.l. ‘In regard to what is at your disposal’ (e(toi/mwn, the advantages offered by the Spartan terms), ‘it is your habit to feel misgivings and to raise objections’.

o(/pou — trofh/n] o(/pou=‘and in such a case’. ‘Such is the choice now; and some people are already saying that they do not understand the meaning of the Convention, if the city is merely to get walls and ships: “we do not recover our possessions on foreign soil”, they argue, “and stone walls do not give us bread”.’ — e)k th=s u(perori/as: Athenian possessions abroad, esp. in Thrace and the Chersonese, of which Athens had been deprived at the end of the Peloponnesian War. Cp. § 15, fe/re, a)lla\ *xerro/nhson kai\ ta\s a)poiki/as kai\ ta\ e)gkth/mata (property acquired in a foreign land) kai\ ta\ xre/a (debts) i(/na a)pola/bwmen. Xen. Mem. II. 8 § 1 (where the speaker refers to the end of the War), e)peidh\...a)fh|re/qhn me\n ta\ e)n th=| u(perori/a| kth/mata, e)n de\ th=| *)attikh=| o( path/r moi ou)de\n kate/lipen.
w(=n — tau=ta] w(=n=tw=n a)gaqw=n: tau=ta=tei/xh kai\ nau=s. — tau/thn, k.t.l.: ‘These were the resources from which our fathers set out’.
pria/menoi from aor. e)pria/mhn: pres. in use, w)ne/omai.

*)aqh/nhsi poih/s ‘To make Athens the seat of the Board which administered the common fund’ (of the Delian Confederacy), derived from the fo/ros of the members; Thuc. I. 95 — 96. The transference of the fund from Delos to Athens is said to have been proposed — not, as Andoc. implies here, by the Athenians — but by the Samians (Plut. Arist. 25): Grote v. 465.

laqo/ntes de\ *pel In 479 B.C., when the walls of Athens were rebuilt and the Peiraeus was fortified. laqo/ntes: alluding to the artifices by which Themistocles gained time, Thuc. I. 90 f. Grote v. 331.

pria/m. p. *laked.] The statement that Athens ‘bought impunity’ from Sparta is not only baseless but absurd. It seems to refer to the Thirty Years' Truce between Athens and Sparta (445 B.C.) by which Athens gave up Achaia, Troezen and the harbours of Megara: see Grote v. 475.

o)gdoh/konta kai\ pe/nte i.e. from the battle of Marathon (490 B.C.) to the battle of Aegospotami (405 B.C.): since the
policy by which Themistocles made Athens a naval power dated from the close of the first Persian invasion.
e)ne/xura as pledges against the restoration of the Athenian a)rxh/: Xen. Hellen. II. 2. 19, 20.

ta\ tei/xh kai\ nau=s The Long Walls (except the Phaleric wall) had been restored by Conon in 393 B.C. — nau=s, without the art., because a fleet had yet to be created under the terms imposed by Sparta in 404 B.C. Athens had retained only 12 ships, acc. to § 12 of this speech.

pa=si/ te toi=s gegr ‘And we can have a peace on the basis of all the terms thus defined’: i.e. any new terms proposed by Athenian critics of the treaty can be added to those already formulated (prosgra/fesqai).
tou/twn d'...h(ma=s ‘And the decision on these questions is with you’ (the e)kklhsi/a), ‘and does not depend on the Lacedaemonians — thanks to us’ (the envoys, who asked for the forty days).
presbeuta/s i.e. presbeuta\s au)tokra/toras. The plur. of presbeuth/s is usually pre/sbeis, but presbeutai/ in Thuc. VIII. 77, 86.
ou(=tos o( presb ‘He is the true plenipotentiary’.

div1.head: Lysias
div1.p: LYSIAS: born 459 B.C. acc. to Dionysius and the Plutarchic Life: between 444 and 436 B.C. acc. to K. F. Hermann, etc.: died later than 380 B.C. Approximate period of extant work, 403 — 380 B.C. Life in Attic Orators, I. 142 — 157.

Style. Lysias takes up the development of Attic prose at a point where the stiffness of the older rhetoric, as seen in Antiphon's work, had been modified, but no perfect reconciliation had yet been effected between literary finish and the Attic idiom of ordinary life. Lysias achieves this reconciliation. Unlike Antiphon before him and Isocrates after him, he has the art of concealing his art. His distinctive qualities are a delicate mastery of the purest Attic, a subtle power of expressing character, a restrained sense of humour, and a certain flexibility of mind which enables him under the most diverse circumstances to write with almost unfailing tact and charm, — with that xa/ris, hardly to be analysed save in so far as felicity of expression and an essential urbanity are implied in it, which the old critics felt in him.

Technically, Lysias represents the ‘plain’ manner as distinguished from the ‘stately’ and the ‘middle’: (i)sxno\s xarakth/r, lith/ or a)felh\s le/cis, opp. to megalopreph/s and me/sh: Cic. or. 6. § 20 grandiloqui — tenues — medius et quasi temperatus.) His composition (su/nqesis) varies with the subject and the occasion. In the first of the following extracts, for example, the *)olumpiako/s, we find elaborate and artistic periods. In the fifth extract — from the kata\ *)eratosqe/nous, where the public and private characters are combined — the periodic structure is blended with a style of greater ease and simplicity. In the last extract, the kata\ *pagkle/wnos, the manner of the composition is throughout of a simpler kind. The diction (le/cis) of Lysias is marked by a general avoidance of words or phrases foreign to the ordinary idiom of the day; by abstinence from rhetorical figures, except such as consist in the parallelism or opposition of clauses; and by the union of clearness with conciseness. His power of delineating character (h)qopoii/a) is illustrated by the speech u(pe\r *mantiqe/ou, our third extract: his power of vivid description (e)na/rgeia) will be seen in the speeches against Eratosthenes and Agoratus. The arrangement (ta/cis) of subject-matter is nearly always simple: — proem — narrative — proof — epilogue. — See Attic Orators, I. 158 — 198. On the Works of Lysias in general, ib. I. 199 — 316.

The following selections have been made in such a manner as at once to illustrate the leading characteristics of his style and to represent the several departments of his work. Thus: — (1) Epideictic. I. (2) Deliberative. II. (3) Forensic. dhmo/sioi lo/goi: III. IV. V. VI. VII. — i)diwtikoi/: VIII. IX. (See table in Attic Orators, I. 215: cp. 203, 211.)

div2.p: . [Or. XXXIII.] — This is a fragment — probably the greater part — of an oration delivered by Lysias at Olympia. The great panhellenic festivals afforded an appropriate opportunity to poets and orators who desired to speak, not of those interests or glories which belonged to a single city, but of those which were common to Greece. The ancient Greeks, although they never formed a nation, had a national sentiment, founded on community of blood, speech and manners: and this sentiment was probably never called forth more vividly than when Greeks of all cities came together at Nemea or at the Isthmus, at Delphi or at Olympia.

Hippias, we are told, e)/qelge th\n *(ella/da e)n *)olumpi/a| lo/gois poiki/lois kai\ pefrontisme/nois eu)=, ‘used to charm Greece at Olympia with ornate and carefully meditated speeches’ (Philostr. I. 11). The *)olumpiko/s of Gorgias ‘dealt with the largest of political questions. Seeing Greece torn by faction, he became a counsellor of concord, seeking to turn the Greeks against the barbarians, and advising them to take the land of the
aliens — not each others' cities — for the prize of their arms’ (ib.).

The Olympiacus of Lysias was spoken, according to Diodorus, in the first year of the 98th Olympiad, 388 B.C. — the year before the Peace of Antalcidas, by which the Corinthian War was brought to a close. Athens, Thebes, Argos and Corinth had then been seven years at war with Sparta. During this time two powers, both dangerous to the freedom of Greece, had been rapidly growing. In the east the naval strength of Persia had become greater than it had been for a century. In the west Dionysius I., tyrant of Syracuse, had reduced Naxos, Catana and Leontini: had twice defeated Carthage; and was threatening the Greek towns of Italy. A magnificent embassy from the court of Dionysius, with his brother Thearides at its head, appeared at the Olympic festival of 388 B.C. Tents embroidered with gold were pitched in the sacred enclosure; a number of splendid chariots were entered in the name of Dionysius for the four-horse chariotrace; while rhapsodists, whose skill in recitation attracted crowds, repeated poems composed by their royal master. While eye and ear were thus allured by the glories of the Syracusan tyrant, Lysias lifted up his voice to remind the assembled Greeks that in Dionysius they must recognise one of the two great enemies of Greece. Let them not admit to their sacred festival the representatives of an impious despotism. Let them remember that their duty is to overthrow that tyranny and to set Sicily free; and let the war be begun forthwith by an attack upon those glittering tents. — Attic Orators, I. 203 f.

div3.p: prw=tos sunh/geire Heracles, the legend said, founded the prizes of the Olympic games with the spoils taken in his war with Augeas: Pind. Ol. II. 3, *)olumpia/da d' e)/stasen *(h. a)kro/qina pole/mou: cp. XI. 57: and brought trees — esp. the olive — from the land of the Hyperboreans to the Olympian valley, — that ‘garden of the gods’ (ka=pos) which had before been ‘naked’ (O. III. 24).

filotimi/an...plou/tou ‘rivalry in wealth’ — i.e. in chariots entered for the races (horses being a)/galma th=s u(perplou/tou xlidh=s), and in the general splendour of the qewri/ai. — plou/tou, not plou/tw|: cp. [Lys.] Epitaph. § 80, a)gw=nes...r(w/mhs kai\ sofi/as (=gnw/mhs here) kai\ plou/tou.

gnw/mhs d' e)pi/deicin ‘a display of intellect’ (in the recitation of poems, orations, etc.); but not properly a)gw=na, a contest, since at Olympia there were not prizes for a mousiko\s a)gw/n, as there were at Delphi. Lucian, it is true, says of Herodotus, a)gwnisth\n parei=xen e(auto\n *)olumpi/wn: but he presently explains
that this is metaphorical — a)nakhruxqei\s ou)x u(f' e(no\s ma\ *di/a kh/rukos a)ll) e)n a(pa/sh| po/lei, k.t.l. (Her. 2). Besides the ‘sophists, historians and speech-writers’, Lucian mentions Aetion as having exhibited at Olympia his picture of the marriage of Alexander and Roxana (ib. 3).

<a)\n> gene/sqai] It seems probable that we should supply a)/n, rather than change gene/sqai to genh/sesqai. One of the two remedies is necessary. The aor. infin., without a)/n, might be used if the context made it clear that the reference was to the future: but, here, h(gh/sato gene/sqai would mean ‘thought that it had become’. On p. 69, § 19, w)/|onto kth/sasqai means, indeed, ‘thought to acquire’; but there a difference is made (a) by the fact that the sense of ‘expecting’ can be given to oi)/omai more easily than to h(gou=mai: (b) by the fact that the context is clearer.

tau=q' u(fhgh/sato, e)gw\ d' h(/kw Heracles ‘traced this plan’, sketched this outline of the Olympic festival, leaving it for us to fill in the details. Now I, Lysias says, do not think that he meant this gnw/mhs e)pi/deicis to be frivolous. ‘I am not here to dispute on subtleties or to cavil about words’: like the sophists (Polus, Prodicus, Anaximenes, — Luc. De Her. 3), who have displayed their niceties of dialectic or of grammar at Olympia. Prodicus taught o)rqo/ths o)noma/twn, the accurate use of synonyms, Plat. Euthyd. 277 E.
sofistw=n, k.t.l. ‘These, I consider, are the tasks of worthless and needy declaimers’. On sofistw=n, see below, introd. to Isocrates kata\ sofistw=n.
poli/tou Lysias never acquired the Athenian citizenship, though he had deserved it; but at Olympia he would feel that he was at least a citizen of Greece: see Attic Orators, I. 151.
tw=| barba/rw| — tura/nnwn The king of Persia (Artaxerxes Mnemon, 405 — 359 B.C.): — Dionysius I. of Syracuse.
tw=n me\n pau/sasqai ‘cease from our feuds’: ta\ de\ kwlu=sai — arrest their consequences.

ei)do/tas...tw=n *a)tuxw=n ‘knowing that rivalry, indeed, is for the prosperous, but that the part of the unfortunate is to devise remedies’. tw=n a)tuxw=n is, I think, the true correction of the reading found in the mss., tw=n au)tw=n. ‘The same men’ would mean here oi( eu)= pra/ttontes. But there is no point here in saying that it is the part of prosperous men gnw=nai ta\ be/ltista. He is saying that the Greeks, being the reverse of prosperous, cannot afford to indulge in strife with each other, but must provide for their common safety.

tw=n de\ xr. — ta\ de\ tw=n *(ell.] Dobree thought that logical order required ta\ de\ tw=n *(ell. — tw=n de\ xrhm.: but the
change is needless. The orator puts his two main propositions first. The third (ta\ de\ tw=n *(ell.) could almost have been understood.
au)to\s he himself, as distinguished from Dionysius, who in this view is his ally. Sauppe need not, then, wish for ou(=tos.
e)poi/hsan...e)sterh=sqai more than sterei=sqai: not merely ‘made them lose’ their land, but ‘left them stripped’ of it.

a)tei/xistoi Sparta was not a town in the proper sense, but a group of hamlets (ou) cunoikisqei=sa po/lis...kata\ kw/mas de\ oi)kisqei=sa: Thuc. I. 10). In the Macedonian period it acquired walls; and Polybius describes Sparta as circular in form (sxh/mati periferh/s, v. 22), having a circumference of about six miles — rather less than that of Megalopolis (IX. 21).

proora=sqai depending on e)lpi/s, this might mean there is hope (1) that they are now providing, or (2) that they will continue to provide, — proora=sqai differing from proo/yesqai or proidei=n (a)/n) by expressing that the vigilance is to be sustained: and this is the sense here. See Goodwin § 15, n. 2.

o( e)piw\n kairo/s ‘The future opportunity’ (at whatever particular moment it is to come): i.e. ‘Now the future can give us no better opening than the present’. — a)mfote/rwn, =tou= te basile/ws kai\ tou= *dionusi/ou: after ai( duna/meis, because the idea is, ‘come upon us from both quarters’.

head.foreign: *peri\ tou= mh\ katalu=sai th\n pa/trion politei/an *)aqh/nhsi

div2.p: [Or. XXXIV.] — ‘A Plea against abolishing the ancestral Constitution of Athens’: a fragment, preserved (like the last) by Dionysius. When, after the fall of the Thirty, the Democracy was restored in 403 B.C., it was the aim of Sparta to restrict it. One Phormisios proposed in the Ecclesia that only land-owners should have the franchise, a measure which, according to Dionysius, would have excluded about five thousand citizens. The speech from which he gives an extract was made against this motion during a debate in the Ecclesia. It appears to have been written by Lysias for some wealthy citizen who was not personally affected by the proposal, and may probably be regarded as the earliest of the orator's works now known. — Attic Orators, I. 211.

div3.p: ta\s gegen. sumfora/s ‘our past misfortunes’: the defeat at Aegospotami, which was popularly ascribed to oligarchic treason (see on Lys. In Eratosth. § 36, p. 256), the surrender of Athens, and the tyranny of the Thirty. The date of the speech is shortly after the restoration of the Democracy in 413 B.C.

w(/ste mhd' a)/n ‘So that not even a later generation [much less our own] could desire a change in the constitution [from Democracy to Oligarchy]’. mhd' a)\n e)piqumei=n, oblique of ou)k a)\n e)piqumoi=en. — a)mfote/rwn: Democracy and Oligarchy.

pro/teron *di\s h)/dh. kai\ So Dobree for pro/teron. dio\ dh\ kai\: — di/s referring to (1) the Revolution of the 400 in 411 B.C., and (2) the tyranny of the Thirty. This gives more point. Yet dio\ dh\ kai\ is possible. ‘For that very reason [i.e. just because you have had these experiences], though I do not marvel at them, I marvel at you’.
tou/twn...u(mw=n As we often have qauma/zw tou=to u(mw=n, ‘I wonder at this in (belonging to) you’, so also qauma/zw u(mw=n o(/ti e)ste/, k.t.l., where o(/ti e)ste/=to\ ei)=nai u(ma=s.

*peiraiw=s...a)/steos ‘men whose fortune associated them with the party of the Peiraeus [the patriots whom Thrasybulus led from Phylè], but whose sympathies were with the party of the Town’ [the oligarchical adherents of the Tyranny]. See note below on In Eratosth. § 92, p. 74.

<ou)/te plou/tw|>] Markland's conj. to supply the lacuna, before ou)/te ge/nei, is better than ou)/te h(liki/a| (Stephanus) or ou)/te ou)si/a| (Sauppe). ‘Though I am not in danger of exclusion [from the franchise] on the score either of wealth or of birth, but have in both respects the advantage of my opponents’. The proposed restriction of the franchise probably threatened to exclude all who could not satisfy some definition of a pure Attic descent (ge/nos), as well as those who did not possess a certain property qualification (plou=tos).
e)kth/meqa ‘we possessed’, from e)kth/mhn, plup. for e)kekth/mhn, as in Andoc. De Pace § 37, Her. II. 108: v. l. e)kthsa/meqa, ‘when we acquired’, i.e. ‘after we had acquired’.

ou)x o(/pws <a)/timon> *)aq. tina\ poih/somen dienoou/meqa ‘We did not think of disfranchising any Athenian’. Note that the constr. differs from (though it is akin to) that in which ou)x o(/pws...a)lla/=‘not only not...but’: for this we should need poih=sai. Cp. Lysias kata\ *fi/lwnos (or. XXXI.) § 17, ou(=tos toi/nun ou)x o(/pws w)felh/sei th\n po/lin e)n toiou/tw| kairw=| kai\ toiau/th| katasta/sei dienoh/qh, a)ll' o(/pws ti kerdanei= a)po\ tw=n u(mete/rwn sumforw=n pareskeua/sato.

*eu)boeu=sin ‘we even proposed to confer on Euboeans the right of intermarriage with Athenians’: probably at some time subsequent to the revolt and reduction of the island in 445 B.C. ‘In Euboea two-thirds of the island gradually became the property of Attic citizens’ (Curt. Hist. Gr. II. 486), i.e. of klhrou=xoi. — e)pigami/a, one of the privileges of i)sopolitei/a, or admission to the citizenship of a foreign state: others were a)te/leia (exemp
tion from the taxes on aliens) and e)/gkthsis, right of acquiring land.
a)polou=men ‘ruin’ (by disfranchisement): so the mss.: Bekker a)pelw=men, ‘eject from their rights’.
meta\ tw=n teixw=n ‘along with the walls’ (of Athens, demolished in 404 B.C. under the terms imposed by Sparta).
ple/on ‘better’ (than you could hope to do otherwise).
e)n tai=s e)f) h(mw=n o)l. g.] ‘under the oligarchies that have arisen in our own time’: those, namely, of 411 and 404 B.C. — e)n is rightly supplied by Reiske.

a)/llws te kai\ memn ‘Especially when you remember that the champions of oligarchy, while nominally waging war on Democracy, are in fact lusting for your property’: alluding to the recent spoliations by the Thirty. See Lys. In Eratosth. § 6 (below, p. 66), kalli/sthn...pro/fasin timwrei=sqai me\n dokei=n, tw=| d' e)/rgw| xrhmati/zesqai (‘to make money’ — in reference to the raid of the Tyrants on the me/toikoi). On the art. with o)ligarxi/as, dh/mw|, cp. ib. § 97, note.

e)rw=si...prosta/ttousin ‘And then, these persons who are so enamoured of your possessions — what safety are they to find for the city, unless we do what Sparta bids us? But I would ask them to tell me, what will be left to the people, supposing that we obey her behests?’ i.e. the proposed narrowing of the franchise would so diminish the number of o(pli=tai and i(ppei=s as to leave Athens, in a military sense, at the mercy of Sparta; and if Sparta's dictation were obeyed, the end would be an Oligarchy of the closest type — like that of the Thirty. With Markland's e)rwtw=si (adopted by Baiter and Sauppe) we must strike out toi=s (as they have not done), and render: — ‘And then they ask, How is the city to save your property, unless we do what Sparta bids us?’ But the tenor of the argument clearly supports the e)rw=si of the mss.

*)argei/ous...*mantine/as ‘Now I observe that the Argives and Mantineians, while they maintain the same policy’ [i.e. have democratic governments, instead of oligarchies servile to Sparta], ‘are in possession of their territory, though the Argives (tou\s me/n) touch the frontier of Lacedaemon, and the Mantineians (tou\s de/) are its neighbours, — the citizens of Argos being not more numerous than we are, while those of Mantineia do not number 3000’. Clinton (F. H. II. 517) computes that at this time Argos and Athens may each have had about 16,000 male citizens, which would give a total free population for each of about 66,000: similarly the free population of Mantineia and its territory would be about 13,000 (ib. p. 507).
i)/sasi sc. oi( *lakedaimo/nioi: tou/twn, the Argives and Mantineians.

w(/ste ou) kalo/s ‘And so the venture strikes them as offering inglorious alternatives; if they conquer their neighbours, they must enslave them too (ge): if they are vanquished, they will have robbed themselves of the advantages which they now enjoy’. Reiske's insertion of ou) before katadoulw/sesqai (adopted by Baiter and Sauppe) seems to me to make nonsense of the whole sentence. Lys. does not mean ‘the risk of failing to enslave them’ (where, too, we should expect mh/, not ou)), but the discredit of being compelled to enslave them, in order to avoid to\ polla/kis e)mba/llein.
<h(=tton>] The sense shows that Reiske is right in supplying h(=tton. It is perhaps to be supplied before a)podecame/nous in Antiph. Tetr. B. b. § 2 (above, p. 2, where see note).

th\n xw/ran temn Cp. Thuc. II. 62 (Pericles to the Athenians, during the Peloponnesian invasion of 430 B.C.), ou)d' ei)ko\s xalepw=s fe/rein au)tw=n (for your lands and houses) ma=llon h)\ ou) khpi/on kai\ e)gkallw/pisma plou/tou pro\s tau/thn (the naval empire of Athens) nomi/santes o)ligwrh=sai.

o( ki/ndunos ou(=tos ‘We know that on this one cast all our hopes of welfare are staked’: o( ki/nd. ou(=tos, i.e. peri\ th=s patri/dos, the question whether the pa/trios politei/a (the Democracy) is to be maintained or not.

to\ di/kaion We can say, e)panorqou=n (or even pra/ssein) e)pi\ to\ di/kaion, to amend (or to act) ‘in the direction of right’; but hardly ei)=nai meta\ tw=n a)dik. e)pi\ to\ di/k., to be on the side of the wronged in the cause of right: hence Taylor's omission of e)pi\ seems warranted. ‘Trusting in the gods, and hoping that Justice will be the ally of the injured’. me/n — kai/, (as me/n — te Soph. O. T. 498), Thuc. II. 65, tri/a me\n e)/th a)ntei=xon ...kai\ ou) pro/teron e)ne/dosan. — If the subject to e)/sesqai is qeou/s understood, to\ di/k.=‘as is just’, an acc. like to\ lego/menon (Thuc. VII. 68): but this is too harsh.
feuco/meqa ‘go into exile’ — as the mass of Athenian citizens had actually done when the Thirty limited the franchise to 3000; see Lys. In Eratosth. § 95, p. 76, and notes, p. 258.

div2.p:
. [Or. XVI.] — The name occurs only in the title, which, contrary to the general rule, is perhaps of the same age as the speech — ‘A defence for Mantitheus on his Scrutiny before the Senate’. The office to which this scrutiny related was perhaps that of an ordinary senator, since in § 8 the speaker cites instances of persons
who had really done what he is charged with doing, and had yet been admitted to the Senate. The complaint against him was that his name appeared on the list (sani/dion, § 6) of those who had served as Knights in the time of the Thirty. As or. XXVI. against Evandrus shows (§ 10), the fact of such service under the Tyrants became, after the restoration of the Democracy, a disqualification for the office of senator. Mantitheus must, then, have been at least eighteen years of age in 405 B.C., and so must have been born before 422. He refers to his share in campaigns subsequent to that of 394 B.C. (§§ 15 — 18). On the other hand, the tone of § 15 rather suggests that Thrasybulus was still alive; — that is, that the speech is earlier than 389 B.C. The date may have been about 392 B.C. The speaker, who was taunted with youthful presumption (§ 20), cannot have been much more than thirty. — Attic Orators, I. 245.

div3.p: tw=n au)toi=s beb ‘their course of life’. Dem. De Cor. § 265, e)ce/tason toi/nun par' a)/llhla ta\ soi\ ka)moi\ bebiwme/na.

a)ciw= de/ ‘What I ask of your House is this: — If I merely prove that I am loyal to the existing Constitution’ [the restored Democracy], ‘and that I have been compelled to share your dangers’ [by ordinary service in war], ‘let not that bring me any positive (pw) credit: but if my career is shown to have been worthy in the most complete sense — in a sense directly opposed to the opinion and the assertions of my enemies — then I pray you to ratify my admission [to the Senate], and to pass a silent condemnation on my foes’. — kai\ peri\ ta\ a)/lla: ‘in all other things also’: i.e. not only in the rudiments of civic loyalty, but in all its duties, public and private.

th=s e)n *(ell. s. — *sa/turon The Athenian overthrow at Aegospotami, 405 B.C. — Satyrus, king of Bosporus in the Tauric Chersonese (Crimea), 407 — 393 B.C. The Trapeziticus of Isocrates (or XVII.) was written for a subject of this Satyrus. Cp. Attic Orators, II. 222.

ou)/te tw=n teixw=n ‘neither when the walls were being pulled down’ [under the terms imposed by Sparta when Athens surrendered to Lysander in the spring of 404 B.C.], ‘nor when the form of government was being changed’ [by the establishment of the Thirty Tyrants a little later, in April, 404]. See Annals in Attic Orators, I. p. xlv. After politei/as, e)pedhmou=men seems to have dropped out of the mss.

tw=n a)llotr. kind.] i.e. the perils of the Thirty Tyrants, who were deposed soon after the advance of Thrasybulus and the exiles from Phylè to the Peiraeus (Dec. 404 B.C.), and
were succeeded by the Ten. The exiles were in possession of Athens in July 403, and the Democracy was formally restored in September.
toi=s mhde\n e)c ‘who had no share in their crimes’, and therefore no claim upon their favour.

e)k...tou= sanidi/ou The tablet (a board covered with gypsum), the official list. Cp. Lys. In Epicr. (or. XXVI.) § 16, ei) me\n dh\ bouleu/swn nuni\ e)dokima/zeto kai\ w(s i(ppeuko/tos au)tou= e)pi\ tw=n tria/konta tou)/noma e)n tai=s sani/sin e)nege/grapto.

tou\s fula/rxous, k.t.l. ‘that the cavalry commanders’ (10 in number, one for each fulh/ — opp. to taci/arxoi, commanders of the tribal infantry) ‘should make a return of those who had served as Knights, in order that you might compel them to refund the sums paid to them for their equipment’ (katasta/seis, ‘appointments’ — allowances for outfit made by the State to i(ppei=s when first enrolled).

toi=s sundi/kois The Fiscal Board of Ten, — the Athenian ‘Solicitors to the Treasury’ — by whom he would have been prosecuted as a public debtor (o)fei/lwn tw=| dhmosi/w|). Cp. Harpocration p. 279, su/ndikoi, pro\s ou(\s ta\ dhmeuo/mena a)pefe/reto, a)rxh/ tis kaqistame/nh meta\ th\n e)k *peiraiw=s ka/qodon (i.e. at the restoration of the Democracy in 403 B.C.): Herm. Ant. I. § 151 n. 4.
ou)/te kat. paral.] ‘nor that I had received any allowance’ (in the first instance). Bake reads katabalo/nta, which could hardly=‘refunded’. Others regard the clause as interpolated.
e)kei/nois The list kept by the fu/larxoi: tou/tois — the list on the sani/dion.
bouleu/ontas=bouleuta\s o)/ntas. The dokimasi/a of Mantitheus himself was probably for admission to the boulh/ (see introd.).
martu/rhson viz. that I returned to the Peiraeus only at the time stated in § 4.

tai=s dokim ‘Cases of scrutiny’: esp. the scrutiny by the Senate of officials designate. Four other speeches of Lysias are concerned with dokimasi/ai, viz. XXVI. XXXI. XXV. XXIV. See Attic Orators, I. 215, and 242 — 254.
e)pidou/s ‘giving a dowry of 30 minas to each’: i.e. giving with (e)pi/) the bride (to the husband): Il. IX. 148, o(/ss' ou)/pw tis e(h=| e)pe/dwke qugatri/.
e)neima/mhn ‘shared my inheritance’: Isae. or. VII. § 5, ou)si/an e)nei/manto pro\s a)llh/lous.

peri\ de\ tw=n koinw=n ‘As to my public life’; — not merely, as the context shows, his discharge of public duties, but, more generally, the character which he bore in society, as distinguished from his conduct of family affairs (ta\ i)/dia).

peri\ ku/bous Cp. Lys. or. XIV. § 27 (of the younger Alcibiades), katakubeu/sas ta\ o)/nta. Isocrates says of the idle youth of the day, oi( me\n ga\r au)tw=n e)pi\ th=s e)nneakrou/nou yu/xousin oi)=non... e(/teroi d' e)n toi=s skirafei/ois (gambling-houses) kubeu/ousi, Antid. § 287.
di/khn...grafh\n...ei)sagg.] Neither a private lawsuit, nor a public prosecution, nor an impeachment (for an offence more directly against the State).

ei)s *(ali/arton The Athenian expedition in 325 B.C. for the relief of Haliartus, defended by the Thebans against the Lacedaemonians, whose leader, Lysander, was killed in the battle under its walls: Xen. Hellen. III. 5. 16 f.

h(goume/nous synonymous with nomi/zontas. The contrasted clauses are toi=s me
 i(ppeu/ousin a)sfa/leian, toi=s d' o(pli/tais ki/ndunon. The notion of ‘thinking’ is common to both clauses. Yet it is repeated in different words, as if these words, too, were contrasted. This trait deserves remark as showing immaturity in the use of antithesis. Cp. or. XXV. § 22, h(gou/menoi dia\ th
 tw=n tria/konta ponhri/an polu\ ma=llon swqh/sesqai h)\ dia\ th
 tw=n feugo/ntwn du/namin katie/nai. Also In Eratosth. § 7 (below, p. 66) peri\ ou)deno\s h(gou=nto...peri\ pollou= e)poiou=nto: ib. § 32 (p. 73) toi=s me/llousin a)di/kws a)poqanei=sqai......tou\s a)di/kws a)poloume/nous. See, too, note on Antiphon De Caed. Herod. § 87 (above, p. 21).
a)dokima/stwn who had not passed the scrutiny necessary for admission to the cavalry: the law was, e)a/n tis a)doki/mastos i(ppeu/h|, a)/timon ei)=nai (Lys. or. XIV. § 8).
tw=| *)orqobou/lw| prob. the phylarch of the tribe to which Mantitheus belonged.
e)fodi/wn ‘funds’ for their equipment and journey. M. assisted the more needy of his own dhmo/tai, who were personally known to him. The tribe consisted of demes not adjacent to each other.

ei)s *ko/rinqon in 394 B.C., when the allies, including the Athenian contingent under Thrasybulus (whose deme was Steiria — hence o( semno\s *steirieu/s), were defeated by the Spartans: Xen. Hellen. IV. 2. 9 — 23.
th=s prw/ths tetagm ‘posted in the front rank’ (ta/cews): cp. Isocr. Panath. § 180, th=s prw/ths ta/ttein. Below, § 16, ta/cis=the contingent of infantry furnished by each fulh/.

*e)napoqano/ntwn ‘died on the field’. The place to which the e)n- of the compound refers is left to be understood from the context; cp. Her. IX. 65, ou)/te e)selqw\n e)s to\ te/menos, ou)/te e)napoqanw/n. Thuc. II. 52, ta\ i(era\...nekrw=n ple/a h)=n au)tou= e)napoqnh|sko/ntwn. While e)napoqnh/|skw is current in classical prose, e)nqnh/|skw is unknown to it, being (like the simple qnh/|skw) a poetical word.

xwri/wn i)sx ‘strong positions having been occupied (by the Athenians and their allies), so that the enemy (the Spartans) could not approach’. The reading parie/nai (pass the Isthmus) would give more point.
*)aghsila/ou d' ei)s th\n *b Agesilaus, recalled from Asia Minor, entered Boeotia from the north, and won the battle of Coroneia against the allies (394 B.C.).

a)poxwri/sai...bohq.] ‘to detach some companies as supports’ (of the allied forces in Boeotia). bohqh/sousi can only mean, against Agesilaus: and e(/teros ki/ndunos, ‘peril in a new quarter’, is opp. to peril at Corinth.
a)gaphtw=s...ses.] ‘barely saved’: i.e. so as only just to satisfy the desire of safety: cp. Plat. Lysis 218 C, e)/xwn a)gaphtw=s o(\ e)qhreuo/mhn, ‘having only just secured my prey’.
a)klhrwti/ ‘without ballot’ — waiving the chance of no being drawn.
strateiw=n kai\ fr ‘expeditions and terms of garrison duty’.

a)ll) ou)k, ei)/ tis *koma=| ‘instead of hating one for wearing long hair’, — a custom which, at this period, was retained by the Spartans, but which, at Athens, was restricted to youths under 18, and to the *(ippei=s, — being regarded, in other cases, as a mark of foppery, or as an affectation of Spartan manners. koma=|, Hamaker's conjecture, is irresistibly commended by the context here. The traditional tolma=| is not only weak, but incompatible with the context; for the verb ought to denote some harmless personal peculiarity which is contrasted with sterling merit in the field (tw=n kinduneu/ein e)qelo/ntwn). So the *(ippei=s say in Ar. Eq. 582, h)/n pot' ei)rh/nh ge/nhtai...mh\ fqonei=q' h(mi=n komw=si: Av. 1281, e)lakwnoma/noun...e)ko/mwn. Cp. § 19, a)p' o)/yews (personal appearance). — With a)ll' ou)k supply xrh/: we could not have xrh\ ou) misei=n.
mikro\n d., k.t.l. ‘though their voice was low and their dress decorous’. Cp. [Dem.] or. XXXVII. Adv. Callipp. § 52, e)pi/fqono/s e)sti kai\ taxe/ws badi/zei kai\ me/ga fqe/ggetai.

new/teros w)n In Anab. III. 1. 14 Xenophon speaks as if his youth made it strange that he should take a leading part — being then, probably, about 30 years old. — kai\ e)mautw=|, ‘to myself also’ (and not only to my possible critics).
mo/nous a)ci/ous Cp. Thuc. II. 40, to\n mhde\n tw=nde (tw=n politikw=n) mete/xonta ou)k a)pra/gmona a)ll' a)xrei=on nomi/zomen.
kritai/ ‘the judgment on their character rests with none but you’: kritai/ is more general than dikastai/, judges of their (legal) cause. Cp. Antiph. De Caed. Her. § 94 (above, p. 24).

div2.p: . [Or. XXIV.] — ‘For the Invalid’. At Athens a certain allowance was made by the State to the a)du/natoi: that is, to persons who were unable, through bodily ailment, to earn a livelihood, and who had less than three minae of private property. Once a year, or perhaps oftener, the list of applicants for such relief was scrutinised by the Senate and then passed by the Ecclesia (§ 22). It is on the occasion of such a scrutiny that the present speech is made. The speaker had for years (§ 8) been in receipt of an obol daily (§ 26) from the State; but lately it had been attempted to show that he was not entitled to public relief. This objection is termed in the title to the speech (not in the speech itself) an impeachment (eisangelia); but had, of course, nothing in common with eisangeliae technically so called, except that it was an accusation laid immediately before the Senate. As appears from § 25, the date was later than 403 B.C.; and it might be inferred that the memory of the tyranny in 404 B.C. was no longer very recent. — Attic Orators, I, 254.

div3.p: i(ppikh=s ‘As to my riding, which he has had the hardihood to mention to you, — so little does he fear Fortune, or respect your common sense — the reply is brief’. *tu/xh may some day make him a)du/naton, and then he will need the cripple's dole: cp. § 22, ou(= mo/nou metalabei=n h( tu/xh moi e)/dwken e)n th=| patri/di, ‘the only privilege which Fortune [who has afflicted me] has permitted me to enjoy in my country’. Cp. Thuc. v. 104, h( tu/xh e)k tou= qei/ou. — ou)/te u(ma=s ai)sx.: because he asks them not to believe their own eyes, § 14.

filosofei=n ‘study’. Isocr. Panegyr. § 6, pw=s ou) xrh\ skopei=n kai\ filosofei=n tou=ton to\n lo/gon; (the theme of a Panhellenic war on Persia): for filosofi/a in the general sense of study, see Attic Orators, II. 36.
ta\s makr. tw=n a)nagk.] ‘for the longer of my necessary excursions’; tw=n a)nagkai/wn is partitive gen., not gen. after makrote/ras. The longest of his o(doi/ were still only a)nagkai=ai.

a)stra/bhs ‘If I were wealthy, I should sit at ease on my mule, instead of riding other men's horses’: a)stra/bh, a padded saddle with a back like a chair, used by luxurious persons, who preferred steady-going mules: hence the notion that a)str. meant a mule. Cp. Dem. In Mid. § 133, e)p' a)stra/bhs o)xou/menos a)rgura=s. In Lucian Lexiphanes 2, o( a)strabhla/ths= ‘the muleteer’. — a)ne/bainon: an effort for him, as the ordinary Greek saddle, or rather horsecloth (e)fi/ppion, sc. strw=ma), of that period had no stirrups.

tou=ton au)to
...siwpa=n ‘that the prosecutor himself should be silent, if he saw me in my mule-saddle (for what could he say?)’ The insertion of a)/n before siwpa=n is unnecessary, because the parenthesis, ti/ ga a)
 kai\ e)/legen; is equivalent to w(/sper a)
 e)siw/pa. — dunato/s, ‘sound’: cp. § 4, tw=| sw/mati du/nasqai.
oi(=s ‘when I have the same reason for using both these resources’ (crutches and riding).

klhr. tw=n e). a)rx.] ‘to ballot for a place among the nine archons’. The archons were klhrwtoi/, chosen by lot, (opp. to ai(retoi/, chosen by xeirotoni/a,) prob. from Solon's time, though Her. VI. 109 ascribes the change to Cleisthenes. Cp. the pseudo-Lysian or. VI. In Andoc. § 4, a)\n e)/lqh| klhrwso/menos tw=n e)nne/a a)rxo/ntwn kai\ la/xh| basileu/s (draw the lot to be Archon Basileus). — a)naph/rw|, ‘a cripple’.

ou) ga\r dh/pou ‘For I presume that the same person will not be deprived of his allowance by you on the ground that he is able-bodied, and excluded by the presidents of the ballot on the ground that he is physically disabled’: oi( de/=oi( qesmoqe/tai, who presided over the ballot for offices: Aeschin. In Ctes. § 13, a)rxa\s e)kei/nas (opp. to ta\s ai(reta/s) a(\s oi( q. a)poklhrou=sin e)n tw=| *qhsei/w|.

w(/sper e)piklh/rou When the property of a deceased citizen was inherited by his daughter, her nearest male kinsman was legally entitled to claim her in marriage: and this claim was sometimes enforced, acc. to Isaeus, even when it involved the dissolution of a marriage contracted before her father's death: Isae. or. III. § 64, polloi\ sunoikou=ntes h)/dh a)fh/|rhntai ta\s e(autw=n gunai=kas. So the prosecutor, the a)du/natos says with grim humour, seeks to take the sumfora/ — dowered as it is with its one obol a day — away from its lawful consort. The Greeks could say, no/sos sunoikei= tini/: thus the common idiom would
make the fancy seem less strained. For a)mfisbhtei=n with gen. of the object claimed, cp. Isae. or. v. § 14 (below, p. 170) a)mfisbhtou=men au)tw=| a(/pantos tou= oi)/kou.

div2.p: . [Or. XII.] — Polemarchus, brother of Lysias, had been put to death by the Thirty Tyrants. Eratosthenes, one of their number, was the man who had arrested him and taken him to prison. In this speech Lysias, himself the speaker, charges Eratosthenes with the murder of Polemarchus, and, generally, with his share in the Tyranny. A special clause in the Amnesty of 403 B.C. excluded the Thirty Tyrants, the Ten who had succeeded them, and the Eleven who had executed their sentences. But any one even of these might enjoy the Amnesty if he chose to stand a public inquiry, and was acquitted. When the oligarchy was finally overthrown, Pheidon and Eratosthenes were the only members of it who stayed at Athens. As they dared to do this, they must have availed themselves of the permission to give account of their office. Here, then, we have not to do with an ordinary indictment for murder (grafh\ fo/nou). The public inquiry into the conduct of Eratosthenes afforded Lysias the opportunity for preferring his accusation. This is indicated (1) by the wide range of topics in the speech, dealing, as it does, with the whole history of the Anarchy: (2) by § 37, where the accuser says that he has done enough in having shown that the guilt of the accused reaches the point at which death is deserved: which he could scarcely have said if (as in a grafh\ fo/nou) death had been the necessary penalty in case of conviction.

Date, 403 B.C., shortly after the formal restoration of the Democracy in Sept., and before the expedition against Eleusis had dislodged the fugitive Tyrants from that place (Xen. Hellen. II. 4. 43): see § 80 of the speech, mhd' a)pou=si me\n toi=s tria/konta e)pibouleu/ete, paro/ntas d' a)fh=te. — Attic Orators, I. 261 f.

div3.head: 1. Narrative: the Murder of Polemarchus. — §§ 1 — 36.
div3.p: au)toi=s=toi=s tria/konta, whose names were already before the court. In § 33, tou/tois=the Thirty as represented in court by Eratosthenes.
mh/t' a)\n y. — du/nasqai i.e. ou)/te yeudo/menos (=ei) yeu/doito) d. tw=n u(. kathgorh/sai a)/n (tis), ou)/te ta)l. boulo/menos (=ei) bou/loito) ei)pei=n a(/panta du/naito a)/n.

tou)nanti/on de/...e)camarta/nein ‘And I believe that our experience’ (as accusers of E.) ‘will be contrary to all prece
dent. Heretofore the accuser has always been expected to show what enmity exists between himself and the accused: here, it is from the accused that we have to ask what was that enmity towards the Commonwealth which gave them the heart to sin so enormously against it’. Personal enmity (e)/xqra) was regarded as a proof that the accuser was in grim earnest, — that he was not a mere busy-body (polupra/gmwn) or mercenary calumniator (sukofa/nths). Thus the accuser of Agoratus begins by showing that his own wrongs entitle him to appear in that capacity: tugxa/nei ou)=n e)moi\ h( au)th\ e)/xqra pro\s *)ago/raton toutoni\ kai\ tw=| plh/qei tw=| u(mete/rw| u(pa/rxousa: ‘so my personal quarrel with A. is the same as that of the Athenian People’: In Agor. § 1.

h(/tis ei)/h — h(/tis h)=n] ei)/h, because e)/dei is a secondary tense. ei)/h may be the oblique either of e)sti/ or of h)=n: dei= tou\s kathg. e)pid. th\n e)/xqr. h(/tis e)sti/, (or h)=n, was when they brought the charge): but is best taken as representing e)sti/. Just to avoid this ambiguity, the Greek imperf. and pluperf. are usually kept in the indic., even when they might be changed into the optat. For an exception, see Dem. Adv. Onet. I. § 20, a)pekri/nanto o(/ti ou)dei\s ma/rtus parei/h: this would usually mean, ‘they replied, “No witness is present”’ (pa/resti): it really means, ‘they replied, “No witness was (at that former time) present”’ (parh=n). — Cp. Goodwin pp. 148, 153.

ou) me/ntoi...o)rgi/z.] ‘I do not speak, however, as one who has no personal resentments or grievances’ [against the Thirty]; ‘I only mean that everyone has abundant matter of indignation against them, either on private or on public grounds’: i.e. if there be any one who (unlike myself) has no private wrongs to resent, he may remember the wrongs of the community. The first part of L.'s speech (§§ 1 — 36) deals with ta\ i)/dia: the second (§§ 37 — end) with ta\ dhmo/sia.

poih/swmai better, I think, here than poih/somai, which Rauchenstein prefers. The fut. indic., after a verb of fearing, usually implies that the thing feared is vividly seen as the more probable of the possible results; the subjunctive suits the present context better, because it better expresses a mind divided between fear and hope.

*ke/falos A Syracusan who settled at Athens as a me/toikos. Plato marks his hospitable disposition in the Republic (328 D), of which the opening scene is laid at the house of his eldest son Polemarchus. — Attic Orators, I. 145.

e)dikasa/meqa...e)fu/g.] ‘maintained’ an action — ‘defended it’. Though dika/zesqai can be said of both parties to a suit, yet di/khn dika/zesqai/ tini is esp. said of him who ‘goes to law’ with another, — o( diw/kwn.

sukofa/ntai ‘mercenary accusers’. Cp. Lys. or. XXV. § 19 (of the demagogues), e)/nioi d' e)pi\ toi=s u(mete/rois e)dwrodo/koun, oi( de\ sukofantou=ntes tou\s summa/xous a)fi/stasan: Xen. Hellen. II. 3. 12, a)po\ sukofanti/as zw=ntas.
trape/sqai ‘and that the rest of the citizens should come into the paths of virtue and justice’. It is needless to conjecture protre/yasqai.

[kai\] toiau=ta le/gontes] The kai\ here seems clearly a spurious addition, whether due to a mere error of the eye, or to a desire of connecting fa/skontes with le/gontes. Only two versions of it are possible, and neither is tolerable. (1) ‘and saying things of that kind’, — so that the words become a general statement appended to the special statement fa/skontes xrh=nai, — a sort of ‘etcetera’: (2) ‘though they said such things’. But, in a simple contrast between deed and word, kai/ would not thus be added to the participle. Here, if so added, it ought rather to mean ‘even when saying’.

w(s e)gw\...peira/somai] ‘as, when I have first spoken of my own affairs (§§ 1 — 36), I will endeavour to bring to your memory in regard to your affairs also’: a)namnh=sai=dida/cai a)namnh/santa, with kai\ peri\ tw=n u(mete/rwn.
th=| politei/a| ‘the constitution’ — a u(poko/risma: for the rule of the Thirty was unconstitutional (ou) meta\ no/mwn), and was known, when a real politei/a had been restored, as the a)narxi/a.

xrhmati/zesqai ‘to make money’: lit. ‘to do business to one's own profit’: oi)o/menoi xrhmatiei=sqai ma=llon h)\ maxei=sqai (Athenians in Sicily), Thuc. VII. 13: but act. xrhmati/zein, to transact (public) business, ib. I. 87.
pa/ntws ‘at any rate’ — i.e. whatever view their colleagues might be disposed to take of the project for plundering the resident aliens.
h(gou=nto...e)poiou=nto See note above on p. 60 § 13, h(goume/nous...nomi/zontas.

i(/na...pro\s tou\s a)/llous ‘in order that, as against the others’, [the eight rich me/toikoi,] ‘they might have the plea’ [h)=| vivid for ei)/h] ‘that these measures had not been taken from mercenary motives, but in the interests of the Constitution, — just as they might defend any other measure adopted for sufficient reasons’. w(/sper ti...pepoihko/tes, sc. a)pologi/an a)\n e)/xoien: the nom., as if i(/na e)/xwsin a)pologi/an (instead of i(/na au)toi=s h)=| a)pol.) had preceded. — eu)lo/gws, i.e. for reasons satisfactory to the government, though not communicated to the people.

dialabo/ntes de/ ‘Each was told off for certain houses [of the me/toikoi], and the visits began’. Cp. Dem. De Cor. § 132, e)p' oi)ki/as badi/zwn a)/neu yhfi/smatos, making domiciliary visits without special authority from the Ecclesia.
to\ e)rgasth/rion The shield-manufactory, the property of the brothers, near the house in the Peiraeus occupied by Lysias: see Attic Orators, I. 147. — a)pegra/fonto, ‘proceeded to take a list of’.
e)/fasken, k.t.l. sc. sw/sein. His words were, sw/sw, a)\n polla\ h)=|. — ei)/hn, oblique of ei)mi/ (not of h)=n): see on h(/tis ei)/h, § 2. — tau=ta, not tou=to: so § 14.
e)cw/leian See Antiph. De Caed. Her. § 11 (above, p. 11).
tw=n u(phretw=n apparitors, attending him in his official capacity, since the search was made by authority of the Thirty.
kuz. — dar.] The *kuzikhno\s stath/r=about £1. 2s. 9d.: the *dareiko\s stath/r (=*)attiko/s) about £1. 1s. 10d.
a)gaph/sein He said, a)gaph/seis ei) to\ sw=ma sw/seis, ‘you will be content’, i.e. ‘you must be’. ‘You may think yourself lucky enough if you save your life’.
e)pitugxa/nei...a)pio/ntes Dem. In Aristocr. § 12, qh/sesqai ta\ o(/pla ou)k h)/mellen o( *si/mwn ou)d' o( *bia/nwr, poli=tai gegenhme/noi.
badi/zoimen...ske/yhtai] badi/zoimen, not badi/zomen, because the historic pres. e)rwtw=sin is equivalent to a secondary tense: ske/yhtai, and not ske/yaito, by the vivid construction.
u(pa/rxontos ‘was assured’.
pro/q. p. th\n seautou= d.] i.e. do all that lies in your power,=o(/son ge e)pi\ soi/ e)sti.

o(/ti a)mfi/quros ei)/h ‘that there was a passage through it’ (from the front-door, au)/leios qu/ra, to the back-door, khpai/a qu/ra). Of the three doors in § 16, one would be the me/taulos, another the khpai/a.

e)nqumoume/nw| — a)poq.] ‘reflecting that, if I escaped notice, I should be saved, but if I were caught — well, in that case I thought that I should get off nevertheless, supposing Th. had been persuaded by D. to take the money; or if he had not, my prospect of death would only be the same’ [as if I did not try to save myself by flight]. Instead of a)feqh/somai, a)poqanou=mai, depending on e)nqumoume/nw|, we have the futures infin. depending
on h(gou/mhn, — inserted to avoid the awkwardness of one conditional clause immediately following another (e)a\n de\ lhfqw=, ei) me\n ei)/h, k.t.l.).
ei)s a)/stu The ship-master lived in the Peiraeus, where Lysias himself resided. — au)to/n, Polemarchus.
to\ u(p' e)kei/nwn ei)qisme/non sc. paragge/llesqai.

triw=n...au)to/n ‘Though we had three houses, they did not allow the funeral (e)kfora/) to take place from any one of them, but hired a mean tenement, and there laid out the corpse’. kli=/sion, also written klei/sion (from klei/w, not kli^/nw?), is used by Antiphanes (*)ake/stria 2, Mein. Frag. Com. p. 348) of an outhouse or shed for cattle: th=s oi)ki/as to\ kli=/sion to\ kalou/menon, | o(\ pro/teron h)=n toi=s e)c a)grou= bousi\ staqmo\s | kai\ toi=s o)/nois, pepoi/hke — ti/ d' ; — e)rgasth/rion. — o(/ti e(/kastos e)/tuxen, sc. dou/s.

ko/smon here, apparently, ‘valuables’, articles of vertu, etc., as dist. from e)/pipla, furniture. ko/smos in sing. usu.=dress, personal adornments, as Il. XIV. 187, pa/nta peri\ xroi\ qh/kato ko/smon.

w)/|onto kth/sasqai ‘thought to acquire’ (not, as the words might mean, ‘thought that they had acquired’). So § 26, ou)k oi)/ei...dou=nai (=dw/sein): § 27, ei)ko\s h)=n u(phreth=sai (=u(phreth/sein). In such cases, the work of indicating future time is done by the principal verb (e)lpi/zw, etc.), and the aor. infin. has its proper function of marking a momentary as opposed to a continued or repeated act. It is tempting here to read kth/sesqai: but the context, and the usage of oi)/omai, seem to render it unnecessary. — Cp. note on p. 50 § 2, h(gh/sato...<a)\n> gene/sqai.
ei)s to\ dhmo/sion a)pe/dosan ‘handed over the rest for the benefit of the Treasury’. (a)pe/donto would have meant ‘sold’.)
tosau/thn...th=s ga/r Cp. Andoc. De Pace § 33 (above, p. 45) tosau/thn...fasi\ ga/r (instead of w(/ste fa/nai).

o(/te to\ prw=ton ‘when Melobius first visited the house’. Francken puts a comma after oi)ki/an, understanding ‘when she first came (as a bride) to the house’: but a Greek would not thus have expressed o(/te prw=ton e)gh/mato.

w(/sper <ou)d'> a)/n sc. e)camarta/noien. The conjectural insertion of ou)d' is a rhetorical, though not a logical, necessity. ‘They outraged us as other men would not outrage their bitterest enemies’. Omit the ‘not’; the statement remains intelligible, but ceases to be effective.

ei)sfora/s — lusame/nous Occasional ‘war-taxes’, in addition to the regular metoi/kion paid by resident aliens. — lusame/nous:
Dem. De Chers. § 70, e)/xwn kai\ trihrarxi/as ei)pei=n kai\ xrhma/twn ei)sfora\s kai\ lu/seis ai)xmalw/twn kai\ toiau/tas a)/llas filanqrwpi/as.
mellou/sas e)kdi/dosqai ‘prevented the approaching marriage of many a daughter’ — by leaving her father without the means of giving her a dower (proi=ka e)pidou=nai).

d' e)boulo/mhn a)/n sc. ei) dunato\n h)=n: Goodwin § 52. 2, cp. Antiph. De Caed. Her. § 1 (above, p. 8). ‘For my part, I could wish that their story were true, since my own share in that gain would not be small’: i.e. his brother would be alive, and their wealth would be intact. — ou)/te...toiau=ta u(pa/rxei, ‘they have not such a case’: cannot plead such innocence.

kai\ pro\s e(/teron The man stained with murder (e)nagh/s) might speak to no one (Aesch. Eum. 426, a)/fqoggon ei)=nai to\n palamnai=on no/mos): and for the relatives of the slain it was not o(/sion to accost him (Isae. or. IX. § 20: cp. Soph. O. T. 238). By a rhetorical exaggeration, Lysias says that he would think it impious to speak even about Eratosthenes, e)p' w)felei/a|, for E.'s advantage.

i(/na <a)poqa/nwmen h)\> mh\ a)poqa/nwmen The words supplied in brackets might easily have dropped out, by accident, or through their supposed redundancy. They are clearly requisite to the rhetorical point of the passage viz., the contrast between his alleged protest and his subsequent acts. In protesting, was your aim to kill us, or to save us? ‘To save you’. And yet afterwards you did everything in your power to kill us? ‘Was the object of your protest to kill us? or to save us?’
ei)=q' ei)=ta, ‘so’ — i.e. after protesting as you allege.
a)nteipw\n ou)de\n w)f ‘because you protested, — though the protest was fruitless’. See on Andoc. De Pace, § 29, p. 232.
ou)k oi)/ei...dou=nai ‘do you not expect to pay the penalty?’ See above on § 19, w)/|onto kth/sasqai.

ou) ga\r dh/ pou ‘For I presume that they did not mean to make the case of the resident aliens the test of his loyalty’: i.e. the Thirty Tyrants had proved the fidelity of Eratosthenes to their commands in the case of so many citizens that they did not need to test him on humbler victims. e)la/mbanon, like e)/mellon labei=n. e)/peita: besides, as it happened, he was a peculiarly unsuitable instrument in this particular case, if (as he says) he had opposed the measure.
toi=s me\n a)/llois *)aq ‘The other Athenians’ are, as § 30 shows, those on whom the Thirty had imposed odious tasks, esp. of domiciliary search.
kai\ lh/yesqe ‘from whom will you ever exact satisfaction?’

kai\ me\n dh\...a)ph/gagen ‘And moreover it was not in the house but in the street — when he might have saved him without breaking the decree of the Thirty — that he arrested him and took him to prison’: i.e. the commands of the Thirty (if such had been given to Eratosthenes) would have been satisfied by a domiciliary search: cp. § 8. He was not obliged to arrest Polemarchus when he met him in the street.

Baiter (see the critical note) keeps closer to the mss. by reading sw/|zonta au(to/n, ‘when trying to save himself’ (the active as in § 11): but the words kata\ ta\ tou/tois e)yhfisme/na must then be taken with sullabw/n, against the sense, since then they tend to excuse E. Sauppe, sw/|zein te au)to\n kai\ ta\ t. e)y. paro/n, i.e. au)to/n te kai/, ‘to save at once his life and the letter of the decree’. This is neat, but the double use of sw/|zein is unseasonably epigrammatic.

kai/toi...ei)=den ‘If, however, you are to make allowance for those who destroyed their neighbours to save themselves, those others’ [who were not members of the Oligarchy] ‘have a better claim to your indulgence’ [than Eratosthenes has]; ‘for they incurred peril if they failed to go when they were sent’ [to make an arrest], ‘or if, when they had found the person at home, they denied the fact. But E. might have said that he had not met with Polemarchus, or at all events that he had not seen him’: e)/peita — i.e. if it was urged that he had certainly met him.
tau=ta...ou)/t' e)/legxon ou)/te ba/sanon ei)=xen ‘these statements could not be disproved, or even tested’.
a)poqanei=sqai...a)poloume/nous On the element of false antithesis (oi( m. a)poq. and oi( a)pol. being the same), cp. note on Pro Mantitheo § 13 (p. 60).
tw=n to/te legome/nwn=e)kei/nwn a(\ to/te e)le/geto, — the discussion at the Board of the Thirty, in which E., as he alleges, had opposed the measures taken against Lysias and Polemarchus: §§ 25 f.

parei=nai — par) au(toi=s ei)=nai ‘Since, so far from being allowed to assist at their councils, we were not allowed even to remain in our own homes’ (chez nous: cp. apud se, Cic. De Or. I. § 214). — tou/tois=toi=s tria/konta, as represented by Eratosthenes.
pa/nta ta\ kaka/, k.t.l. Dobree would read pa/nta kaka/, as in § 57, pa/nta a)gaqa/. But cp. § 41, pa/nta ta\ kaka/. — pa/nta kaka/, all sorts of evils: pa/nta ta\ kaka/, all possible evils.
tou=to me/ntoi ou) feu/gw ‘I do not shrink, however, from meeting you on this point’: i.e. as I cannot prove that you did not protest, I am ready to assume that you did.

* e)poi/hsas So Dobree for poih/sais. The optative can be defended as an abstract hypothesis. But the mention of Polemarchus in the sentence certainly strengthens the presumption that Lysias said, ‘what would you have done?’ rather than, ‘what would you do?’

e)tu/xete...a)peyhfi/sasqe;] I should hesitate to write, with Kayser, e)tugxa/nete...a)peyhfi/zesqe; The imperf. (a)\n) a)peyhfi/zesqe;=‘would you have been disposed to acquit him?’ The aor. (a)\n) a)peyhfi/sasqe;=‘would you have acquitted him?’ — which is more forcible here, since it implies that his condemnation is already assured. And if a)peyhfi/sasqe is genuine, then e)tu/xete may well be so too, though e)tugxa/nete would be equally fitting.

kai\ me\n dh/ Cp. § 30. ‘And further’: i.e. apart from the intrinsic merits of the case, it will be taken as a precedent. a)stw=n simply ‘Athenians’: not tw=n e)c a)/steos opp. to oi( e)k *peiraiw=s (below § 92).

dustuxh/santes de\ to\ i)/son u(. e(/c.] ‘Or, if they fail, will be no worse off than the rest of you’; i.e. will retain their civic privileges, instead of being punished with a)timi/a or death. Cp. § 92, h(tthqe/ntes toi=s nikh/sasi to\ i)/son e)/xete.

e)kkhru/ttousin ‘banish by proclamation’: — referring, apparently, to some particular members of the late Oligarchy who had vainly sought refuge in other cities. The party of the Thirty still had their head-quarters at Eleusis: see introd., p. 249.
timwroume/nous The act. might seem more natural here, but the midd. need imply no more than that the chastiser's own sense of justice is satisfied: cp. below § 94, In Agor. § 76.

tou\s...strathgou/s The six generals who were put to death after the Athenian victory at Arginusae (406 B.C.) for having failed to pick up the floating bodies of the slain, or to save the men in the disabled ships, (both are included under tou\s e)k th=s qala/tths:) Grote, VIII. 238. Cp. Plat. Apol. p. 32 B, ou)k a)nelome/nous tou\s e)k th=s naumaxi/as.

oi(\ i)diw=tai me\n o)/ntes ‘who, while still private persons, did all that lay in their power to bring disaster on your fleet’ (at Aegospotami, 405 B.C.). ‘The general belief...held that the Athenian fleet had been sold to perdition by the treason of some of its own commanders’, Grote, VIII. 300. Lysias means that the oligarchical e(tairi/ai — worked by such men as soon
afterwards became Tyrants — had prepared this result. Cp. Xen. H. II. 1. 32, Isocr. Philipp. § 62.
a)poktinnu/nai imperf.=o(/ti a)pekti/nnusan.

ou)k a)/ra xrh/ The construction, as originally planned, was ou)k ou)=n deino
 ei) tou\s me
...e)zhmiw/sate,...tou/tois de\ mh\ kola/sete; where, however, ou) kola/sete would stand, as in Thuc. I. 121, deino
 a)
 ei)/h ei) oi( me
...ou)k a)perou=sin, h(mei=s de\...ou)k a)/ra dapanh/somen. (See note to p. 93 § 8, ou) ga dh/pou, k.t.l.) But here the insertion of xrh/ gives a new turn to the close: — ‘now ought they not to be punished?’ Cp. the insertion of h(gou/mhn in § 15, note, p. 252.

div3.head: 2. Peroration. — §§ 92 — 100 (end).
div3.p: This passage is translated in the Attic Orators, I. 189 — 192.

tou\s e)c a)/st. — tou\s e)k *p.] oi( e)c a)/steos, ‘the party of the Town’: those who were at Athens under the tyranny of the Thirty, and who were thus identified with the oligarchical side in the struggle between the Tyrants and the patriots. oi( e)k *peiraiw=s, the popular party: the exiles led by Thrasybulus, who came from Phylè to the Peiraeus in Dec. 404 B.C., and recovered Athens before the end of July, 403 B.C. Cp. above, p. 52, § 2: Dem. In Timocr. § 134, tw=n e)k *peiraiw=s kai\ a)po\ *fulh=s ou(=tos h)=n.

toiou=ton po/lemon ‘a war of such a sort that, having been vanquished, you are the equals of the conquerors’ (the patriotic party), ‘whereas, had you conquered, you would have been the slaves of the Tyrants’: i.e. they had been forced to fight against their own interests. tou/tois=toi=s tria/konta, as in § 33.

a)\n e)kth/santo ‘they would have gained wealth for their own houses from the administration’ (if they had prevailed in the struggle). There seems no reason for suspecting the genuineness of a)/n. If it were absent, the statement of fact would apply to the time before the struggle, when the Thirty were in power.
tw=n a)gaqw=n ‘their prizes’ (their power and ill-gotten wealth): tw=n o)neidw=n, ‘their dishonours’ — the outrages in which they compelled Athenian citizens to be their instruments: see § 30.

* eu)=noi w)/|onto ei)=nai ‘(Instead of seeking to win your loyalty by giving you partnership in their prizes), they fancied themselves friendly if they gave you a share of their dishonours’. I read eu)=noi, instead of eu)/nous, which the mss. give, for the following reasons. (1) eu)/nous can be taken only as accus. plur. We find, indeed, a statement that the comic poet Philemon
used eu)/nous for eu)=noi, as if by crasis from eu)/noes (Philem. fr. 122, Meineke): but such a notice is not sufficient warrant for assuming so strange a license in Lysias. (2) eu)/nous being, then, accus. plur., the words would mean, ‘thought that you were friendly’. But the sense wanted is, ‘thought that you ought to be much obliged to them’. This sense would be obtained if we adopted Dobree's suggestion, and read eu)/nous w)/|onto <dei=n> ei)=nai. (3) But it appears more probable that an original eu)=noi should have been altered to eu)/nous, for the sake of symmetry with pistou\s in the preceding clause, than that dei=n should have been omitted.
toi=s polemi/ois The party of the Thirty at Eleusis: cp. § 80, a)pou=si toi=s tria/konta e)pibouleu/ete.

tw=n e)pikou/rwn ‘the foreign troops’: the Lacedaemonian garrison of 700, under Callibius, which supported the Tyranny: Xen. Hellen. II. 3. 13 f. e)pi/kouroi=ce/noi, misqofo/roi, here used invidiously, because the Athenian oligarchs promised to maintain the Spartan frouroi/: Xen. l.c. qre/yein de\ au)toi\ u(pisxnou=nto.
tosau=ta ‘only thus much’: Thuc. II. 72.

a)fh|re/qhte ta\ o(/pla The Thirty formed a picked body of 3000 hoplites, and then proclaimed a general muster of all the hoplites in Athens. When this was over, the 3000 seized the arms which the other hoplites had piled in various places, and deposited them in the Acropolis; Xen. H. II. 3. 20, 41: Grote VIII. 336.
e)cekhru/xqhte The Thirty proclaimed that every one not included in the list of 3000 should quit Athens: Grote VIII. 349.

e)k tw=n po/lewn ‘The Laced. government, at the instance of the Thirty, issued an edict prohibiting all the members of their confederacy from harbouring fugitive Athenians’: ib. 350. The emigrants were received, however, in Megara, Thebes, Orôpus, Chalcis, Argos.

to\n qa/naton ‘death’, not ‘the death which threatened them’: the art. giving merely a certain rhetorical emphasis, ‘the doom of death’. So h( ei)rh/nh peace, o( po/lemos war, o( dh=mos democracy: see Shilleto, Dem. Fals. Legat. §§ 100, 149.

die/fugon...h)/lqete The thought of the slain being uppermost in his mind at the beginning of the sentence causes him to use the third pers. pl. in reference also to the survivors, though these are the same whom he presently addresses in h)/lqete.
e)n polemi/a| th=| patr. k.t.l. ‘in that fatherland which had become hostile soil, or in the land of strangers’.
tou\s me\n h)leuq ‘you freed some’ [viz. tou\s e)c a)/steos, the unwilling subjects of the Thirty], ‘you restored others to their country’ [viz. tou\s e)k *peiraiw=s, the patriotic exiles].
a)/n...e)feu/gete ‘would now be exiles’.

mikrw=n...e(/neka s.] ‘would now be in slavery on account of petty liabilities’, i.e. small debts which their poverty made them unable to discharge, thus giving the creditor a claim upon their persons. Isocr. Plataicus § 48, tou\s pai=das (the children of the destitute Plataeans)...pollou\s me\n mikrw=n e(/neka sumbolai/wn douleu/ontas, a)/llous d' e)pi\ qhtei/an i)o/ntas, — where to\ douleu/ein, slavery, is opp. to qhtei/a, labour for wages.
th=s e)mh=s proq lit. ‘nothing is wanting to my zeal’, i.e. ‘my indignation is perfect’. ou)de/n was supplied by Canter.

a)pe/donto ‘bartered away’: meaning, perh., that the Thirty allowed sacred buildings to be sold and put to secular uses. Others understand, ‘sold the sacred vessels and furniture’ of the temples: as if ta\ i(era/, a general term, had different meanings with a)pe/donto and e)mi/ainon.
ei)sio/ntes e)mi/ainon ‘defiled by entering them’ — since the Tyrants were e)nagei=s, guilty of blood.
ei)/sesqai th\n yh=fon f ‘will be aware of you when you give your verdict’.

* kateyhfi/sqai ‘have [by that very act] passed sentence’. This is Baiter's simple correction of the corrupt katayhfiei=sqai. It is more probable than kateyhfisme/nous e)/sesqai, ‘will have passed’ (Rauchenstein). — pepoihme/nous, sc. ei)=nai, as if kateyhfisme/nous ei)=nai had preceded.

a)khko/ate, k.t.l. Inexactly cited by Arist. Rhet. III. 19. 6, teleuth\ de\ th=s le/cews a(rmo/ttei h( a)su/ndetos, o(/pws e)pi/logos a)lla\ mh\ lo/gos h)=|, (enumeratio and not altera oratio, Quint. VI. 1. 2,) ei)/rhka, a)khko/ate, e)/xete, kri/nete.

div2.p: . [Or. XIII.] — Agoratus, son of a slave, had gained the Athenian citizenship by pretending (falsely, his accuser says) to have had a hand in the assassination of Phrynichus in 411 B.C. (§ 76.) For six years afterwards he had lived at Athens, exercising the trade of an informer, and laying ‘all conceivable indictments’ (ta\s e)c a)nqrw/pwn grafa/s, § 73) before the law-courts. He is now charged with having slandered away the lives of several distinguished citizens just before the establishment of the Thirty.

It was in the spring of 404 B.C. that Theramenes came back from Sparta with the hard conditions of peace. Athens had been suffering for months the extreme of famine and misery;
the mass of citizens were thankful for relief on any terms. But there were still a few men, influential by their position and services, who stood out against the bargain which the oligarchical party were about to strike with Sparta. The oligarchs, impatient to get rid of their opponents, had recourse to the aid of Agoratus. It was arranged that he should himself be charged with plotting to defeat the peace, and should then denounce a certain number of other persons as his accomplices. One Theocritus accused him before the Senate. A party of Senators went to the Peiraeus to arrest him. Agoratus, feigning alarm, took sanctuary at the altar in the temple of Artemis at Munychia. Certain citizens who suspected him to be the victim, or the agent, of a plot, gave bail for him, and offered to take him out of Attica to await quieter times. He declined this proposal, and appeared before the Senate to give information. He denounced, first, the men who had bailed him; then several of the Generals and taxiarchs (§ 13), among whom were the General Strombichides, Dionysodorus (kinsman of the accuser in this case), and probably Eucrates the brother of Nicias; also a number of other citizens. These, with Agoratus himself, were imprisoned; and it was decreed that they should be tried both by the Senate and by a special court of Two Thousand. Immediately afterwards the peace with Sparta was ratified.

The government of the Thirty having been established, the prisoners were tried; but not by the Two Thousand; only by a new oligarchical Senate. They were all condemned to death, except Agoratus, who was banished. In 404 B.C. he joined the democratic exiles at Phylè, and afterwards returned to Athens with them; but appears to have been ill received (§ 77). He is now accused of murder by Dionysius, cousin and brother-in-law to Dionysodorus.

The procedure was by e)/ndeicis (information) laid before the archon, followed by a)pagwgh/ (summary arrest) — just as in the case of Herodes (see introd. to Antiph. De Caed. Her., p. 208). — Date about 399 B.C. — Attic Orators, I. 269 f.

div3.head: Narrative: §§ 5 — 48.
div3.p: ou) poll. xr. u(/st.] The capture of 170 Athenian triremes by the Peloponnesians under Lysander at Aegospotami took place about Sept. 405 B.C. (Grote VIII. 297): Lysander next took measures to secure Byzantium, Chalcedon, Lesbos, etc., establishing ‘dekarchies’: and it was about Nov. 405 B.C. when he arrived with his fleet of 200 triremes in the Saronic Gulf (ib. 307).

lo/goi...peri\ th=s ei)rh/nhs The Athenians ‘proposed to Agis to become allies of Sparta, retaining their walls entire and their
fortified harbour of Peiraeus’: Grote VIII. 308. Agis referred the envoys to the Ephori, who would not even receive them: Xen. H. II. 2. 11 — 15. — th=s ei)rh/nhs, ‘peace’, not ‘the peace’: see In Eratosth. § 97, to\n qa/naton, note, p. 258.

ei)lhfe/nai kai\ ma/list' <a)\n> ... katasth/sasqai ‘thinking that they had found an excellent opportunity, and that this was the moment at which they were most likely to constitute the government in accordance with their own views’. It seems better thus to add a)/n than to alter the aor. inf. into katasth/sesqai. One of the two remedies is required. For we cannot render — ‘that they had found an...opportunity to constitute the gov. as much as possible (kai\ ma/lista)’ etc...as if katast. depended on ei)lhf. kairo/n. And here nomi/zontes katasth/sasqai could mean nothing but ‘thinking that they had constituted’. Cp. Olympiacus § 2 (p. 50), note on <a)\n> gene/sqai.

taciarxou=ntas The commanders of the tribal infantry (taci/arxoi) would have democratic sympathies, while the i(ppei=s, with their tribal commanders (fu/larxoi), would, as the wealthier class, be the natural allies of oligarchy. Cp. Arist. Pol. VI [IV] 3. § 3, o(/sais po/lesin e)n toi=s i(/ppois h( du/namis h)=n, o)ligarxi/ai para\ tou/tois h)=san: and ib. 13. § 10.

a(mwsge/pws ‘by some means or other’. Lys. or. XXIV. De Inval. § 20, a(/pantes ga\r ei)/qisqe prosfoita=n kai\ diatri/bein a(mou= ge/ pou. Cp. a(mo/qen. On the stem a(mo — perh. akin to that of ei(=s — see Curt. Gr. Etym. 600.
bou/lointo might represent either a(\ bou/lontai or a(\ a)\n bou/lwntai: here it represents the latter.

*kleofw=nti] o( luropoio/s, — the demagogue who led the popular party at this time: Lys. or. XIX. § 48, *kleofw=nta de\ pa/ntes i)/ste o(/ti polla\ e)/th diexei/rise ta\ th=s po/lews pa/nta kai\ prosedoka=to pa/mpolla e)k th=s a)rxh=s e)/xein (and yet died poor).
e)pi\ de/ka sta/dia i.e. to the length of about a mile and a quarter.
oi(=o/n te ei)/h oblique of e)sti/ (not of h)=n). Acc. to Aeschin. Fals. Legat. § 76, Cleophon threatened ‘to cut off the head of anyone who mentioned peace’.

le/gei o(/ti...eu(rh/sesqai ‘He says that, if they appoint him envoy with plenary powers to treat for peace, he will effect a peace (poih/sein, sc. ei)rh/nhn) on such terms (w(/ste) that no breach shall be made in the walls, and that Athens shall suffer no detriment whatever: and “I think”, he added, “that I shall even obtain some further advantage for the city from the Lacedaemonians”.’ poiei=n ei)rh/nhn, Xen. Cyr. III. 2. 12. —
poih/sein w(/ste might (less well) be taken as=‘to effect that’ no breach shall be made: cp. Isocr. Adv. Soph. § 1, pepoih/kasin w(/ste dokei=n, k.t.l. For poih/sein instead of poih/sei (or -oi) after o(/ti, cp. Xen. Cyr. II. 4. 15, a)kou/w o(/ti...gene/sqai (for e)ge/nonto). — oi)/oito depending on o(/ti: he said oi)/omai: cp. Soph. Phil. 617. — The subject to dielei=n, e)lattw=sai is not tou\s *laked. understood, but au)to/n, Theramenes.

tw=| prote/rw| e)/tei In 405 B.C. — prob. on the occasion when three new strathgoi/ were appointed (Xen. H. II. 1. 16). The people were doubtless disgusted with his conduct the year before, when he had been active in procuring the judicial murder of the Generals after Arginusae. Thirlwall thinks that in that affair Theramenes was the agent of an oligarchical plot (IV. 138).

e)lqw\n ei)s *lak. — polu\n xro/non Theramenes went first to Lysander, who was now blockading the Peiraeus [Xen. H. II. 2. 9], and remained with him ‘three months or more’, on the pretext that L. detained him. In the fourth month, at his own request, he was sent to Lacedaemon as a plenipotentiary, with nine colleagues: Xen. H. II. 2. 16 f. Lysias omits the visit to Lysander, and represents the long sojourn of Ther. as made at Sparta (e)kei=).

diaqei/h...a)po/rws ‘reduce you to destitution’, — by the pressure of famine, which was already severe when he left Athens (w)/|onto...pollou\s tw=| limw=| a)polei=sqai, Xen. H. II. 2. 14). — a)po/rws is not indispensable, but neither is it, I think, a gloss.

ou)k h)=lqen ei)s ta\ o(/pla a)nap ‘because he did not come to pass the night at his post’: cp. Xen. H. II. 4. 24, e)ceka/qeudon de\ kai\ oi( i(ppei=s e)n tw=| *)widei/w|. So in the panic of 415 B.C. the hoplites were ordered to muster under arms in the agora (and bivouac there), Andoc. De Myst. § 45 (p. 35), note. For ta\ o(/pla as=‘the place where the arms are piled’, ‘the camp’, cp. Xen. Anab. III. 1 § 3, e)pi\ de\ ta\ o(/pla polloi\ ou)k h)=lqon tau/thn th\n nu/kta, a)nepau/onto de\ o(/pou e)tu/gxanen e(/kastos.

e)kei/nw|...tau/th| ‘So, having contrived the appointment of a court to try him, and having taken seats in it themselves, the promoters of the oligarchy put Cleophon to death by means of this pretext’. Acc. to Lysias or. XXX. §§ 10 f., the boulh/, with the corrupt connivance of Nicomachus (then a nomoqe/ths), claimed a legal right to sit in judgment along with the dikasts — w(s xrh\ th\n boulh\n sundika/zein. Cleophon had already denounced the boulh/, — fa/skwn sunesta/nai (was in a conspiracy against the Democracy), ib.

e)n th=| profa/sei t.] Baiter and Cobet conj. e)pi/. But e)n=‘by means of’, cp. Lys. or. VII. § 20 (below, p. 91) e)n tou/tw| tw=|
tro/pw|: e)n do/lw| a)/gein (Soph. Phil. 102), e)n litai=s ste/llein (ib. 60), e)n lo/gois pei/qein (ib. 1394).

toiau/thn, h(/n...e)/gnwmen ‘a peace of that character which stern experience taught us to know’: e)/gn., came to know: h(/n=oi(/an, as oft. after toiou=tos. Cp. Shaksp. All's W. III. 6. 24, ‘Such will I have whom I am sure he knows not’.
e)chla/qhmen Cp. In Eratosth. § 95, e)cekhru/xqhte e)k th=s po/lews (p. 76), note.
h)=n...kataska/yai ‘For its terms were that...we should destroy’. The subj. to h)=n is ei)rh/nh, which, as=su/mbasis or o(mologi/a, takes the infin.

legome/nhn, k.t.l. ‘These men [Strombichides and the democratic party, § 13] seeing that, though the talk was of peace, the work really in hand was the overthrow of the Democracy, said that they could not allow such terms to be ratified’. — o)no/m. legom. ei)r., lit. ‘that (the arrangement) was nominally called peace’. The conjecture genome/nhn is unsuitable, since peace had not been concluded: we should require gignome/nhn. — ou)k <a)\n> e)/fasan e)pitre/yai. Cp. note on § 6 above, ma/list' <a)\n>...katasth/sasqai.

ou)k e)leou=ntes...poih/s.] ‘Not because their pity was moved by the threatened destruction of the walls, — not because they shrank from the thought of our fleet being surrendered to Sparta — for these things did not touch them more nearly than they touched every one of yourselves — but because they perceived that this was the way to ruin your Commonwealth: they were not, as some allege, reluctant that peace should be made, but they desired to obtain for the Athenian people a peace on better terms than these’. — Lysias has to show two things: (1) that the democrats were right in objecting to this peace; (2) that they sincerely desired a peace, and were not pursuing a party war-policy in selfish disregard of the extreme sufferings endured by their fellow-citizens. They would have made sacrifices, he says, however painful, if these sacrifices had not further involved the destruction of the Commonwealth.
ei(/lonto ‘mira locutio: an proei/lonto?’ Dobree: but ei(/l.=‘elected’ as the least of two evils. Isocr. Philipp. § 93, ei(lo/mhn mh\ ponei=n.

th\n e)kkl. th\n peri\ th=s ei)r.] The meeting of the Ecclesia at which the peace was accepted took place, acc. to Xen. H. II. 2. 22, on the day after the return of Theramenes with the terms offered by Sparta. In the Attic Orators, I. 270 note, I have given reasons for dissenting from Grote's view that Agoratus laid his information after the capitulation of Athens,
and for believing that the account of Lysias is correct in this particular.
ou) cuneido/ta e)kei/nois ‘though he was in none of their secrets’. — e)kei/nois, the Generals and the democratic party: au)toi=s below, the oligarchic conspirators.

o(/pws p. u(mi=n u(pofai/noito Dobree would read fai/noito, thinking that u(po/ has arisen from u(mi=n: but u(pof. expresses what is hinted by the look of that about which we cannot be sure. ‘In order that the affair might have a more plausible colour in your eyes’. — kai\ u(ma=s: ‘you, too’ will see (as clearly as the speaker himself).

* ei)spe/mpousi Dobree's correction of e)kpe/mpousi. The verb ei)spe/mpw is often used of suborned agents. Cp. Andoc. De Red. § 4, e(te/rous d' ei)spe/mpousi: Isocr. De Bigis § 7, mhnuta\s ei)se/pempon. On the other hand, e)kpe/mpousi could mean only, ‘send forth (from their secret councils)’, — a use of the word which seems rather forced (at least for prose) without further definition of the place to which e)k refers.
[th\n pro\ tw=n tria/k. b.] plainly a gloss which has crept in from § 20 ad init.
*q. to\n tou= *)e. kalou/menon The nickname *)elafo/stiktos (‘dappled like a deer’) may have been that of a slave or freedman, — a branded stigmati/as. Perh. kaloume/nou.

*e)ge/neto Markland's correction of e)le/geto. I formerly preferred e)le/geto, on the ground that it shows the yhfi/smata in the making, and is thus more vivid. But there seems to be no warrant for such a phrase as le/gw yh/fisma in the sense of gra/fw yh/fisma, to ‘propose’ a decree. Rather reluctantly, then, I have acquiesced in the emendation, — which, from the palaeographical point of view, is an easy one.

kai\ w(s toiou/t. ou)=sin au)t. to\n nou=n prose/xhte ‘and that (i(/na), knowing them to be such, (w(s toi. ou)=s.,) you may carefully note their conduct’: i.e. this knowledge will throw light on the facts which I have to relate. Bekker with one ms. mh\ prose/xhte, ‘may disregard them’, and so Reiske conj. h(=sson: but this destroys the point.

e)n a)porrh/tw| Cp. Andoc. De Myst. § 45 (p. 35), h( de\ boulh\ e)celqou=sa e)n a)porrh/tw|. Strangers (i)diw=tai) were often present at the sittings of the boulh/, Dem. F. L. § 18, to\ ga\r bouleuth/rion mesto\n h)=n i)diwtw=n: to move that they withdraw, was metasth/sasqai tou\s i)diw/tas, Aeschin. In Ctes. § 125.
toi=s to/te kaqist. pra/gmasi ‘The government which was then in process of being established’,=a(\ to/te kaqi/stato — the Oligarchy. — e)kei/nois, the democratic opposition.
nuni\ de\...e)yhf.] ‘but, as it was, the Council passed the following decree’ — merely for the arrest of Agoratus, instead of compelling Theocr. to give a complete list of names.
