e)n a)gora=| The *(ippodamei/a a)gora/ in the Peiraeus, Andoc. De Myst. § 45 (p. 35).
*niki/as...*nikome/nhs supporters of the democratic party, mentioned only here.

ou)x oi(=a be/ltista ‘seeing that the state of affairs in Athens was not all that could be desired’,=ou) toiau=ta oi(=a a)\n o)/nta be/ltista ei)/h. Dem. De Cor. § 207, w(s ou) ta\ be/ltista e)mou= politeusame/nou.

proh/sesqai, k.t.l. ‘said that they could not allow A. to be taken away, — vindicated him from arrest (a)fh|rou=nto), — and offered bail, binding themselves to produce him before the Council’. a)fairei=sqai ei)s e)leuqeri/an=vindicare in libertatem: but A. was not a slave, and here a)fh|r. merely=‘asserted his right to be at large’ against oi( a)/gontes. Cobet was not right in altering pare/cein into para/cein: the surety ‘produces’ (pare/xei) the bailee, the accuser ‘brings’ the accused ‘into court’ (para/gei). Cp. Lys. or. XXIII. § 9 (p. 99), e)gguhsa/menoi pare/cein ei)s a)gora\n (to\n a)/nqrwpon).
to\n bwmo\n *moun The altar in the temple of Artemis: *mounuxi/as nao\s *)arte/midos, Paus. I. 1. 4.

parorm. du/o ploi=a *moun.] ‘having brought two boats alongside the shore at Munychia’. The blockade of the Peiraeus need not have hindered this (Xen. H. II. 2. 9, the Pelop. fleet ta\ ploi=a ei)=rge tou= ei)/splou): see Attic Orators, I. 271, note.
e(/ws ta\ pr. katast.] ‘until quieter times’: i.e. until the terms of peace should have been fixed, and the strife of parties in Athens allayed.

a)lla\ me\n dh/, k.t.l. ‘But this is not all — your situation was very different from theirs’: i.e. much more perilous, if you stayed: if they were ready to go, much more would you have been so, had you not had a secret understanding with the government.
basanisqh=nai Citizens were protected from torture by to\ e)pi\ *skamandri/ou yh/fisma, Andoc. De Myst. § 43, p. 35.

ou) patri/da, k.t.l. ‘you would not have forsaken your land’: Agoratus, acc. to Lys., being of foreign and servile origin. The v. l. a)pe/lipes=‘quitted’: kate/l. (cp. katalipo/ntes above) ‘left behind’.
prospoih=| sc. a)poktei=nai, as below § 75, ei) me\n ou)=n mh\ a)poktei/nas prospoiei=tai (a)poktei=nai).
pareskeua/sqh ‘contrived’ (between Agor. and the boulh/): so paraskeua/santes, § 12.
to\ yh/fisma The object of the new yh/fisma, as §§ 29, 30 show, was to authorise the arrest of Agoratus, notwithstanding that e)gguhtai/ had been found for him: § 24.

e)komi/sqhsan ‘were brought’ (not merely ‘came’). The plural verb would most naturally refer to Agoratus and the persons who, by giving bail for him, had frustrated the first attempt to arrest him. They were probably still with him at Munychia (cp. § 24) when he was arrested by the second mission from the Council, armed with the second decree (§§ 28, 29) — which apparently authorised an immediate arrest, irrespective of bail having been given. The plural e)komi/sqhsan may, however, also refer to the fact that, besides Agoratus, two other persons denounced by Theocritus were brought before the Council at the same time, as we learn from a later part of the speech (§ 54), where the phrase is, u(po\ th=s boulh=s metepe/mfqhsan.

h( de\ a)rxh\ au(/th The more usual form would be a)rxh\ d' au(/th. Cp. note on Antiph. De Caed. Herod. § 93 (p. 23), th\n timwri/an oi( h(/kein tau/thn, ‘that this has come on her as the punishment’.
e)p' au)tofw/rw| ‘I will convict him in the very act’, — i.e. I will show precisely how and when he did it.

e)/rrwto...ou)/shs ‘So vigorously was the Council bent on mischief’: Thuc. II. 8, e)/rrwnto e)s to\n po/lemon. At first the Council had accepted the a)nw/numos mh/nusis of Theocritus (§ 22): then Agor. had given certain names (§ 30): and, after that, the Council still pressed for more: this fact was elicited by the e)rw/thsis (§ 31, toi/nun). — e(kw/n, since he had not yet been threatened with torture (cp. § 27), a)na/gkh.

*moun. e)n tw=| qea/trw| Thuc. VIII. 93, e)s to\ pro\s th=| *mounuxi/a| *dionusiako\n qe/atron e)lqo/ntes kai\ qe/menoi ta\ o(/pla e)ceklhsi/asan (411 B.C.). The theatre was at the N.W. side of the Munychian hill. — e)gi/gneto, ‘came to be held’.

ou(/tw sfo/dra ‘Some persons were so anxious that the information regarding the Generals and the Infantry Commanders should be laid before the people as well, (in regard to the others, the information laid before the Council sufficed,) that they bring Agoratus before the people in the Ecclesia also’ (kai\ e)kei=). kai\ e)kei=...ei)s to\n d., i.e. ‘there also’, and this time before the people. — a)pe/xrh, k.t.l. Dobree is right in
condemning mh/nusis as a scholion, but e)n th=| boulh=| is prob. genuine: it makes the contrast with e)n tw=| d. clearer. Cp. § 33.
a)nagnw/setai sc. o( grammateu/s.
kai\ ta\ e)n th=| b., k.t.l. sc. a)pografe/nta: ‘both those names which were given before the Council and those which were given before the Ecclesia’.

ei)se/pleuse Xen. H. II. 2. 23, e)/doce de/xesqai th
 ei)rh/nhn. meta\ de\ tau=ta *lu/sandro/s te kate/plei ei)s to
 *peiraia= [hitherto he had been at anchor off the Peiraeus, pro\s to
 *p., § 9], kai\ oi( fuga/des kath/|esan, kai\ ta\ tei/xh kate/skapton u(p' au)lhtri/dwn pollh=| proqumi/a|, nomi/zontes e)kei/nhn th
 h(me/ran th=| *(ella/di a)/rxein th=s e)leuqeri/as.

katesta/qhsan ‘were installed in office’. The 1st aor. pass. seems here to differ from the 2nd aor. act. kate/sthsan in § 34 (‘were established’) by suggesting the formal induction into office. On the other hand, in Antiphon De Chor. § 11 (p. 25), xorhgo\s katesta/qhn seems to be no more than kate/sthn. The pass. aor. is mainly poetical.
kri/sin...e)poi/oun ‘proceeded to direct that these men should be tried before the Council’: but kri/sin e)poiou=nto would be merely e)/krinon, ‘proceeded to try them’.
o( de\ dh=mos ‘whereas the words of the people's decree had been, “before the (ordinary) court, with a jury of 2000”.’

ei)...e)kri/nonto ‘If they had been on their trial before the ordinary court, they would have been in a fair way to be acquitted’: the imperf. referring here to a continued action in past time, whereas e)kri/qhsan...e)sw/qhsan would have meant simply, ‘If they had been tried, they would have been acquitted’. Cp. Goodwin § 49. 2.
e)n w(=| referring to h)/dh: ‘for now, when you could no longer do any good, you had recognised the desperate situation of Athens’. — nu=n d', ‘but as it was’, with historic pres., as in § 22.

e)pi\ tw=n ba/qrwn ‘The Thirty sat on the seats usually occupied by the Presidents of the Assembly’ (50 in number). Cp. Plat. Prot. 315 c, where Hippias the sophist is seen e)n qro/nw|, surrounded by his hearers e)pi\ ba/qrwn.

kadi/skous ‘urns’ for the secret ballot, — the yh=foi being dropped through a funnel-shaped top (khmo/s). Lycurg. In Leocr. § 149, duoi=n kadi/skoin keime/noin, to
 me
 prodosi/as to
 de\ swthri/as ei)=nai.

ou)deno\s a)peyhfi/santo The Thirty afterwards as sumed the right of putting to death without trial any one who
was not in the list (kata/logos) of 3000. Isocrates speaks of them as having executed ‘1500 citizens without trial’ (a)kri/tous: or. XX. § 11). Cp. Xen. H. II. 3. 51: Grote VIII. 327.

me/lan [te] Baiter and Sauppe would omit te: and I incline to think that it may have been a spurious addition, designed to link the participles. If we retain it, we must suppose a partic. (e.g., o)durome/nh, a)pokeirame/nh, kekarme/nh) lost before or after h)mfiesme/nh.
die/qeto not dieti/qeto (though e)/legen, etc.), because the testamentary disposition — dia/qesis, the making of a diaqh/kh — is an act completed at a definite moment.
timwrei=n timwrei=sqai could stand: cp. In Eratosth. § 35, u(pe\r u(mw=n timwroume/nous (p. 74): but the active marks more clearly that the cause in which the punishment is dealt is another's.

tou\s e)k *sal. — e)c *)eleus Cp. In Eratosth. § 52, e)lqw\n (Eratosthenes) meta\ tw=n sunarxo/ntwn ei)s *salami=na kai\ *)eleusi=na/de triakosi/ous tw=n politw=n a)ph/gagen ei)s to\ desmwth/rion, kai\ mia=|: yh/fw| au)tw=n a(pa/ntwn qa/naton kateyhfi/sato. — tou\s e)nqade, at Athens. From § 30 of the speech against Eratosthenes (above, p. 72) we may infer how frequently such i)/diai e)/xqrai were thus indulged. In Lys. or. XXV. § 15 a speaker claims credit for not having gratified his enmities during the Oligarchy.
e)/ti de\ ta\ tei/xh w(s kateska/fh sc. i)/ste, to be supplied from § 44.
ou)k <a)\n> e)/fasan e)pitre/yai See note above on § 15.

a)pe/kteinas, k.t.l. The words th=| po/lei occur thrice in the sentence. Before e)pibouleu/ein they are clearly, as Dobree saw, an interpolation, either from the previous or from the subsequent clause. ‘You put them to death, by denouncing them as plotters against the Commonwealth’. There is no incongruity in this, since the oligarchical *boulh/ claimed to represent the Commonwealth, and would affect the language of patriotic citizens. — Dobree, with great plausibility, proposed to read, a)pe/kteinas mhnu/sas, au)to\s e)pibouleu/wn tw=| plh/qei tw=| u(mete/rw|.

div2.p:
. [Or. VII.] — ‘On the Sacred Olive’. The man for whom this defence was written — a rich Athenian citizen (§§ 21, 31) — had originally been charged with destroying a moria, or sacred olive, on a farm which belonged to him. As to do this was a fraud upon the Treasury, the
form of the original accusation had been an apographè (a)pegra/fhn, § 2). But the charge was not supported by the persons who had rented from the State the produce of the moriae on this farm (oi( e)wnhme/noi tou\s karpou\s tw=n moriw=n, § 2). The accusers had therefore changed their ground. They now charge the defendant merely with uprooting the fenced-in stump (shko/s) of a moria; and they lay against him an indictment for impiety. The chief accuser is one Nicomachus.

Throughout Attica, besides the olives which were private property (i)/diai e)lai=ai, § 10), there were others which, whether growing on public or on private lands, were considered as the property of the State. These were called moriae (mori/ai) — the legend being that they had been propagated (memorhme/nai) from the original olive which Athene herself had caused to spring up on the Acropolis. This theory was convenient for their conservation as State property, since, by giving them a sacred character, it placed them directly under the care of the Areiopagus, which caused them to be visited once a month by Inspectors (e)pimelhtai/, § 29), and once a year by special Commissioners (gnw/mones, § 25). To uproot a moria was an offence punishable by banishment and confiscation of goods (§ 41).

The case is tried by the Areiopagus under the presidency of the Archon Basileus. The offence was alleged to have been committed in the archonship of Suniades (§ 11), Ol. 95. 4, 397 B.C. To judge from § 42 (tosou/tw| xro/nw| u(/steron) the trial took place not earlier than 395 B.C.; probably later. — Attic Orators, I. 289.

div3.p: e)/ti toi/nun The speaker has been arguing that he could not have destroyed the olive without the knowledge of his slaves. He now adds that the deed would have been liable to detection by (1) former tenants of the farm, § 17: (2) passers-by, (3) neighbours, § 18.

ei) pare/sth moi ‘if it had occurred to me’: i.e. ‘if I had been so ill-advised’ as to pay no heed to my slaves. Cp. the trans. 1st aor. Paus. IX. 14. 6, tou=to *)epameinw/nda| pare/sthsen... a)pagagei=n, ‘this suggested to E. that he should lead them back’.

tosou/twn mem ‘when so many persons had rented the farm’; the speaker having let it to four different tenants in succession, before he took it into his own hands (§§ 9, 10). misqou=n of landlord, misqou=sqai of tenant: § 10, *)alki/a|... e)mi/sqwsa,...ka)=|ta...*prwte/as e)misqw/sato. — suneido/twn: ‘in the secret’ (that a moria had existed on the land).

proqesmi/as ‘when there was no statutable limit to my
liability’: i.e. a grafh/ might be laid at any length of time after the alleged offence. In some cases (e.g. the grafh\ parano/mwn) the proqesmi/a was a year.

toi=s ei)rgasme/nois ‘while it was the common interest [prosh=kon, acc. absol.] of all who had worked the farm that the olive should be safe, so that, if any of them were inculpated, they could have laid the blame on him to whom they gave up the land’: (i.e. each would shift the blame on to his own immediate successor: hence o(/tw|, not w(=|.) For prosh=kon in this sense, cp. In Agor. § 15, p. 80, ou)de\n au)toi=s tou/twn plei=on h)\ u(mw=n e(ka/stw| prosh=ken.

ei)=nai sw=|on to\n shko/n i.e., it would be the interest of each man who had rented the farm to prove that, at the time when he gave it up, the olive was still safe. Tenant A would be prepared to show that he had transmitted the olive to B, B to C, and so on. A series of vigilant witnesses would thus fix the responsibility on the latest tenant, — the speaker.

i(/na...ei)=xon the secondary tenses of the indic. in final clauses with i(/na (or w(s, o(/pws) ‘denote that the end or object is dependent upon some unfulfilled condition, and therefore is not or was not attained’: Goodwin § 44. 3. — a)nenegkei=n o(/tw|=tou/tw| o(/tw|: cp. In Eratosth. § 81, kathgo/rhtai dh\ *)eratosqe/nous kai\ tou/tou fi/lwn, oi(=s ta\s a)pologi/as a)noi/sei, i.e. ‘on whose shoulders he will lay the blame of his acts’: but in § 64, ta\s a)pologi/as ei)s e)kei=non a)naferome/nas.

pareskeuasa/mhn ‘Now, supposing that I had arranged matters in these quarters also’ [as well as with my oi)ke/tai], i.e. had bribed the former tenants of the farm to be silent: so In Agor. § 12 (p. 79), dikasth/rion paraskeua/santes: ib. § 22 (p. 82) e)k paraskeuh=s. — pei=sai=to bribe, as § 21.

a)llh/lwn, k.t.l. ‘know not only such of each other's concerns as are plain for all to see’: a)ll. with tau=ta, a constr. like sou= tou=to qauma/zw: cp. Lys. or. XXXIV. § 2 (above, p. 52). — kai\ peri\ e)k. punqa/n., ‘inform themselves about these also’.
dia/foroi peri\ tw=n e)mw=n ‘at feud with me about my own’: tw=n e)mw=n emphatic, things which are really mine, but which they claim as theirs: alluding to boundary disputes or the like.

kai\ mh\ mo/non ou(/tw ‘instead of making audacious charges in this off-hand way (ou(/tw) on his bare word (mo/non)’: cp. Plat. Gorg. 494 E, o(\s a)\n fh=| a)ne/dhn ou(/tw (in this reckless fashion) tou\s xai/rontas, o(/pws a)\n xai/rwsin, eu)dai/monas ei)=nai.

ta\ pre/mna ‘that my servants cut the olive-stump out by
the roots, and the waggoner carted the wood and drove off with it’. pre/mna=to\ ste/lexos, the roots or stump of the mori/a: in § 11 we have even shko\n e)kkeko/fqai, — shko/s, properly the fence round the stump of a sacred olive, coming to mean the fence with the stump.
kai/toi...to/te ‘Now it was your further (kai/) duty at the time (to/te, when the alleged act was happening) to call the passers-by as witnesses, and to make the fact known’.
e)n tou/tw| t. tr.] Cp. In Agor. § 12 (p. 79), e)n th=| profa/sei tau/th|.

ou(/tws e)cele/gcas ‘after thus proving your case, you could not longer have been suspected of calumny’: — ou)k a)
 e)do/keis, you would not have continued to seem: implying w(/sper e)do/keis. The words might mean, ‘you would not now seem’, implying w(/sper dokei=s: but the context (a)
 u(pe/lipes, a)
 e)/labes) shows that the imperf. refers to the past.

*fh/sas m' i)dei=n ‘if, when you alleged that you had seen me destroying the sacred olive, you had invoked the presence of the Archons, or other representatives of the Areiopagus’. fh/sas (Xen. Cyr. IV. 1. 22) a rare form, Reiske's emend. of fh\|s mh\ dei=n. The conject. fh/nas m' i)dw/n=‘having informed against me [by a fa/sis laid before the magistrates] as having been seen by you’. — e)ph/gages: referring to the procedure called e)fh/ghsis, which consisted in bringing the proper officer to the spot where the criminal was to be arrested: here that officer would be the a)/rxwn basileu/s, or one of the e)pimelhtai/ (§§ 25, 29) charged by the Areiopagus with the care of the sacred olives.

deino/tata ou)=n pa/sxw, o(\s...a)\n h)ci/ou ‘My case, then, is a very hard one, seeing that he would have claimed’, etc. The antecedent to o(/s, if expressed, would have been u(po\ tou/tou, ‘at his hands’, after pa/sxw. As the antecedent is not expressed, the relative o(/s is virtually equivalent to e)peidh\ ou(=tos. For this causal use of the relative, cp. my note on Soph. O. C. 263. — The conjecture o(/sw| (to replace o(/s) is neither needful nor tenable. When o(/sw|=‘inasmuch’, it always stands with a double comparative or a double superlative (e.g. ma/lista ploutou=sin, o(/sw| kai\ plei=sta ponou=sin).

e)moi\ kai\ tau/thn ‘he thinks that this, too, [the fact of his having no witnesses] must be turned to my prejudice’ [by the insinuation that I have bribed them to be silent]. tau/thn (sc. th\n z.), virtually=tou=to, as Andoc. De Pace § 37, tau/thn labo/ntes a)formh/n.

kai\ tou/tou, k. t. l.] ‘Nor do I wonder at him: of course, when he is bringing a vexatious charge, he will take care that,
if he has no witnesses, at least he shall have such assertions at command’: toiou/twn lo/gwn, allegations of bribery on the part of the accused. — tou/tou: either tou=to or a clause with ei) or o(/ti would usually follow qauma/zw: but here the sentence ou) ga/r k.t.l. takes its place. Cp. p. 240, note on Lys. or. XXXIV. § 2.

purkai+a/s mori/ai which had been burnt down, as often happened in the raids during the Peloponnesian War. On the vitality of the olive cp. Her. VIII. 55: Soph. O. C. 698 (fu/teum' a)xei/rwton au)topoio/n, ‘a growth unconquered, selfrenewing’): Verg. Geo. II. 30, 181.

e)perga/sasqai ‘cultivate its former site’: e)perg. of sacrilegiously cultivating sacred soil, Aeschin. In Ctes. § 113, (the Amphissaeans) e)peirga/santo to\ pedi/on (of Crisa). So e)pergasi/a th=s gh=s th=s i(era=s, Thuc. I. 139.

w(/sper kai\ th\n a)/llhn ou)si/an ‘as much as any part of my own property’. The mori/ai were not part of his ou)si/a, but belonged to the State, so that th\n a)/ll. ou)s. strictly=‘all my property besides’: Plat. Phaed. 110 E, kai\ li/qois kai\ gh=| kai\ toi=s a)/llois zw/|ois te kai\ futoi=s.

h(gou/m. peri\ a)mf.] ‘deeming that I have interests at stake in both of them’ — both in the mori/ai and in my own property: i.e. he regards himself as bound by public duty and by religion to protect the mori/ai. Cp. or. XXXIV. § 9 (p. 55), o( ki/ndunos ou(=tos, the interests staked on the maintenance of the Constitution.

e)pimeloume/nous Cp. § 28, o(\s ou)/te gewrgw=n e)ggu\s tugxa/nei ou)/t' e)pimelhth\s (‘Inspector’) h(|rhme/nos. — The gnw/mones were higher officials, ‘Commissioners’, who made a general survey once a year.

e)rgaz., k.t.l. ‘cultivating the soil around the sacred olives’ (to the endangering of the shkoi/): not so much as e)perga/s. in § 24, which means to cultivate the spot on which a shko/s (now destroyed) had stood.

div2.p: . [Or. x.] — Theomnestus, a young Athenian, had been indicted by one Lysitheus for throwing away his shield in battle, but had been acquitted. The present speaker had been among the witnesses of Lysitheus, and in the course of the trial had been called a parricide by Theomnestus. A certain Dionysius, also a witness of Lysitheus, was next prosecuted by Theomnestus for perjury, and was sentenced to disfranchisement (§ 22). The present speaker then brought his action against Theomnestus.

The Athenian law against Defamation (kakhgori/a) punished with a fine of 500 drachmas (about £20) the utterance of certain reproaches classed as a)po/rrhta (§ 2). To call a citizen a murderer, a striker of father or mother, or to charge him with having thrown away his shield in battle, was among these. The present case had already been submitted to arbitrators (§ 6); it now came before an ordinary court, under the presidency of the Thesmothetae.

From § 4 the date is certain. The speaker had been thirteen years old in the time of the Tyrants (404 — 3 B.C.), and was now thirty-three: the speech belongs therefore to 384 — 3 B.C. — Attic Orators, I. 293.

div3.p: diaithth/n The Attic diaithtai/ were of two kinds, — public (klhrwtoi/), and private, chosen (ai(retoi/) by the parties themselves. Here, private arbitration is meant.
a)porrh/twn ‘forbidden’ words, which rendered those who used them liable to a di/kh kakhgori/as.
a)pektone/nai The term used by Theomnestus, acc. to the speaker, § 3, to\n pate/ra m' e)/fasken a)pektone/nai to\n e)mautou=.

tw=| nomoqe/th| We often find similar intimations that the intention or principle of a law is to be considered where the letter is not explicit: e.g. Arist. Mag. Mor. II. ad init. o( nomoqe/ths e)cadunatei= kaq' e(/kasta a)kribw=s diori/zein: cp. Rhet. I. 1.

ou) ga dh/pou, k.t.l. ‘If anyone were to call you a “striker” of father or mother [the a)po/rrhta, or actionable words] you would claim damages from him: surely, then, if anyone were to say that you had “smitten her who bore you” or “him who begat you”, you would not consider him deserving of impunity or innocent of libel’. For the form of the sentence, ou) dh/pou, ei) me/n...ei) de/, cp. In Eratosth. § 36 (above, p. 74), ou)k ou)=n deino/n, ei) tou\s me
 strathgou\s k.t.l.: Isocr. Panegyr. § 181 (below, p. 133), kai\ ga ai)sxro
 i)di/a| me
 k.t.l.: Plat. Gorg. 512 A, logi/zetai o(/ti ou)k, ei) me/n...ei) de\ k.t.l. — w(s ou)de
 ei)r. ‘on the ground that he has not’: but w(s mhde/n, ‘as if he had not’.

peri\ tou=to ga\r kai\ poiei=n kai\ le/gein ‘For you are an expert in this subject (tou=to, =to\ kakologei=n), and have studied both the theory and the practice’. poiei=n, how ‘to invent’ taunts; le/gein, how to utter them.

r(i=yai th\n a)sp r(i/ptein, abicere, was stronger than a)poba/llein, which, like iacturam facere, was capable of meaning
simply ‘to lose’: hence r(i/yaspis is the term of reproach, one who flings away his shield.

ei)/rhto Dobree, ei)/rhtai, which would be easier: but a)pobeblhke/nai was the word actually used in the law, as appears from the epitome of this speech (kata\ *qeomn. B § 5). Retaining ei)/rhto, take it as depending on ei): ‘If some one were to say... and it had been prescribed by the law...’: the actual provision of the law being stated hypothetically, as one of the data of the imagined case.

e)ch/rkei a)/n soi...me/lein ‘You would be content to be set down as one who had thrown away his shield, saying merely that you did not care’. Dobree would omit e)rrife/nai th\n a)spi/da: wrongly, I think. The perf. is thoroughly Greek: ‘you would be content to have thrown away’, i.e. you would acquiesce in the position of one who was said to have done so. He is supposed to say, ou)/ moi me/lei. Cp. Her. VI. 129, ou) fronti\s *(ippoklei/dh|.

tw=n e(/ndeka ‘Or again, if you had been made one of the Eleven [the Commissioners of Police], you would not be satisfied if a person were arrested for “robbing a man of his cloak” or “stripping him of his tunic”; you would acquit him on the same principle, because the epithet “clothesstealer” was not applied to him’. — a)pod., e)kded., true perfects pass.: lit. ‘if one were to arrest another saying that (he himself) had been robbed’: a)podu/ein, of the i(ma/tion: e)kdu/ein, of the under-garment, the xitw/n.

ou)d' ei)...ti/qentai ‘Nor, if any one were convicted of “having sold a boy into slavery”, would you call him a kidnapper, — on your principle [ei)/per, with fut. ind. maxh=|] of cavilling about words, instead of attending to the facts which all men have in view when they establish the terms’. — e)cag.: cp. Her. v. 6, pwleu=si ta\ te/kna e)p' e)cagwgh=| (for exportation as slaves).

e)/ti toi/nun, k.t.l. ‘Well, here is another illustration, judges. The defendant appears to be so averse to trouble or exertion that he has never even gone up to the Areiopagus. As you are all aware, when cases of homicide are tried in that place, the term employed in the preliminary oaths of the parties is not this [tou/tou, i.e. the accuser does not say that the accused is a)ndrofo/nos]; it is the phrase in which I have been reviled [i.e. ktei/nein]; for the prosecutor deposes that the prisoner “hath slain”, and the prisoner replies, “I have not slain”.

ou)kou=n a)/topon...diwmo/sato ‘Now it would be absurd that the prisoner, after having been adjudged guilty of
“slaying”, should defend himself on the plea that he was “a homicide”, the prosecutor's statement having charged him with “slaying”.’ As to the text of this passage, which has been corrupted in the mss., see the critical note.

ti/ ga\r tau=ta...diafe/rei ‘How, I ask (ga/r), do such cases differ from that which the defendant is prepared to maintain [e)rei=]?’ i.e. the defendant uses a)poktei/nein, implying a)ndrofo/nos: the Areiopagus, vice versa.
pentak. draxm.] about £20.

*lamba/neis ‘If you accept the laws in the sense in which I now take them’; — ou(/tw, i.e. with a view to the spirit rather than to the letter. The mss. have lamba/nein, — an impossibly harsh anacolouthon when ei) precedes and a)cioi=s follows. It was probably a mere error of transcription.
ou)k a)cioi=s for ou) instead of mh/ after ei) in such a sentence, cp. In Eratosth. § 36 (p. 74) ou)k a)/ra xrh/.

ei)=t' ou)k ai)sx., k.t.l. ‘Now do you not blush for being such a simpleton as to suppose that you are to be enriched, not by the rewards of patriotism, but by the profits of impunity?’ i.e. do you not see that every one will soon recognise you as a sukofa/nths?

w(/ste ou) du/nasqai Not w(/ste mh/: a parallel, if the text is sound (as it seems), to the anomaly in Soph. El. 780, w(/st' ou)/te nukto\s u(/pnon ou)/t' e)c h(me/ras | e)me\ stega/zein h(du/n. The ‘rules’ of Greek grammar were in the making in those days, and the thought sometimes overbore the normal usage: here, for instance, the writer was thinking most of the negative fact.

a)/n pws, k.t.l. ‘if, even at this late hour, when he stands at your bar, he can be educated, and prevented from troubling us in the future’. (ei) mh\ pro/teron,) a)lla\ nu=n, ‘better late than never’: cp. note on Soph. O. C. 1276. — There was one bh=ma (tribune) for the accuser, another for the accused: Aeschin. In Ctes. § 207, to\ tou= kathgo/rou b.,...to\ tou= feu/gontos.

*so/lwnos The laws written boustrofhdo/n on the wooden rollers (a)/cones) and triangular tablets (ku/rbeis) preserved in the Prytaneion were known as the ‘laws of Solon’. Acc. to Plut. Sol. 17, tou\s *dra/kontos no/mous plh\n tw=n fonikw=n a)nei=len (‘he cancelled’) a(/pantas, but, as Grote says (III. 180), ‘there is room for supposing that the repeal cannot have been so sweeping’. Solon was popularly credited with political reforms that came after him (ib. 169), and so also, doubtless, with laws that had been before him.

podoka/kkh| This sentence (with to\n po/da pe/nq' h(me/ras kai\ nu/ktas i)/sas) occurs also in the no/mos (interpolated?)
ap. [Dem.] or. LVIII. In Theocr. § 105. Hesych. podoka/kh|: o( e)n tw=| cu/lw| desmo/s, e)n w(=| oi( kakou=rgoi desmeu/ontai, oi(=on podokatoxh/: citing Plato comicus (circ. 420 — 390 B.C.).
prostimh/sh| ‘If the Heliaea award an additional penalty’ (in an aggravated case). The Periclean subdivision of the h(liai/a into dikasth/ria was subsequent to this law.

e)piorkh/santa — draska/zein ‘He shall give security, calling Apollo to witness his oath’ [e)piork. would ordinarily mean ‘having sworn falsely’ by the god]. — ‘If in fear of the proceedings, he should attempt flight’: — a detached phrase, which in the original may have depended on e)a\n sumbh=| or the like.

a)pi/llei th=| qu/ra| ‘Whoever shuts the door of the house [lit. excludes by the door] when the thief is within’...(to prevent the master entering, or to secure the burglar?). — a)pi/llw, from root vel, whence ei)/lw, ei)le/w, a(/l-u-si-s, a chain — a(l-i/-sk-omai, etc. Curt. Gr. E. § 656. Hesych. quotes a)pe/llai ‘enclosures’=shkoi/, e)kklhsi/ai: whence the Lacon. a)pella/zein=e)kklhsia/zein, to hold assemblies. — On the question between the spellings a)pi/llw and a)pei/llw, cp. my note on Soph. Ant. 340 (appendix, p. 250).
kai\ mhde\n...diafe/rou ‘and make no cavil on that account’, — said derisively to Theomnestus: i.e. ‘you cannot pretend that here the strange word makes the sense of the law doubtful’.

to\ a)rgu/rion sta/simon ‘The money shall stand at whatever rate the lender chooses’. The word sta/simon here does not refer to weighing, but to the exaction of interest as high as he pleases: i.e. sta/simo/n e)sti=du/natai i)/stasqai or staqh=nai, the loan can stand, can remain put out: cp. Andoc. De Red. § 11, o(/sou e)moi\ kate/sthsan, n., p. 221. For sta/simos in the sense of ‘weighable’ (zugw=| i(sta/nai), cp. Pollux IV. 173, who cites sta/sima as used for sta/qmia, ‘weights’, by Cephisodorus (Fragm. Com. 342): Polyb. VIII. 21. § 1, e(/lkonta to\ th=s pra/cews sta/simon, ‘turning the scale of the crisis’.

oi)kh=os kai\ *dou/lhs, k.t.l. ‘He shall be required to make good the injury done to the male or female slave’. Cp. the no/mos cited in Lys. or. I. § 32, e)a/n tis a)/nqrwpon e)leu/qeron h)\ pai=da ai)sxu/nh| bi/a|, diplh=n th\n bla/bhn o)fei/lein.

to\ de\ oi)kh=os qera/pontos] oi)keu/s in Il. and Od. sometimes=a (free) member of a household; sometimes, as here and in Soph. O. T. 756, a slave, oi)ke/ths. In Homer qera/pwn usu.=a free attendant — e.g. an esquire, etc.: later, it is simply a more honourable name for the slave as the personal attendant of his master. In Thuc. IV. 16 qera/pwn is the servant of the Spartan
hoplite: in VII. 13 the qera/pontes perh. include the free qh=tes who had been pressed for naval service, as well as the dou=loi. qera/pontes was esp. the Chian word for oi)ke/tai, Eustath. ad Dionys. 533.

sidhrou=s i.e. impenetrably stupid — incapable of receiving knowledge, even when it is hammered into him: cp. Aeschin. In Ctes. § 166, pw=s pot' , w)= sidh/reoi, e)karterei=te a)krow/menoi, i.e. men of iron endurance: Ar. Acharn. 491, a)nai/sxuntos sidhrou=s t' a)nh/r, shameless and brazen.
tou= bh/matos Cp. note on § 15.

div2.p: . [Or. XXIII.] — The speaker had formerly indicted Pancleon, a fuller living at Athens (§ 2), for some offence not specified, and, believing him to be a resident-alien, had summoned him before the Polemarch, who heard cases in which foreigners were concerned. Pancleon thereupon put in a ‘plea to the jurisdiction’, on the ground that he was a Plataean by birth, and, as such, entitled at Athens to the rights of an Athenian citizen: and that, therefore, the action ought not to have been brought before the Polemarch. This plea (paragrafh/) gave rise to a previous trial to decide whether the action, in its original form, could be brought into court (§ 5). In such a case the first speech was usually made by the maintainer of the special plea: here it is evidently made by the opponent. The date is uncertain. — Attic Orators, I. 302.

div3.p: o)rqw=s th\n di/khn e)/laxon ‘brought the action in proper form’. The speaker's object is to show that Pancleon is not an Athenian citizen but a foreigner, and that therefore the Polemarch was the magistrate who had jurisdiction in the di/kh. What the matter of the original di/kh was, does not appear. Here we are concerned solely with the question concerning its form. The issue is that raised by the paragrafh/, or special plea, put in by Pancleon, who relied on exceptio fori, denying that the Polemarch had jurisdiction. Every answer made in writing by a defendant to a plaintiff was a)ntigrafh/. The paragrafh/ was a species of a)ntigrafh/ — that answer, namely, which consisted in an objection to the form of the procedure. Hence in § 5 we read, a)ntegra/yato mh\ ei)sagw/gimon ei)=nai th\n di/khn: which is only another way of saying that his a)ntigrafh/ took the particular form of a paragrafh/.

gnafei=on The Athenian fuller had a thriving trade, as the woollen i(ma/tion was sent to him to be renovated; this process consisted in scouring, — i.e. rubbing in ‘Cimolian clay’, a sort of white earth, — and carding (kna/ptw), to raise the
nap. In Ar. Eccles. 415 and Athen. XIII. p. 582 we have people complaining of the gnafeu/s who delays to send back their i(ma/tia by the promised day. Cp. Theophr. Char. XXII, where it is noted as a trait of the a)neleu/qeros (the man who shows ‘excessive indifference to honour where expense is concerned’), that ‘he will stay in the house when he has sent his cloak to be scoured’ (e)/ndon me/nein o(/tan e)kdw=| qoi)ma/tion e)kplu=nai).

prosekalesa/mhn ‘summoned him before the Polemarch, supposing him to be a resident alien’. Harpocration p. 246 s.v. *pole/marxos (quoting Arist.'s *)aqhnai/wn politei/a) au)to/s te ei)sa/gei di/kas ta/s te a)postasi/ou kai\ a)prostasi/ou (for having deserted a prosta/ths, or for having none) kai\ klh/rwn kai\ e)piklh/rwn toi=s metoi/kois, kai\ ta)/lla o(/sa toi=s poli/tais o( a)/rxwn, tau=ta toi=s metoi/kois o( pole/marxos. Herm. Ant. I. § 138. 10.
o(po/qen dhmoteu/oito ‘to what deme he belonged’. Cp. [Dem.] or. LVII. Adv. Eubul. § 49, dhmoteuo/menos (=dhmo/ths w)/n) met' e)mou=.

paraine/santos, k.t.l. ‘one of those who were with me’ [one of the klhth=res, or officers who assisted at the summons] ‘having recommended that I should also summon him’ [as he had evaded the citation before the Polemarch] ‘before the tribe of which he pretended to be a member’ (the adviser said, skh/ptetai: this becomes skh/ptoito after h)ro/mhn). Before he could be brought under the jurisdiction of a tribe, it was necessary to ascertain his deme.

pro\s tou\s th=| *(ipp. dika/z.] ‘The judges for the Hippothontid tribe’, to which the deme of Deceleia belonged. Judges, appointed annually for each tribe, made the circuit of the demes included in it, deciding causes where not more than ten drachmas were at stake. Pollux VIII. 100, periio/ntes kata\ dh/mous ta\ me/xri draxmw=n de/ka e)di/kazon, ta\ de\ u(pe\r tau=ta diaithtai=s paredi/dosan: cp. Arist. Polit. IV. 13. § 2.

to\ kour. to\ para\ tou\s *(erm.] ‘the barber's shop by the Hermae’. The northern limit of the Athenian Agora was formed by rows of Hermae (busts of the god, on plain quadrangular posts), which extended from the *poiki/lh stoa/, or Portico of Frescoes, on the eastern side of the Agora, to the *basi/leios stoa/, or Portico of the Archon Basileus, on its western side. Among these Hermae, a few were of marble, bearing metrical inscriptions, and erected there by special permission in memory of the capture of Eion on the Strymon from the Persians — though neither Cimon, nor any individual victor, was allowed to be recorded by name. (Curtius, Hist.
Gr. II. 564: cp. his explanatory text to the ‘Sieben Karten’ of Athens, p. 52.)

ta\s me\n feu/goi, k.t.l. ‘on learning that he was actually defending some actions before the Polemarch, and had already been cast in others, I brought mine also’: they said, feu/gei, w)/flhke: cp. Goodwin § 18. 1.
e)pi/labe ‘stop the water-clock’: since the time occupied by the ma/rtures was not deducted from the time allowed for the speech.
e)k tou/twn ‘on these grounds’ (the statements about Pancleon just mentioned): not ‘by these persons’, which in Attic prose would be u(po\ tou/twn.
a)ntegra/yato ‘entered a plea against the jurisdiction of the court’: see note on § 1.
presbu/taton ‘the oldest inhabitant of Plataea that I knew’.

ei)s to
 xlwro
 turo/n ‘They said that I should be most likely to obtain precise information (puqe/sqai a)/n, oblique of pu/qoio a)/n), if I went to the cheese-market on the first day of the month’, — fair-day at Athens: Ar. Vesp. 171, Eq. 43. Cp. Theophr. Char. IV (XIV in my edit., and note there, p. 223). — to
 xl. turo/n, the place where fresh cheese is sold, like oi( i)xqu=s, the fish-market, Ar. Vesp. 789, ta\ la/xana, the green-market, Lysistr. 557, ai( murri/nai, the myrtle-wreath-market, Thesm. 448.
a)festw=ta ‘who had forsaken him’, — the word expressing, not merely the flight of the slave (a)podra/nta), but the fact that he has set up for himself. — te/xnhn, the fuller's trade.

to\n o(\s e)/fh despo/ths tou/tou ei)=nai=to\n fa/nta despo/thn t. ei)=nai: the relative clause being substituted for the partic. in order to give greater precision and emphasis to the statement of the fact, e)/fh.
a)go/menon ‘being carried off’, sc. ei)s doulei/an by his despo/ths.

to/te me\n ou)=n ‘At that time, then [to/te, in contrast with what happened next day], some of Pancleon's supporters said that he had a brother who would vindicate his liberty. On this understanding they gave bail that they would produce him in the market-place, and departed’. pare/cein: cp. In Agor. § 23, note on proh/sesqai, p. 265. For ei)s a)gora/n, perh. ei)s au)/rion.

th=| d' u(ster ‘Next day, with a view both to this
special plea and to the original action’ [brought before the Polemarch § 3], ‘I thought it right to take witnesses with me to the place, that I might know who it was that proposed to assert Pancleon's freedom, and on what ground he would do so. Now, as to the understanding on which he was bailed, [viz. o(/ti ei)/h a)delfo/s, k.t.l., § 9] no brother came, nor any other man’, etc.

ei)s tou=to de/, k.t.l. ‘But the defendant's supporters and the defendant himself carried matters with such a high hand that, though Nicomedes on his part, and the woman on hers, were willing to let Pancleon go if any one would assert his freedom, or else would claim him as a slave, Pancleon's friends did neither one thing nor the other, but carried him off’.
e)pi\ tou/tois the understanding that his brother was to vindicate his freedom, § 9.

mh\ o(/ti *pl ‘that even in his own eyes Pancleon is not a Plataean, — or rather, not even a free man’: mh\ (le/cwmen) o(/ti ou) nomi/zei e(. *pl. ei)=nai,=ou)x o(/pws *plataieu\s ei)=nai nomi/zei, a)ll' ou)d' e)leu/qeros.

e)no/xous...toi=s biai/ois ‘liable to the penalties of forcible seizure’ (di/kh biai/wn). The dikastai\ kata\ dh/mous (note on § 2) had jurisdiction in cases of ai)ki/a and ta\ tw=n biai/wn, Dem. Adv. Pantaen. § 33: Herm. Ant. I. § 146. 10.
tou= sw/matos=th=s e)pitimi/as, ‘his status’: which would be changed by a conviction from that of a citizen to that of a slave.

e)n th=| a)ntwmosi/a| ‘When Pancleon contended (in his affidavit on the occasion of the suit brought against him by Aristodicus here) that the Polemarch had no jurisdiction over him, it was proved by testimony that Pancleon was not a Plataean: and, though he indicted the witness for perjury [e)piskhya/menos, sc. yeudomarturiw=n], he failed to follow up the indictment, but allowed A. to obtain a verdict against him. And when his term of grace had expired, he paid the fine, on such conditions as he could obtain’ (from Aristodicus). — kaqo/ti e)/peiqe: i.e. he obtained an abatement, or arranged to pay by instalments; cp. Thuc. I. 117, kata\ xro/nous taca/menoi a)podou=nai.

pri\n toi/nun ‘Now before he had effected this compromise, in his fear of Aristodicus he removed from Athens and resided as an alien at Thebes’. tau=ta, the arrangement abating the sum, or allowing him to pay it gradually. After w)/|kei below, e)kei= is rightly supplied by Markland.

div1.head: Isocrates
div1.p: ISOCRATES: 436 — 338 B.C. Period of extant work, 403 — 338 B.C. Life in Attic Orators, II. 1 — 34.

Style. The work of Isocrates was to establish a standard type of literary rhetorical prose. His discourses were meant to be read rather than to be spoken. This is one essential characteristic which distinguishes them from the compositions of the other Attic orators. Isocrates is properly an ‘orator’ only in his forensic speeches, the earliest, and in his own view the least significant, of his writings. In his later life he altogether repudiated Forensic Rhetoric; on the other hand, ‘want of voice and nerve’, as he tells us, deterred him from taking part in the debates of the Ecclesia. The real work of his life was twofold. First, he was an educator, the head of a school which became renowned — teaching young men the art which he calls h( tw=n lo/gwn paidei/a, the discipline of discourse — meaning by this, the art of speaking and writing on large political subjects, considered as a preparation for advising or acting in political affairs. (Cp. Attic Orators, II. ch. XIII. on his filosofi/a, or theory of culture.) Secondly, he was a political essayist. In this quality — his writings being widely read throughout Greece — he had perhaps a greater influence on popular opinion than belonged to any literary man of his time. The style of literary prose which he developed had found general acceptance before 350 B.C.; through Greek teachers who gave it a more florid colour, it did much to mould the style of Cicero, who speaks of himself as using ‘all the fragrant essences of Isocrates, and all the little stores of his disciples’ (ad Att. II. 1); and through Cicero, or directly, it has exerted an influence on modern literature. It has been truly remarked that, for the modern world, the oratory of the preacher is the best image of that grave eloquence in which Isocrates excelled. Isocrates is one of three Greek writers — Plato and Demosthenes being the others — to whom Bossuet declares himself most indebted in the matter of style.

Isocrates has not the distinctively Attic spirit, the subtle grace or finished simplicity of Lysias. His diction, indeed, resembles that of Lysias in purity, and also — though it has a general bent towards grandeur — in avoiding ornament of a poetical kind. But his composition is of an altogether different stamp. Instead of aiming at the vigorous compression fittest for real contests, it has a certain rich diffuseness. Dionysius speaks of the u(pagwgikh\ peri/odos, the ‘meandering’ periods of Isocr. — having in his mind such an image as that of a river which leads us on from bend to bend through the
soft beauties of its winding course. Isocrates was the first great artist in a Greek prose which, without being bound by the constraints of metre (e)/mmetros), has yet a free rhythm of its own (eu)ru/qmws kai\ mousikw=s ei)pei=n, Adv. Soph. § 16, p. 115). The peculiar smoothness of Isocr. results esp. from his careful observance of his own rule, dei= ta\ fwnh/enta mh\ sumpi/ptein, i.e. a vowel at the end of a word must not be followed by a vowel at the beginning of the next. Plutarch speaks of Isocr. as o( fobou/menos fwnh=en fwnh/enti sugkrou=sai (De Glor. Athen. c. 8). Demosthenes did not press this rule so far (Attic Orators, II. 67). The figures (sxh/mata) specially used by Isocr. are those which depend on parallelism: viz. (1) a)nti/qesis — a parallelism in sense: (2) pari/swsis, a parallelism in form between two clauses or sentences: (3) paromoi/wsis, a parallelism of sound, when the latter of two clauses gives an echo of the former, either at its opening or at its close, or throughout. The same antithetical bent appears in Isocr.'s treatment of subject-matter, where his habit is to work out a leading idea by developing all the contrasts which it suggests. Thus the subject of the Panegyricus is a Greek war with Persia. Greece is dealt with in the first part, Persia in the second: in part I., again, Athens is contrasted with Sparta: the services of Athens to Greece are divided into the civil and the military, — the latter being classed as in wars between Greeks or in wars between Greek and barbarian: part II. shows that Persia is open to attack, while Greece has every motive for attacking.

Isocrates marks the moment at which the purest Attic prose begins to pass over into an artificial literary prose of greater richness, but with less of spiritual grace and delicate precision. In this respect his literary style corresponds to his intellectual position. He belongs to the latter days of free Hellenic life, and while he has the political exclusiveness of a true Hellene, is already able to conceive that men not Hellenic in blood should come to share in Hellenic culture — a conception which, in the generation after his own, began to be realised by the civilisation of Hellenism. This has been well brought out by Curtius (Hist. Greece v. 116, 204). ‘Athens’, says Isocr., ‘has so distanced the rest of the world in power of thought and speech that her disciples have become the teachers of all other men. She has brought it to pass that the name of Greek should be thought no longer a matter of race but a matter of intelligence; and should be given to the participators in our culture rather than to the sharers of our common origin’: Panegyr. § 50. — See Attic Orators, II. 16; 54 — 79: 425 f.

On the Works of Isocr. in general, ib. II. 80 — 260. The
following Extracts represent the several departments of his writings: —
A. Scholastic: I. Nicocles, §§ 14 — 24: II. Encomium on Helen, §§ 54 — 58: III. Evagoras, §§ 47 — 50: IV. Against the Sophists: V. On the Antidosis, §§ 270 — 302.
B. Political: VI. Panegyricus, §§ 160 — 186: VII. Philippos, §§ 81 — 104: VIII. Plataicus, §§ 56 — 63: IX. On the Peace, §§ 121 — 131: X. Archidamus, §§ 52 — 57: XI. Areopagiticus, §§ 36 — 55.
C. Forensic: XII. Aegineticus, §§ 18 — 27.
D. Letters: XIII. Letter v., to Alexander: XIV. Letter III., to Philip. — See Table in Attic Orators, II. 83.

div2.p: [Or. III.] — Nicocles succeeded his father Evagoras as king of the Cyprian Salamis in 374 B.C. The discourse of Isocrates entitled *pro\s *nikokle/a (or. II.) was addressed to the young king soon after his accession. It is a series of precepts on the duty of a ruler to his subjects. The *nikoklh=s h)\ *ku/prioi is a companion piece to the former. Here it is Nicocles who is supposed to speak, and who instructs his Salaminian subjects in their duties towards their king. Since the prince can appeal to his people's past experience of his rule (§ 63), the date can hardly be earlier than 372 B.C.: on the other hand it cannot be later than 355 B.C., and may probably be placed between 372 and 365 B.C.

In the following passage the king urges the advantages of a Monarchy as compared with an Oligarchy or a Republic. Here Isocrates is essentially the professional rhetor — it being distinctive of Rhetoric that, like its counterpart Dialectic, it is equally ready to argue either side of a question (ta)nanti/a sullogi/zetai, Ar. Rhet. I. 1). Isocrates has given the other side in his *)areopagitiko/s (p. 151) as well as in the Panathenaicus, where he interprets his own political ideal, — a Democracy tempered by a censorship. — Attic Orators, II. 87, 90 f.

The advantages claimed for Monarchy, it will be seen, are briefly these: (1) it discriminates merit, §§ 14, 15: (2) it has more insight into the natures and actions of men: (3) it is the mildest of governments, § 16: (4) its ministers learn and perform their duties more thoroughly, §§ 17, 18: (5) it is prompt in action, § 19: (6) it has fewer jealousies, § 20: (7) it has a more direct interest in good government, § 21: (8) it is more effective in war, § 22. — As a plea for monarchy by the citizen of a Greek Republic, compare the brief speech invented by Herod. for Dareius in the debate of the Persian conspirators, III. 82.

div3.p: ta\s i)so/thtas ‘Now Oligarchies and Democracies aim at conditions of equality for all who participate in the franchise, and the principle which they approve is that no one should be permitted to have the advantage of his neighbour’. ta\s i)so/thtas, plur., because the two forms of ‘civic equality’ are different: oi( mete/xontes th=s politei/as are in the one case the many, in the other the few. Cp. Thuc. III. 62, o)ligarxi/a i)so/nomos, i.e. constitutional oligarchy, opp. to a dunastei/a.

to/ ge bou/lhma ‘the intention’, — that to which its theory points, — that which it purposes to achieve. Plat. Laws 769 D, a)=r' ou) toiou=ton dokei= soi to\ tou= nomoqe/tou bou/lhm) ei)=nai; Arist. Pol. VI [IV] 2. § 1 (speaking of a)ristokrati/a and basilei/a), bou/letai ga\r e(kate/ra kat' a)reth\n sunesta/nai kexorhghme/nhn: and De Anim. Gen. IV. ad fin., bou/letai me\n ou)=n h( fu/sis (tends) — ou)k a)kriboi=de/, ‘but does not attain a perfect result’.

ta\s turanni/das ‘Again, all would allow that despotic governments have superior insight into men's natures and actions’. Here, as in § 22, the monarxi/a is tacitly identified with the turanni/s. The tu/rannos is a ruler whose power is above and against the laws; it is characteristic of him that he rules in his own interest (to\ e(autou= sumfe/ron skopei=, Arist. Eth. Nic. VIII. 12). Depending much on the choice of instruments (Arist. Polit. VIII [V] 11. § 12), he has, indeed, practice in the study of character: only, as Arist. says, the turanni/s is apt to be ponhro/filon, to favour bad men. The founder of a despotism was usually a man of exceptional energy and sagacity: the fallacy here consists in crediting the turanni/s with the merits of some tu/rannoi.
fe/resqai m. tou= plh/qous ‘to be carried with the stream of the crowd’. — a)lla\ mh/n, ‘then, again’.

o(/ti me
 o)=n...r(a/|dio/n e)sti] ‘That Monarchy is the more agreeable, the milder and the juster form of government, might be proved in ampler detail; however, the general view just given may perhaps suffice’: lit. ‘not but that (ou) mh
 a)lla\) it is easy to see this comprehensively (sunidei=n) by means of the foregoing considerations’: dia\ tou/twn, i.e. in §§ 15, 16. Cp. Xen. Cyr. I. 4. § 8, o( i(/ppos pi/ptei ei)s go/nata, kai\ mikrou= ka)kei=non e)cetraxh/lisen (threw him over his head), ou) mh
 a)ll' e)pe/meinen, ‘nevertheless he kept his seat’: where, after ou) mh/n, supply e)cetraxh/lisen, as here, a)podei=cai dei=. — sunidei=n: cp. Arist. Rhet. I. 2. § 12, dia\ pollw=n sunora=n, ‘to take in a long chain of reasoning at one view’, joined with po/rrwqen logi/zesqai, ‘to reason from far back’, i.e. to connect a series of syllogisms.

peri\ de\ tw=n loipw=n See introd. ad fin. Eight points of advantage are claimed for Monarchy. Three — graduation of merit, — insight, — clemency, — have now been noticed. Five (ta\ loipa/) remain. ‘As to the other points, the superiority of Monarchies [to Oligarchies or Democracies] with respect to deliberation or action in needful matters may best be judged by us, if we endeavour to institute a systematic comparison in the most important provinces of activity’. Lit., ‘if, comparing the most important actions [as performed by Monarchy and by its rival forms of government respectively], we attempt to examine these’ (au)ta/s,=ta\s megi/stas pra/ceis).
i)diw=tai gi/gn ‘return into private life’ (their year of office having expired).

oi( d' a)ei\...gi/gnesqai] ‘while the ministers of a Monarchy, having permanent charge of their duties, even if their natural abilities are inferior, have at least (ou)=n) a decided preeminence in the lessons of experience. Further, the one class [oi( me/n the ministers of an Oligarchy or a Democracy] betray many interests by neglect, because they rely upon each other [i.e. what is every one's business is no one's]; but the ministers of a Monarchy neglect nothing, since they know that everything must pass through their hands’. — The plur. ai( monarxi/ai, § 17, leaves room for doubt whether oi( d' a)ei\ toi=s au)toi=s e)pistatou=ntes, k.t.l.,=oi( mo/narxoi, or the monarch and his ministers: the context favours the latter view: cp. §§ 15, 16.

oi( me\n e)n tai=s o)lig. — oi( d' e)n tai=s monarx.] oi( e)n tai=s o)lig. kai\ tai=s dhmokr. mean the citizens of oligarchical or democratical states; lit., those who are in these forms of government, i.e. who hold their powers. So oi( e)n tai=s monarxi/ais ought to mean, those who hold monarchical power, viz. oi( mo/narxoi. But, for the sense of the context, pa/ntwn be/ltista pra/ttousin ought to mean that the subjects, as well as the monarch, are eminently prosperous. Now the clause, ou)k e)/xontes o(/tw| fqonh/sousi, is not against this: since Monarchy is here conceived (§ 15) as a system which fixes each man in his proper rank, and thus precludes uneasy rivalry. Therefore I take oi( e)n tai=s monarxi/ais o)/ntes here as meaning ‘those who live in monarchical States’.

sune/dria...xro/nwn] sune/dria, ‘public conferences’, a general term, including (e.g.) the Athenian boulh/, e)kklhsi/a, dikasth/ria. — xro/nwn, limits of tenure: § 17, kat' e)niauto\n ei)s ta\s a)rxa\s ei)sio/ntes. — ou)k a)polei/pontai tw=n kairw=n, ‘do not allow the right moments to slip’, do not ‘lag behind’ them.

dusmenw=s e)/xousi ‘The ministers of other govern
ments (oi( me/n) cherish enmities;...monarchs, (oi( de/,) having a life-long tenure of office, maintain their friendships also through life’.

oi( me\n w(s i)di/ois ‘The monarch regards the public interests as his own, — the citizen, as belonging to others’: — a remark utterly untrue to the spirit of the Athenian democracy as described by Pericles, e)/ni de\ toi=s au)toi=s oi)kei/wn a(/ma kai\ politikw=n e)pime/leia, k.t.l. Thuc. II. 40. The essence of Greek political life, while vigour remained to it, was the identification of the citizen's interests with the city's: au(/th ga\r h( sw/|zousa, kai\ tau/ths e)/pi | ple/ontes o)rqw=s tou\s fi/lous poiou/meqa, Soph. Ant. 189.
e)n toi=s o)/xlois ‘before mobs’; i.e. ‘before the Ecclesia or law-courts’: cp. Eur. Hipp. 989, oi( ga\r e)n sofoi=s | fau=loi, par' o(/xlw| mousikw/teroi le/gein.
ou) mo/non d ...perieilh/fasin ‘It is not only in matters of routine and in the affairs of every day that monarchies are superior; they hold in their grasp [perf.] also all the gains of war’.

w(/ste kai\ laqei=n...prosagage/sqai ‘for purposes of surprise or of display [o)fqh=nai, so as to strike terror], — in order to persuade or to compel, — to buy advantages in one quarter, or to conciliate by attentions in another’. Cp. Andoc. De Pace § 37, p. 47, which Isocr, may have had in mind, ta\ me\n pei/santes tou\s *(/ellhnas, ta\ de\ laqo/ntes, ta\ de\ pria/menoi, ta\ de\ biasa/menoi. — tai=s a)/llais qerapei/ais, attentions, flatteries, other than money (implied in e)kpria/menoi): for the idiom, see Lysias or. VII. § 25, th\n a)/llhn ou)si/an, note, p. 272. — Observe turanni/s tacitly identified with monarxi/a, as in § 16.

*persw=n...*dionu/sion In illustrating the advantages of monarxi/a, Isocr. takes the word in its widest sense, and draws his examples from the most diverse forms of government, viz. (1) the Persian monarchy, — a hereditary and constitutional despotism, — monarxi/a turannikh/, but kata\ no/mon kai\ patrikh/, Arist. Pol. III. 14: (2) the turanni/s, an unconstitutional despotism, which is only a perverted form, pare/kbasis, of monarchy, and not properly a politei/a at all: (3) the constitutions of Sparta and of Carthage, in both of which the general tendency was oligarchical, and the ‘royal’ office meant principally the chief command in war: Arist. Pol. II. 9. § 11.
thlikau/thn geg The real lessons taught by the Persian Wars were that free men fight better than slaves, and that good strategy is incompatible with the caprices of a feeble despot.

poliork When Dionysius became tyrant of Syracuse in 406 B.C. the Carthaginians were rapidly conquering the Sicilian cities. His first operations against them failed: and the words in the text refer, not to an actual siege of Syracuse (th\n au(tou= patri/da), but to its imminent danger after the fall of Gela and Camarina. The peace which he made with Himilcon in 405 B.C. was a compromise which gave him leisure to confirm his own power. His tyranny was disastrous to all the higher interests of Hellenic civilisation. Cp. Lysias or. XXXIII. § 5 (above, p. 51).
tou\s a)/rista tw=n *(e. polit.] An awkward clause, referring as it does to *laked. only: for grammatical clearness, it should stand between kai\ and *laked.

o)ligarx. — basil.] Arist. (Pol. II. 11) compares the Carthaginian Council of One Hundred and Four with the Spartan Ephors, and the Carthaginian Elders (ge/rontes) and Kings (basilei=s) with those of Sparta. — The Carthaginian ‘Kings’ or Suffetes seem to have been chosen annually from a few principal families: Corn. Nepos speaks of Hannibal being made rex when appointed to his foreign command (c. 7), and Diod. (XIV. 54) of Himilcon, and Herod. of Hamilcar (VII. 166); Grote. X. 548. — Of the Spartan kingship, Arist. says, dokei= me
 ei)=nai basilei/a ma/lista tw=n kata\ no/mon, ou)k e)/sti de\ kuri/a pa/ntwn, a)ll' o(/tan e)ce/lqh| th
 xw/ran, h(gemw/n e)sti tw=n pro\s to
 po/lemon...au(/th me
 ou)=n h( bas. oi(=on strathgi/a tis au)tokra/twr kai\ a)i+/dio/s e)stin, Pol. III. 14.

pollou/s...e(no/s] pollou/s — e.g. in the case of the Sicilian expedition, and of the defeat at Aegospotami: e(no/s — e.g. Cimon, Phormio. The argument might be illustrated by the story of the dissension among the Athenian commanders before the battle of Marathon, when the four who agreed with Miltiades resigned to him their days of command (Her. VI. 109 f.).

div2.p:
. [Or. X.] — The Encomium on Helen (like another of his works, the Busiris, or. XI.) is a slight essay by Isocr. in a province not his own. Declamations on subjects taken from epos or from the myths had always a prominent place among the ‘displays’ of ordinary Sophists. Such, for instance, are the Encomium on Helen and the Defence of Palamedes ascribed to Gorgias; the speech of Odysseus Against Palamedes ascribed to Alcidamas; the speeches of Ajax and Odysseus in the contest for the arms, ascribed to Antisthenes. The bent of Isocrates, as he himself tells us, was not towards this kind of composition. He was not, indeed, hostile to it, any more than he was hostile to criticism
of the poets and other branches of literary work which employed the Sophists. The encomia which he depreciates in or. X. § 12 are encomia on bumble-bees and salt; on the other hand he expressly commends the choice of such a subject as Helen (§ 14); and if he speaks of Busiris as a poor theme (or. XI. § 22), he clearly means only that it is one which baffles the panegyrist. Yet it is important to note that he comes upon this field of ‘display’ not as a candidate for distinction, but merely as a critic. The Busiris and the Encomium on Helen are alike criticisms, in which he first reviews the work of others, and then shows, for the sake of vindicating his right to criticise, how he would have done the work himself.

Two indications help to fix the time at which Isocrates wrote. 1. From § 3 it may be inferred that Gorgias was dead; and Gorgias died about 380 B.C. 2. In § 1 there is an allusion to the three chief Socratic sects — the Cynics, the Academy, the Megarics. These sects must have already been mature. The language implies further that Antisthenes, founder of the Cynics — who died in 376 B.C. — is still alive. The Encomium may probably be put about 370 B.C. — Attic Orators, II. 93, 102.
A translation of the following passage will be found in the Attic Orators, II. p. 78.

div3.p: ka)kei=noi tau=t' e)/gnwsan The kai\ before e)kei=noi is not ‘also’, but ‘both’, to which ka)gw/ answers. — e)kei=noi, Helen's lovers — Theseus, Menelaus, Paris and the heroes who fell in the War of Troy — Achilles, Sarpedon, etc.: §§ 39 — 53. tau=t' e)/gnwsan, ‘made this choice’, sc. teqna/nai maxome/nois peri\ th=s *dio\s qugatro/s, § 53.
h)\ tou/twn e(/kaston i.e. than a)ndri/a, sofi/a, dikaiosu/nh. — We might expect e(ka/stou (sc. mete/xonta), but e(/kaston is more forcible.

tau/ths th=s i)de/as So below, § 58, peri\ th\n i)de/an th\n toiau/thn: ‘this attribute’ or ‘quality’ (viz. to\ ka/llos, beauty): a meaning derived from that of ‘species’ or ‘kind’: cp. Lat. genus, e.g. Cic. De Or. II. 4. 17, qui in aliquo genere aut inconcinnus aut multus est, ‘in any respect’. Isocr. has also some peculiar uses of i)de/ai in reference to literary composition, viz. (1) as = tro/poi lo/gwn, the branches or styles: Antid. § 11: (2) = sxh/mata, figures of rhetoric, Panath. § 2: (3) in a larger sense, all ‘artificial resources’ which can be formulated, Antid. § 183: see Attic Orators, II. 39 and note.
ou)k a)pagor. qerap.] ‘are never tired of paying homage’.

a)pokalou=men here, as usually ‘call contemptuously’: cp. below, p. 111 § 4, a)rguri/dion...to\n plou=ton a)pokalou=ntes: but not always so: e.g. Arist. Eth. II. 9, tou\s xalepai/nontas a)ndrw/deis a)pokalou=men: cp. Shilleto on Dem. F. L. § 274.

peri\ th=s au(tw=n h(liki/as Cp. below, p. 123 § 290, to
 o)rqw=s kai\ prepo/ntws proestw=ta th=s h(liki/as kai\ kalh
 a)rxh
 tou= bi/ou poiou/menon.

o(/soi d' ‘but we honour for all time, and as benefactors to the State, those who have guarded the glory of their own youth in the chasteness of an inviolable shrine’. — a)/baton, bolder than a)/qikton: cp. Plat. Phaedr. 245 A, a)po\ *mousw=n katokwxh/ te kai\ mani/a labou=sa a(palh\n kai\ a)/baton yuxh/n, e)gei/rousa kai\ e)kbakxeu/ousa...paideu/ei. Soph. frag. 86 (Aleuadae), Nauck p. 118, deino\s ga\r e(/rpein plou=tos e)/s te ta)/bata | kai\ pro\s be/bhla (vulg. ta\ bata/), wealth can worm its way into sacred places no less than into those that all may tread.

div2.p: . [Or. IX.] — On the occasion of a festival held by Nicocles, king of the Cyprian Salamis (cp. introd. to or. III., p. 283), in memory of his father Evagoras (who died in 374 B.C.), Isocrates sent this encomium as his tribute. The date is probably about 365 B.C.

Evagoras appears to have been a man of unusually strong character, and of great abilities both military and political. Cyprus was divided between Phoenician settlements, such as Citium and Paphos, and later Greek settlements, such as Salamis and Soli. But the bulk of the population was, till long after the time of Evagoras, Phoenician; and continual contact with the non-hellenic East must always have tended to depress the Greek element in Cyprus. Evagoras was the champion of Hellenism against barbarism at this out-post; first, as restorer of that Greek civilisation which the Phoenician and Tyrian masters of Salamis had effaced; afterwards, as antagonist of Persia in a War of Independence. Perhaps the most striking passage in the memoir is the following, which describes how commerce, arts, letters, humane intercourse with the outer world, having become extinct under the rule of the barbarian, speedily sprang into a new life under the rule of the Hellene. — Attic Orators, II. 113.

div3.p:
paralabw\n th\n po/lin e)kb ‘When the city (Salamis) came into his hands, it had been reduced to barbarism; owing
to the domination of the Phoenicians, it had no intercourse with Greeks, no knowledge of the useful arts, no commerce, no harbour: but he supplied all these deficiencies’, etc.

dia\ th\n tw=n *foini/kwn a)rx The earliest Greek immigrants into Cyprus seem to have found Phoenicians already established. The Greek settlements traced their origin to Athens, Salamis, Arcadia, Cythnus (one of the Cyclades): Her. VII. 90. Long after the time at which Isocrates is writing the Phoenician element in Cyprus greatly preponderated over the Hellenic: thus Scylax in his *peri/plous, p. 97 (written in the time of Philip of Macedon, 359 — 336 B.C.), calls the inhabitants of the interior collectively ‘barbarians’. Of the Greek cities on the coast, the chief in the time of Scylax seem to have been Salamis, Soli and Marium. (See Rawlinson on Her. v. 104.)

In 500 B.C. the Cyprian Salamis was ruled by a dynasty of Greek princes tributary to Persia (Her. v. 104, 114). Acc. to Isocr., this Greek dynasty — which claimed descent from Teucrus — was dispossessed by a Phoenician adventurer (e)k *foini/khs a)nh\r fuga/s, § 19), whose descendants (e)/kgonoi, § 21) held the throne until it was again taken from them by Evagoras, the heir of the old Greek kings.

Grote would place the Phoenician usurpation about 450 B.C. (X. 21), with good reason: though Isocr. at least seems to have conceived it as occurring much earlier. The restoration of the Greek ‘Teucrid’ dynasty by Evagoras cannot have been later than 411 B.C., in which year Andocides visited Cyprus, and found Evagoras reigning at Salamis, [Lys.] In Andoc. § 28. And Evagoras must have been ‘not merely established, but powerful’ (Grote X. 25) when he ventured to harbour Conon after Aegospotami (405 B.C.). At the time of his death in 374 B.C. Evagoras was an old man (§ 71).
ou)/t' e)mpori/w| xrwm i.e. Salamis did not afford an e)mpo/rion, a centre or seat of commerce, to foreign traders. At Athens the e)mpo/rion was the ‘Exchange’. It is unnecessary to read e)mpori/a|.
tei/xh prosperieba/leto k.t.l. ‘protected his city with new fortifications’, in addition to its old tei/xh. — e)nauphgh/sato, ‘caused to be built’. Her. and Thuc. always use the midd.

tai=s a)/llais kataskeuai=s ‘and, further, so embellished the city with public buildings that it is surpassed by no other in Hellas’. For tai=s a)/llais cp. Nicocles § 22, tai=s a)/llais qerapei/ais, note. The term kataskeuai/ might perhaps include tei/xh, but not trih/reis. Cp. Thuc. I. 10, ou)/te cunoikisqei/shs th=s po/lews (Sparta) ou)/te i(eroi=s kai\ kataskeuai=s polutele/si
xrhsame/nhs, ‘costly public buildings’. A Greek would think of temples, stoai/, theatre, prutanei=on, gymnasium, baths.

thl. e)pido/seis...lamba/nein ‘take such rapid steps in progress’, = tosou=ton e)pidido/nai, — opp. to a)nadido/nai or u(podido/nai, to fall back, fail. At Athens e)pido/seis had the special meaning of ‘benevolences’ contributed by the citizens in the emergencies of the State. Hence the story in Athenaeus IV. 168 of Phocion's dissolute son: ‘Once, when subscriptions to the Treasury (e)pido/seis) were being made, he came forward in the Ecclesia, and said, “I, too, advance” (e)pidi/dwmi) — “in profligacy”, roared the House with one accord’.

toiou/tois h)/qesin ‘with such qualities’, a dat. of circumstance (= e)/xwn toiau=ta h)/qh). — o)li/gw| pro/teron: in §§ 22 f., where it is said that Evag. was distinguished in youth by swfrosu/nh as well as r(w/mh and ka/llos, — in manhood, by a)ndri/a, sofi/a, dikaiosu/nh.
polu\ li/an a)pol = li/an polu/, so w)mw=s a)/gan, Xen. Vect. v. 6.
e)fi/koito ‘do justice to’: Dem. F. L. § 65, ou)d' a)\n ei(=s du/nait' e)fike/sqai tw=| lo/gw| tw=n e)kei= kakw=n nu=n o)/ntwn. So oratione consequi aliquid, Cic. Post Red. ad Quir. 2. § 5.

to\n to/pon to\n perie/x ‘The coast adjacent to Cyprus’ — meaning esp. the seaboard of Cilicia and Caria. Phoenician trading posts had existed there from early times, but on the Cilician coast the Greeks had few settlements before the time of Alexander.

a)prosoi/stws, k.t.l. ‘their temper was so unsociable and savage that they deemed those rulers the best who were most cruelly disposed towards the Greeks’: — a description which doubtless includes the Phoenician colonists as well as the natives of the Asiatic mainland. In the pseudo-Lysian speech ‘Against Andocides’ it is stated that when he visited Cyprus he was imprisoned by the [Phoenician] king of Citium, kai\ ou) mo/non qa/naton e)fobei=to a)lla\ kai\ ta\ kaq' h(me/ran ai)ki/smata, oi)o/menos ta\ a)krwth/ria zw=ntos a)potmhqh/sesqai, § 26.

a(mill. oi(/tines...do/cousi ‘vie with each other, which of them shall seem’. The relative with fut. ind. here expresses a purpose, oi(/tines do/cousi being equiv. to an object-clause, o(/pws e(/kastoi do/cousi. So presbei/an pe/mpein, h(/tis e)rei=, Dem. Ol. I. § 2: Goodwin § 65.

kth/masi — e)pithd By kth/mata are meant esp. works of art, the beautiful objects which surrounded a Greek in his homelife: cp. Thuc. II. 38, i)di/ais kataskeuai=s eu)prepe/sin, w(=n kaq' h(me/ran h( te/ryis to\ luphro\n e)kplh/ssei. — e)pithdeu/masi, ‘pursuits’
(business or recreation) in the most general sense: cp. Thuc. ib., ta\ kaq' h(me/ran e)pithdeu/mata.

plei/ous de/, k.t.l. ‘a greater number of men versed in literature and art (mousikh/), and men of intellectual accomplishment generally (h( a)/llh pai/deusis), reside in these regions than in the communities [par' oi(=s, apud eos] which they formerly frequented’.

tw=n peri\ th\n mousikh/n Here, mousikh/ is best taken in its larger sense. But cp. Epist. VIII. of Isocr. (toi=s *mutilhnai/wn a)/rxousin), which commends to the government of Mytilene the eminent musician Agēnor, by whom the grandsons of Isocr. had been taught music — paideuqe/ntes ta\ peri\ th\n mousikh/n, Ep. VIII. § 1. In § 4 ib. he calls Mytilene mousikwta/thn, i.e. famous for poetry, letters and art — where again the larger sense is uppermost. (See Attic Orators, II. 247.)

prosomologh/seien ‘concede’. pro/s in this verb and its subst. prosomologi/a does not usu. mean ‘besides’, ‘in addition’, but merely ‘to’, i.e. ‘in discussion with another’: as prosonoma/zw in Her. II. 52 is not ‘to give an additional name’, but ‘to accost by a name’.

div2.p: . [Or. XIII.] — ‘Against the Sophists’. — As Isocr. himself tells us (Antid. § 193), this discourse was written at the beginning of his professional life; and it may probably be assigned to the year 391 or 390 B. C. The speech would thus have the character of a manifesto in which, at the outset of his career, the teacher protests against the system adopted by other members of his profession, and declares the principles by which he himself intends to be guided. In its extant form the discourse is plainly imperfect. It breaks off at the point where Isocr. is passing — as he passes in the introductions to the Busiris and the Encomium on Helen — from destructive criticism to positive illustration.

Isocr. accepts for himself the name of sofisth/s, as of honourable import when rightly understood (Antid. § 220), but distinguishes himself from the a)gelai=oi sofistai/, the common herd of the profession (Panathen. § 18). Under the title of sofistai/, three classes of teachers are censured in this piece, viz.: —

(1) The Eristics, — oi( peri\ ta\s e)/ridas diatri/bontes, § 1: whose characteristic is that they profess, for a small fee, to impart absolute knowledge (e)pisth/mh). Isocr. probably includes, if he does not specially designate, the minor Socratics, and particularly Eucleides.

(2) The professors of ‘Political Discourse’ — oi( tou\s politikou\s lo/gous u(pisxnou/menoi — meaning the teachers of Practical Rhetoric, Deliberative and Forensic. Now the general aim of these teachers was that of Isocr. himself, viz. to train men for the active duties of civic life. The point of this censure is that they claim too large and infallible an efficacy for their method: paidei/a, instruction, can do much, but it must be aided by fu/sis, natural aptitude, and by e)mpeiri/a, experience.

(3) The writers of Treatises on Rhetoric, oi( ta\s te/xnas gra/yantes. These are censured for devoting themselves to the Rhetoric of the law-courts, neglecting the higher or political province of their art, and so becoming ‘teachers of meddlesomeness and greed’.

Here, Isocr. is stating what his filosofi/a, or theory of culture, is not. In the discourse on the Antidosis (written 35 years later, in 353 B.C. — see p. 117) he states what it is. — Attic Orators, II. 127 — 134.

div3.p: a)lazoneu/esqai ‘As it is, the reckless bragging of impostors has created an impression that the votaries of indolence are better advised than those who give their days to serious study’. r(a|qumei=n — careless enjoyment, opp. to strenuous preparation (through politikoi\ lo/goi) for public life. filosofi/a, in the special sense of Isocr., is the art of speaking or writing on large political subjects, considered as a preparation for advising or acting in political affairs. See Attic Orators, II. 36, ch. XIII, on his ‘Theory of Culture’. The term filosofi/a was often used at this period, as later, in the general sense of filokali/a tis kai\ diatribh\ peri\ lo/gous (Aristeid. II. 407).

tw=n peri\ ta\s e)/ridas diatrib including some of the minor Socratics, e.g. Antisthenes and the Cynics, Eucleides and the Megarics — to whom he alludes again in a later work, the Encomium on Helen, § 1. There, we find a clear allusion to Plato also, as teaching that Valour, Wisdom and Justice form the subject-matter of one science. Here there is prob. no reference to Plato, who at this time (390 B.C.) was perh. not yet conspicuous: in the Panathenaicus (339 B.C.), however, the e)ristikoi\ dia/logoi named as popular with young men (§ 118) must certainly include the dialogues of Plato.

bouleuome/nous u(pe\r au)tw=n ‘deliberating about the future’: u(pe\r au)tw=n = peri\ tw=n mello/ntwn: a common use of u(pe/r in early Greek, but somewhat rare in good Attic: cp. Plat. Apol. 39 E, h(de/ws a)\n dialexqei/hn u(pe\r tou= gegono/tos toutoui+\ pra/gmatos.

ou) th\n e)kei/nwn, k.t.l. ‘not that he knew their [the gods’], mind, but because he wished to show us that, for men, know
ledge of the future is a thing impossible’: — a fortiori, if not even gods are certain about it.

e)pisth/mhs Cp. § 8, where ‘those who profess to have knowledge’ (e)pisth/mhn) are said to be ‘less consistent and less successful than those who act upon opinions’, oi( tai=s do/cais xrw/menoi. The mention of e)pisth/mh here again points to the Socratics. The view of Isocr. was that the teacher of filosofi/a has to prepare men to deal with occasions (kairoi/) as they arise. It is impossible to foresee exactly all these occasions; there can be no science (e)pisth/mh) of them. There can be only opinion (do/ca), conjecture (stoxasmo/s), about them: and he is the wisest man who — exact foresight being out of the question — can best conjecture what any given crisis will demand of him (Attic Orators, II. 40). Cp. Isocr. Antid. § 184, i(/na... e)ggute/rw tw=n kairw=n tai=s do/cais ge/nwntai. tw=| me\n ga\r ei)de/nai perilabei=n au)tou\s ou)x oi(=o/n t' e)sti/n.

ou)k a)
 h)mfisb. w(s [ou)k] eu)= fr. tugx.] ‘Were they selling any other of their possessions for a small fraction of its value, they would not dispute [ = they would admit] their own folly’. This is plainly the sense: but, in order to obtain it, we must omit ou)k before eu)=. For ou)k a)mfisbhtei= w(s ou)k eu)= fronei= means, ‘he does not maintain that he is senseless’: see Plat. Polit. 476 D, e)a
 a)mfisbhth=| w(s ou)k a)lhqh= le/gomen, if he maintains that we do not speak truly: Parm. 135 A, a)mfisbhtei=n w(s ou)k e)/sti tau=ta, k.t.l. Dobree (Advers. I. 275) saw that the second ou)k must be omitted here, noticing Isocr. or. XVIII. Adv. Callim. § 35 as a case in which, on the contrary, ou) should be inserted: w(s me
 xrh/...ou)d' au)to
 oi)=mai a)nterei=n. But there, I think, the order of the clauses confirms the text: ‘As to the propriety...I do not think that even he would deny it’. Had a)nterei=n preceded w(s xrh/, then ou) must have been inserted.

a)rguri/dion, k.t.l. ‘The scientific aim of the teachers described, coupled with their moderate earnings, and contempt, genuine or affected, of “filthy lucre” (a)rguri/dion, k.t.l.) are features which meet in the minor Socratics, and in them only’: W. H. Thompson, Phaedrus, p. 177, n. 9. — For a)pokalou=ntes, cp. Helen. Encom., § 57, note.

para\ tou/tois...mesegguou=ntai ‘they cause the fees paid by their pupils to be deposited with these men’. Isocr. says that the sofisth/s, who professes to teach his pupils virtue, believes so little in the virtue which his pupils will have acquired at the end of the course that he requires them to deposit their fees beforehand in the hands of a surety, who acts as a middleman (mesegguhth/s) between teacher and disciples. — The form
mesegguou=sqai is illustrated by mesegguw/matos in Panath. § 13, where Sauppe conj. mesegguh/matos.
ou)de\n kwlu/ei] kwlu/ei impersonal: ou)de/n adverbial: cp. Ar. Av. 463, o(\n diama/ttein ou) kwlu/ei.

e)nergazome/nous ‘those who engender virtue and temperance’ (in their disciples). The same topic of ridicule is used by Plato: Gorg. 519 C, oi( sofistai/, ta)/lla sofoi\ o)/ntes, tou=to a)/topon e)rga/zontai pra=gma: fa/skontes ga\r a)reth=s dida/skaloi ei)=nai polla/kis kathgorou=si tw=n maqhtw=n w(s a)dikou=si sfa=s, tou/s te misqou\s a)posterou=ntes, k.t.l. Cp. ib. 460 E.

ta\s e)nantiw/seis ‘contradictions’. Plat. Pol. 454 A, kat' au)to\ to\ o)/noma diw/kein tou= lexqe/ntos th\n e)nanti/wsin, i.e. to press a verbal discrepancy. Cp. Isocr. Evag. § 44, o(moi/ws ta\s e)n toi=s e)/rgois o(mologi/as w(/sper ta\s e)n toi=s lo/gois diafula/ttwn, observing consistency alike in word and deed.
tai=s do/cais See § 3, e)pisth/mhs, note.

a)lla\ kai\ toi=s tou\s pol. lo/g. u(pisx.] Isocr. now turns from the ‘Eristics’ to the second class of sofistai/ whom he censures. politikoi\ lo/goi meant properly Deliberative or Forensic Rhetoric: see Attic Orators, I. 90. Isocr. would limit the name to what he regards as the properly ‘political’ themes: forensic speeches are in his view merely sham politikoi/. Cp. below, § 20, and introd.

a)naisqh/tws — paralipei=n ‘So stupid are they, and so dull do they conceive others to be, that, although they compose worse than some amateurs extemporise, they yet promise to make their pupils such consummate speakers that they shall miss not one of the topics which their subjects afford’. w(/ste mhde
 paralipei=n: as if they said, ou)de
 a)
 parali/poite.

tai=s e)mpeiri/ais...th=| fu/sei ‘the lessons of experi ence’...‘the native power of the learner’. In Antid. §§ 186 — 191 Isocr. explains that three things go to make a consummate speaker, — fu/sis, paidei/a, e)mpeiri/a, — and that the first is by far the most important. The mistake of the teachers censured here is that they represent paidei/a (=h( tw=n lo/gwn e)pisth/mh) as being of certain and absolute efficacy.
o(/son e)/nestin e)n e(ka/sth| ‘the capability’ of each art; what it can, or cannot, do.
th\n filosofi/an i.e. the study of politikoi\ lo/goi, as opp. to natural power or practical experience in them: cp. § 1, note on a)lazoneu/esqai.

ou)d' a)
 e)la/xiston me/ros Cp. Lysias In Eratosth. § 22 (above, p. 70), e)gw\ d' e)boulo/mhn a)
 au)tou\s a)lhqh= le/gein: meth=n ga a)
 kai\ e)moi\ tou/tou ta)gaqou= ou)k e)la/xiston me/ros.
tou\s fluarou=ntas Dobree would omit tou/s, or change it to au)tou/s: needlessly, I think.

ta\s blasfhmi/as ‘for I perceive that the slanders which arise do not touch the offenders only, but affect all who are engaged in the same pursuit’, — Isocr. regarding himself as a sofisth/s, though not a)gelai=os, ‘of the herd’; see introd. Cp. the Antidosis, the apology for his life, of which a great part (§§ 167 — 269) is devoted to answering h( koinh\ peri\ tw=n sofistw=n diabolh/ (§ 168).

poihtikou= pra/gm ‘who are not aware that they are measuring a creative process by the analogy of an exact art’: i.e. to make a really good speech is a poihtiko\n pra=gma, — it demands some degree of inventive faculty and natural ability; but these sophists pretend that they can teach a man to speak well with as much certainty and precision as they can teach him his letters. tetagme/nh te/xnh, an art with fixed rules, where nothing is left to imagination or invention. For poihtikou=, cp. § 17, yuxh=s a)ndrikh=s kai\ docastikh=s. Dobree strangely says, ‘malim poiki/lou’.

mhde\n de\ tw=n au)tw=n ‘and is capable of finding topics different in all respects from those used by others’. — eu(/resis, invention, and ta/cis, arrangement, were the two provinces of pragmatiko\s to/pos, the treatment of subject-matter (Dionys. De Comp. I): as le/cis (in the narrow sense), diction, and su/nqesis, composition, were the two provinces of lektiko\s to/pos, the treatment of language.
th=s a)nomoio/thtos au)tw=n i.e. gramma/twn, grammar, the ‘art with fixed rules’, and lo/gwn, political speaking, the ‘creative’ effort.

i)diw=tai ‘Many of those who have studied this art [of ‘political discourse’] have remained private persons, while others, who have never attended the lectures of any professor, have proved themselves powerful orators and statesmen’: i)diw=tai, with an allusion to the case of Isocr. himself, who, as he tells us, was hindered by want of nerve and weakness of voice (to/lma — fwnh/, Panath. § 10) from entering public life. See Attic Orators, II. 5.
