toi=s peri\ ta\s e)mp. geg.] ‘those who have passed the ordeals of experience’ — in the Ecclesia and the law-courts.

zhtei=n...e)di/dacen i.e. their training gives them greater readiness of resource in the search for topics: they know
where to look for them. The very phrase to/poi, loci communes, meant those places (in the mind or memory) where classified arguments or illustrations are stored. ‘Those things which they now light upon at random [planw/menoi, temere], the discipline teaches them to find by a more ready method’: e)c e(toimote/rou, the comparative only, because, though a systematic training gives the speaker a surer command of his weapons, it cannot enable him to foresee the exact requirements of each occasion.

a)gwnista\s...lo/g. poihta/s ‘It cannot make them good debaters or masterly orators, but it can improve their natural power, and in many respects sharpen their insight’. — a)gwnisth/s, a combatant in real debate, opposed to a mere student or declaimer. Cleon's speech in Thuc. III. 37, 38 brings out this image of debate as an a)gw/n: Attic Orators, I. 39.

tw=n me\n i)dew=n ‘the forms’, or ‘elements’: strictly, the various kinds, classes of argument or ornament which prose composition employs. Cp. Antid. § 183, ta\s i)de/as a(pa/sas ai(=s o( lo/gos tugxa/nei xrw/menos: where, as here, it includes all the resources of literary art which can be reduced to formulas. Isocr. also uses i)de/ai in narrower senses, as (1) branches or styles of composition, Antid. § 11, or (2) figures of rhetoric, Panath. § 2. Attic Orators, II. 39.
toi=s r(a|di/ws u(pisxn ‘those who make rash promises’. Cp. § 9.

to\ de\ tou/twn ‘But to choose from among these resources [tou/twn fem., sc. tw=n i)dew=n] those which should be applied to each subject, — to combine and arrange them fitly, — further, not to miss the right moments [for using each], but to stud the whole discourse with points happily made, and to clothe it in phrase of gracious movement and melody, — this, I say [de/], demands much study, this is the task of a mind possessing vigour and imagination, and, for this, the learner must not only have the due natural gifts, — he must further learn to distinguish the branches (ei)/dh) of oratory, and must gain practice in their use. The teacher, again, must expound the theory (ta\ me/n) with all possible precision, so as to omit nothing that can be taught; while in the practice (tw=n loipw=n) he must set such an example that those who have already been formed in the rough (e)ktupwqe/ntas), and who are capable of imitating him, may from the outset (eu)qu/s) exhibit a style of more than ordinary elegance and finish’. — e)nqumh/masi, rhetorical syllogisms: see Attic Orators, II. 289. — docastikh=s, capable of forming a sagacious do/ca (e)pisth/mh being out of the question: cp. § 3, note); parodied by Plato, Gorg. 463 A, dokei= toi/nun moi, w)= *gorgi/a, ei)=nai/ ti e)pith/deuma (sc. Rhetoric) texniko\n
me\n ou)/, yuxh=s de\ stoxastikh=s kai\ a)ndrei/as, — ‘a soul with the courage of its conjectures’.

a)/rti a)nafuo/menoi, k.t.l. The sophists who have ‘lately sprung up’, and ‘recently embraced their pretentious callings’, are both the two preceding classes — (1) the Eristics, (2) the professors of politikoi\ lo/goi. These, he says, will at last be converted to his principles (tau/thn th\n u(po/qesin). He now comes to the third class.

te/xnas Artes, treatises on Rhetoric. The writers primarily meant are doubtless Corax of Syracuse (circ. 466 B.C.), and his pupil Tisias, on whom see Attic Orators, I. cxxi f.: perh. also Antiphon. Gorgias, Thrasymachus of Chalcedon, and Pôlos had also written te/xnai, but were probably less liable to the charge brought here — that of dealing exclusively with Forensic Rhetoric.

dika/zesqai ‘to conduct law-suits’, to frame kathgori/ai or a)pologi/ai. This was strictly true of Corax, whose express object was to help Sicilian litigants (Attic Orators, I. cxviii), and also perhaps of Tisias. Aristotle makes the very same criticism on the writers of te/xnai generally who had preceded him, Rhet. I. 1 § 10, peri\ me\n e)kei/nhs th=s dhmhgorikh=s pragmatei/as (the Rhetoric which trains for political debate), ou)de\n le/gousi, peri\ de\ tou= dika/zesqai pa/ntes peirw=ntai texnologei=n.

kai\ tau=ta referring to u(pe/sxonto, k.t.l.: ‘and this, when the accomplishment, in so far as it can be taught, is available for all other branches of oratory just as much as for the forensic’. — tou= pra/gmatos: cp. § 12, poihtikou= pra/gmatos, and note. He prefers this vague term, because it suits his doctrine that Rhetoric is not a mere tetagme/nh te/xnh, but largely a matter of natural aptitude. — ou)de\n ma=llon, k.t.l.: i.e. Rhetoric is sumbouleutikh/ and e)pideiktikh/ as well as dikanikh/.

tw=n peri\ ta\s e)/r. kalind.] ‘those who dabble in frivolous disputations’: cp. § 1, note on tw=n peri\ ta\s e)/ridas. — kalindei=sqai, like versari, but with a contemptuous sense, implying busy idleness (‘to potter about’), cp. Isocr. Philipp. § 81 (p. 136), toi=s e)pi\ tou= bh/matos kalindoume/nois, ‘the busy triflers of the platform’.

e)mmei/neien ‘abide by’, i.e. put into practice: — ‘(quibbling arguments, logi/dia), on which a man could not act in real life without instant and utter disaster’. — peri\ au)tw=n, sc. tw=n logidi/wn: ‘still they are wont to urge these in the name of virtue and of temperance’. — e)phgg., ‘profess’: cp. e)paggelma/twn, § 1.

e)pi\ tou\s polit. lo/gous] politikoi\ lo/goi, in the proper sense,
were such as belonged to practical civic life, i.e. either deliberative, sumbouleutikoi/, or forensic, dikanikoi/. These teachers, Isocr. says, neglect the real benefits which their study can confer (ta\ proso/nta au)toi=s a)gaqa/, that is, in the higher or deliberative branch), and undertake to be ‘teachers of meddlesomeness and greed’ (i.e. of the forensic branch, — the art of litigation).

kai/toi...w)felh/seien ‘Those, however, who choose to obey the precepts of this study [filosofi/as — the true lo/gwn paidei/a] will be aided by it to acquire moral worth much more surely than rhetorical skill’: polu\ qa=tton, because, as he has said (§ 10), the teacher cannot promise to make the pupil a good speaker. — Cp. Antid. §§ 274 f., p. 118.

w(s e)/sti dikaios. didakto/n Plat. Protag. 328 D (Socrates to Protagoras), th
 a)reth
 fh\|s didakto
 ei)=nai. ‘That virtue cannot be taught is a paradox of the same sort as the profession of Socrates that he knew nothing. Plato means to say that virtue is not brought to a man, but must be drawn out of him, — and cannot be taught by rhetorical discourses or citations from the poets’ (Jowett, Plato, I. 119). Cp. Antid. § 279, p. 120.

ou) mh\n a)lla/ ‘At the same time I think that the study of political oratory is most likely to be helpful [sun — ] in stimulating and forming such a disposition’: sunaskh=sai a)/n, i.e. will help a man to practise these virtues. — ou) mh/n: or. III. § 17, note, p. 284.

div2.p: . [Or. XV.] — ‘On the Antidosis’, or ‘Exchange of Properties’. — In the discourse ‘Against the Sophists’ Isocr. sought to distinguish his own conception of his calling — as a sofisth/s in the higher sense — from those of teachers whose views he deemed false and mischievous. In the present discourse — written 35 years later (353 B.C.) — he explains his own conception more fully, and defends his art (h( tw=n lo/gwn paidei/a) against its assailants generally. Taken together, these two essays express his whole literary and educational creed, both on its negative and on its positive side: they are the prologue and epilogue of his professional life.

Isocrates had lately been called upon to undertake the trierarchy, or to make exchange of properties (antidosis) with his challenger. The case had come to a trial; the trierarchy had been imposed upon Isocrates, and he had discharged it (§ 5). Vexed, however, by the general prejudice against his pursuits to which he felt that the verdict had been due, he determined to publish an Apologia — a discourse ‘which should be an image of his mind and life’ (§ 7). This he throws into the form of a speech made in court against one Lysimachus (§ 14), who, by
working on popular prejudice, is seeking to cast the burden of the trierarchy upon him. Much of the discourse is not, he allows, in the forensic style (§ 10); yet, by the concluding allusion to a verdict (§ 323), he aims, in some measure, at sustaining the fiction to the end.

It is known that, in 355 B.C., Isocrates had really been challenged to an exchange of properties by one Megacleides; and, being unable through illness to appear in court, had been represented by his adopted son Aphareus, whose speech on the occasion is quoted by Dionysius. Now this is probably the trial to which Isocrates refers as having been decided against him. It must have taken place at least a year before the date of this discourse, since it is implied that the public service had now been discharged (§ 5). Lysimachus is a fictitious person who stands for the Megacleides of the real trial. — Attic Orators, II. 134 f.
The following passage contains the pith of the whole discourse — his account of his filosofi/a, and the general grounds on which he rests its claims.

div3.p: peri\ me\n ou)=n tou/twn i.e. the practical worth for the State of those studies to which Isocr. has given his life, and the danger to Athens from the sukofa/ntai who denounce them: §§ 199 — 269. — to\ nu=n ei)=nai, ‘for the present’: so e(kw\n ei)=nai, to\ th/meron ei)=nai (Plat. Crat. 396 E), kata\ tou=to ei)=nai, (Prot. 317 A), to\ e)p' e)kei/nois ei)=nai (Xen. H. III. 5, 9). Goodwin § 100. 2.

sofi/as kai\ filosof ‘Wisdom and philosophy’. The term filosofi/a, said to have been invented by Pythagoras, prob. did not come into general use at Athens much before the time of Socrates. Cp. Thompson's note on Plat. Phaedr. 278 D. Attic Orators, II. 36.

pa/sais tai=s pragmatei/ais ‘for they [these notions, sofi/a, filosofi/a] have nothing to do with any legal issue’ — and would usually, therefore, be out of place in a forensic speech, such as this purports to be. Cp. Isocr. Ad Nicocl. [or. II] § 18, ta\s me\n e)rgasi/as au)toi=s kaqi/sth kerdale/as, ta\s de\ pragmatei/as e)pizhmi/ous, ‘make their industries profitable to them, and their lawsuits costly’.

e)peidh\ kai\ kri/nomai...kai\...fhmi/ ‘since I am being tried on such issues, and since, too,...’ The kai\ before kri/nomai = ‘both’ (not ‘actually’), answering to the kai\ before th\n kaloume/nhn. — peri\ tw=n toiou/twn = sofi/as kai\ filosofi/as, because the
action concerning the a)nti/dosis had been brought against him on the strength of a general prejudice against his pursuits. The real issue, for him, is to vindicate his past life.

th
 dikai/ws a)
 nomizome/nhn ‘that which might properly be deemed such’ — the genuine filosofi/a: = h(\ a)
 dikai/ws nomi/zoito.

e)pisth/mhn Cp. Adv. Sophist. § 3, note, p. 294. Isocr. does not deny e)pisth/mh in the Platonic sense, a possible knowledge of absolute truth, but merely an e)pisth/mh of the contingencies which may arise in practical life. His view means no more than that the future is uncertain. See Attic Orators, II. 52.
e)k tw=n loipw=n ‘in the next resort’: lit. ‘of the men who remain’, — men gifted with e)pisth/mh being out of the question.

ou(/tw...sfo/dra...kai\ polu/ The adverb sfo/dra (the adjective would have been sfodra/) goes both with para/doca and with polu\...a)festw=ta. For the combination sfo/dra polu/, cp. or. IX. § 48, polu\ li/an (= li/an polu/), note, p. 291.

th
 a)rxh/n adverbial, ‘at the outset’: Andoc. De Pace § 20, e)ch=n ga au)toi=s kai\ th
 a)rxh
 e)w=sin *)orxomeni/ous au)tono/mous ei)rh/nhn a)/gein. In negative sentences, a)rxh/n, without art., = ‘at all’ (omnino).

w(s a(/r) e)gw/, k.t.l. ‘as to suppose (a)/ra) that, standing in peril as I do [of your verdict], I would have resolved to use arguments which contravene your views, did I not consider that they follow from those which I have already urged, and that the proofs by which I can support them are sound and clear’. He means, ‘It will startle you to hear that virtue cannot be taught: but a definition of the intellectual and moral scope which I claim for my filosofi/a is a necessary supplement (a)ko/louqos) to what I have already said on its practical worth’.

ou) mh\n a)ll), k.t.l. ‘At the same time, I grant that their characters are likely to be improved and ennobled’: cp. Adv. Sophist. § 15, p. 115, au)tou\s d' a)\n au(tw=n proaga/goi kai\ pro\s polla\ fronimwte/rws diakei=sqai poih/seien.
th=s...th\n du/namin t. e)xou/shs ‘that which is truly what the term imports’, = th=s o)rqw=s o)nomazome/nhs, that pleoneci/a which means ple/on e)/xein in the highest sense: see below, § 282.

p. ta\s u(poqe/seis, k.t.l. ‘he is certain not to take his themes from the dishonest or frivolous controversies of private litigation, but from great and noble subjects which concern the welfare of mankind and the interests of the
Commonwealth: since, if he does not find such themes, he will utterly fail to achieve his objects’, — viz., will fail to deserve e)/painos and timh/. — i)di/wn sumbol., ‘private contracts’, i.e. all the transactions between men which give rise to di/kai: cp. Lys. In Erat. § 98, mikrw=n e(/neka sumbolai/wn (for small debts), note, p. 259. So in Arist. Rhet. I. 1 § 10 Forensic Rhetoric is h( peri\ ta\ sunalla/gmata.

mega/las kai\ kala/s Earlier in this speech Isocr. has given examples of what he means by mega/lai u(poqe/seis, — viz. the comparative claims of Athens and Sparta to the hegemony (§ 59), treated in his own Panegyricus: and the measures needed for a reform of Athenian policy (§ 65), treated in his De Pace.

tw=n pra/cewn ‘Next, he will select the most impressive and the most beneficent of the actions which illustrate his subject’. Thus, in showing that Athens had a better claim than Sparta to lead Greece, Isocr. adduces (in the Panegyricus) the great services of Athens to Greece: these are pra/ceis suntei/nousai pro\s th\n u(po/qesin, historical facts bearing on this theme. — o( de\ ta\s toiau/tas, k.t.l.: i.e. the habitual contemplation of noble actions, as illustrating a noble subject, will educate the intelligence no less than the literary faculty of the student — will give him to\ eu)= fronei=n as well as to\ eu)= le/gein.

th=s a)reth=s ‘virtue’. Cp. Adv. Sophist. § 21 (p. 116), polu\ a)\n qa=tton pro\s e)piei/keian h)\ pro\s r(htorei/an w)felh/seien (h( filosofi/a), and note, p. 299. The argument is that the professor of persuasion will cultivate virtue, because virtue is persuasive.

tw=n eu)= diakeime/nwn ‘men of good disposition’ (cp. or. IX. § 49, p. 109, w)mo/tata pro\s tou\s *(/ellhnas diakei/menoi), opp. to oi( diabeblhme/noi, ‘men of tarnished character’. The fallacy peeps out in the tacit substitution of tw=n eu)= diakeime/nwn for tw=n dokou/ntwn eu)= diakei=sqai: for, even granting that the surest way to seem anything is to be it, yet for Isocr.'s argument it would suffice that one should seem without being.

ta\s e)k tou= bi/ou gegen ‘the proofs which have been afforded by a man's life’: i.e. apart from the logical value of the speaker's reasonings (pi/steis ai( u(po\ tou= lo/gou peporisme/nai), he will be the more persuasive in proportion as his past conduct makes it probable that he is sincere.

th\n th=s eu)noi/as du/namin ‘the power of good-will’ — the eu)/noia felt by the hearers for a man whom they believe to be good. Arist. Rhet. II. 1 says that h)qikh\ pi/stis — the persuasiveness arising from the speaker's qualities as conceived by the hearer — has three elements, — the intelligence (fro/nhsis),
the moral worth (a)reth/), and the good-will (eu)/noia) towards themselves, which the hearers recognise in him. The eu)noi/as du/namis of which Isocr. speaks here means, the power of the good-will which the hearers feel for the speaker: thus it answers to the whole h)qikh\ pi/stis of Aristotle, and not merely to the third element therein.

ta\ ei)ko/ta — ta\ tekmh/ria — pa=n to\ tw=n pi/stewn ei)=dos ‘that probabilities (ei)ko/ta), proofs (tekmh/ria), and the rhetorical instruments of persuasion generally (pa=n to\ tw=n pi/stewn ei)=dos), are valid only for that particular occasion to which they may severally be applied’, — whereas a good reputation creates in every case a presumption that its possessor is acting rightly. — ei)ko/ta. The topic of ei)ko/s, general probability, had been prominent in the early te/xnai, as those of Corax and Tisias: see Attic Orators, I. cxxi. Arist. defines the enthymeme, or rhetorical syllogism, as a sullogismo\s e)c ei)ko/twn kai\ shmei/wn — i.e. drawn (1) from (mere) general likelihoods: (2) from particular signs which may, or may not, be conclusive. — tekmh/ria here=merely ‘sure signs’, as opp. to ‘probabilities’: not, in Arist.'s technical sense, the demonstrative as dist. from the fallible shmei=on: cp. Antiph. De Caed. Her. § 81, note, p. 215. — pa=n to\ tw=n pi/stewn ei)=dos = ai( pi/steis genikw=s. Arist. distinguishes pi/stis (1) logikh/, (2) h)qikh/, (3) paqhtikh/: here Isocr. means (1), and perhaps (3), but treats (2) as something of a different and higher order.

o(\ dusxere/staton h)=n tw=n r(hq ‘the most invidious, as I felt, of the terms which I used’: h)=n, was, as I felt and hinted at the time, referring to § 275, where pleoneci/a is named with an apologetic explanation that it is not employed in its common sense. Plat. Rep. 522 A, h)=n h( mousikh\ a)nti/strofos th=s gumnastikh=s, ei) me/mnhsai. Goodwin § 11. 6.

paralogizome/nous ‘making a false reckoning’, cheating in bills or accounts (not ‘reasoning falsely’): cp. Dem. Adv. Aphob. I. § 29, a)=ra mikro/n ti kai\ e)c a)fanou=s poqen kai\ paralogi/sasqai r(a/|dion, a)ll) ou) fanerw=s ou(twsi\ mikrou= dei= tri/a ta/lanta tau=ta a)nhrpa/kasin.
ma=llon e)lattou=ntai ‘are at a greater disadvantage’: cp. e)lasswqei/s, Antiph. De Caed. Her. § 19, note, p. 212.
kai\ nu=n ple/on e)/xein ‘are not only more fortunate now [in this mortal life], but will receive the better portion from the gods’.

kai\ tai=s a)lhqei/ais = toi=s e)/rgois, ‘not only are the realities of the case thus’. Philemon frag. 40, tai=s a)lhqei/aisin. The tendency to use the plurals of abstract nouns, common in later Greek, is marked in Isocr. Cp. § 284, tai=s
kakohqei/ais: § 288, tai=s a)kmai=s: § 292, ta\s e)pimelei/as: § 300, ta\s pikro/thtas: see also Areop. § 44, p. 154.

ou)de\ toi=s o)no/masin ‘some people do not even employ the names of things in their natural sense’ (much less distinguish between the things themselves). Thuc. III. 82 (of the moral confusion arising from the passions of party strife), th\n ei)wqui=an a)ci/wsin tw=n o)noma/twn e)s ta\ e)/rga a)nth/llacan th=| dikaiw/sei.

bwmolox. — eu)fuei=s ‘buffoons, who can mock and mimic, are said to have ‘wit’, — a description which should be reserved for those whose wit is most happily bent towards virtue’. By some such turn as this we may express the paronomasia in eu)fuei=s — a)/rista pefuko/tas. Cp. Adv. Sophist. § 14, p. 114, where the intellectual sense of eu)fuh/s is uppermost.

tai=s kakohqei/ais, k.t.l. ‘who practise malignity and villainy in all their forms’ [the plur. as in § 283], ‘who make petty gains, but acquire an evil repute’ [if nothing else]: cp. Adv. Sophist. § 4, p. 111, mikrou= ke/rdous, § 9, p. 112, th=| mikro/thti tw=n misqw=n.

teratologi/as ‘who give the name of philosophers to those who neglect necessary things and affect the marvellous lore of the old sophists’: a reference, probably to the Socratics, and especially to the Platonic dialogues. teratologi/a, k.t.l., possibly alludes more particularly to the traces of Pythagoreanism and to the cosmogonic speculations in Plato.

tou\s newte/rous Cp. Panath. § 29, tou\s dialo/gous tou\s e)ristikou\s kaloume/nous, oi(=s oi( me\n new/teroi ma=llon xai/rousi tou= de/ontos, tw=n de\ presbute/rwn ou)dei/s e)stin o(/stis a)\n a)nektou\s au)tou\s ei)=nai fh/seien, and note on Adv. Soph. § 1, p. 293.

*)enneakrou/nou Thuc. II. 15, kai\ th=| krh/nh| th=| nu=n me\n tw=n tura/nnwn [Peisistratus, Paus. I. 14. 1] ou(/tw skeuasa/ntwn *)enneakrou/nw| kaloume/nh|, to\ de\ pa/lai fanerw=n tw=n phgw=n ou)sw=n [when the natural springs, phgai/ opp. to krh/nh, sprang directly from the rock] *kallirro/h| w)nomasme/nh|, e)kei=noi/ te [the old Athenians] e)ggu\s ou)/sh| ta\ plei/stou a)/cia e)xrw=nto, kai\ nu=n e)/ti a)po\ tou= a)rxai/ou pro/ te gamikw=n kai\ e)s a)/lla tw=n i(erw=n nomi/zetai tw=| u(/dati xrh=sqai.

skirafei/ois ‘gambling-houses’. Stephanus Byz. p. 607, to\ skira/feion...dhloi= to
 to/pon ei)s o(
 oi( kubeutai\ suni/asi: kai\ o( skira/frouros shmai/nei to
 a)ko/laston kubeuth/n. Pollux VII. 203 quotes skira/fia and to
 skirafeuth/n from the *kubeutai/ of Amphis. The Etym. Magn., p. 717. 28, has skeira/fia, ta\ kubei=a: and notices three derivations, — from skei/rafos, an o)/rganon kubeutiko/n (dice-box?) — *ski/rafos, a gambler — and *skira\s *)aqhna=, in whose temple (at *ski/ron, near Athens) e)kubeu/onto.
Harpocrat. *skira/fia...e)/legon ta\ kubeuth/ria, e)peidh\ die/tribon e)n *ski/rw| oi( kubeu/ontes, w(s *qeo/pompos (the historian) e)n th=| penthkosth=| u(poshmai/nei. Meineke Frag. Com. 484, Müller Frag. Hist. I. 322. — Cp. Lys. Pro Mantith. § 11, o(/soi peri\ ku/bous h)\ po/tous, k.t.l., note, p. 245.

th=s h(liki/as tau/ths ‘those who profess to care for persons of this age’ — i.e. tw=n ne/wn — alluding, not to official paidono/moi, but to those who dissuade young men from following the filosofi/a of Isocr.
oi(=s a)/cion h)=n...xa/rin e)/xein ‘who might well have been grateful’: h)=n like xrh=n, e)/dei, Goodwin § 49. 3.

dusmene\s...au)tw=n ‘The tribe of informers are so distinctly the public enemies’ [i.e. so hostile to public morality] ‘that, so far from being disposed to censure those who pay a ransom of 20 or 30 minas for the paramours who are to help them in squandering the rest of their substance, they positively rejoice in the dissolute acts of such men’. — luome/nois: i.e. they ransom dou=lai from those into whose hands they had come as prisoners of war. Cp. Antiph. De Caed. Her. § 20, p. 14, ta/ te a)ndra/poda a(\ e)/dei au)to\n a)polu=sai, kai\ oi( *qra=|kes oi( luso/menoi.
t. tai=s a)kmai=s ‘that youthful prime’: for plur., cp. § 283, tai=s a)lhqei/ais, note.

e)k pai/dwn ‘from boyhood’. Dem. In Mid. § 154, ka)gw\ me\n kat' e)kei/nous tou\s xro/nous e)trihra/rxoun eu)qu\s e)k pai/dwn e)celqw/n. Properly said of one who is e)/fhbos (aet. 17 — 20) but not yet technically a)nh/r.

proestw=ta ‘who duly and meetly watches over his own youth’. Contrast Helen. Enc. § 58, p. 108, kakw=s bouleusame/nous peri\ th=s au(tw=n h(liki/as. Cp. Eur. Androm. 220, xei/ron' a)rse/nwn no/son | tau/thn nosou=men, a)lla\ prou)/sthmen kalw=s: ‘we have this weakness more than men, but ever rule it well’: lit. ‘administer’, i.e. control it.

h)\ tw=n au(tou= neut., ‘his property’: but e(te/rwn masc., ‘other men’. For the thought that self-government (e)gkra/teia, perfected in swfrosu/nh) should precede the attempt to rule others, cp. Plat. Gorg. p. 491.
w(s...sumbebhko/tos ‘on the ground that they have been endowed with a good and noble gift’: sumb., as an ‘accident’ of genius, opp. to the skill gained by mele/th and filoponi/a.
sumfe/rei, k.t.l. ‘It is expedient in all cases, and especially in the case of oratory, that credit should be won by the efforts of study rather than by the gifts of fortune’.

o(/pws a)\n tu/xwsin, k.t.l. sc. xrw/menoi: ‘use their eloquence at random: while those who have acquired this faculty by study and reflection say nothing without consideration, and so commit fewer errors in practical affairs’: i.e. the discretion trained by study will be carried into pra/ceis, real life. Cp. § 277.

ka/ll. politeu/esqe, k.t.l. ‘nor because you have the best constitution, and are most conservative of the laws bequeathed to you by your ancestors’: — implying that all this is true of Athens, though not its distinctive glory. Isocr. thought, however, that the Athens of his day had departed too much from the lines of the old Democracy: see Areopagiticus, §§ 36 — 55, p. 151, with notes, pp. 340 f.

th\n fro/nhsin...tou\s lo/gous ‘by unequalled excellence of training in the twofold province of thought and of expression’. fro/nhsis, as dist. from military and political ability, means here the general cultivation of the intelligence by literature and art.

th=| paidei/a| tau/th| = th\n tw=n lo/gwn paidei/an (§ 168), ‘this discipline’ of thought and expression. — sumfora=|, in the forensic sense, of an adverse verdict. Cp. Andoc. De Myst. § 86, e(wrw=men o(/ti polloi=s tw=n politw=n ei)=en sumforai/ (penal disabilities), toi=s me\n kata\ no/mous, toi=s de\ kata\ yhfi/smata. Dem. In Mid. § 17, a)stratei/as e(a/lw kai\ ke/xrhtai sumfora=|.
gegenh=sqai ‘to be established’ as the teacher: emphatic perf. Cp. Thuc. II. 41, le/gw th\n pa=san po/lin *(ella/dos pai/deusin ei)=nai.

a)=qla...gumna/sia...e)mpeiri/an Athens offers to the students of oratory (1) the greatest prizes, — i.e. political power or literary fame: (2) ‘the most numerous and most various fields of exercise’, gumna/sia — viz. the law-courts, the ecclesia, the public recitations: (3) experience, e)mpeiri/a, — the result of using these opportunities.

kai\ th
 th=s fwnh=s, k.t.l. ‘Further, men deem that the wide currency (koino/thta) and standard character (metrio/thta) of the Attic idiom, no less than a general flexibility of mind and love of literature, contribute not a little to the formation of an orator; and hence they conceive, not without reason, that all masters of eloquence are pupils of Athens’. metrio/thta: because the Attic dialect — afterwards the basis of the koinh\ dia/lektos — represents a temperate compromise between the Ionic and the Doric, — elastic without too much softness, precise and vigorous without harshness. In Thuc. 7. 63 Nicias reminds the me/toikoi serving in the Athenian army that their familiarity with the Attic dialect
had been a recommendation for them to all Greeks: th=s... fwnh=s...th=| e)pisth/mh|...e)qauma/zesqe kata\ th
 *(ella/da. — eu)trapeli/an: cp. Thuc. II. 41 (of the typical Athenian), e)pi\ plei=st' a)
 ei)/dh kai\ meta\ xari/twn ma/list' a)
 eu)trape/lws to\ sw=ma au)/tarkes pare/xesqai. Here, eu)trapeli/a=‘flexibility of intelligence’: not exactly ‘versatility’, as with Thuc., nor yet ‘liveliness’, ‘wit’, as with Aristotle (Eth. N. II. 7. § 13).

ou)de
 ga a)ll) h)/...a)cioi=en ‘for you will have virtually pronounced yourselves as unjust as the Lacedaemonians would be, and will have acted as they would act, if they were to think of fining those who practised warlike exercises, or the Thessalians, if they proposed to punish those who cultivated skill in horsemanship’. — th
 toiau/thn and o(/moion are both to be connected with w(/sper a)
 (sc. e(autw=n kateyhfisme/noi ei)/hsan). — *lakedaim.: cp. Arist. Polit. v [VIII] 4. § 4, e)/ti d' au)tou\s tou\s *la/kwnas i)/smen, e(/ws me
 au)toi\ prosh/dreuon tai=s filoponi/ais, u(pere/xontas tw=n a)/llwn, nu=n de\ kai\ toi=s gumnasi/ois kai\ toi=s polemikoi=s a)gw=si leipome/nous tw=n a)/llwn: ou) ga tw=| tou\s ne/ous gumna/zein tou=ton to
 tro/pon die/feron, a)lla\ tw=| mo/non mh\ pro\s a)skou=ntas a)skei=n [i.e. because they studied these things, while their competitors did not]. — *qettaloi/: ‘Breeding the finest horses in Greece, they were distinguished for their excellence as cavalry; but their infantry is little noticed’ (Grote, II. 370).
u(pe\r w(=n=peri\ w(=n: cp. u(pe\r au)tw=n, Adv. Sophist. § 2, note, p. 293.

po/lin — a)/stu Cp. § 296, th=s po/lews, kat' e)coxh/n for Athens: Lys. In Agor. § 46, w(/ste mhde
 diafe/rein th=s e)laxi/sths po/lews th
 po/lin. — a)/stu: Athenians spoke of Athens as a)/stu (without the art.), ‘town’: cp. Philochorus frag. 4 (Frag. Hist. I. 384), a)/stu de\ proshgo/reusan th
 po/lin, where he derives it from sth=nai, as the place where wanderers (noma/des) ‘fixed their abode’. a)/stu, for va)/stu, is the Sanscr. vâstu, place, house (Curt. Gr. Et. § 206), the local habitation of the po/lis or civic society. po/lis is akin to Sanscr. pur (Cawnpore), from root par (pel, ple), denoting fulness (whence also polu/s): hence (1) a throng: (2) a town.

dia\ th=s e(t. w)mo/t.] ‘than receive benefits through the rude hands of others’. The meaning is not that the mercies of others are cruel, but that their way of doing good is harsh. The flatterers of Athens alluded, of course, to Spartan manners.

oi( de\ tau_ta...kathgor.] ‘Others [=oi( dusko/lws pro\s u(ma=s e)/xontes, § 299, opp. to oi( me/n, ib.] disparage these merits, and, recounting the malignities and disasters of the slander
mongers, denounce Athens at large as unsocial and cruel’: i.e. they quote the bitter things which the sukofa/ntai say of Athenian life, and then point to the penalties which these calumniators sometimes incur, — inferring that Athens is savage because such men are punished.
peripoiou=ntas ‘surrounding the name of Athens with infamy’ (not peripoiou/menoi, ‘winning’ disgrace for her). Cp. Plat. Apol. 35 A, ai)sxu/nhn th=| po/lei peria/ptein.

stefani/tais A wreath of wild olive at Olympia; of laurel at Delphi; of pine at Nemea; of parsley at the Isthmus. Cp. Plut. Praec. Ger. Reip. XXVII. 820 C (simple rewards, of an honorary, not a substantial kind, ought to suffice in a Republic), w(/sper ou)k a)rguri/thn ou)de\ dwri/thn a)gw=na politei/as a)gwnizome/nois, a)lla\ i(ero\n w(s a)lhqw=s kai\ stefani/thn, ‘seeing that the competition of political life is not for money or gifts, but in truth a sacred contest, of which the prize is a wreath’ (as in the great national a)gw=nes of Greece).
prwteu/ein prokri/n ‘would place us in the first rank’. For the pleonasm, cp. Xen. Cyr. II. 3. 8, tou=to proke/kritai ei)=nai be/ltiston.

div2.p: . [Or. IV.] — The title means, ‘A Discourse for a Public Festival’: in this case, for the Olympic festival of 380 B.C. The duty of Hellenic unity against the barbarian had already been the theme of Gorgias and of Lysias in speeches delivered at Olympia. It is not likely that, like theirs, the oration of Isocrates was recited at the festival by its author. His want of nerve and voice, and much in the composition itself, would probably have deterred him from such an attempt. The discourse may, indeed, have been recited for him; but it is more likely that it was first introduced to the Greek public by copies circulated at Olympia, and sent to cities in which Isocrates had friends among the leading men.

His appeal to Panhellenic patriotism was made at a time when such patriotism was sorely needed. By the Peace of Antalcidas in 387 B.C. Artaxerxes II. had become master of the Asiatic Greeks, and ultimate arbiter in the affairs of western Hellas; the Aegean, no longer protected by an Athenian fleet, was infested by pirates; the party strife which the decarchies had exasperated was everywhere filling the smaller cities with bloodshed; and Sparta, regardless of the autonomy which the Peace had guaranteed to every state, was using these troubles for her own ends. In 385 B.C. the Spartans had destroyed Mantineia; in 383, besieged Olynthus; in 382, seized the Cadmeia; in 380, besieged Phlius.

The Panegyricus falls into two main divisions. In the first (§§ 1 — 132) Isocrates urges that Athens and Sparta, laying aside their jealousies, should assume the joint leadership of Greece. He argues that, if Sparta at present holds the first place, Athens has the better historical claim to it; and that, therefore, a compromise might well be made. In the second part (§§ 133 — 189) he shows the direction in which the forces of Greece, once consolidated, ought to be turned — namely against Persia.

The Panegyricus is the earliest and the most complete expression of its author's ruling political idea — the idea of a Panhellenic War on Persia. This, he believed, would heal Greek discord, liberate the Asiatic Greeks, draft the roving and lawless paupers who infested Greece into new Asiatic settlements, and bring wealth into Greece Proper. (See the Life of Isocr., Attic Orators, II. 20 f.) The tradition that Isocr. spent ten or more years on this discourse (Quint. X. 4: Plut. Mor. 350 E) shows the ancient feeling that it was a masterpiece of careful work. It is, indeed, admirable alike for finished brilliancy of composition and for the lucid power with which a wide range of topics and a multitude of details are marshalled in subordination to the central thought.

div3.head: Motives for an Invasion of Persia: §§ 160 — 186.
div3.p: w(/ste moi dokei= The general and permanent causes of Persian weakness have just been stated: viz. that the country cannot have good soldiers while the mass of the people is an unruly, nerveless and slavish mob, or good generals while the Persians of the upper classes are insolent and abject by turns, with pampered bodies and craven spirits. He now goes on to urge that the present moment is peculiarly favourable for an attack by the united forces of Greece.

o( parw
 kairo/s, o(
 ou)k a)fete/on So Bekker, Baiter and Sauppe with the first hand of the Urbino ms. (*g). Between kairo/s and o(
 ou)k a)fete/on the Ambrosian ms. (*e) and the corrector's hand in the margin of *g insert ou(= safe/steron ou)de/n, i.e. ‘than which nothing could be a clearer summons’. Cp. Dem. Olynth. I. § 2, o( me
 ou)=n parw
 kairo/s, w)= a)/ndres *)aq., mo/non ou)xi\ le/gei fwnh
 a)fiei\s o(/ti tw=n pragma/twn u(mi=n a)ntilhpte/on e)sti/n.
ti/ ga\r a)\n kai\ boulhqei=men ‘What further advantage could we desire in prospect of a war with Persia, beyond those which are already assured to us?’

*ai)/guptos — *ku/pros (1) This revolt of Egypt is not known from other sources, but is noticed again in the
Philippus, § 101. From Panegyr. § 140 it appears that Egypt had held out for three years against three of the best Persian generals, and had finally discomfited them. (2) The war between Persia and Evagoras, king of the Cyprian Salamis, seems to have begun in 385 B.C., and to have lasted ten years: at this time a Persian fleet was blockading Salamis, § 134. See Attic Orators, II. 158 and notes.
*foini/kh — *suri/a — *tu/ros Evagoras had ‘ravaged Phoenicia, stormed Tyre, made Cilicia revolt from the Persian king’: Isocr. Evag. (or. IX.) § 62.

*luki/as ‘Of Lycia no Persian has ever become master’. Lycia had been tributary to Persia (Her. III. 90) from the time of its conquest by Harpagus, the general of Cyrus: but the warlike dwellers in the Lycian highlands had not been thoroughly tamed. e)kra/thse, then,=‘subjugated’ as dist. from h)=rce ‘(nominally) reigned over’. Cp. Her. II. 1 (Cambyses goes against Egypt) a)/llous te paralabw\n tw=n h)=rxe (his Asiatic subjects) kai\ dh\ kai\ *(ellh/nwn tw=n e)pekra/tee, ‘over whom he had the mastery’.

*(ekato/mnws Hecatomnus, Greek prince of Caria, had been appointed admiral of the Persian fleet at the beginning of the war with Evagoras, but had afterwards become disaffected, and had secretly supplied Evagoras with money: Diod. XIV. 98. — e)pi/staqmos: prop. ‘quarter-master’, as supervising staqmoi/, stations or quarters: a term for the military governors (properly subordinate to the satra/pai) in the Persian provinces: so Panegyr. § 120 the Persian king dictates to Greece, mo/non ou)k e)pista/qmous e)n tai=s po/lesi kaqista/s. A Greek prince tributary to Persia was esp. duna/sths.

th\n *)asi/an paroikou=sin, k.t.l. ‘from Cnidus [in Caria, at the s. w. corner of Asia Minor] to Sinope [on the Euxine] Greek settlements fringe the coast of Asia’ (th=s *)asi/as th\n parali/an, Ep. IX. § 8). para/ in the compound here with accus.=‘along’: but paroikei=n tisin, to live near or among, Thuc. I. 71, III. 93.
ou(\s ou) dei=, k.t.l. ‘and these we need not incite to war, — we have only not to restrain them’ (and they will go to war of their own accord).

o(rmhthri/wn ‘Now, when such bases of operation have been established, and when Asia is encompassed by hostile forces so great, why need we examine the probable issues in minute detail? When they [the Persians] are unable to cope with small fractions of our strength, it is plain what their situation would be, if they were forced to grapple with the whole’. — o(rmhthri/wn: i.e. Egypt, Cyprus, Tyre, Cilicia,
and the Greek cities of the coast, — viewed as so many points from which the assailants of Persia will set out (o(/qen o(rmh/sontai): Polyb. I. 17, ei)s tau/thn (th\n po/lin) sunh/qroisan...ta\s duna/meis, o(rmhthri/w| (headquarters) kri/nontes xrh=sqai tau/th| th=| po/lei pro\s to\n po/lemon.
e)rrwmeneste/rws ‘more vigorously’. Isocr. prefers this form: but cp. (e.g.) e)rrwmene/steron, Antid. § 72, Archid. § 101: safe/steron, Adv. Sophist. § 16: a)kribe/steron, Antid. § 279.

au)ta/s, k.t.l. ‘But if we are the first to occupy them [the cities on the coast], it is likely that the populations of Lydia, Phrygia and the upper [interior] country generally will be at the mercy of those who hold these bases of attack’: e)nteu=qen=e)k tw=n e)pi\ qala/tth| po/lewn.

u(steri/santes Referring to the subjugation by Persia of the Greek cities on the Ionian seaboard (500 — 495 B.C.). The Greeks of Greece Proper (oi( pate/res h(mw=n, Spartans as well as Athenians) having ‘allowed the barbarians to get the start of them’, and ‘abandoned’ the Ionians to their fate, were afterwards forced to fight, without Asiatic allies, against the whole strength of Persia. Had they gone to Asia soon enough, they might have vanquished in succession (e)n me/rei) each of the nations that made up the Persian host. — e)qnw=n: Her. VII. 61 f. enumerates 46 nations or tribes as represented in the land-force of Xerxes.
de/deiktai ‘It has been proved’ (by experience): cp. Archid. § 4, ei) me\n ga\r h)=n dedeigme/non, w(/ste tou\s me\n presbute/rous peri\ a(pa/ntwn ei)de/nai to\ be/ltiston, k.t.l.

e)pistw=sin ‘they have come upon us’: cp. Her. IV. 203, e)pei\ e)pi\ th=| *kurhnai/wn po/li e)pe/sthsan, when the Persian army suddenly appeared before Cyrene: Isocr. Evag. § 58, mikrou= dei=n e)/laqen au)to\n e)pi\ to\ basi/leion e)pista/s, before Artaxerxes was aware, Cyrus was almost at his palace gates.

proecamarto/ntes...e)phnwrqw/santo ‘Our fathers, after making an error in the first instance’ [by failing to support the Ionians in their revolt], ‘retrieved all these faults when they were confronted with the most urgent perils’ [in the Persian invasions].

e(ka/stwn, k.t.l. ‘The Persian king does not rule the peoples of Asia by their consent [e(ko/ntwn, predicate], but by surrounding himself [poihsa/menos, causal] with a power which overmatches those peoples taken singly’ [e(ka/stwn]: if they unite, and are helped from Greece, they will prevail. — boulhqe/ntes=ei) boulhqei=men, Goodwin § 109.

e)pi\ th=s nu=n h(liki/as ‘in the present generation’: strictly, in the time of the men who are now capable of active service. In Antid. § 290, etc., th=s h(liki/as=‘youth’, but it is the context which so defines it: here it has the military sense, oi( e)n h(liki/a| (Thuc. VIII. 75) being opposed to a)xrei=oi. — tw=n sumforw=n. Men who at this time (380 B.C.) were 40 years old would have known the closing years of the Peloponnesian War, the troubles bred by the Spartan dekarxi/ai, the Corinthian War, and, generally, that widespread distress and disorder of which Isocr. speaks below (§ 168 f.). See Attic Orators, II. 17.

pole/mous kai\ sta/seis With this picture cp. the following, abridged from Isocr. Epist. IX. §§ 8 — 10 (date, about 356 B.C.): ‘It is strange that no powerful statesman or speaker has yet taken pity on the miserable condition of Hellas. Every part of it is full of war, factions, massacres, woes unnumbered. Most wretched of all are those Greeks on the seaboard of Asia whom by the treaty [of Antalcidas, 387 B.C.] we gave over, not merely to barbarians, but to those of our race who are barbarian in all save speech. These roving desperadoes, under any chance leader, form armies larger and better than those of the settled communities; armies which do trifling damage to Persia, but bring desolation to the Greek cities which they visit: they slay, they banish, they violate, they plunder’. — See Attic Orators, II. 244.
e)pikourei=n ‘to serve as mercenaries’: Thuc. II. 33, e)pikou/rous tina\s prosemisqw/sato — like ce/noi, an honourable name for misqofo/roi.

sugkeime/nais ‘composed’, ‘invented’ by the [tragic] poets. In pure Attic of the classical time kei=mai is the perf. passive of ti/qhmi, te/qeimai is the perf. middle: e.g. a father te/qeitai o)/noma paidi/, but paidi\ kei=tai o)/noma: cp. Shilleto on Thuc. I. 37, who quotes as an exception, belonging to the early decadence, Menand. frag. 65, tw=| me\n to\ sw=ma diateqeime/nw| kakw=s (=diakeime/nw|).

e)forw=ntes Not, I think, merely ‘gazing upon’, but ‘seeing in their own lifetime’, or ‘with their own eyes’ (and not merely in legends from the past); cp. Xen. Cyr. VIII. 7. 7, tou\s fi/lous e)pei=don di' e)mou= eu)dai/monas genome/nous, ‘lived to see their friends made prosperous’. So Il. XXII. 61, kaka\ po/ll' e)pido/nta, | ui(=a/s t' o)llume/nous, k.t.l.: and other passages quoted by Thompson on Plato Gorg. 473 C, au)to/s te lwbhqei\s kai\ tou\s au(tou= e)pidw\n pai=das (lwbhqe/ntas).
eu)hqei/as ‘simplicity’. — a)ndrw=n, individuals as opp. to whole countries.

*)itali/a — *sikeli/a Italy. In 389 — 387 B.C. Dionysius I. had reduced successively Caulon, Hipponium and Rhegium in Magna Graecia: Diod. XIV. 106 ff. Sicily. He had surrendered Acragas, Himera, Selīnus, etc., to Carthage, and had brought other towns — as Naxos, Leontini, Messene — under his own power: Diod. XIII. 114.

e)kde/dontai ‘have been abandoned’ [not ‘restored’ to a lawful possessor, the sense of e)kdi/dwmi in Il. III. 459] — by the Peace of Antalcidas: below, § 175. — ta\ loipa\ me/rh: Greece Proper as opp. to (1) Sicily and Magna Graecia, (2) Asiatic Hellas.
tw=n dunasteuo/ntwn ‘the leading statesmen’,=oi( proestw=tes h(mw=n, § 172. With the same meaning he says in Epist. IX. § 8, qauma/zw de\ kai\ tw=n a)/llwn tw=n pra/ttein h)\ le/gein duname/nwn.
ei)pei=n...e)nqumhqh=nai ‘to expound or [even] to devise’ a remedy: Thuc. VIII. 68 (of Antiphon) kra/tistos e)nqumhqh=nai... kai\ a(\ gnoi/h ei)pei=n, a master of device and of expression.

e)xrh=n...a)/cioi An iambic trimeter. In this and other cases where an accidental verse occurs in prose, it may usually be noticed that the rhythm or division of clauses imposed by the sense would have prevented the metre from being perceived in speaking: thus, here, there is a pause at au)tou/s, and the words ei)/per h)=san a)/cioi th=s parou/shs, k.t.l., cohere closely. So in Dem. Olynth. I. § 5 (quoted by Sandys), dh=lon ga/r e)sti toi=s *)olunqi/ois, o(/ti k.t.l., the metrical effect is destroyed by the coherence of o(/ti with the following words.

ei)shgei=sqai kai\ sumbouleu/ein ‘to introduce and discuss [not necessarily ‘advocate’, though Isocr. implies this] the project of the war with Persia’: ‘the war’, because the project had long been familiar to the Greeks: thus Agesilaus had entertained it, Isocr. Philipp. § 85.

tuxo
 me
 ga/r, k.t.l. ‘Perchance they would have achieved something; but even if they had been baffled, still the counsels bequeathed by them would have been as oracles for the future’. — tuxo/n, acc. abs., Goodwin § 110. 2. — proapei=pon, ‘give up’, from weariness or disgust, before they had carried their point: cp. Antid. § 274, h(gou=mai (au)tou\s) pro/teron a)perei=n kai\ pau/sesqai lhrou=ntas, pri
 eu(reqh=nai, k.t.l. — xrhsmou/s: so Socr. to his judges, Plat. Apol. 39 C, e)piqumw= u(mi=n xrhsmw|dh=sai, k.t.l.

toi=s tw=n polit. e)cesthko/si ‘who stand apart from public life’. With a similar reference to his own abstention from political life (owing to want of fwnh/ and to/lma), he says,
Adv. Sophist. § 14, polloi\ me\n tw=n filosofhsa/ntwn i)diw=tai diete/lesan o)/ntes, where see note.

ou) mh\n a)ll)...e)/xqras] ou) mh\n [dei= siwpa=n] a)lla\... dei= skopei=n: ‘At the same time [i.e. discouraging as is this apathy on the part of the statesmen, and little as i)diw=tai may seem entitled to speak] the rest of us are bound to consider’, etc. — e)rrwmeneste/rws, § 163. — e)/xqras, ‘discord’ among Greeks.
ta\s peri\ th=s ei)rh/nhs sunq ‘As things are, it is in vain that we make treaties of peace’: not the treaty: cp. Lys. In Erat. § 97, note on to\n qa/naton.

a)gagei=n...o(monoh=sai Not a)/gein, o(monoei=n, because the speaker is thinking of the moment from which such a peace is to date, and at which such a concord is to be established: the pres. would have expressed merely the continuance of the conditions. ‘It is impossible that we should cement an enduring peace, or that concord should be established among the Greeks’. — e)k tw=n au)tw=n, masc., tw=n barba/rwn.

h(\ kai\ ta\s e(tair...proa/gei ‘which dissolves friendships [cp. e(tairi/as limh/n, Soph. Ai. 683] and draws kinsmen on to quarrels’. proa/gein of leading onward in an evil path; cp. Theogn. 396, peni/hn, (just as here, a)pori/a,) h(/ t' a)ndrw=n proa/gei qumo\n e)s a)mplaki/hn [where para/gei is a doubtful v. l.]: Dem. In Androt. § 78, ei)s tou=to proh/xqht' eu)hqei/as kai\ r(a|qumi/as.

to\n e)nqe/nde po/lemon...dioriou=men ‘transfer the war from Greece to Asia’: Plat. Legg. 873 E, to\ d' o)flo\n [vulg. o)/flon] e)/cw tw=n o(/rwn th=s xw/ras a)poktei/nantas diori/sai, ‘the animal which is adjudged guilty (of causing death) they shall slay and cast beyond the borders’: Eur. Helen. 394, stra/teuma kw/ph| diori/sai, ‘to carry a host from its own land in ships’,= porqmeu=sai or diaperaiw=sai.
tw=n kindu/nwn tw=n pro\s h(ma=s au)tou/s ‘the ordeals of intestine warfare’ (between Greek cities).

kataxrh/sasqai ‘to utilise them’: kata/ meaning here, not ‘wastefully, perversely’ (abuti), but ‘to the full’ (cp. ‘to use up’): so Panegyr. § 9, to\ d' e)n kairw=| tau/tais [sc. tai=s pra/cesin, these historical examples] kataxrh/sasqai...tw=n eu)= fronou/ntwn i)/dio/n e)stin.

a)lla\ ga/r, k.t.l. ‘But perhaps it will be said that the Convention [of Antalcidas] is a reason for pausing, instead of making haste and accelerating the expedition’. For a)ll' ou)k (a)/cio/n e)stin), instead of mh/, cp. Lys. Pro Mantith. § 18, kai/toi xrh\...skopei=n, a)ll' ou)k, ei)/ tis tolma=|,...misei=n. The terms of the Peace of Antalcidas (387 B.C.) were as follows (Xen.
Hellen. V. I. 31): — ‘King Artaxerxes thinks it just that the cities in Asia, and the islands of Clazomenae and Cyprus, shall belong to him. He thinks it just also to leave all the other Hellenic cities autonomous, both small and great — except Lemnos, Imbros and Scyros, which are to belong to Athens, as they did originally. Should any parties refuse to accept this peace, I will make war upon them, along with those who are of the same mind, by land as well as sea, with ships and with money’. Grote IX. 534.

h)leuqerwme/nai...e)kdedome/nai The liberated cities are those in Greece Proper, or belonging to the Aegean coasts and islands, which Athens or Sparta might otherwise have claimed as tributaries: those abandoned to the barbarians are the Hellenic cities of the Asiatic seaboard, with Clazomenae and Cyprus.

o(\ de\ pa/ntwn...e)sti/n ‘Most absurd of all, those stipulations of the Treaty which we actually observe are the very worst. The articles which grant independence to the islands and the Greek cities of Europe have long ago been violated, and are dead letters in the record’. tw=n gegramme/nwn: cp. Andoc. De Pace § 35, gra/mmata ta\ gegramme/na, the letter of the terms (of peace): ib. § 34 sth=lai staqh/sontai, note. — le/lutai: meaning that Sparta had been levying tribute on the Aegean islands (tou\s nhsiw/tas dasmologei=n, § 132), and helping Amyntas II. of Macedon against Olynthus, besides devastating Mantineia, besieging Phlius, and seizing the Theban Cadmeia (§ 126). — For the constr., o(\ de\ pa/ntwn [sc. e)sti\] katagelasto/taton [tou=t' e)sti/n], o(/ti, cp. Plat. Apol. 18 C, o(\ de\ pa/ntwn a)logw/taton, o(/ti ou)de\ ta\ o)no/mata oi(=o/n te au)tw=n ei)de/nai. So Isocr. Panegyr. § 128, o(\ de\ pa/ntwn deino/taton, o(/tan: Plataic. § 45, o(\ de\ pa/ntwn deino/taton, ei): De Pace § 53, o(\ de\ pa/ntwn sxetliw/taton: ou(\s ga/r, k.t.l. For other examples see Madvig, Syntax § 197.

e)kde/dwke, k.t.l. Cp. e)kde/dontai, § 169, note. — tau=ta de\ kata\ xw/ran me/nei: ‘these articles, on the other hand [de/ in apodosis], remain undisturbed’. — prosta/gmata: ‘dictates’ (of the Persian king): see the terms, § 175, note.

tw=n presbeusa/ntwn tau/thn th\n ei)rh/nhn ‘those who negotiated this peace’: cp. Andoc. De Pace § 29, a(\ h(mi=n e)pre/sbeusen *)epi/lukos, k.t.l., note. The reference is to the diplomatic agents of Sparta generally, but esp. to Antalcidas, by whom, with the help of the satrap Teiribazus, the terms of the treaty were virtually settled. Grote IX. 531.

e)xrh=n...peri\ au)tw=n ‘Whether it was their view (1) that each State should retain its own territory, or (2) that each
should have dominion also over all that it acquired by conquest, or (3) that each of us should keep these possessions which we happened to hold on the eve of the peace, — they were bound to define some one of these views, — to apply their principle impartially, — and on this basis to frame the terms of the treaty’ (peri\ au)tw=n, neut., about the interests thus involved). Isocr. means: The Peace of Antalcidas is based on no intelligible principle. If (1) had been adopted, Persia would not have got the Greek cities of Asia: if (2), autonomy would not have been guaranteed to the Greek cities of Europe: if (3), Athens and Sparta would not have had to renounce dependencies which they claimed. Observe that tw=n dorialw/twn refers, not to all that each State had from time to time acquired, but to all that it might hereafter acquire.

a)ll' ou)k e)kei/nwn After w(/sper we should expect mh/ (=w(/sper ei) e)polemh/samen, a)lla\ mh\ ei)=xon): but the emphasis on the negative fact warrants ou). Cp. Lys. In Eratosth. § 36, note on ou)k a)/ra xrh/.
e)kei/nws ei)pw/n ‘by the following illustration’.

th/n te peri\ h(ma=s a)tim. gegen.] dhlw/sw th
 a)timi/an gegenhme/nhn could mean only, ‘I will show that the dishonour has happened’, gegen. being a predicate. But dhlw/sw th
 peri\ h(ma=s a)timi/an gegenhme/nhn can mean, ‘I will show the dishonour that has been done to us’, because peri\ h(ma=s is really a part of the adjective; and when this part has been put in its right place between th
 and a)timi/an, the supplementary gegenhme/nhn can be allowed to wait. Cp. Thuc. VII. 23, ai( pro\ tou= sto/matos nh=es naumaxou=sai, ‘the ships fighting before the mouth of the harbour’: here, the complete adjective is pro\ tou= sto/matos naumaxou=sai, and it is enough that the first part of it, pro\ tou= sto/matos, should stand between the article and the subst. So id. I. 11 tou= nu=n peri\ au)tw=n dia\ tou\s poihta\s lo/gou katesxhko/tos: VII. 36 th=| pro/teron a)maqi/a| tw=n kubernhtw=n dokou/sh| ei)=nai.

th=s ga\r gh=s...poiou/menos ‘Whereas the whole earth beneath the firmament is divided into two parts, “Asia” and “Europe”, the great King has under this Treaty taken one-half, — as if he were dividing the territory with Zeus, and not making his compact with men’. That is, the Persian king has taken all Asia, as if he were a god who would not yield up more than half of the whole earth even to Zeus himself. Isocr. prob. began with the thought of Artaxerxes being on earth what Zeus is in heaven, and then passed to this image of him as one who, in partitioning the earth, would consider himself the equal of Zeus. On ne/mesqai pro/s, cp. Lys. Mantith. § 10, p. 42. — ko/smos, the starry firmament,=o( peri\ th\n gh=n ko/smos,
Arist. Meteor. I. 2. — di/xa tetm.: cp. Soph. Tr. 100, dissai\ h)/peiroi.

toi=s koinoi=s tw=n i(er ‘The national temples’ (at Olympia, Delphi, etc.), not merely the ‘public’ temples of each State. Cp. Panathenaicus § 107, ta\s toiau/tas sunqh/kas (of Antalcidas) au)toi/ t' e)n toi=s i(eroi=s toi=s sfete/rois a)ne/grayan kai\ tou\s summa/xous h)na/gkasan. — sth/lais: Thuc. v. 47, ta\s de\ cunqh/kas a)nagra/yai e)n sth/lh| liqi/nh| *)aqhnai/ous me\n e)n po/lei (the Acropolis), *)argei/ous de\ e)n a)gora=| e)n tou= *)apo/llwnos tw=| i(erw=|, *mantine/as de\ e)n tou= *dio\s tw=| i(erw=| e)n th=| a)gora=|: kataqe/ntwn de\ kai\ *)olumpi/asi sth/lhn xalkh=n.
mia=s tu/xhs ‘a single success’: Antidosis § 128, ei)/ tis e)n mia=| tu/xh| (alluding to Aegospotami) thlikou=to/n ti katw/rqwsen w(/sper *lu/sandros. Cp. e)pi\ r(oph=s mia=s o)/ntes, Thuc. v. 103.
kaq' o(/lhs th=s *(e ‘but these pillars stand as witnesses on the whole war against all Greece’.
tou\s...peri\ ta\ *trwi+ka\ gen.] ‘those who were en gaged in the Trojan war’. If the meaning were, ‘those who lived in the time of the Trojan war’, we should rather expect kata\ ta\ *trwi+ka/.

eu)xh=s a)/cia ‘all for which men would pray’: not merely ‘desirable’ things, but such things as might satisfy the highest aspirations. So again in Isocr. Philipp. § 19. Cp. Arist.'s u(poti/qesqai kat' eu)xh/n, to suppose the best imaginable case; h( kat' eu)xh\n politei/a, the ideal polity, Polit. II. 6.

qewri/a|...stratei/a| ‘like a sacred embassy rather than a hostile expedition’, — i.e. encountering no resistance, but received with joyous welcome and homage in its stately progress. The image suggested by qewri/a is the more appropriate, since the Hellenic gods are conceived as making common cause against those barbarians who had destroyed their shrines when Ionia was conquered: see § 155, oi(\ kai\ ta\ tw=n qew=n e(/dh kai\ tou\s new\s sula=n e)n tw=| prote/rw| pole/mw| kai\ kataka/ein e)to/lmhsan.

— § 184. fe/re ga/r...e)nqumoume/nous] ‘Let us see: who are fitting objects of hostility for those who desire no aggrandisement, but have a view to justice in the abstract?... And who are proper objects for the envy of those who, though not devoid of courage, exercise that quality under the restraint of prudence?...And against whom should those men march who are at once loyal to their duty and mindful of their interest?’ i.e. The arms of Greece ought to be turned against Persia, (1) if we consider abstract justice — because Persia has wronged Greece: (2) if we desire a field of enterprise agreeable at once to our valour and to our discretion — because Persia is
rich and weak: (3) if we think both of duty and of interest — for the above reasons combined. The phrase tou\s mh\ panta/pasin a)na/ndrws diakeime/nous a)lla\ metri/ws tou/tw| tw=| pra/gmati xrwme/nous is a circumlocution for ‘men in whom courage is subordinate to prudence’. The fqo/nos felt by such men — however timid — will find in Asia a field of plunder both ample and safe.

kai\ mh\n ou)de/, k.t.l. ‘Nor again [kai\ mh/n=further] shall we distress the cities by levying soldiers on them, — a burden which at present, in their warfare with each other, they find most oppressive’. ou) luph/s. katale/g., not, ‘we shall abstain from vexing by a levy’, but, ‘we shall levy without vexing’; since all will prefer the service to staying at home (me/nein, i.e. oi)/koi,=u(pome/nein). The disinclination of citizens for ordinary military service, and the consequent demand for mercenaries (e)pi/kouroi, § 168), was a growing symptom of the decay in Greek political life: see Attic Orators, II. 17. — Cp. Thuc. VI. 43, oi( e)k tou= katalo/gou, those on the roll for service: oi( e)/cw tou= katalo/gou,=emeriti, Xen. H. II. 3. 51.

h)\ ne/os h)\ palaio/s Doubtless the poetical palaio/s is to be explained by a reminiscence of the familiar Homeric formula, h)\ ne/os h)e\ palaio/s, Il. XIV. 108: ne/oi h)de\ palaioi/, Od. I. 395, etc.

fh/mhn de\ kai\ mnh/mhn kai\ do/can ‘name and fame and repute’: fh/mhn, the rumour in men's mouths (volitare per ora), as gratifying to the living, — mnh/mhn, the posthumous fame of the dead. Arist. Rhet. III. 7. § 11, (words or phrases of an unusual or a poetical colour may be used by the speaker) o(/tan e)/xh| h)/dh tou\s a)kroata\s kai\ poih/sh| e)nqousia/sai h)\ e)pai/nois h)\ yo/gois h)\ o)rgh=| h)\ fili/a| (‘when the speaker has got his hearers into his power, and has worked them up into enthusiasm by praise or blame, by indignation or by love’), oi(=on kai\ *)isokra/ths poiei= e)n tw=| panhgurikw=| e)pi\ te/lei, ‘fh/mh de\ kai\ gnw/mh’: — where gnw/mh is a slip for mnh/mh — a strange one, since it weakens the paronomasi/a (similarity of form) and destroys the paromoi/wsis (similarity of sound). Cp. Phil. § 134, kai\ th\n fh/mhn kai\ th\n mnh/mhn. Ar. Ran. 463, kaq' *(hrakle/a to\ sxh=ma kai\ to\ lh=m) e)/xwn.

pro\s *)ale/candron=*pa/rin. ‘The heroes (of Troy) themselves bear each a double name, as Alexander and Paris, Hector and Darius; of which the one indicates their connexion with Hellas, the other with interior Asia’: Curt. Hist. Gr. I. 79.

poiei=n...le/gein, k.t.l. ‘who that has the gift of the poet or
the art of the orator will not devote his labour and meditation to the purpose of bequeathing for all time a monument of his own intellect and of their heroism?’ poiei=n: as in Plat. Ion 534 B (quoted by Sandys), pri\n a)\n e)/nqeos ge/nhtai...a)du/natos pa=s poiei=n kai\ xrhsmw|dei=n. — filosofh/sei: cp. Lysias Pro Invalido § 10, note.

div2.p: . [Or. v.] — This appeal to Philip of Macedon may fitly be taken after the Panegyricus. As the latter recommends that Athens should lead a Panhellenic War against Persia, so this discourse presses the task on Philip. It is the final expression — as the other was the first — of a lifelong desire.

Philip had taken Amphipolis in 358 B.C. and Potidaea in 356. The hostilities between him and Athens, carried on intermittently from 356, were closed in March, 346, by the so-called Peace of Philocrates. Before that event Isocrates had been composing a letter to Philip ‘On Amphipolis’, urging, in favour of peace, that Amphipolis, the chief cause of the war, was not a desirable possession either for Athens or for the king of Macedon (§§ 1, 3).

This letter had not been sent when peace was concluded (§ 7). Isocrates now writes on another and a larger subject. He sees in Philip, at length reconciled to Athens, the man who can lead the united Hellenes against Persia. Ever since the failure of the Panegyricus to bring about such an expedition under the joint leadership of Athens and Sparta, he had been looking for an individual powerful enough to execute his favourite plan (§§ 84, 128, 129). He had already applied to Dionysius I. — probably about 368 B.C. (Ep. I. § 8) — and in 356 to Archidamus III. (Ep. IX. § 16). This oration was addressed to Philip soon after the Peace (§§ 8, 56), but before the conclusion of the Sacred War (§§ 54, 74); that is, between March and July, 346 B.C.

The most striking characteristic of the whole discourse is the recognition of Philip as the first of Hellenes and the natural champion of Hellas, in whom — though his subjects are aliens — the Heraclid spirit is as true as it was in the Argive Têmenus, the founder of his dynasty. — Attic Orators, II. 166 — 176.

div3.p:
a(/per e)pe/steila ‘as I said in my letter to Dionysius after he had acquired the tyranny’. The words are, in fact, closely similar: Ep. I. (to Dionysius) § 9, kai\ mh\ qauma/sh|s, ei) mh/te dhmhgorw=n (being a speaker in the Ecclesia) mh/te
strathgw=n mh/t' a)/llws duna/sths w)
 ou(/tws e)mbriqe\s ai)/romai pra=gma (take upon me so grave a task) kai\ duoi=n e)pixeirw= toi=n megi/stoin, u(pe/r te th=s *(ella/dos le/gein kai\ soi\ sumbouleu/ein. Dionysius became tyrant of Syracuse in 406 B.C., and the probable date of the Letter to him is 368 B.C. (Attic Orators, II. 239): kthsa/menon, then, cannot=‘immediately on his acquiring’: but Isocr. is thinking of the career of Dionys. as divided into two great chapters, that which preceded and that which followed his acquisition of the tyranny. Isocr. felt that the war must be led either by a city or by a prince. He appealed successively to Athens — to Dionysius (when now a tu/rannos) — to Archidamus — and to Philip. We need not, then, insert to
 before th
 turanni/da kthsa/menon.
mh/t' a)/llws duna/sths ‘nor in any way a person of influence’: cp. Paneg. § 170, tw=n dunasteuo/ntwn, ‘the leading statesmen’, note, p. 313.

o)/xlw|...kalindoume/nois ‘capable of dealing with a mob, and of exchanging scurrilous personalities with the busy triflers of the platform’ (bh=ma, the raised place for speakers in the ecclesia). — o)/xlw|, an invidious term for plh/qei, the audience in a popular assembly or law-court: oi( ga\r e)n sofoi=s | fau=loi, par' o)/xlw| mousikw/teroi le/gein, Eur. Hipp. 989. — molu/nesqai, pass., ‘to be defiled’, — i.e., here, to have mud thrown at one, to be coarsely abused. — loidorei=sqai, midd., ‘to revile’, with dat. (the act. loidorei=n usu. with acc.). — On kalindoume/nois, cp. Adv. Soph. § 20, note. Baiter and Sauppe give here kulindoume/nois (a collateral form with the same meaning), but retain the other form in Isocr. Panegyr. 151, prokalindou/menoi: Adv. Sophist. § 20, kalindoume/nwn: Antid. § 30, tw=n peri\ ta\ dikasth/ria kalindoume/nwn: § 213, kalindoume/nas.

pro\s tou\s *(/ellhnas In the former part of the discourse Isocr. has impressed on Philip that his duty is to reconcile the four great cities of Greece — Sparta, Argos, Thebes, Athens — and has shown in detail that this task is feasible (§§ 30 — 67).

ou) th\n au)th\n e)/x. dia/n.] ‘though not with the same feeling [dia/noian, thoughts about my own work] as at the former period of life when I was writing on this same subject’. The Panegyricus appeared in 380 B.C., Isocr. aetat. 56: but he had certainly commenced it some years before — acc. to the tradition, at least ten: see introd. to Panegyr., p. 263. In 346 B.C., when this discourse was sent to Philip, Isocr. was ninety years of age.

parekeleuo/mhn...katagela=n, k.t.l. A literally exact reference to the opening of the Panegyricus, § 14, e)gw\ d' h)\n mh\ kai\ tou= pra/gmatos a)ci/ws ei)/pw kai\ th=s do/chs th=s e)mautou= kai\ tou=
xro/nou, mh\ mo/non tou= peri\ to\n lo/gon h(mi=n diatrifqe/ntos, a)lla\ kai\ su/mpantos ou(= bebi/wka, parakeleu/omai mhdemi/an suggnw/mhn e)/xein a)lla\ katagela=n kai\ katafronei=n. — tou= xro/nou: Isocr. spent ten years on the Panegyr. acc. to Quint. X. 4, [Plut.] Vitt. X. Oratt., Phot. Cod. 260: Plut. Mor. 350 E makes it ‘almost three olympiads’ (nearly 12 years).

ou)/te ga\r tau)ta/, k.t.l. Cp. the maxim, to\ kalw=s ei)pei=n a(/pac perigi/gnetai, di\s de\ ou)k e)nde/xetai, a thing can be well said once, but cannot be well said twice (quoted and questioned by Theon, progumna/smata, c. 1, Rhet. Graec. II. 62). In several places Demosth. repeats phrases or short passages of his own. See on this — which illustrates the ancient view of oratory as a fine art — Attic Orators, I. lxxii.

ou) mh
 a)postate/on ‘I must not desist, however, but must speak on my chosen theme as the moment may prompt, and as may be expedient for the purpose of persuading you to act thus’. o(/ ti a)
 u(pope/sh|, ‘whatever may suggest itself’: cp. Od. XII. 266, kai/ moi e)/pos e)/mpese qumw=|: Plut. Ages. 7, u(ph=lqe to
 *)aghsi/laon, ‘it occurred to him’. As the Panegyricus was the result of long thought and study, so the present discourse is to be rather an extemporary appeal of a more personal kind.

e)lli/pw ti not — ‘omit anything’ (wh. would be rather parali/pw), but — ‘fail in any respect’; to\n au)to\n tro/pon toi=s prot. e)kded. meaning, ‘up to the level of’ the work which he had formerly put forth (the Panegyricus).

a)ll' ou)=n u(pogr ‘yet at least I think that I can trace a pretty clear outline for those who are able to execute my idea, and to carry the work through’: i.e. for one who, like Philip, is in a position to levy war against Asia. Cp. u(fhgh/sato, Lys. Olymp. § 3, note, p. 238.

h)\ sunagwnizome/nous, k.t.l. ‘Nothing must be done until one has got the Greeks either as active supporters of the project, or as cordially favourable spectators’: tou\s *(/ell., the Greeks collectively. Agesilaus had, of course, Greek troops; but the public opinion of Greece at large was not with him.

*)aghsi/laos Alluding to the campaigns of Agesilaus in Asia Minor, 396 — 395 B.C. Cp. Panegyr. § 144, *)aghsi/laos de\ tw=| *kurei/w| strateu/mati xrw/menos [the remnant of the Ten Thousand] mikrou= dei=n th=s e)nto\s *(/aluos xw/ras e)kra/thsen, ‘all but conquered Asia Minor west of the Halys’. See Annals in Attic Orators, I. xlvi. ‘Agesilaus...assimilated his expedition (396 B.C.) to a new Trojan War — an effort of united Greece, for
the purpose of taking vengeance on the common Asiatic enemy of the Hellenic name’: Grote IX. 357.

tou\s e(tai/rous See Isocr. Epist. IX. § 13 (Agesilaus) geno/menos e)gkrate/statos kai\ dikaio/tatos kai\ politikw/tatos [as here fronimw/tatos] ditta\s e)/sxen e)piqumi/as:...h)bou/leto ga\r basilei= te polemei=n kai\ tw=n fi/lwn tou\s feu/gontas ei)s ta\s po/leis katagagei=n kai\ kuri/ous katasth=sai tw=n pragma/twn. Here tou\s e(tai/rous are not ‘his friends’, but, ‘the members of the oligarchical clubs’ (e(tairi/ai) by whom the Spartan dekarxi/ai had been supported in the various cities: cp. Lysias In Eratosth. § 43, pe/nte a)/ndres e)/foroi kate/sthsan u(po\ tw=n kaloume/nwn e(tai/rwn (at Athens in 404 B.C.). Not long after these dekarxi/ai had been established by Lysander (in 405 — 4 B.C.) a reaction set in against them, and in many cities they were either dissolved or modified, with the express approval of the Spartan Ephors. When Agesilaus went to Asia in 396 B.C., Lysander accompanied him, ‘in order’, as Xen. says (Hellen. III. 4. 2), ‘to restore, with the help of Agesilaus, the decarchies which he [Lysander] had established in the cities, but which had been banished (e)kpeptwkui/as) by the (Spartan) Ephors, who directed the cities to resume their traditionary constitutions’.

Isocr. correctly represents the general situation in the Asiatic Hellas of 396 B.C.; but he does not accurately describe the attitude of Agesilaus. It was Lysander, not Agesilaus, who desired to restore the e(tai=roi, the oligarchical partisans. Agesilaus appeared in contrast with Lysander as dhmotiko/s (Plut. Ages. c. 7). Isocr. seems to confound the political enterprise, in which Lysander sought (not very successfully) to engage Agesilaus, with the marked eagerness of Agesilaus to enrich or honour his personal friends (see Xen. Ages. I. 18, pa/ntes pamplh/qh xrh/mata e)/labon, k.t.l.): and this misapprehension appears when, in the passage cited above (Epist. IX. § 13), he uses the phrase tou\s e(autou= fi/lous.

e)n kakoi=s...th
 taraxh
 th
 e)nqa/de g.] i.e. (1) The Asiatic Greeks were involved in troubles and dangers by that strife between the democratic and oligarchic parties which arose from the attempt to restore the oligarchic exiles. (2) The tumult excited in Greece Proper by the outbreak of the Corinthian War in 394 B.C., h( taraxh\ h( e)nqa/de gignome/nh — which caused Agesilaus to be recalled from Asia — left the European Greeks no leisure to think about a war against Persia.

e)k tw=n a)gnohqe/ntwn ‘And so, from the oversights which were made at that time, it is easy to deduce the lesson that no prudent man will make war on Persia until he has reconciled the Greeks and cured them of the madness which now possesses them’ [the discord which is ruining them]:
po/lemon e)kfe/rein, inferre bellum; Xen. Hellen. III. 5, e)f' w(=|te e)coi/sein po/lemon pro\s *lakedaimoni/ous.

tw=n me\n a)/llwn ‘Most other people, perhaps, if they were minded to urge on you an expedition against Asia, would have recourse to this topic of exhortation — that all who have ever undertaken a war against Persia have had the fortune to exchange obscurity for eminence, poverty for wealth, a humble station for the lordship of wide lands and of cities. My appeal to you, however, will not rely on such examples (tw=n toiou/twn masc., cp. Panegyr. § 173, e)k tw=n au)tw=n) but on the case of those who are adjudged to have failed — I mean the comrades of Cyrus and Clearchus’. doca/ntwn, who have been set down as failures — more than dokou/ntwn.

th\n *ku/rou prope/teian ‘the impetuosity of Cyrus’, — at the battle of Cunaxa (401 B.C.). The Greeks were conquering, and those around Cyrus were already saluting him as king. But he still restrained himself: ou)d' w(\s e)ch/xqh diw/kein (Xen. Anab. I. 8. 21). Presently, however, to defeat a movement of the enemy, he charged the Persian centre, and routed the 6000 who surrounded Artaxerxes. His own body-guard went on in pursuit. Cyrus was left alone with his immediate staff (o(motra/pezoi). At this moment he caught sight of his hated brother. He cried, ‘I see the man’ — rushed at him — wounded him — and was slain (ib. § 25).
th=s peri\ au(to\n duna/mews ‘the power about him’ — the military resources of the Persian empire. Cp. Panegyr. § 166, mei/zw du/namin peri\ au(to\n e(ka/stwn au)tw=n poihsa/menos, note, p. 311.

prokalesa/menos...ei)s lo/gon e)lqei=n ‘having invited’ them ‘to a conference’. We cannot render ‘having caused to be invited’, since the act. prokalei=n is not classical as=prokalei=sqai. Take w(/ste with a)pe/kteine, not with e)lqei=n: prokalesa/menos requires ei)s lo/gon e)lqei=n to explain it. Note the series of participles: prokalesa/menos — kai\ u(pisxnou/menos (representing the imperf. u(pisxnei=to) — u(pagago/menos kai\...dou\s — sullabw/n (this last being in closer connection with a)pe/kteine). — Xen. does not say that Tissaphernes offered ‘large presents’ to the leaders, and ‘their pay in full’ to the soldiers. Acc. to Xen., Tissaphernes offered (1) a safe conduct back to Greece, (2) a market for provisions on the march, — if the Greeks would abstain from ravage, and would pay for what they took: Xen. Anab. II. 3. 26, 27.

pi/steis...ta\s megi/stas Xen. ib. § 28, tau=ta e)/doce: kai\ w)/mosan kai\ decia\s e)/dosan *tissafe/rnhs kai\ o( th=s basile/ws gunaiko\s a)delfo\s toi=s tw=n *(ellh/nwn strathgoi=s kai\ loxagoi=s kai\ e)/labon
para\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn. The oaths between the Greeks and Ariaeus (the Persian leader of the Asiatic contingent under Cyrus) were ratified in more solemn fashion after the battle: a bull, a wolf, a boar, and a ram were slain, and their blood received in a shield, the contracting parties dipping their weapons in it. Xen. Anab. II. 2. 9. Here Isocr. seems to be thinking of this, rather than of the simple decia\s dou=nai.
sullabw\n...a)pe/kteine Tissaphernes seized in his tent five of the strathgoi/: four, including Clearchus, were put to death soon afterwards, and Menon a year later: Xen. An. II. 5. 31, 6. 29.
fai/nontai...krath/santes a)/n=dh=lo/n e)stin o(/ti e)kra/thsan a)/n: [grammatically, the words might equally well mean, o(/ti krath/seian a)/n:] Goodwin § 41. 3.

ei) mh\ dia\ *ku=ron sc. e)sfa/lhsan, ‘had it not been for Cyrus’: Plat. Gorg. 516 E, ei) mh\ dia\ to\n pru/tanin, e)ne/pesen a)/n: Dem. F. L. § 73, ou) ga\r w(s ei) mh\ dia\ *lakedaimoni/ous,...ou)d' w(s ei) mh\ dia\ to\ kai\ to/ (if it had not been for this or that), e)sw/qhsan a)\n oi( *fwkei=s, — ou)x ou(/tw to/te a)ph/ggeilen: Goodwin § 52. 1, n. 1.

soi\ de/, k.t.l. ‘But for you it is not difficult to guard against the mishap which occurred on that occasion [such rashness as that of Cyrus, § 90], and it is easy to provide a force much stronger than that which overmastered the power of the King’ (e)kei/nou, Artaxerxes II.).
u(parca/ntwn ‘have been secured’: for the tense, cp. Panegyr. § 162, toiou/twn o(rmhthri/wn u(parca/ntwn, p. 128, and below § 95, u(parca/shs.

pro/teron In Panegyr. §§ 145 — 149, where he thus sums up the lesson of the famous Retreat, — a)sfale/steron kate/bhsan [came down to the coast] tw=n peri\ fili/as w(s au)to\n [to\n basile/a] presbeuo/ntwn.

e)pista\s ga/r, k.t.l. ‘For, as my argument had brought me to the same topics, I spared myself the labour of striving to find new words for ideas which had been fully illustrated already’ (in the Panegyr.). e)pista/s: i.e. the course of the discussion led him to a point where the same dia/noiai must be repeated: cp. e)pistw=sin, Panegyr. § 165, note, p. 311.

toi=s me\n ou)=n oi)kei/ois, k.t.l. ‘Now, I may perhaps draw upon my own materials [i.e. repeat my own thoughts or language from former works], if in any case there be urgent need, and it be fitting: but I will adopt nothing from the work of others, any more than of old’. — katepei/gh|: cp. Dem. In Timocr. § 18,
a)/lla, peri\ w(=n ou)de\n i)/sws u(ma=s katepei/gei nu=n a)kou=sai, ‘there is no pressing need’ for you to hear.
th=s e)kei/nois u(parca/shs ‘which had been raised by them’ [the Cyreians]: =h(\ u(ph=rce, not h(\ u(ph=rxe: cp. on § 92.

dia\ ta\s dekarxi/as, k.t.l. ‘while they [Cyrus and his followers] had the Greeks most strongly prepossessed against them on account of the decarchies of the Spartan period’. dekadarxi/a (the rule of a deka/s) is here, as often, a v. l. for dekarxi/a (the rule of de/ka). Harpocrat. supports dekadarxi/a, Suidas and Xen. dekarxi/a. The fact that deka/darxos had a technical military sense, ‘a commander of ten’ (freq. in Xen.), seems to favour dekarxi/a in the sense of government by ten: so pentarxi/a (not pempadarxi/a), triarxi/a (not triadarxi/a), k.t.l. Cp. Panegyr. §§ 110 f., oi( tw=n dekarxiw=n koinwnh/santes kai\ ta\s au)tw=n patri/das dialumhna/menoi (those who supported the oligarchies of ten, established by Lysander, and so ruined their native cities); see note on § 87, tou\s e(tai/rous. — e)pi\ *lakedaimoni/wn, ‘in the time of the Lacedaemonians’, i.e. of their h(gemoni/a, which now (346 B.C.) was a thing of the past: it lasted, roughly, from 404 B.C. to 371 B.C., when the battle of Leuctra gave the ascendancy to Thebes.
e)c e(toi/mou ‘readily’: cp. Adv. Sophist. § 15, p. 114, e)c e(toimote/rou lamba/nein.

tw=n planwme/nwn — tw=n polit.] ‘A large and powerful force can more easily be raised from among the homeless vagrants than from among the dwellers in cities’. Cp. Epist. IX. (to Archidamus, 356 B.C.) § 9, mei/zous kai\ krei/ttous sunta/ceis stratope/dwn gignome/nas e)k tw=n planwme/nwn h)\ tw=n politeuome/nwn. These ‘vagrants’ were political exiles, driven out by the troubles bred of the ‘decarchies’ — ruined men and criminals of every sort. See Panegyr. § 168, w(/ste tou\s me\n e)n tai=s au(tw=n a)no/mws a)po/llusqai, tou\s d' e)pi\ ce/nhs meta\ pai/dwn kai\ gunaikw=n a)la=sqai, and note.
ou)k h)=n ceniko/n Cyrus (in 401 B.C.) found it hard to raise 10,000 mercenaries from all Greece: in 338 B.C. 10,000 such formed a single contingent at Chaeroneia: see Attic Orators, II. 17.

toi=s sulle/gousi Thus Cyrus gave Clearchus about £10,000 with which to levy mercenaries: o( de\ labw\n to\ xrusi/on stra/teuma sune/lecen a)po\ tou/twn tw=n xrhma/twn, Xen. Anab. I. 1. 9. — th\n ei)s tou\s stratiw/tas misqofora/n, the pay (spent) on the soldiers.

*kle/arxon to\n e)pistath/santa, k.t.l. ‘Clearchus, who was placed in command [aor.] of that expedition’, — as being the leader of the Greek mercenaries, and the only officer
who knew from the first the real object of the march (Xen. Anab. III. 1. 10).

ou)/te nautikh=s ou)/te pezh=s...ku/rion ‘that he had never before been placed in control of any naval or land-force’. To make this exact, ku/rion must mean ‘commander-in-chief’. Clearchus had held a command under Mindarus at Cyzicus in 410 B.C., and under Callicratidas at Arginusae in 406 B.C. At the end of the war he was sent as general to Thrace, but was recalled by the Ephors before he had arrived there. He disregarded their orders; and sentence of death was recorded against him at Sparta. After holding Byzantium for a time, he took service with Cyrus. — a)tuxi/as: his seizure and execution by Tissaphernes, Xen. Anab. II. 6. 29.

tosau=ta kai\ thlikau=ta with peri\ w(=n: ‘so great... that if I were speaking of them’...The sentence, as commenced, should have gone thus: — peri\ w(=n, ei) me
...e)poiou/mhn, kalw=s a)
 ei)=xe dielqei=n, e)peidh\ de\...diale/gomai, a)no/hton kai\ peri/ergon a)
 ei)/h diecie/nai. But with pro\s se\ de\ dialego/menos a fresh departure is taken. The expected apodosis, a)no/hton a)
 ei)/h...diecie/nai, is broken up into a protasis and apodosis, ei) diecioi/hn...a)no/htos a)
 dokoi/hn, thus forming an independent conditional sentence on a new plan.

tou/tou path/r Artaxerxes II. [Mnêmon] regn. 405 — 359 B.C. (Clinton F. H. II. Append. c. 18). katepole/mhsen is incorrect: he gained no great military success over the Greeks. But Greek disunion and Persian money combined to bring him his political victory over Athens and Sparta in the Peace of Antalcidas (387 B.C.). — ou(=tos: Artaxerxes III. (Ochos): 359 — 339 B.C. Isocr. writes in 346 B.C.

o( me\n...ou(=tos de/ ‘The former king [Artaxerxes Mnêmon] received the surrender of all Asia under the Treaty; the present king [Artax. Ochos], so far from being capable of extending his dominion, is not master even of the cities which were surrendered to him’. Note the aor. e)kdoqeisw=n, whereas in Panegyr. § 175, p. 131, we have ai( e)kdedome/nai of the same cities, when the king was still master of them. — e)ce/laben, correlative of e)kdido/nai: see Panegyr. § 169, note, p. 313. — sunqh/kais: for the terms of the Peace of Antalcidas, see Panegyr. § 175, note, p. 314. — ou(=tos tosou/tou dei= [tou=] a)/rxein: cp. Lys. In Eratosth. § 17, ou(/tw pollou= e)de/hse kriqh=nai kai\ a)pologh/sasqai: Plat. Apol. 30 D, pollou= de/w a)pologei=sqai: so dei=s, Lysis 204 E.

tou=ton au)tw=n a)festa/nai ‘that the king has abandoned them [au)tw=n=tw=n po/lewn] from cowardice, or that they have conceived disdain and contempt for the barbarian authority’
[dunastei/as, the Persian suzerainty over Greek cities with municipal self-government]: i.e. these cities could not be more practically independent than they are if Persia had given them up, or if they had revolted from Persia.
ta\ toi/nun peri\ th\n xw/ran The state of Persia is the next topic. This passage, to the end of § 104, is parallel to Panegyr. §§ 160 — 166 (pp. 127 ff.).

*ai)/guptos...a)feisth/kei ‘was in revolt’: kat' e)kei=non to\n xro/non, in the days of the late king's prosperity after the Peace of Antalcidas: see note on Panegyr. § 161, p. 309. This revolt prob. began earlier than 385 B.C.

kai\ th=s dia\ to
 potamo
 dusxwri/as, k.t.l. ‘At the same time [ou) mh
 a)ll), Panegyr. § 172, note] the Egyptians were afraid lest the king should some day make an expedition against them in person, and become master of the difficult passage over the river, as well as of their defences generally’. — h( dia\ to
 potamo
 dusxwri/a, the passage of the Nile at Pelusium, on the E. frontier of Egypt. When Cambyses invaded Egypt in 625 B.C. he approached by way of Cadytis (Gaza), obtaining safe guidance through the desert from ‘the King of the Arabians’ (Her. III. 4.), — i.e. from some powerful sheikh, — who also provided a supply of water for the three days passage of the desert. Psammenitus, with his army, awaited the Persians at the Pelusiac mouth of the Nile, and was there routed by Cambyses, who next besieged and took Memphis (Her. III. 10 — 13). dusxwri/a, here, suggests the desert by which the Nile is approached from the E.

nu=n d' ou(=tos, k.t.l. The chronology of the revolt, spoken of here as not yet subdued, is uncertain. Schäfer (Demosth. u. seine Zeit, I. 436 f.) thinks that Artaxerxes Ochos made three expeditions against Egypt, viz. (1) On the occasion noticed, but without date, by Diod. XVI. 40. (2) In the winter of 351 — 350 B.C., when Nectanebos II. was assisted by Diophantus and Lamius: Diod. XIV. 48: cp. Isocr. Ep. VIII. § 8.
