This would be the expedition alluded to here, when the king was ignominiously repulsed. (3) In 340 B.C., when Egypt was reconquered, the king again commanding in person. See Thirlwall, c. 48, Vol. VI. p. 187 n.; Clinton, F. H. Vol. II. Append. c. 18. — Attic Orators, II. 172, note 4.

*ku/pron...*foini/khn...*kiliki/an See on Panegyr. § 161, p. 309. to/te me\n h)=n basile/ws is accurate only if we suppose Isocr. to speak of a moment soon after the Peace of Antalcidas in 387 B.C. The war between Persia and Evagoras of Salamis began prob. in 385 B.C. In 380 B.C. Cyprus and Cilicia had revolted and Phoenicia had been ravaged.

*)idrie/a Idrieus, second son of Hecatomnus [Panegyr. § 162, note, p. 310] succeeded his sister Artemisia as dynast of Caria in 351 B.C., and reigned till 344 B.C. On the chronology of the Carian princes cp. Clinton F. H. II. Append. c. 14 (Attic Orators, II. 173).

h)\ pa/ntwn, k.t.l. ‘else he would be the most heartless of men’ — sxetl., most devoid of natural affection. th
 ai)kisame/nhn...to
 a)delfo/n, ‘which ill-treated his brother’ Mausōlus. Idrieus, Mausolus and Artemisia were the three children of Hecatomnus. Artemisia married her own brother Mausolus, dynast of Caria from about 377 to 353 B.C. He seems to have died a natural death: Diod. XVI. 36 says merely e)teleu/thsen: but he had taken part in the revolt of the satraps from Artaxerxes Mnêmon (362 B.C., Diod. XV. 90) and may have suffered imprisonment. — polemh/sasan pro\s au)to/n: Idrieus began his reign as a loyal subject of Artaxerxes Ochos; but he may have thrown off his allegiance later, for Dem. alludes to him as to
 *ka=ra who had seized Chios, Cos and Rhodes (De Pace § 25).

qerapeu/ein ‘to court his favour’: alluding esp. to the fact that, soon after his accession in 351 B.C. Idrieus responded to a demand of Artaxerxes Ochos by sending 40 triremes and 8000 mercenaries against Cyprus: Diod. XVI. 42. — a)nape/mpein — from the seaboard to the Persian coast.

h)\n u(po/sxh|...kate/lusen ‘If you promise them liberty, and send abroad over the face of Asia that name, which had no sooner sounded in the ears of Greece than it destroyed our empire, as also the empire of Sparta’. The ‘liberation of the Greeks’ from Athenian tyranny was the watchword of Sparta in the Peloponnesian War: see esp. the speech of Brasidas in Thuc. IV. 86. The oppression of the cities by the Spartan oligarchies was the cause which chiefly discredited and at last ruined the Spartan h(gemoni/a: see Isocr. Panegyr. § 64, tw=n *ei(lw/twn e(ni\ douleu/ein (i.e. to the mo/qac Lysander, who set up the decarchies).

div2.p: . [Or. XIV.] — The revolution of 379 B.C. at Thebes had been a blow to Spartan influence throughout Hellas, and especially in Boeotia. Agesilaus in 378 and 377, Cleombrotus in 378 and 376, had invaded Boeotia without gaining any advantage. By the end of 376 the oligarchies supported by Sparta had been abolished in all the Boeotian towns except Orchomenus; and the Boeotian Confederacy, with Thebes at its head, had been reconstituted.

After its destruction in 427 B.C. Plataea had been left desolate till 386, when it was rebuilt by Sparta as a stronghold
against Thebes. Cut off from Spartan support, Plataea had come (377 or 376 B.C.) into the Boeotian Confederacy; but, like Thespiae and Tanagra (§ 9), had joined it unwillingly. The relief felt by most other towns at riddance from the philoSpartan oligarchies was more than balanced, in the case of Thespiae, Tanagra and Plataea, by hatred of Thebes. Diodorus states that the Plataeans secretly offered their town to Athens. At any rate the alarm felt at Plataea was so great that it was only on the days of public assemblies at Thebes that the men ventured to go into the fields, leaving their wives and children within the walls.

On one of these days a Theban force under the Boeotarch Neocles surprised Plataea, in the latter half of 373 B.C. The town was destroyed, and the territory was again annexed to Thebes. The inhabitants, with such property as they could carry, sought refuge, like their ancestors in 427, at Athens. Their case was discussed there, not merely in the Ecclesia, but in the congress of the allies (sune/drion § 21); Callistratus being the foremost advocate of Plataea, as Epameinondas of Thebes. It was not till 338, after Chaeroneia, that Plataea was restored; this time through the enmity of Philip, as formerly through the enmity of Sparta, towards Thebes.

The speech of Isocrates is supposed to be spoken by a Plataean before the Ecclesia; and there is nothing in the matter or form of the speech itself to make it improbable that it was actually so delivered. The date is 373 B.C. — Attic Orators, II. 176 f.

div3.head: Peroration: §§ 56 — 63.
div3.p: u(pe\r w(=n a(/pantas u(ma=s i(keteu/omen ‘Wherefore we supplicate you all to give us back our land and our city’. u(pe\r w(=n (neut.), in the name of the miseries which have been set forth (§§ 46 — 55). The town of Plataea had been wholly, or in great part, demolished, and the territory had been annexed to Thebes. The object of the appeal is to obtain the assistance of Athens in restoring the town and recovering the land. a(/pantas: all of you: in allusion to the fact that the Plataeans had some ties with Athens through marriage: § 51, tai=s me\n eu)noi/ais a(/pantes oi)kei=oi, th=| de\ suggenei/a| to\ plh=qos h(mw=n: ‘we are all your kinsmen in heart, and most of us in blood’.
periidei=n...paqo/ntas ‘not to see us crushed by sufferings even beyond those which have been recounted’. — paqo/ntas, not pa/sxontas: cp. Andoc. De Myst. § 53, a)poqano/ntas, note.

mo/noi ‘And you, above all the Greeks, owe us this good office, that you should succour us when we have been made homeless’. mo/noi o)fei/lete=unice debetis (not as implying that no other Greeks ought to pity them): cp. Soph. O. C. 260, ei) ta/s g' *)aqh/nas fasi\ qeosebesta/tas | ei)=nai, mo/nas de\ to\n kakou/menon ce/non | sw/|zein oi(/as te kai\ mo/nas a)rkei=n e)/xein.

tou=ton to\n e)/ranon (1) The primary notion of e)/ranos seems to be ‘a putting together’, ‘a collection’ (of money): from rt. a)r, with the fundamental idea of motion towards a goal which is attained: see Curt. Gr. E. 488. (2) Then e)/ranos=‘a subscription’ (whether for a pic-nic as opp. to an ei)lapi/nh, as in Od. I. 226, or for any other purpose). (3) Then figuratively, a contribution or offering to a cause: Thuc. II. 43, ka/lliston... e)/ranon au)th=| proie/menoi, ‘lavishing on the city the tribute of their lives’. Cp. [Dem.] In Aristog. I. § 22, ‘everything that each man among us does by injunction of the law is his contribution (e)/ranos) as a citizen of the Commonwealth’. At Athens there were organized societies which, as well as the subscriptions paid to them, were called e)/ranoi. Some of these were private clubs for social purposes; others, associations for mutual relief in case of need, with collecting officers, plhrwtai/: Dem. In Mid. § 184. Cp. Theophr. Char. I. tou\s daneizome/nous h)\ e)rani/zontas, ‘applicants for a loan or a subscription’.

a)nasta/tois ‘homeless’: lit. ‘forced to arise’. Used by Isocr. either of a ruined town, Panegyr. § 98, h( po/lis h(mw=n a)na/statos genome/nh — Athens sacked by the Persians: or a desolate house, a)nasta/tous oi)/kous, Arch. § 66, or a ravaged country, *)itali/a a)na/statos, Panegyr. § 169, or a population made homeless, o(mo/rous a)nasta/tous, ib. § 108.

e)n tw=| *persikw=| pole/mw| ‘For they say that when, in the Persian War, your fathers had quitted this land [Attica], our ancestors were the only people north of the Peloponnesus who shared their dangers and helped them to recover their city’. Isocr. is thinking here of the fact that the Plataeans (with the Thespieans) were the only Greeks who joined with the Athenians in meeting the Persians at Marathon: cp. Thuc. III. 54. But, as e)klipo/ntwn and sunanasw=sai show, he has confused this with the crisis of the later invasion, when Athens was twice occupied by the Persians — first under Xerxes, in the autumn of 480 B.C., secondly under Mardonius in the early summer of 479. Similarly in Panegyr. § 94 he supposes that the Persian offers which the Athenians rejected were made by Xerxes in 480 B.C. They were really made by Mardonius in 479. Cp. Grote V. 147.

h(/nper...u(pa/rcantes Dem. F. L. § 280, dia\ ta\s eu)ergesi/as a(\s u(ph=rcan ei)s u(ma=s: Lysias or. XXI. § 25, a)na/cia tw=n ei)s u(ma=s u(phrgme/nwn, a fate ill-merited by our former services to you. — tugxa/nomen u(pa/rcantes, we are in the position of having first rendered: ‘which we ourselves were in fact the first to render’.

ei) d' ou)=n ‘If, however’: d' ou)=n marking the descent from the greater to the lesser claim, as often the return from a parenthesis: e.g. Aesch. Ag. 34, Her. VI. 76: cp. my note on Soph. Ai. 28. — peporqhme/nhn: see on paqo/ntas, § 56.

shmei=a...katalei/petai ‘in which abide the greatest witnesses to the heroism of Athenians and of those who fought by their side’ [at Plataea, 479 B.C.]: viz. (1) the tombs of those who fell in the battle of Plataea, at which yearly honours were paid: (2) the festival of the *)eleuqe/ria, or Liberation, held once in every four years. Thuc. III. 58 (Plataeans to Spartan judges), i(ke/tai gigno/meqa u(mw=n tw=n patrw/|wn ta/fwn, ‘supplicate you by the tombs of your fathers’. Plut. Aristeid. 21, sunie/nai me
 ei)s *plataia\s kaq' e(/kaston e)niauto
 a)po\ th=s *(ella/dos probou/lous kai\ qewrou/s, a)/gesqai de\ pentaethriko
 a)gw=na tw=n *)eleuqeri/wn.

*qhbai=oi ‘The Thebans naturally wish to destroy them [ta\ shmei=a], since the memorials of those achievements are their shame’. In Thuc. III. 62 the Theban speakers seek to excuse the mhdismo/s of their fathers on the ground that (in 480 B.C.) the Theban government was neither a democracy nor yet an o)ligarxi/a i)so/nomos, but merely a dunastei/a o)li/gwn a)ndrw=n. ‘The Theban people, and the Boeotians generally, with the exception of Thespiae and Plataea, seem to have had little sentiment on either side, and to have followed passively the inspirations of their leaders’: Grote v. 104.

e)c e)kei/nwn, k.t.l. ‘for it was owing to those deeds that you acquired the leadership of Greece’. Thuc. I. 95 (478 B.C.), oi(/ te a)/lloi *(/ellhnes h)/xqonto (at the insolence of Pausanias) kai\ ou)x h(/kista oi( *)/iwnes kai\ o(/soi a)po\ basile/ws newsti\ h)leuqe/rwnto: foitw=nte/s te pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous h)ci/oun au)tou\s h(gemo/nas sfw=n gene/sqai kata\ to\ suggene/s, k.t.l.

e)kei=non to
 to/pon Plataea and its territory. Thuc. II. 71 (Plataeans to Archidamus, 429 B.C.), ma/rtura/s te qeou\s tou/s te o(rki/ous to/te [after the battle in 479 B.C.] genome/nous poiou/menoi kai\ tou\s u(mete/rous patrw/|ous kai\ h(mete/rous e)gxwri/ous le/gomen u(mi=n th
 gh=n th
 *plataii+/da mh\ a)dikei=n.

oi(=s kallierhsa/menoi When Pausanias offered sacrifice before the battle of Plataea, the signs were at first unfavourable; but when at last he looked towards the temple of
the Plataean Hera, and invoked her, au)ti/ka meta\ th\n eu)xh\n... e)gi/neto quome/noisi ta\ sfa/gia xrhsta/: Her. IX. 62. To Mardonius, on the other hand, ou) du/natai ta\ sfa/gia kataqu/mia (satisfactory) gene/sqai, ib. 44, 45.

xrh\ de\ kai\ tw=n progo/nwn, k.t.l. ‘You must take some thought, too, for your ancestors, and avoid an incidental neglect [paramelh=sai] of your duty to them also; for what would be their feelings — if indeed the departed [toi=s e)kei=] have any consciousness of what passes on earth — supposing they should become aware that, by your fiat, those who stooped to be the barbarian's slaves were being set as masters over their brethren, — while we, who fought the fight of freedom, have, alone of the Greeks, been made homeless; — that the tombs of those who shared their peril are deprived of the due honours, because there are none to render them, — while the Thebans, who stood in the ranks of the enemy, are lords of the land?’ The pro/gonoi invoked are not merely the Athenians who fell at Plataea, but the Athenians generally who were contemporary with the Persian Wars. — paramelh=sai: cp. Dem. Fals. Legat. § 175, dediw\s mh\ sumparapo/lwmai dia\ tou/tous, ‘fearing lest I should be ruined as an incident of their ruin’: cp. In Mid. § 116, parapo/lwlen ‘has incidentally become a victim’ (to Meidias, whose principal victim was Demosthenes).

ta/fous, k.t.l. Cp. the Plataean appeal to the Spartan judges (Thuc. III. 58): ei) ktenei=te h(ma=s kai\ xw/ran th\n *plataii+/da *qhbai+/da poih/sete, ti/ a)/llo h)\ e)n polemi/a| te kai\ para\ toi=s au)qe/ntais (their murderers) pate/ras tou\s u(mete/rous kai\ cuggenei=s a)ti/mous gerw=n (=tw=n nomizome/nwn here) w(=n nu=n i)/sxousi katalei/yete;

*lakedaimoni/wn Alluding to the destruction of Plataea in 427 B.C. — *qhbai/ois xarizo/menoi: so the Plataeans say, Thuc. III. 53, de/dimen mh\ a)/llois xa/rin fe/rontes (i.e. for the gratification of the Thebans) e)pi\ diegnwsme/nhn kri/sin (a prejudged case) kaqistw/meqa.

blasfhmi/as, k.t.l. ‘these evil rumours’: cp. Adv. Sophist. § 11, o(rw= ga\r ou) mo/non peri\ tou\s e)camarta/nontas ta\s blasfhmi/as gignome/nas. — e(/lhsqe: ‘do not espouse their violence, to the loss of your present repute’ (for e)piei/keia).

a)ll) au)tou\s...sunido/ntas ‘but you must comprehend in your own survey those points also which I have omitted, — you must think first of the oaths and compacts [exchanged with the Plataeans by the Greeks in 480 B.C.], next of our friendship with you, and of Theban enmity, — and so give the righteous sentence in our cause’. — sunido/ntas: cp. Nicocl. § 17, note.

div2.p: . [Or. VIII.] — ‘On the Peace’. Like the Areopagiticus, this is a political pamphlet with the form of a deliberative speech. In 357 B.C. Chios, Cos, Rhodes and Byzantium revolted from Athens. The Social War was concluded about midsummer, 355 B.C., by a treaty which declared the independence of the seceding states. The Speech On the Peace was probably written while negotiations for peace were pending, i.e. in the first half of 355 B.C.

The leaders of the War Party — esp. Chares and the orator Aristophon of Azenia — are the men against whom Isocr. directs this vigorous appeal. Athens, he urges, must resign pretensions to foreign domination (a)rxh/), and be content with the headship (h(gemoni/a) of a free league. The following passage is his censure on the corrupt public men of the day.

div3.p: w(=n e)nqumoume/nous ‘Remembering these things’ — the dangers of an ambitious foreign policy, as illustrated by the experience of Athens and Sparta, §§ 74 — 120.
th\n e)pi\ tou= bh/m. dunast ‘the mastery of the platform’ (in the Ecclesia): ‘the ear of the House’. Cp. Philipp. § 81, duna/sths — toi=s e)pi\ tou= bh/matos kalindoume/nois, note, p. 320.
proh/gagon Cp. Panegyr. § 174, note, p. 314.

a(\ kai\ pa/ntwn, k.t.l. ‘And, just for that reason, nothing is more surprising than that you elect’, etc. a(/, acc. referring to the whole preceding statement, lit. ‘and as to these things’ (like quod before si and nisi): cp. Thuc. II. 40 § 3, diafero/ntws ga\r dh\ kai\ to/de e)/xomen w(/ste tolma=n te oi( au)toi\ ma/lista, kai\ peri\ w(=n e)pixeirh/somen, e)klogi/zesqai: o(\ [acc., as to which thing, ‘whereas’] toi=s a)/llois a)maqi/a me\n qra/sos logismo\s de\ o)/knon fe/rei.
proxeiri/zesqe ‘elect’, lit. ‘make ready for yourselves’: cp. [Dem.] In Aristog. I. § 13, o(rw=n u(ma=s katata/ttonta/s me (designating) kai\ proxeirizome/nous e)pi\ th\n tou/tou kathgori/an.
e)pi\ me\n e)kei/nwn ‘in their time’ — i.e. when they were in the ascendant: cp. Philipp. § 95, dekarxi/as ta\s e)pi\ *lakedaimoni/wn, note, p. 325.
di\s h)/dh katal By the Four Hundred in 411 B.C., and the Thirty in 404 B.C. Cp. Lysias or. XXXIV. § I, p. 52.

ta\s fuga/s, k.t.l. ‘and that the exiles who were sent into banishment in the time of the tyrants [the Four Hundred], and in the time of the Thirty, were restored, not through the
mercenary adventurers, but through those who hate such men’. — fuga/s...katelqou/sas=fuga/das...katelqo/ntas. — tw=n tura/nnwn would more naturally mean the Peisistratidae; but e)n o)li/gw| xro/nw|, with di/s, excludes that view.
e(kate/rwn i.e. the supporters of an imperial policy (a)rxh/), and its opponents.
ou)de\ fqonou=men ‘nor are jealous’ — with a righteous jealousy or envy: cp. the use of fqonei=n in Panegyr. § 184, note, p. 317.

dasmologei= ‘levies imposts’, an invidious mode of describing the collection of the su/ntacis, as the tribute of the allies (fo/ros) was euphemistically called under the revived Athenian Confederacy. Cp. Panegyr. § 132, xrh\...toiou/tois e)/rgois e)pixeirei=n polu\ ma=llon h)\ tou\s nhsiw/tas dasmologei=n. So dasmoforei=n, Aesch. Pers. 586.

oi(=s d' ou)de\n u(ph=rxen a)gaqo/n ‘while men who began with no property — these, on the other hand [de/ in apodosis], have been raised from a low estate to wealth, through our folly’: a common topic of accusation against the demagogues, and often probably a false one. Cp. Lysias, or. XIX. § 48, speaking of the demagogue Cleophon (condemned to death by the oligarchs in 405 B.C.), prosedoka=to xrh/mata pa/mpolla e)/xein e)k th=s a)rxh=s, a)poqano/ntos d' au)tou= ou)damou= dh=la ta\ xrh/mata, a)lla\ kai\ oi( prosh/kontes kai\ oi( khdestai/, par) oi(=s kate/lipen (his legatees), o(mologoume/nws pe/nhte/s ei)si.

*periklh=s...dhmagwgo/s ‘Pericles, who preceded such men as these in the leadership of the people’. Thuc. uses dhmag. only in IV. 21, *kle/wn...a)nh dhmagwgo\s...kai\ tw=| plh/qei piqanw/tatos, where it has not necessarily a bad sense: cp. what he says of Pericles, II. 65, ou)k h)/geto ma=llon u(po\ tou= plh/qous h)\ au)to\s h)=ge. Lysias or. XXVII. § 10, kai/toi ou) tau=ta a)gaqw=n dhmagwgw=n e)sti, ta\ u(me/tera e)n tai=s u(mete/rais sumforai=s lamba/nein. Isocr. has the word again in Panath. § 148, *peisistra/tou...o(\s dhmagwgo\s geno/menos kai\ polla\ th
 po/lin lumhna/menos kai\ tou\s belti/stous tw=n politw=n w(s o)ligarxikou\s o)/ntas e)kbalw/n, teleutw=n to
 dh=mon kate/luse, k.t.l. Cp. Helen. Encom. § 37 (of Theseus), th=| tw=n politw=n eu)noi/a| doruforou/menos, th=| me
 e)cousi/a| turannw=n, tai=s d' eu)ergesi/ais dhmagwgw=n, ‘having for his body-guard the affection of the citizens, — placed in authority above the laws, but leading the people by acts of kindness’. Plato never uses the word. In Arist. the bad sense is usu. marked, e.g. Polit. VIII [V] II. § 12 (the flatterer is popular both in democracies and tyrannies), para\ me
 toi=s dh/mois o( dhmagwgo\s (e)/sti ga o( dhmagwgo\s tou= dh/mou ko/lac), para\ de\ toi=s tura/nnois oi( tapeinw=s o(milou=ntes.

pro\ tw=n toiou/twn meaning e.g. Cleon, Hyperbolus, Cleophon, and, among contemporaries, esp. Aristophon of Azenia. In this speech Isocr. distinguishes practically three stages of Athenian statesmanship: (1) the stage before Athens was imperial — represented by Aristeides, Miltiades, Themistocles, § 75: (2) the best period of the empire — under Pericles: (3) the period of its decline, and then of unbridled democracy, represented by the ponhroi\ dhmagwgoi/ (§ 129).

e)la/ttw...kate/lipen Thuc. II. 65, xrhma/twn...diafanw=s a)dwro/tatos geno/menos. Cp. Plat. Gorg. 515 E, tauti\ ga\r e)gw\ a)kou/w, *perikle/a pepoihke/nai *)aqhnai/ous a)rgou\s kai\ deilou\s kai\ la/lous kai\ filargu/rous, ei)s misqofori/an prw=ton katasth/santa: but even his enemies admitted his personal probity.

ei)s th\n a)kro/polin...xwri\s tw=n i(erw=n i.e. to the Treasury, the o)pisqo/domos, or chamber at the back of the Parthenon (Boeckh, I. 575), i(ero\n to\ o)/pisqen tou= a)du/tou, e)n w(=| kai\ ta\ dhmo/sia a)pe/keito xrh/mata, schol. Lucian Tim. 53. See Thuc. II. 13, where Pericles tells the Athenians that they have (1) 600 talents a year from the fo/ros of the allies; (2) 6000 talents [about £1,400,000] in money e)n th=| a)kropo/lei, — the greatest total having been 9700: (3) xrusi/on a)/shmon [uncoined] kai\ a)rgu/rion in sacred offerings, vessels, etc., to the value of 500 talents. Cp. Grote VI. 165.

ta\ a)melou/mena...h)ci/wsan ‘these neglected affairs, however, [ironical,=ta\ i)/dia au(tw=n, their private fortunes,] are found to have increased in a measure for which formerly [i.e. in the early days of their poverty, § 125] they would not have presumed even to pray to the gods’. — th\n e)pi/dosin: see on e)pido/seis, Evag. § 48, note, p. 291. — ou)d' a)\n eu)/casqai: cp. Panegyr. § 182, eu)xh=s a)/cia, note, p. 317.
oi( me\n...oi( de/ oi( me\n...oi( de/ are the two classes of the poli=tai: oi( me/n are the very poor, who suffer positive want: oi( de/, the comparatively rich, who are oppressed by public burdens.

peni/as...e)ndei/as ‘their narrow circumstances and their privations’: for the plural, cp. Antid. § 283, tai=s a)lhqei/ais, note, p. 303. — pro\s sfa=s au)tou/s, ‘to themselves’, i.e. ‘among themselves’ — since they find no sympathy from their so-called patrons, the dhmagwgoi/.

to\ plh=qos tw=n prostagma/twn kai\ tw=n leit ‘the number of arbitrary imposts and of public services’: prosta/gmata, lit. ‘dictates’ (cp. Panegyr. § 176, prosta/gmata kai\ mh\ sunqh/kas, p. 132), i.e. special taxes imposed at the will of the demagogues, and, in general, extraordinary demands on the citizen's purse or labour: leitourgi/ai, the ordinary or
regular services (ai( e)gku/klioi leitourgi/ai, Dem. In Mid. § 21) for the festivals — xorhgi/a, gumnasiarxi/a, etc., — not including the trierarchy, which is indicated by ta\ peri\ ta\s summori/as. The leitourgi/ai may be classified as (1) ‘recurring’ or annual, e)gku/klioi: (2) periodic at longer intervals, as the sacred missions, qewri/ai, to the great festivals: (3) extraordinary: e.g. missions to the Delphic oracle, and the trierarchy. See my note on Theophrastus Char. XXIX. (=XXVI.) p. 227.

ta\ kaka\ ta\ p. t. summori/as...a)ntido/seis ‘the vexations of the Navy Boards and Exchanges of property’. The duty of a trierarch was to maintain in efficiency, for one year, a trireme found, rigged, and manned by the State (Dem. In Mid. § 156), — the average cost being about £240 (ib.). Till 358 B.C. the trierarchy had been discharged by one person, or by two persons jointly. In 358 B.C. the 1200 richest citizens were divided into 20 summori/ai (‘partnerships’, ‘associations’) of 60 each, for the division of the burden, — a company (sunte/leia), usu. of 15, jointly defraying the cost of each trireme. This plan proved unfair to the poorer men, as the simple or dual trierarchy had been hard on the rich. Demosth. or. XIV. peri\ summoriw=n points this out (354 B.C., the year after this speech of Isocr.). A subsequent reform (340 B.C.?) distributed the burden acc. to assessed property, at the rate of one trireme to about £2400 of taxable capital. (Cp. my note on Theophr. Char. XXV.=XXII. p. 253.) — a)ntido/seis: challenges to exchange properties with the person on whom a leitourgi/a had been laid, or else to relieve him of it: see introd. to Isocr. peri\ a)ntido/sews, above, p. 299.
sunidei=n ‘see at a glance’ [i.e. comprehending in one view all that you know]: cp. Nicocles § 17, note, p. 284: Plataicus § 63, p. 332.

r(hto/rwn Thuc. has the word thrice, — always of the regular speakers in the Ecclesia, and always in a more or less unfavourable sense: III. 40, VI. 29, VIII. 1. Cp. Isocr. Panathenaicus, § 12, pa/ntes i)/sasi tw=n me\n r(hto/rwn tou\s pollou\s ou)x u(pe\r tw=n th=| po/lei sumfero/ntwn a)ll' u(pe\r w(=n au)toi\ lh/yesqai prosdokw=si, dhmhgorei=n tolmw=ntas. Philipp. § 81, p. 136, mh/te strathgo/s... mh/te r(h/twr...mh/te duna/sths.
th=s po/lews o)/ntas ‘are on the side of the Commonwealth and of its best advisers’ — opp. to u(f' au(toi=s ei)=nai, servile to the demagogues.

ei)saggeli/ais — grafai=s — sukofanti/ais ‘the impeachments [for offences more directly against the State], the indictments, and, generally, the vexatious proceedings of which they are the instruments’. Cp. Lysias Pro Mantith. § 12, p. 59, ou)/te di/khn ai)sxra\n ou)/te grafh\n ou)/te ei)saggeli/an.

div2.p: . [Or. VI.] — At the beginning of 366 B.C. Sparta, Athens, Corinth and the smaller states dependent on Corinth, as Epidaurus and Phlius, were allied, and were at war with Thebes and her allies, of whom the chief was Argos. But in that year the treacherous attempt of Athens to seize Corinth gave the Corinthians a sense of insecurity and a desire for peace. They accordingly sent envoys to Thebes, asking on what terms peace would be granted to the allies. The Thebans prescribed, as one condition of peace, the recognition of the independence of Messene, the new state founded by Epameinondas in 370. A congress met at Sparta. The Spartans refused to recognise the independence of Messene; and accordingly remained, with Athens, at war against Thebes. The Corinthians, Epidaurians, Phliasians, and probably some other small states, accepted the condition, and made peace on their own account, B.C. 366: see § 91.

The Archidamus is in the form of a deliberative speech. It purports to be spoken in 366 B.C. by Archidamus III., son of the king Agesilaus, during a debate at Sparta on the Theban proposal. There seems no reason to doubt that the speech was written in 366 B.C., either just before or soon after the actual decision of the question. It may have been composed in the first instance as an exercise; yet, as discussing a question of contemporary politics from the point of view which a large party at Sparta must really have taken, it claims to be considered as something more. Isocrates probably sent it to Archidamus, — not, of course, for delivery, but as a proof of sympathy with the Spartan policy. — Attic Orators, II. 193 f.

div3.p: w(=n e)nqumoume/nous Remembering the examples of recovery from apparently hopeless disaster — Dionysius of Syracuse, when he was on the point of abandoning his city to the Carthaginians (394 B.C.) — Amyntas II. of Macedon when compelled by the Illyrians to evacuate Pella (393 B.C.) — and Thebes, lately at the mercy of Sparta, and now the foremost State in Greece (§§ 40 — 51).

propetw=s...o(mologi/as ‘commit yourselves with headlong haste to shameful terms’. — propetw=s: cp. Philipp. § 90, p. 102, th\n *ku/rou prope/teian. — o(mologi/as: the articles requiring Sparta to recognise the independence of Messene.
h)\ tw=n a)/llwn ‘pursuing a less spirited policy in the defence of our own country than in the cause of others’ — e.g. of the Chians, the Syracusans, the Amphipolitans.

ei)...bohqh/seien...a)\n w(mologei=to ‘whenever a Lacedaemonian — were it but one — went to the rescue of an allied city under siege, it used to be allowed on all hands that the deliverance of the community was his work’. — a)\n w(mologei=to, expressing a customary action; so, though more rarely, with aor., Thuc. VII. 71, ei)/ tines i)/doien...a)neqa/rshsan a)/n: Goodwin § 30. 2. — para\ tou=ton, ‘all along of him’, i.e. indirectly the work of his spirit and example, even where it was not due to his personal effort.

para\ tw=n presbute/rwn ‘The greater number of such names may be heard from the older men among us, but even I can recount the most famous of them’. The speaker, Archidamus, was now (366 B.C.) about 35 years of age (new/teros w)/n § 1: see note in Attic Orators, II. 195). He means, — ‘though I am too young to remember these men, as my elders can, I am still familiar with their deeds’. para\ tw=n presb., k.t.l., is a reminder that the days of Spartan heroism are within living memory.

*peda/ritos When Chios revolted from Athens in 412 B.C., Pedaritus was posted there as Spartan governor: Thuc. VIII. 28. Soon afterwards the Athenians set about fortifying Delphinion, a promontory on the E. coast, ib. 38. Pedaritus — who received no support from the Spartan fleet at Rhodes under Astyochus — attacked Delphinion with a small force. He was defeated and slain, Thuc. VIII. 55. The words here, then — ei)s *xi/on ei)spleu/sas th\n po/lin die/swse — convey an inaccurate impression. Pedaritus did, indeed, hold out in Chios for a year, but his command ended disastrously. — Attic Orators, II. 198.

*brasi/das The majority in Amphipolis were loyal to Athens, and it was only by offering the most favourable terms that he enticed the place to capitulate (423 B.C.): Grote VI. 559. Thuc. IV. 106. — e)ni/khse: at the battle of Amphipolis (422 B.C.), in which both Brasidas and Cleon were killed. — o)li/gous: Brasidas made his sally against the retreating Athenians with a mere handful of men, — a)poleca/menos...penth/konta kai\ e(kato\n o(pli/tas, Thuc. v. 8. — tw=n poliorkoume/nwn: not inhabitants of Amphipolis, as the phrase suggests, but the Peloponnesian troops shut up in it: Thuc. l.c.

*gu/lippos Nicias having omitted to invest Syracuse in 415 B.C., Gylippus was able to enter it in 414, and in 413 crushed the Athenian force in the last sea-fight. du/namin th\n kratou=san au)tw=n, i.e. h(\ e)kra/tei, the Athenian force which was overmastering the Syracusans — against which, alone, they could not cope. — kai\ kata\ gh=n, k.t.l., with e)/laben, alluding to (1) the
sea-fight, (2) the defeat and surrender of the force retreating by land: Thuc. VII. 70, 84.

to/te me\n e(/kaston...nuni\ de\ pa/ntas ‘that, whereas in those days the individual Spartan was capable of guarding foreign cities, now the Spartans collectively should not even attempt to preserve their own land’. to/te me\n e(/kastos diefu/latten — nuni\ de\ pa/ntes ou)de\ peirw/meqa: when such a contrast is to be expressed in dependence on a comment, such as ai)sxro/n e)sti, the regular Greek idiom co-ordinates the clauses, turning diefu/latten as well as peirw/meqa into the infin. A modern composer would be apt to write (e.g.) ai)sxro/n e)stin, ei)/per to/te e(/kastos diefu/latte, nuni\ pa/ntas mhde\ peira=sqai.

e(te/ras me\n po/leis Alluding to such cases as those of Syracuse, Mytilene, Melos, all of which might be said, in some sense, to have suffered u(pe\r th=s *laked. a)rxh=s, in the cause of Spartan against Athenian ascendancy.

a)dhfagou/ntwn ‘eating their heads off’: Phot. 9. 23 e)/fh de\ kai\ a)dhfagou=sa *sofoklh=s kai\ a)dhfagei=n *(/ermippos (poet of the Old Comedy), Meinek. Frag. Com. p. 145. Cp. kriqw=n pw=los, Aesch. Ag. 1641, i(/ppos a)kosth/sas e)pi\ fa/tnh|, Il. VI. 506.
ou(/tw referring to w(/sper, i.e. ou(/tw poiou/meqa, w(/sper oi( ei)s ta\s d. a)na/gk. a)figm. (poiou=ntai or poioi=nto a)/n), ‘to make peace on conditions fit only for those who’, etc.
sxetliw/taton ‘most intolerable’: cp. Philipp. § 103, p. 105, sxetliw/tatos, ‘most heartless’: or. XVIII. § 35, le/cein w(s deina\ kai\ sxe/tlia pei/setai, ‘monstrous and cruel things’.

filoponw/tatoi ‘most laborious’: referring to the military and athletic exercises of the Spartans. Cp. Arist. Pol. v [VIII] 4. § 4, e)/ti d' au)tou\s tou\s *la/kwnas i)/smen, e(/ws me\n au)toi\ prosh/dreuon tai=s filoponi/ais, u(pere/xontas tw=n a)/llwn, nu=n de\ kai\ toi=s gumnasi/ois kai\ toi=s polemikoi=s a)gw=si leipome/nous e(te/rwn. Isocr. or. I. § 40, peirw= tw=| me\n sw/mati ei)=nai filo/ponos, th=| de\ yuxh=| filo/sofos. But of literary industry as opp. to physical effort, Epist. VIII. § 5, dwrew=n a)ciou=si tou\s e)n toi=s gumnikoi=s a)gw=si katorqou=ntas ma=llon h)\ tou\s th=| fronh/sei kai\ th=| filoponi/a| ti tw=n xrhsi/mwn eu(ri/skontas.

w(=n kai\ poih/sasqai, k.t.l. ‘worthy of any [kai/] mention’ — Thuc. I. 15, kata\ gh=n de\ po/lemos, o(/qen tis kai\ du/namis (any power) parege/neto, ou)dei\s cune/sth: IV. 48, ou) ga/r e)/ti h)=n u(po/loipon tw=n e(te/rwn o(/ ti kai\ a)cio/logon.

a(/pac h(tthqe/ntes by the Thebans under Epameinondas at Leuctra, 371 B.C.: cp. § 10 of this speech, ei) de/...prohso/meqa/ ti tw=n h(mete/rwn au)tw=n, bebaiw/somen ta\s *qhbai/wn a)lazonei/as kai\ polu\ semno/teron tro/paion tou= peri\ *leu=ktra...sth/somen kaq' h(mw=n au)tw=n.

mia=s ei)sbolh=s At this time (366 B.C.) Epameinondas had thrice invaded the Peloponnesus — in 370, 369, 367 B.C. But he had invaded Laconia only once — in 370 B.C. The next invasion of Laconia occurred shortly before the battle of Mantineia in 362 B.C.

pw=s d' a)\n...a)ntarke/seian ‘And how should such men [i.e. those who succumb to a single reverse] hold out against prolonged ill fortune?’ dustuxou=ntes implies ei) dustuxoi=en, but is in close connection with a)ntarke/seian.

*messhni/wn ‘Who would not reproach us, if, when the Messenians stood a siege of twenty years in defence of this territory, we should resign it so hastily under a treaty?’ The poliorki/a is the siege of Ithome in the first Messenian War, 743 — 723 B.C., acc. to the legendary chronology. Cp. § 27 dia\ tetrakosi/wn e)tw=n me/llousi katoiki/zein, they propose to restore Messene after the lapse of 400 years: where triakosi/wn would agree better with the common tradition that the Second Messenian War ended, and the conquest of the country by Sparta was completed, about 688 B.C. — Attic Orators, II. 197 — 9.

kai\ mhde\ tw=n prog. mnhsqei/hmen ‘and should not even mention our ancestors’ — i.e. should not once recall their laborious conquest of Messenia: — not ‘remember’, which would be memnw/|meqa (or memnh/|meqa).

div2.p: . [Or. VII.] — As a picture of the older Athenian Democracy this discourse supplements the Panegyricus. The latter describes the external relations of Athens in her great days; the Areopagiticus, the inner life.

In this speech Isocrates contrasts the Athenian Democracy as it existed in the middle of the 4th century B.C. with the Democracy of Solon and of Cleisthenes (§ 16). He dwells chiefly on two features of the elder Democracy: — 1. the preference of election (ai(/resis) to ballot (klh/rwsis) in the appointment of State officers, §§ 22 ff.; 2. the supervision of public morals exercised by the Council of the Areiopagus: §§ 36 — 55. It is owing to the prominence of the latter topic that the speech has been called *)areopagitiko/s. It is cast in a deliberate form. Isocrates supposes himself to have given notice in writing to the prytanes of an intention to speak ‘On
the Safety of Athens’ (peri\ swthri/as pro/sodon a)pogra/yasqai, §§ 1, 15); and to be now urging in the ecclesia, as absolutely necessary to the welfare of the city, the restoration of censorial power to the Areiopagus (cp. § 84). Like the De Pace (Or. VIII.), this speech was not delivered, or meant for delivery, in the Assembly. The deliberative form was adopted merely for the sake of giving greater life and impressiveness to the pleading.

The date is to be inferred from five indications: — (1) There was now peace on the frontiers of Attica (ta\ peri\ th\n xw/ran), and a confident sense of security at Athens, §§ 1 — 3: (2) The Athenians had ‘lost all the cities in Thrace’ (§ 9): (3) had spent more than 1000 talents on mercenaries, ib: (4) had got a bad name in Hellas and incurred the enmity of Persia, § 10: (5) had been forced ‘to save the friends of the Thebans’ and to lose their own allies. The latter half of 355 B.C. is the date to which these indications seem to point. (See Attic Orators, II. 202 f., where the question of the date is examined in detail.)

The powers exercised by the Areiopagus before the reforms of Ephialtes were of two kinds, definite and indefinite. The definite powers were: 1. A limited criminal jurisdiction: 2. the supreme direction of religious worship, especially of the cultus of the Eumenides. The indefinite powers were: 1. A general supervision of all magistrates and law-courts: 2. a general guardianship of the laws, with the right of protest (though not of veto) when proposed new laws conflicted with old: 3. a general control of the education of the young: 4. a general censorship of public morals: 5. competence to assume, in emergencies of the State, a dictatorial authority.

The definite powers of the Areiopagus were never at any time taken from it. But Ephialtes abolished almost wholly the indefinite powers. It is for the ievival of these — especially of (3) and (4) — that Isocrates is anxious. While it possessed these, the Areiopagus had been the strongest influence, though mainly a negative influence, in the State; it had been able to impress a conservative character upon the whole civic body. Deprived of these, it was merely a criminal court of narrow competence. Its connection with what was most venerable in the old religion, and the high standing of its individual members, still secured to it, indeed, a large measure of respect. Isocrates speaks of the good influence which, even in his own day, wrought on those who became members of the college. But politically the Areiopagus was now powerless. The plea of Isocrates for a restoration of its strength is strikingly illustrated by the protest of Aeschylus against its enfeeblement. It is not on any well-defined function, but rather on those prerogatives
which, being vague, were boundless, that orator and poet alike insist: —

Here, on the Hill of Ares, Once seat and camp of Amazons who came In anger against Theseus, and defied From their new ramparts his acropolis, And poured blood unto Ares, where is now The hill, the rock of Ares — in this place Awe kin to dread shall hold the citizens From sinning in the darkness or the light, While their own voices do not change the laws.
This Court, majestic, incorruptible, Instant in anger, over those who sleep The sleepless watcher of my land I set.
Attic Orators, II. 202: 211.

div3.p:
gegenhme/nas I believe this to be the true reading, and not gignome/nas (=ai(\ e)gi/gnonto, adopted by Benseler from the Urbino ms.), because the perf. better expresses the feeling of Isocr. that this glorious chapter of Athenian history was closed. The pra/ceis are the political and social life of Athens under the Old Democracy, and before the rule of the demagogues. Isocr. would date the latter from the death of Pericles — regarding the administration of Pericles as a transitional period, in which the deterioration, moral and political, was mitigated by the personal qualities of the leader: see esp. De Pace § 126, p. 109, *periklh=s...labw
 th
 po/lin xei=ron me
 fronou=san...e)/ti d' a)nektw=s politeuome/nhn, k.t.l.

kalw=s kai\ ta\ pro\s sfa=s au)tou\s ei)=xon, k.t.l. ‘were so happy in their relations to each other [i.e. in their social and private life], and in their administration of the Commonwealth’. Cp. Thuc. II. 37, a)nepaxqw=s de\ ta\ i)/dia prosomilou=ntes ta\ dhmo/sia dia\ de/os ma/lista ou) paranomou=men.
safe/steron For the form cp. note on Panegyr. § 163, e)rrwmeneste/rws, p. 311.

e)kei=noi ga\r...h)\ pai=des o)/ntes ‘The preceptors of the young Athenian's studies in that age were, indeed, numerous; but it did not follow that, when he entered on man's estate, he was allowed to do as he pleased; rather he was subject to stricter supervision just in the years of his prime than during his boyhood’. Affirmatively, the sentence would be: e)n me\n
tai=s paidei/ais pollou\s tou\s e)pist. ei)=xon, e)peidh\ de\...dokimasqei=en, e)ch=n, k.t.l. Place the whole in brackets: prefix ou)k: and we have the negative form. This is due to the Greek love of symmetrical antithesis, and therefore of co-ordinated rather than subordinated clauses. Cp. Archidamus § 54, to/te me/n, k.t.l., note, p. 339.

pollou\s tou\s e)pist e.g. paidagwgo/s, paidotri/bhs (teacher of gymnastics), grammatodida/skalos, a(rmoniko/s (music-master), etc.; after the age of 17, the e)pimelhtai\ tw=n e)fh/bwn or swfronistai/ (=the Spartan paidono/moi): Herm. Ant. III. § 34. 6, § 35. 18.

ei)s a)/ndras dokimasq At 18 the e)/fhbos (e)k pai/dwn e)celqw/n) passed his dokimasi/a as such: at 20, his dokimasi/a ei)s a)/ndras (a)nh\r ei)=nai dokimasqh=nai, ei)s a)/ndras e)ggra/fesqai): Herm. Ant. I. § 121. — e)n au)tai=s tai=s a)kmai=s, i.e. just in those years of early manhood when passion is strongest: cp. Antid. § 289, p. 123, e)n tau/tais...tai=s a)kmai=s o)/ntes u(perei=don ta\s h(dona\s e)n ai(=s oi( plei=stoi ma/list' au)tw=n e)piqumou=sin.

th
 swfrosu/nhn — th=s eu)kosmi/as ‘sobriety’ — ‘decorum’. Cp. Aeschin. In Ctes. § 2 (in reference to Solon's regulations peri\ r(hto/rwn eu)kosmi/as): the oldest citizen was to speak first, swfro/nws e)pi\ to\ bh=ma parelqw
 a)/neu qoru/bou kai\ taraxh=s. Dem. F. L. § 251, e)/fh to
 *so/lwna a)nakei=sqai th=s tw=n to/te dhmhgorou/ntwn swfrosu/nhs para/deigma, ei)/sw th
 xei=ra e)/xonta a)nabeblhme/non (with his cloak drawn round him, and his hand within the folds). See Attic Orators, I. 25.

h(=s...toi=s kalw=s gegono/si ‘membership of which [h(=s, sc. th=s e)c *)arei/ou pa/gou boulh=s] was possible only for the well-born’. If kalw=s gegono/sin is pressed, this is true only of the preSolonian time when the Areiopagus was confined to the Eupatridae: since Solon's reforms opened the archonship to the Pentakosiomedimni, and past archons (unless rejected at their eu)qu=nai on laying down office) ‘went up’ to the Areiopagus. Herm. Ant. I. § 109: Grote III. 162. But no such clear distinction is present to Isocr.'s mind, who is thinking only of the broad contrast between the old aristocratic Republic and the later Democracy. kalw=s gegono/tes cannot be explained as merely=kaqarw=s geg., ‘of pure Attic parentage’.

sunedri/wn ‘assemblies’ — a general term: cp. Nicocles § 19, p. 75: Antid. § 38, ou)/t' e)n toi=s sunedri/ois (Boulè or Ecclesia) ou)/te peri\ ta\s a)nakri/seis (preliminary law proceedings before the archon) ou)/t' e)pi\ toi=s dikasthri/ois ou)/te pro\s toi=s diaithtai=s.

tw=n peri\ th\n ai(/resin, k.t.l. ‘when the safeguards of election and of scrutiny have fallen into neglect’. In § 22 Isocr. had said that the Athenians of yore w)/|koun th\n po/lin, ou)k e)c a(pa/ntwn ta\s a)rxa\s klhrou=ntes, a)lla\ tou\s belti/stous kai\
tou\s i(kanwta/tous e)f' e(/kaston tw=n e)/rgwn prokri/nontes: and goes on to speak of the risk run by to\ lagxa/nein and h( klh/rwsis (ballot for office). The substitution of ballot (klh/rwsis) for election (ai(/resis), in the case of the nine archons, prob. dated from Cleisthenes. The strathgoi/, at least, and the tami/as (steward of the Treasury) always remained ai(retoi/. As regards most other offices, ballot was prob. substituted for ai(/resis about 478 B.C. But the term ai(/resis, in its general sense, included klh/rwsis as well as ai(/resis in the special sense (xeirotoni/a): so kua/mois ai(rei=sqai, Lucian Vit. Auct. 6. Here Isocr. is thinking of ballot as a mischievous substitute for xeirotoni/a: but the word ai(/resin prob.=merely ‘mode of selection’. — dokimasi/a, the scrutiny, before the boulh/, of those who had drawn the lot to be archons: including, here, the idea of the eu)qu=nai on retirement also.
a)nabw=sin Cp. Plut. Pericl. 9, di' au)tw=n [tw=n a)rxw=n] oi( dokimasqe/ntes a)ne/bainon ei)s *)/areion pa/gon (which was h( a)/nw boulh/): below, § 46, a)nh=gon.
th=| fu/sei xrh=sqai ‘to indulge their propensities’.
fo/bon...e)n tw=| to/pw| Cp. Aesch. Eumen. 659, pe/tra pa/gos t' *)/areios: e)n de\ tw=| se/bas | a)stw=n fo/bos te cuggenh\s to\ mh\ a)dikei=n | sxh/sei, k.t.l.

th
 dh\ toiau/thn...a)llh/lwn ‘Such then, as I have said [§ 37], was the Council to which they committed the care of good order; a Council which deemed those men ignorant who suppose that the best characters are produced in the communities whose laws are framed with the greatest precision; since (they felt) there was nothing to hinder all Greeks being on the same level, so far as concerns the facility of obtaining written codes from each other’. — th
 toiau/thn...h(/,=oi(/a (cp. Lys. or. XIII. § 13, note, p. 263): the omission of boulh/n helping to personify the influence. — e)ntau=qa,=e)n tou/tois, anteced. to par' oi(=s. — kei/menoi,=perf. pass. of ti/qhmi: cp. u(pekkei/mena, Aegin. § 18, p. 158. — a)gnoei=n=a)gnw/monas ei)=nai. — ou)de
 a)
 kwlu/ein, oblique either of a)
 e)kw/luen (nothing would hinder, whereas something does), or kwlu/oi a)/n (would conceivably hinder): better taken as representing the latter.

a)lla\ ga\r...paideuqw=sin ‘But in fact (the Council knew) it is not by such things that virtue is promoted, but by the pursuits of daily life; since most men retain the impress of the particular habits in which they have been educated’. paideuqw=sin a)/n, vivid for paideuqei=en, in spite of e)no/mizen, on which the whole oblique discourse depends: cp. Goodwin § 74. 1. — e)pithdeuma/twn: Thuc. II. 37, tw=n kaq' h(me/ran e)pit.: cp. Antiph. Tetr. B. b. § 10, note, p. 206.

e)pei\ ta/ ge plh/qh...a)nagka/z.] ‘For the number and precision of the laws (the Council held) is a sign that the city in which they exist [tau/thn] is ill administered; since it is in the attempt [pres. part.] to erect barriers against crime that such a community [au)tou/s] is compelled to multiply its laws’. plh/qh — a)kribei/as: for the plur. see Antid. § 283, note, p. 303. — ti/qesqai, of the legislator who is bound by his laws: tiqe/nai, of one who legislates only for others: kei=sqai, of the laws themselves. Dobree cp. Tac. III. 27, corruptissima re publica plurimae leges.

ta\s stoa\s e)mpipl. gramma/twn ‘to cover the walls of their porticoes with statutes’; Andoc. De Myst. § 85, e)dokima/sqhsan me
 ou)=n oi( no/moi, tou\s de\ kurwqe/ntas a)ne/grayan ei)s th
 stoa/n (i.e. the stoa\ basi/leios in the Agora). The yh/fisma cited there directs, tou\s de\ kuroume/nous tw=n no/mwn a)nagra/fein ei)s to
 toi=xon, i(/naper pro/teron a)negra/fhsan, skopei=n tw=| boulome/nw|. So here a)kribw=s a)nagegramme/nous=‘posted up’, ‘promulgated’, in strict terms.

kai\ toi=s a(plw=s keime/nois ‘even those laws which are conceived in simple terms’ — opp. to a)kribw=s, i.e. with less attempt to define rigorously a number of special cases. Cp. Lysias In Theomn. § 7, note.

di' w(=n — e)c w(=n dia/ — ‘by what means’: — e)c — ‘on [starting from] what principles’....paraskeua/sousi, ‘contrive’, often in a bad sense, of intrigue: cp. Lys. In Agor. § 12, p. 79, e)kei/nw| dikasth/rion paraskeua/santes.

to\ de\ peri\ ta\s timwri/as ‘but that to press for retribution is the province of personal resentment’: i.e. the affair of the injured. Cp. Lysias In Eratosth. § 2, pro/teron me\n ga\r e)/dei th\n e)/xqran tou\s kathgorou=ntas e)pidei=cai, k.t.l., where see note.
taraxwde/stata diak ‘subject to the most unruly passions’: cp. § 37, note on ei)s a)/ndras dokimasqei=en.

e)n mo/nois...ei)qisme/nous ‘for to such labours only [sc. toi=s ta\s h(dona\s e)/xousi], they saw, would those be constant, who had received a liberal education and learned to cherish a high spirit’. e)mmei=nai a)/n, oblique of e)mmei/neian a)/n. — For megalofronei=n we ought perhaps to read me/ga fronei=n. Isocr. has me/ga fronei=n in seven passages: or. II. § 30: III. §§ 35, 39: IV. §§ 81, 132: IX. § 45: X. § 35: but megalofronei=n only here. The only other place in a classical writer where megalofronei=n has strong ms. authority is Xen. Hellen. VI. 2. § 39, where Cobet would read me/ga fronou=ntos, and G. Sauppe gives mega/la fronou=ntos. In Plat. Protag. 342 D, and Alcibiades I. 104 C, it is merely an ill-attested variant. In later writers, however (though Pollux
III. 114 seems to condemn it altogether), megalofronei=n is not rare: e.g. Plut. Ages. 30, Joseph. Ant. XIX. 7. 3, Aelian Var. Hist. XII. 22. Cp. Cobet N. L. 269, 340, 643, Lobeck Ai. 443.

a)nwma/lws...e)/xontas ‘owing to the disparity of their circumstances’: ta\ peri\ to
 bi/on=th
 ou)si/an: cp. § 45 bi/on i(kano
 kekthme/nous.
ta\s gewrgi/as, k.t.l. Note the six plurals: see Antid. § 283, note.

ta\s a)pori/as me/n, k.t.l. This form of kli=mac (gradatio, ascensus) was specially called e)piplokh/, catena: cp. Dem. F. L. § 179, ou)k ei)=pon me\n tau=ta, ou)k e)/graya de/, ou)d' e)/graya me/n, ou)k e)pre/sbeusa de/, k.t.l. Cic. Pro Rosc. Am. 27. 75, in urbe luxuries creatur; ex luxuria existat avaritia necesse est; ex avaritia erumpat audacia, etc. Volkmann, Rhet. Gr. und Römer, p. 403.
a)palla/cein that they would draw away [the youth, tou\s newte/rous].

ta\ gumna/sia — ta\ kunhge/sia not here ‘the gymnasiums’, but ‘athletic exercises’: Plat. Laches 181 E, (to\ e)n o(/plois ma/xesqai is good for young men) ou)deno\s ga\r tw=n gumnasi/wn faulo/teron ou)d' e)la/ttw po/non e)/xei, kai\ a(/ma prosh/kei e)leuqe/rw| ma/lista tou=to/ te to\ gumna/sion kai\ h( i(ppikh/. — ta\ kunhge/sia: cp. the taunt of Aeschines against Demosthenes, In Ctes. § 255, ti/nes u(mw=n ei)sin oi( bohqh/sontes tw=| *dhmosqe/nei; po/teron oi( sugkunhge/tai h)\ oi( suggumnastai\ au)tou= o(/t' h)=n e)n h(liki/a|; a)lla\ ma\ to\n *di/a to\n *)olu/mpion ou)x u(=s a)gri/ous kunhgetw=n...diagege/nhtai.
o(rw=ntes ‘seeing that by these pursuits [tou/twn] some are made excellent men, and others are led to abstain from most vices’. a)pexome/nous, midd.
ou)de\ to\n loipo\n xro/non ‘neither did they neglect the [citizen's] later years’; i.e. they continued to watch over his adult life, as they had already watched over his boyhood and youth (§ 37).

kw/mas...dh/mous ‘taking the city by wards (kw=mai) and the country by townships, they continued to supervise each man's life’: dielo/menoi not necessarily implying that they were the authors of such a division, but only that they took this division as the basis of their systematic inspection. (Cp. Lys. In Erat. § 7, p. 66, dialabo/ntes ta\s oi)ki/as.) — kw=mai (vici), wards or quarters of the town; at Athens prob. merely local divisions, without any further political significance, Herm. Ant. 1. § 11. 11: the word perh. preserving a reminiscence of the time before the sunoi/kisis ascribed to Theseus, Thuc. II. 15. See Arist. Poet. III. 6, e)n *peloponnh/sw| [as in Lacedaemon] kw/mas
ta\s perioiki/das kalei=n fasi/n, *)aqhnai=oi de\ dh/mous. — The division into dh=moi (pagi) was ascribed to Theseus, and was at least much older than Cleisthenes. Plato, Legg. 756 D, has fratri/as kai\ dh/mous kai\ kw/mas, where, however, kw/mas may be ‘villages’. Isocr. seems to be the only writer who names the city kw=mai as parallel with the country dh=moi: cp. Herm. Ant. I. § 111. 4.
a)nh=gon Cp. § 38, a)nabw=si, note.
e)nouqe/tei — h)pei/lei — e)ko/lazen ‘admonished’ (for a first offence): ‘threatened’ (for repeated offences): ‘punished’ (the contumacious).

du/o tro/poi ‘for they knew that there are in fact (tugxa/nousin) two systems, one of which impels men to wrong-doing, while the other deters them from evil courses’: oi( kai\ protre/pontes kai\ pau/ontes=which respectively impel or deter. For ta\s a)diki/as and tw=n ponhriw=n, where the antithesis required opposites, cp. Antiph. De Caed. Her. § 87, note, p. 216.

par) oi(=s me
 ga...ta\s kakohqei/as The infins. dia- fqei/resqai...gi/gnesqai depend on h)pi/stanto: cp. §§ 40 — 42 (depending on e)nomi/zen § 39). — Observe the double me/n in the protasis (par' oi(=s me/n, para\ tou/tois me/n) balanced by the double de/ in the apodosis (o(/pou de\...e)ntau=qa de/). Cp. De Pace § 55, oi(=s me
 ga...sumbou/lois xrw/meqa, tou/tous me
 ou)k a)ciou=men xeirotonei=n,...oi(=s d' ou)dei\s a)
 sumbouleu/saito, tou/tous d'...e)kpe/mpomen.

e)cith/lous gi/gnesqai ‘malignant tendencies gradually disappear’. So Philipp. § 60, w)/ste mhde/pw nu=n e)cith/lous ei)=nai ta\s sumfora\s ta\s di' e)kei=non to\n po/lemon (the Peloponnesian) e)n tai=s po/lesin e)ggegenhme/nas, ‘have not even yet been effaced’. Cp. Xen. Oec. 10. 3, ei)...porfuri/das e)cith/lous fai/hn a)lhqina\s ei)=nai, ‘if I were to say that sham [quickly fading] purples were real’.
tosou/tou...e)/deon...lanqa/nein Cp. Philipp. § 100, tosou/tou dei=...a)/rxein, note.

tou\s e)pido/cous a(marth/sesqai not, ‘those who were meditating an offence’, but, ‘those on whose part an offence was apprehended’. For this use, cp. Isocr. Epist. IV. § 6, tw=n e)pido/cwn diafqarh/sesqai pragma/twn, ‘the affairs which seemed likely to be ruined’. So or. XX. § 12, tou\s e)pido/cous genh/sesqai ponhrou/s. In Archidamus § 8, e)pi/docos w)\n tuxei=n th=s timh=s tau/ths, the sense is, ‘being heir presumptive to this dignity’ (the Spartan kingship).

skirafei/ois, k.t.l. ‘gambling-houses’: cp. Antid. § 287, note. — e)n tai=s au)lhtri/sin, might=simply ‘among’, but prob.=‘in their part of the town’,=e)n toi=s au)lhtridi/ois (Athen. XII. 532). Cp. *keramei=s as the name of a district or deme, Plat. Prot. 315 D.

e)n oi(=s e)ta/xqhsan ‘were constant to the pursuits to which they had been appointed’ (by the paternal authority of the Areiopagus): cp. above § 44, ou(/tws e(ka/stois prose/tatton. Each man was given his ta/cis, his place in the ordered life of the city.
swfrosu/nhs ‘sobriety’ (of demeanour): see on th\n swfrosu/nhn, § 37.

e)n kaphlei/w| ‘in a tavern’. ka/phlos o( meta/bolos [read metaboleu/s, huckster] kai\ oi)nopw/lhs, Etym. M. 490. Athen. p. 566 F, *(uperei/dhs e)n tw=| kata\ *patrokle/ous tou\s *)areiopagi/tas fhsi\n a)risth/santa/ tina: e)n kaphlei/w| kwlu=sai a)nie/nai ei)s *)/areion pa/gon. Cp. Plato, Legg. 918 D, pa/nta ta\ peri\ th\n kaphlei/an kai\ e)mpori/an kai\ pandokei/an (inn-keeping) ge/nh diabe/blhtai/ te kai\ e)n ai)sxroi=s ge/gonen o)nei/desin.
bwmoloxeu/esqai ‘buffoonery’: cp. Antid. § 284, tou\s me/n ge bwmoloxeuome/nous kai\ skw/ptein kai\ mimei=sqai duname/nous eu)fuei=s kalou=sin, and note, p. 304.

eu)trape/lous ‘And indeed [de/, ‘again’, — to say nothing of positive bwmolo/xoi] the proficients in repartee and jest who are now called wits were then thought warnings’: eu)fuei=s — dustuxei=s, a paronomasi/a (cp. Panegyr. § 186, fh/mhn...mnh/mhn, note, p. 318). Arist. Eth. II. 7. § 13, peri\ de\ to\ h(du\ to\ me\n e)n paidia=| (playfulness) o( me\n me/sos eu)tra/pelos:...h( d' u(perbolh\ bwmoloxi/a...o( d' e)llei/pwn a)groi=ko/s tis. Eth. IV. 8. § 10, o( me/sos...ei)/t' e)pide/cios ei)/t' eu)tra/pelos [oi(=on eu)/tropos, ib. § 3: his mark is to\ e)mmelw=s pai/zein] le/getai: o( de\ bwmolo/xos h(/ttwn e)sti\ tou= geloi/ou, the buffoon cannot resist the temptation to raise a laugh (even when the joke is coarse, or will give pain): he differs from the ei)/rwn, again, in jesting, not for his own amusement, but for that of others (Rhet. III. 18). On the sense of eu)trapeli/a in Antid. § 296, see note.
katasta/sei ‘this state of things’ (not in a political sense, ‘constitution’).
toi=s o)li/gw| pro\ h(mw=n alluding to the reforms of Ephialtes about a century before (459 B.C.), by which the powers of the Areiopagus were restricted: see introd.
h(=s e)pistatou/shs ‘while that Council exercised a censorship’ — referring to its general moral supervision: cp. Aesch. Eum. 659, eu(do/ntwn u(/per | e)grhgoro\s frou/rhma.

dikw=n...e)gklhma/twn...ei)sforw=n (private) law-suits — (criminal) indictments (e)gklh/mata comprehending grafai/ and ei)saggeli/ai) — special war-taxes: the first two being parallel with peni/as, the third with pole/mwn.

para\ de\ tw=n Cp. Panegyr. § 82, toi=s me
 ga ou)x u(/peisi pra/ceis, pro\s de\ tou\s ou)k ei)di
 a(rmo/ttontes lo/goi. Bernhardy, Synt. p. 310, truly remarks that this use is peculiar to Isocr. among the orators, though not rare among other Attic prose-writers. — ei) pa/sxoien: they would say, a)gapw=men e)a
 mhde
 pa/sxwmen.
toiga/rtoi ‘Accordingly’: the notion is, ‘And so, sure enough’ — as might have been expected from these precautions.

kataskeua/s ‘establishments’. Thuc. II. 65, kala\ kth/mata kata\ th\n xw/ran oi)kodomi/ais te kai\ polutele/si kataskeuai=s a)polwleko/tes. So Pericles speaks of the country-houses and lands as khpi/on kai\ e)gkallw/pisma plou/tou, ib. 62. Demosthenes touches on the same topic in Olynth. III. § 25 f., i)di/a| d' ou(/tw sw/frones h)=san kai\ sfo/dra e)n tw=| th=s politei/as h)/qei me/nontes, so constant to a republican simplicity, that the house of Aristeides or of Miltiades is (e)sti/n, implying that it is still pointed out) no grander, semnote/ra, than the house of the ordinary citizen.

ta\s qewri/as ‘spectacles’ — including sacred processions (pompai/), dramatic or musical contests (a)gw=nes) at the festivals, etc. Cp. Panegyr. § 45, (h( po/lis, Athens) qea/mata plei=sta kai\ ka/llista ke/kthtai, ta\ me
 tai=s dapa/nais u(perba/llonta, ta\ de\ kata\ ta\s te/xnas eu)dokimou=nta. For qewri/a, cp. ib. § 44, pa/ntes e)pi\ th
 sfete/ran qewri/an h(/kousi, (knowing) that all come to see them (the athletes). So, too, or. XIX. § 10, ou)/te qusi/an ou)/te qewri/an (spectacle) ou)/t' a)/llhn e(orth
 ou)demi/an xwri\s a)llh/lwn h)/gomen. On the other hand, in or. XVI. § 34, th
 qewri/an has the technical sense, a sacred mission (to a festival).

xorhgi/as ‘rivalries in the equipment of choruses’ (for the festivals). Lysias speaks of two such xorhgi/ai together costing about £200 (or. XIX. § 42), and of another which cost about £120 (or. XXI. § 161). The a)neleu/qeros, or mean man, is apt, nikh/sas tragwdoi=s taini/an culi/nhn a)naqei=nai tw=| *dionu/sw| (a wooden scroll instead of a tripod); Theophr. XXII. (=XXV. in my ed., where see note p. 251). — a)lazoneiw=n, ‘forms of pretentiousness’.

e)c w(=nper, k.t.l. ‘It is by these tests [the every-day circum stances of the average citizen] that we must distinguish a solid prosperity from a social system of vulgar display’: fortikw=s — the profuse ostentation on great occasions, combined with sordid meanness and misery in daily life.

o(/tan i)/dh|...ou) bou/lomai le/gein ‘When he sees many citizens drawing lots in person outside the law-courts for a doubtful chance of daily bread, while their dignity prompts them to feed any Greeks who will row their ships for them, — leading the dance in gold-spangled raiment, and passing the
winter in garments which I decline to describe’. — e)n oi(=s ou) bou/lomai le/gein (au)tou\s xeima/zein): the simple oi(=s would have been by attract. for a(/.

klhroume/nous casting lots in the morning for employment as dicasts during the day: peri\ tw=n a)nagkai/wn, because on this depended the fee, triw/bolon. — ei)/q' e(/cousin ei)/te mh/, (casting lots, to see) whether they are to have ta\ a)nagkai=a or not. — Every year 600 members of each fulh/ were chosen h(liastai/ by lot, thus constituting a body of 6000, of whom 1000 formed a reserve. The other 5000 were divided into 10 sections of 500 each. On the morning of each day when the courts sat, lots were cast to determine which court should be assigned, for that day, to each section. In some cases only part of one section was employed; in others, two or more sections sat together, — the number of dicasts in a court ranging from 200 to 1500 or even 2000. The courts were assigned by lots to the dicasts (tw=n dikasthri/wn e)pikeklhrwme/nwn, Dem. Adv. Pantaen. § 39). Each dicast received a ticket (su/mbolon — not pina/kion, which denoted the tablet given to each of the 6000 heliasts of the year), and a staff, bakthri/a, of the colour which distinguished the court in which he was to sit (o(mo/xroos tw=| dikasthri/w|, schol. Ar. Vesp. 1110). On presenting his ticket, he received his day's fee from the kwlakre/tai.

All who ‘drew lots before the law-courts’ were already heliasts. The only uncertainty was as to whether they should be employed on that particular day. And this is the very point of the passage. The dicast's fee, wretched as it was, had actually become the main-stay of citizens who were living from hand to mouth. Cp. Isocr. De Pace § 130, p. 109, tou\s a)po\ tw=n dikasthri/wn zw=ntas: and Antid. § 152, where he says that he should have been ashamed ‘if, having enough of his own to live on, he should stand in the way of those who were compelled to live by the law-courts (e)nteu=qen) and to receive the dole of the state’. Hence the power of the sukofa/ntai, — the men who got up law-suits to enrich themselves and to make work for this hungry mob.

a)ciou=ntas in contrast with au)tou/s: the citizens, who themselves have to struggle for bread, are too proud to row their own ships. In the early years of the Peloponnesian War Athens employed ce/noi nauba/tai (Thuc. I. 121), but the commanders (kubernh=tai) and the hoplites on board (e)piba/tai) were usu. citizens. When the soldiers were also the rowers (as in a rare emergency) they were called au)tere/tai (Thuc. III. 18). The Pentakosiomedimni and Hippeis rarely served even as e)piba/tai (cp. ib. 16). Isocr. is not complaining of the citizens for not serving as rowers: he merely notes the contrast between their penury and their sense of dignity.

xoreu/ontas — xeima/zontas A paronomasi/a, like eu)fuei=s — dustuxei=s, § 49. Antiphanes, the poet of the Middle Comedy (flor. about 380 — 330 B.C.), was exactly contemporary with Isocr.; and, in the passage quoted by Athenaeus III. 62, he thus describes the uncertainties of human life —

o(/stis a)/nqrwpos de\ fu\s a)sfale/s ti kth=m' u(pa/rxein tw=| bi/w| logi/zetai plei=ston h(ma/rthken. h)\ ga\r ei)sfora/ tis h(/rpake ta)/ndoqen pa/nt': h)\ di/kh| tis peripesw\n a)pw/leto: h)\ strathgh/sas prosw=flen: h)\ xorhgo\s ai(reqei/s, i(ma/tia xrusa= parasxw\n tw=| xorw=| r(a/kos forei=.

toi=s e)pithd. kai\ tai=s au)tw=n e)pimelei/ais ‘by their pursuits’ [the intellectual or physical exercises mentioned in § 45, as distinguished from the agricultural or commercial labours assigned to the poorer] ‘and by the careful watch kept over them’: au)tw=n, tw=n newte/rwn, not tw=n e)pithdeuma/twn: the v. l. au(tw=n would mean ‘the care exercised by themselves’ (the Areopagites).

tou\s de\ presbute/rous...tai=s timai=s Isocr. tacitly refers to a time when the archons and other officers were chosen by xeirotoni/a, not by klh/rwsis, since selection by lot destroyed the prerogative of age: see § 38, tw=n peri\ th\n ai(/resin, k.t.l.

div2.p: . [Or. XIX.] — The six forensic speeches of Isocrates which are extent cover a period of about ten years, 403 — 393 B.C. The speech Against Euthynus (XXI) may be placed in 403, immediately after the restoration of the Democracy; that Against Callimachus (XVIII) in 402; the De Bigis (XVI) in 397 or 396; the speech Against Lochites (XX) in 394; the Trapeziticus (XVII) and Aegineticus (XIX) in the second half of 394 or early in 393.

In his later writings Isocrates nowhere recognises this phase of his own activity. He speaks with contempt of those who write for the law-courts, and emphatically claims it as his own merit that he chose nobler themes. It may have been partly the tone of such passages which emboldened his adopted son Aphareus to assert that Isocrates had never written a forensic speech. This statement is decisively rejected by Dionysius, who concludes, on the authority of Cephisodorus, the orator's pupil, that Isocrates wrote a certain number of such speeches, though not nearly so many as Aristotle had reported. The modern hypothesis that Isocrates composed the extant forensic orations merely as exercises (mele/tai), not for real causes, is another attempt to explain his later tone. But these later utterances merely mean that Isocrates regarded his former work for the law-courts as an unworthy accident of
his early life, previous to the beginning of his true career. Nowhere, be it observed, does he deny that he had written for the courts, or that, to use his own phrase, he had been a dollmaker before he became a Pheidias. He only says that his choice, his real calling, lay in another direction. — Attic Orators, I. 7 f.

The Aegineticus is so called because the case to which it refers was tried in Aegina, — probably, to judge from the indications in §§ 18 — 20 and 36, at the end of 394 or early in 393 B.C. Thrasylochus, a citizen of Siphnos, one of the Cyclades, had at his death left his property to the speaker, whom he had previously adopted as his son. The speaker's right to the inheritance is disputed by a daughter of the testator; and the speech is in answer to her claim (e)pidikasi/a). The case is tried at Aegina, where the speaker had settled (katoikisa/menos, § 24) before his death. — Att. Or. II. 217.

The narrative, of which the following passage is the chief part, is briefly as follows. The speaker's object is to show that the will is not only genuine, but also just and reasonable, since his own conduct towards the testator Thrasylochus had established a strong claim. In the first place he had saved the very property now in question. Thrasylochus and his brother Sopolis, citizens of Siphnos, had, for security, placed the greater part of their fortune in the neighbouring island of Paros. Paros was suddenly seized by a party of democratic exiles, Parians and Siphnians, led by one Pasīnus. At the risk of his life, the speaker sailed by night to Paros, and carried the endangered property back to Siphnos. Presently the democratic masters of Paros attacked and took Siphnos itself. The speaker — whose family belonged to the aristocracy of the island, and had even given it kings — was among those who were forced to fly. He took with him, not only his own mother and sister, but Thrasylochus, who was then in weak health. The speaker and his family wished to remain at Melos. But Thrasylochus entreated them to accompany him to Troezen; and, though they knew the place to be unhealthy, they consented. The speaker's sister and mother died soon after their arrival. He afterwards nursed Thrasylochus through a long and distressing illness in Aegina. During that illness the half sister of Thrasylochus, who now claims his property, never once visited him; nor, on his death, did she attend his funeral (§§ 16 — 33).

div3.p:
kai\ peri\ me\n tw=n palaiw=n...e)/xein ‘The whole story of the past would be long to tell: when, however, Pasinus seized
Paros, they [Thrasylochus and his brother Sopolis] happened to have the greater part of their property deposited there for safety in the hands of my Parian friends, as we believed that island to be more secure than any other’. tw=n palaiw=n: the early relations between the speaker and Thrasylochus, who had been friends from boyhood (§ 10). — *pa/ron: in 410 B.C. the oligarchy set up by Peisander during the rule of the Four Hundred was deposed by Theramenes, who established a democracy in its place (Grote VIII. 159). The oligarchy was doubtless restored in Paros, as elsewhere, after the final defeat of Athens in 405 B.C. From § 36 of this speech it is clear that the speaker belonged to the oligarchic party, and therefore that the exiles before whom he fled were democratic. The democratic revolution, led by the otherwise unknown Pasīnus, may have been encouraged by the blow dealt to Sparta — and at the same time to oligarchy throughout Hellas — by the victory of Conon at Cnidus in the autumn of 394 B.C. — u(pekkei/mena, perf. pass. of u(pekti/qhmi: cp. Thuc. I. 89, diekomi/zonto eu)qu\s o(/qen u(pece/qento [from Salamis, etc.] pai=das kai\ gunai=kas kai\ th\n periou=san kataskeuh/n: VIII. 31, o(/sa u(pece/keito au)to/qi tw=n *klazomeni/wn. — a)sfalw=s e)/xein: i.e. Paros was most likely to resist an attack (showing that this was a time of general trouble) — as it had baffled Miltiades in 490 B.C., Her. VI. 132 f.
e)ceko/mis' au)toi=s ‘conveyed their money for them out of Paros’ [back to the neighbouring island of Siphnos — a distance of about 20 miles].

e)frourei=to ‘for the coast (of Paros) was guarded, and some of our exiles [democrats expelled by the oligarchs of Siphnos] had helped to seize Paros’. sugkateil.: cp. § 18, kate/laben. So Xen. Cyr. IV. 2. 42, toi=s sugkateilhfo/si, those who have helped us to take (the camp).

a)pe/kteinan au)to/xeires geno/menoi ‘slew with their own hands’ (when Siphnos was subsequently taken, § 20). Cp. Isocr. Panegyr. § 111, tou\s au)to/xeiras kai\ fone/as tw=n politw=n, ‘the assassins and murderers’. Archid. § 150, ou) ga\r au)to/xeires ou)/te tw=n a)gaqw=n ou)/te tw=n kakw=n gi/gnontai, ‘(the gods) do not give either good or evil with their own hands to men’ (but only implant the e)/nnoia which leads to either).
fugh=s h(mi=n ‘when we were compelled to fly from our island’ (Siphnos, which the democratic exiles, masters of Paros, next attacked).
tw=n sfete/rwn au)tw=n genit. of oi( sfe/teroi au)tw=n, their own kinsfolk. Lysias In Agor. § 45, p. 88, oi( me\n gone/as sfete/rous au)tw=n presbu/tas katalipo/ntes.

ou)k h)ga/phsa ei)...dunhqei/hn ‘was not content with the hope
of being able’ [the historical form of ou)k a)gapw e)a
 dunhqw=]. Cp. Areopagit. § 52, p. 156, w(/st' a)gapa=n e)kei/nous ei) mhde
 e)/ti kako
 pa/sxoien. — ei)dw/s, ‘although I knew’.

suneceko/mis) au)tw=|, k.t.l. ‘I conveyed out of Siphnos, not only Thrasylochus, but also my mother, my sister and all our property’. Cp. § 23, th
 mhte/ra th
 e)mautou= kai\ th
 a)delfh/n. From Melos (§ 21) they removed to Troezen. The speaker's mother and sister both died within 35 days after their arrival (§ 22). Thrasylochus had subsequently removed from Troezen to Aegina (§ 24), and there fell into the illness of which — after more than a year — he died (to
 me
 plei=ston xro/non...e(\c de\ mh=nas, § 24).

ta\ me\n toi/nun ei)rhme/na...perie/peson ‘Thus far, I have spoken of services which, though they exposed me to risk, entailed no loss [viz. his voyage to Paros for the money, kinduneu/sas peri\ tou= sw/matos, § 18, and the escape from Siphnos]; but I can mention others by which, in obliging him, I brought the gravest afflictions on myself’. — a)pe/lausa: cp. § 23, a)gaqo\n a)pole/lauka.

*mh=lon Melos is about 12 miles S.W.S. of Siphnos: from Melos it is a voyage of about 75 miles N.W. to Troezen on the coast of Argolis — just opposite the little island Calauria (where Demosthenes died — now Poro, po/ros, because the narrow strait can sometimes be forded).
me/lloimen ‘that we intended’, — meaning the speaker, his mother and sister: so below, e)/docen h(mi=n.

kai\ o(/ti xwri\s e)mou=...pra/gmasin ‘and (representing, le/gwn) that, without me, he will be utterly helpless in his affairs’. He said, ou)de\n e(/cw: the fut. opt. in classical Greek being used only to translate, after secondary tenses in oratio obliqua, a fut. indic. of the direct discourse: Goodwin § 26. In ou)k e)/xw ti/ xrh/somai or xrw=mai (deliberative subjunctive) tou/tw|, ti/ is a cognate accus. [not an adverb],=ou)k e)/xw ti/na xrei/an xrw=mai tou/tw|, I do not know what use to make of this, — what to do with it. The phrase is used colloquially to express helplessness or bewilderment: Her. VII. 213, a)pore/ontos de\ basile/os o(/ ti xrh/setai tw=| pareo/nti prh/gmati, not knowing what to make of the situation. Cp. Isocr. Panath. § 106, diarrh/dhn gra/yantes xrh=sqai tou=q' o(/ ti a)\n au)to\s bou/lhtai, ‘on the express understanding that he should do with them [au)toi=s understood] whatever he pleased’.

ou)k e)/fqhmen...kai\...e)lh/fqhmen ‘No sooner had we arrived, than we were seized’. Cp. Panegyr. § 86, oi( d' ou)k e)/fqhsan puqo/menoi to
 peri\ th
 *)attikh
 po/lemon kai\...h(=kon. Isocr. uses e)/fqasa, fqa/saimi, as well as e)/fqhn, but infin.
fqh=nai, not fqa/sai: Thuc. has both fqh=nai and fqa/sai: Xen. and Dem. fqa/sai.

para\ mikro
 h)=lqon a)poqanei=n ‘I very nearly died’. In such phrases (par' e)la/xiston, par) o)li/gon, para\ tosou=ton, etc.) para/=‘beside’ in the sense of ‘except’: I came — save for a narrow margin — to death: the infin. depending on para\ mikro
 h)=lqon as=e)kindu/neusa. In Her. IX. 33, para\ e(
 pa/laisma e)/drame nika=n o)lumpia/da, e)/drame is rhetorical for h)=lqe: ‘he missed the Olympic prize by nothing but a wrestling-match’: i.e. he won two of the first four contests in the pe/ntaqlon, but lost ‘the odd event’, the wrestling-match (pa/lh). In Aeschin. In Ctes. § 258, par' ou)de
 h)=lqon a)poktei=nai=‘they all but put him to death’, ou)de/n is rhetorical for mikro/n — there was nothing to spare.

ti/n) oi)/esqe...gnw/mhn e)/xein...;] ‘what do you suppose my feelings were?’ Cp. Soph. Philoct. 276, su\ dh/, te/knon, poi/an m' a)na/stasin dokei=s | au)tw=n bebw/twn e)c u(/pnou sth=nai to/te; Isocr. Plataic. § 61, pw=s a)\n diateqei=en, k.t.l., ‘how would they feel?’
o(\s...h)=n=qui (or quom) fuissem. Cp. Soph. Electr. 595, ou)de\ nouqetei=n e)/cesti/ se, | h(\ pa=san i(/hs glw=ssan, and my note on 599. For this causal use of the relative, see Goodwin § 65. 4.

metoikei=n ste/resqai ‘live as an alien’. Lysias In Eratosth. § 20, p. 70, ou)x o(moi/ws metoikou=ntas w(/sper au)toi\ e)politeu/onto, ‘better resident aliens than they were citizens’. — (tou=) ste/resqai de\ tw=n [masc.] ‘separation from my friends’ (in Siphnos): =carere, not sterei=sqai, privari.
teleutw/sas Not teleuthsa/sas. He has related their death: but now his thoughts go back to the month or more (§ 22) after the arrival at Troezen, during which he saw them dying.

a)pole/lauka Note the perfect, where a)pe/lausa (§ 21) might have stood. It hints the speaker's confidence that the will cannot be upset. Cp. Antid. § 295, p. 125, h( po/lis h(mw=n dokei= gegenh=s qai dida/skalos, seems to be the established teacher.

h)sqe/nhse tau/thn th\n no/son e)c h(=s ‘took the illness of which he died’: tau/thn, as opp. to the indisposition (a)rrwsti/a) from which he suffered at the time when they left Siphnos, § 20. — h)sqe/nhse: for the force of the aor., cp. h)=rce, e)basi/leuse, ‘came to the throne’.

w(s ou)k oi)=d' o(/stis, k.t.l. ‘as perhaps no one ever yet tended another’: ou)k oi)=d' o(/stis=i)/sws ou)dei/s, (cp. haud scio an nemo=fortasse nemo:) Eur. Med. 941, ou)k oi)=d' a)\n ei) pei/saimi, peira=sqai de\ xrh/, i.e. ‘perhaps I may not persuade him, but I must try’: ou)k oi)=da ei) [=i)/sws ou)] pei/saimi a)/n. Cp. Goodwin § 42.
to\n me\n plei=ston, k.t.l. showing, in connection with e(\c mh=nas, that the illness lasted more than a year.

tw=n suggenw=n ‘And in this painful office not one of his relatives thought proper to bear a part; nay, not one of them even came to visit him, with the exception of his mother and sister, who only made matters worse, for they were ill when they came from Troezen, so that they required nursing themselves’. ou)dei\s h)ci/wsen...a)ll' ou)d' a)fi/keto: a)lla/ here= ‘nay’, ‘what is more’: the commoner form would be, ou)dei/s... ou)x o(/pws h)ci/wse (not only did not), a)ll' ou)d' a)fi/keto (but did not even...). — e)piskeyo/menos. The Modern Greek for making a visit or call is e)piske/ptomai, a visit e)pi/skeyis, a visiting-card e)piskepth/rion.

ple/on qa/teron e)poi/hsan ‘made matters worse’. qa/teron= to\ kako/n. Soph. Phil. 503, paqei=n me
 eu)= paqei=n de\ qa)/tera: O. C. 1443, tau=ta/ g' e)n tw=| dai/moni | kai\ th=|de fu=nai xa)te/ra|, that they should issue thus [i.e. happily] or otherwise. Dem. In Androt. § 12, o(/sa pw/pote th=| po/lei ge/gonen h)\ nu=n e)/stin agaqa\ h)\ qa/tera, i(/na mhde
 ei)/pw flau=ron. Pind. Pyth. III. 60, dai/mwn e(/teros, where schol., o( kakopoio/s, w(s pro\s (as contrasted with) to
 a)gaqopoio/n.

ou)k a)pei=pon ou)d' a)pe/sthn, k.t.l. ‘I did not lose heart, or desert my post’. Cp. Philipp. § 85, p. 137, ou) mh\n a)postate/on e)sti/n, I must not desist from my task. — e)nosh/leuon, ‘nursed him, with the help of one attendant’. Anaxilas (Middle Comedy) *ma/geiroi (Meinek. Com. Frag. 501), ti/ su\ le/geis; i)xqu/dia; sussi/tion (Mein. su/ssiton ou)=n) me/lleis noshleu/ein o(/son: ‘What? broil fish?’ (instead of more solid food): — ‘what invalid's fare you are going to give your mess!’ noshlei/a, the care of the sick, Plut. Lycurg. 10, (a luxurious life) tro/pon tina\ noshlei/as kaqhmerinh=s deome/nhn, in need, as it were, of daily nursing.
e)kei/nwn qauma/zein, ei) mh/ cp. Lys. or. XXXIV. § 2, note, p. 240.

o(\s e)/mpuos ‘for he had long been suffering from ulcers’: e)/mpu_os (pu=on), puris plenus, e)mp. ba/sis, the festering foot of Philoctetes, Soph. Ph. 1378. — o(/s...h)=n=e)pei\ e)kei=nos h)=n, the causal use of the relative (Goodwin § 65. 4, cp. above § 23): the anteced. is Thrasylochus, the subj. of die/keito.

tau=t' ou)de/na xro/non die/lipen ‘And all this went on without intermission’: die/lipen, intrans.: ou)de/na xro/non, accus. denoting duration of time, ‘not for a moment’. Isocr. Panathen. § 5, ou)de/na diale/loipa xro/non diaballo/menos, ‘I have never for a moment ceased to be slandered’. dialei/pein is said also of the interval which elapses, Thuc. III. 74, dialipou/shs h(me/ras.

ou)de\ ga\r a)pelqei=n, k.t.l. ‘for I could not even quit him without seeming neglectful, — a thing from which I shrank far more than from the troubles which beset me’: i.e. he could not
endure to pain the sick man. — h)\ dokei)=n a)melei=n, short for h)\ [or else, i.e. ei) a)pe/lqoimi, if I should go away] e)/dei [supplied kat' e)/nnoian from oi(=o/n t' h)=n] dokei=n a)melei)=n, I could not but seem neglectful. The sentence=e)/dei mh\ a)pelqei=n, h)\ [=ei) de\ mh\] dokei=n a)melei=n. Cp. Thuc. II. 63, ei)ko/s...mh\ feu/gein tou\s po/nous, h)\ [=ei) de\ mh/, i.e. if you do shirk them] mhde\ ta\s tima\s diw/kein.

div2.p: . [Epist. v.] — In writing to Philip of Macedon, who was not then at open war with Athens, Isocrates takes the opportunity of enclosing a letter to the young Alexander. Philip was in Thrace or the Chersonese from May, 342 B.C., to the latter part of 339 B.C.; and, at some time after his departure, appointed Alexander his regent in Macedonia. But, when this letter was written, that arrangement had not yet been made. Alexander, a boy of fourteen, is busy with his studies. It was probably in this very year (342 B.C.) that Alexander began to receive the lessons of Aristotle.

div3.p: pro\s to\n pate/ra...gra/fwn referring, probably, to Epist. II. of the extant series, in which Isocr. remonstrates with Philip for recklessly exposing his life, and urges him to intervene in the affairs of Athens with the same prudence which he had just shown (342 B.C.) in constituting the Thessalian tetrarchy: see Attic Orators, II. 250.

Apophth. Lac. 222 D, w(s e)/gnw ou)x oi(=o/n t' ei)=nai sumbalei=n au)tw=|, to confer with him. The midd. is more suitable when those who consult are equals; the act. here suggests the prince bringing business before a council over which he presides.

pleonektikh/n ‘advantageous’: on the good sense of pleoneci/a see Antid. § 281, p. 303.
toi=s tou= plh/qous proestw=sin ‘the leaders of a democracy’: cp. Panegyr. § 172, p. 130, oi( proestw=tes h(mw=n.
