th\n paidei/an th\n peri\ tou\s lo/gous ‘the discipline of those discourses which we bring to bear on the acts incident to daily life, and which aid us in the discussion of public affairs’. On the lo/gwn paidei/a of Isocr., see Adv. Sophist., introd., p. 292, and Antid., introd., p. 299.

doca/zeis...e)pisth/sei...kri/nein Isocr. taught that it was impossible to know (e)pisth/mhn labei=n) ‘what is to be done or said’ (Antid. § 271, n., p. 301), in the sense that the precise circumstances of a future situation cannot be foreseen: but that the study of political questions (u(poqe/seis...peri\ tw=n koinw=n pragma/twn, ib. § 276, p. 119) will form intelligent opinion, do/ca. He held, further, that he who cultivates the art of persuasion will cultivate a)reth/, moral excellence, as a means to that end, ib. § 278. And so here he claims for his paidei/a that, through it, Alexander (1) is already able to form intelligent conjecture, do/ca, about the future: (2) that he will know, when the time comes, the principles of government — e)pisth/sei hinting that he would be at no disadvantage as compared to the pupils of those who profess to impart absolute e)pisth/mh, Adv. Soph. § 8, p. 112: (3) that he will be able to distinguish between justice and injustice, merit and demerit — i.e. will be a judge of a)reth/. Cp. Nicocles § 15, ai( de\ monarxi/ai plei=ston me\n ne/mousi tw=| belti/stw|, k.t.l.

div2.p: . [Epist. III.] — A letter written to Philip of Macedon in 338 B.C., some time after the battle of Chaeroneia, when Isocrates had completed his ninety-eighth year. It is thus the latest of all his extant writings.

The genuineness of the Third Letter has been doubted (as by Prof. E. Curtius Hist. Gr. v. 459): but there seems to be no ground, internal or external, for doubting it, except the difficulty of reconciling it with the tradition that Isocrates committed suicide on learning the tidings of Chaeroneia. [Dionys. De Isocr. I.; Paus. I. 18. 8; Philostr. I. 17. 4; Lucian (?) *makro/bioi § 23; (Plut.) Vit. Isocr. § 14; Anon. Biogr.] According to the usual account, he was in the palaestra of Hippocrates at Athens when he heard the news of
the fatal defeat. He repeated three verses of Euripides — verses commemorating three aliens who had been conquerors of Greeks, — Danaus, Pelops, Cadmus — and four days afterwards, on the burial-day of those who fell at Chaeroneia, he died of voluntary starvation. Undoubtedly Isocrates regretted the struggle between Athens and Philip: but the result of the struggle was that the idea of his life — a Panhellenic war against the barbarian — had been made possible. The conduct of Philip to Athens after Chaeroneia was studiously temperate and conciliatory; there was nothing in it to estrange Isocrates from his ideal leader, who, having struck one necessary blow, was now bent on healing the discords of Greece. It would be more easy to conceive that Isocrates should have destroyed himself because he saw Athens still resolved to resist, and could not support the anguish of a divided loyalty. But, to my mind, the Letter itself leaves little room for doubting that it was written after the conclusion of the peace between Philip and Athens, and was taken to Philip by Antipater on his return: see §§ 1, 2. Cp. Schäfer, Demosth. u. seine Zeit, III. 25. — Attic Orators, II. 31 f.: 255, note 1.

div3.p: diele/xqhn kai\ pro\s *)anti/patron Demades, who had been taken prisoner at Chaeroneia, was sent by Philip to Athens as the bearer of proposals for peace. The Athenian captives were to be restored: Oropus was to be transferred from Thebes to Athens. On the other hand, Athens was required to recognise Philip as the military head of Greece. On receiving this message, the Athenian Ecclesia sent an embassy to Philip, who was then at Thebes. Among the envoys were Demades, Phocion and Aeschines. They were hospitably entertained by Philip, and returned to Athens with the message that Philip released the prisoners without ransom, and would presently send, for interment at Athens, the remains of those who had fallen at Chaeroneia.

Antipater, the young Alexander, and probably Alcimachus, were the envoys who escorted these relics to Athens. By them the conditions of peace were formally proposed to the Senate and the Ecclesia. Demades then drew up a yh/fisma by which the treaty — known as ‘the Peace of Demades’ — was finally ratified. The ‘conversation with Antipater’, to which Isocr. refers, must have been held on the occasion of this visit. (Cp. Schäfer, Dem. III. 19 — 27.)

Disting. the pluperf. from the perf. of the direct discourse: Isocr. said to them, ou)k oi)=da — ou) sunegegenh/mhn — oi)/omai au)to\n e)gnwke/nai (=o(/ti e)gnw/kei), e)me\ (or e)gw\) de\ suneirhke/nai (=o(/ti sunei/rhka).

div1.head: Isaeus
div1.p: ISAEUS: born circ. 420 B.C.: died circ. 350 B.C. Approximate period of extant work: 390 — 353 B.C. Life in Attic Orators, II. 261 — 271.

Style. Isaeus has a twofold interest. He is the earliest Attic master — not, indeed, of forensic rhetoric — but of strict forensic argument. He also represents the final period of transition in the history of Attic oratory, the transition from the studied ‘plainness’ (a)fe/leia) of the Lysian school to the open triumph of that technical mastery (deino/ths) which reached its summit in Demosthenes. We have seen that the peculiar significance of Isocrates is rather for literary rhetoric than for oratory. With Isaeus, we return to the development of practical oratory: and his place in this must be determined, first, by his relation to his predecessor Lysias, secondly by his relation to Demosthenes.

Isaeus closely resembles Lysias in diction (le/cis): the qualities of purity, conciseness, clearness, simplicity, vividness (e)na/rgeia) are common to both. In composition (su/nqesis), on the other hand, there is marked difference. Lysias broke through the rigid monotony of the earlier periodic style, replacing it by one which was more flexible and various: yet, though his composition as a whole has ease and variety, his love of antithesis frequently gives too much stiffness and uniformity to the structure of his periods themselves. Isaeus is exempt from this excessive love of antithesis: but, on the whole, his composition is distinguished from that of Lysias mainly by the stamp of conscious art. In reading him we have a continual sense of trained and confident skill. The more open and vigorous character of this art, as compared with that
of Lysias, is illustrated by the freedom with which Isaeus employs the animated ‘figures of thought’ (sxh/mata dianoi/as), especially the rhetorical question (e.g. or. VIII. § 28, p. 194). This does not deprive Isaeus of ethical persuasiveness. Reasoned remonstrance, vigorous contention, just indignation, are powerfully expressed: it is only in the delineation of the ingenuous youth or the plain citizen that he yields to the veiled subtlety of Lysias. In the treatment of subject-matter the contrast gains strength. Lysias is usually content with the simple four-fold partition, — prooi/mion, dih/ghsis, pi/steis, e)pi/logos. Isaeus interweaves narrative and proof, managing his complex material with manifold tactics, — doing everything with art, but nothing by rule. Lysias seldom attempts more than a rhetorical or sketchy proof: Isaeus elaborates a complete logical proof: as Dionysius says, Lysias speaks kat' e)nqu/mhma, but Isaeus, kai\ kat' e)pixei/rhma (Attic Orators, II. 289).

‘The oratorical power’ (deino/ths) ‘of Demosthenes’, says the same critic, ‘took its seeds and beginnings (ta\ spe/rmata kai\ ta\s a)rxa/s, Isae. 20) from Isaeus’. This is true in the limited sense that Demosthenes derived important hints from Isaeus (1) in versatile arrangement of material, (2) in elaboration of systematic proof, (3) more generally, in that art of close and strenuous conflict, the art of grappling with the adversary's case point by point, which the Greek critics mean by a)gwni/zesqai, to\ e)nagw/nion. The two speeches of Demosthenes against Aphobus (363 B.C.), and the two against Onetor (362 B.C.), were written at the time when their author (aet. 22 or 23) was probably most under the influence of Isaeus. The two speeches against Onetor — which exhibit the influence in its most mature form — are especially Isaean in this, that they end, not with an ordinary peroration, but with a keen argument swiftly thrust home (Dem. Adv. Onet. I. §§ 37 — 39: II. §§ 10 — 14). On the other hand these earliest speeches of Demosthenes have a thoroughly original stamp. The link between Isaeus and Demosthenes is chiefly technical, depending on the essential continuity of Attic prose expression as an art. It is also, in a narrower sense, personal, so far as a vigorous intensity of logic was common to the intellectual character of both. But that is all. The great achievements of Demosthenes are his own: so, too, the masterpieces of Isaeus, in their own kind, bear a distinctive stamp of keen ability and consummate art. — Cp. Attic Orators, II. 273 — 310.

On the Works of Isaeus generally, ib. II. 311 — 368. The striking characteristic of the extant twelve speeches is the contrast between monotony of subject and versatility of tone: the form has its affinities at once with earlier and with later
style. Of the twelve, the three typical speeches are (1) the fifth, On the Estate of Dicaeogenes — Lysian in the graceful and persuasive management of narrative: (2) the eleventh, On the Estate of Hagnias — Demosthenic in its unity of impulse and its victorious mastery of technical resource: (3) the eighth, On the Estate of Ciron — distinctively Isaean in its mediation between these types.

It is from these that the following extracts have been taken: viz. I. or. v. peri\ tou= *dikaioge/nous klh/rou, 1. §§ 7 — 24 (narrative): 2. §§ 39 — 47 (peroration). — II. or. XI. peri\ tou= *(agni/ou klh/rou, §§ 1 — 19. — III. or. VIII. peri\ tou= *ki/rwnos klh/rou, §§ 1 — 42.

div2.p: . [Or. v.] ‘On the Estate of Dicaeogenes’. — Dicaeogenes, son of Menexenus — whom, for distinction from his grandfather, of the same name, we call Dicaeogenes II. — had four sisters. These, when he died childless, shared among them two-thirds of his estate. The other third went to his first cousin, Dicaeogenes III., son of his uncle Proxenus, in accordance with a will produced by Proxenus, in which the deceased declared Dicaeogenes III. to be his adopted son, and heir to one-third of his estate (ui(o\s poihto\s e)pi\ tri/tw| me/rei th=s ou)si/as, § 6).

Twelve years later (§ 7), Dicaeogenes III. alleged that this first will was invalid. Under a second will, he said, he was heir, not to a third only, but to the whole of the estate. He gained his cause. The sisters of the testator were deprived of their shares, and the whole was transferred to Dicaeogenes III.

Ten years more elapsed (§ 35). Meanwhile the nephews of the testator had grown up. They now resolved to seek redress for their mothers and themselves. They began by bringing an action against one Lycon, who had been called by Dicaeogenes III. as a witness to the second will. Lycon was convicted of perjury.

The state of things was now this: — Dicaeogenes III. had himself declared the first will — which gave him one-third — to be invalid. The judges of Lycon had declared the second will — which gave him all — to be false. Accordingly, the nephews (with the exception of Menexenus II., who had deserted their cause) now sued Dicaeogenes III. for the whole estate. One Leochares interposed a protest (diamarturi/a) that their claim was inadmissible. They indicted Leochares for perjury. Leochares was certain to be convicted. Dicaeogenes III. therefore made a compromise. He was to keep his original onethird, and leave his adversaries in secure possession of the other two-thirds. Leochares and Mnesiptolemus became his sureties for the performance of this engagement.

Leochares is now sued (by an e)ggu/hs di/kh) to discharge his liability as surety, since his principal Dicaeogenes III. has made default. The speaker, son of Polyaratus (§ 5), is one of the nephews of the testator, and is supported by his first-cousin Cephisodotus (§ 2). — Attic Orators, II. 349.

The date is probably 390 B.C., — the sea-fight off Cnidus mentioned in §§ 6, 42 being that of 412 B.C. (Thuc. VIII. 42), not the more famous battle of 394 B.C. This question has been fully examined in the Attic Orators, II. 350 f.

The speaker first defines his case by quoting his own affidavit (a)ntwmosi/a, § 1). He then refers to a register (a)pografh/) of the property left by his uncle, to prove that Dicaeogenes III. has not refunded the due amount, and that Leochares has therefore not discharged his suretyship (th\n e)ceggu/hn ou)k a)pe/dwken), §§ 1 — 4. The facts, of which an outline has been given above, are then narrated in the following passage, §§ 7 — 24.

div3.p: e)peidh\ e)nei/manto, k.t.l. ‘When they had divided the estate, after taking oaths not to transgress the terms of the agreement, each party remained for twelve years in possession of the share assigned to him’. This refers to the first will (412 B.C.), under which Dicaeogenes III., as adopted son of the testator, Dicaeogenes II., received one third of the estate. The other two thirds were shared between the four sisters of the testator, represented by their respective husbands, — viz. Polyaratus (father of the speaker), Democles, Cephisophon, Theopompus. — e)nei/manto: cp. Lysias Pro Mantith. § 10, p. 59, pro\s to\n a)delfo\n d' ou(/tws e)neima/mhn.

ou)sw=n dikw=n ‘though the law-courts sat’: i.e. in the course of the years 412 — 400 B.C., though there were short periods during which the sittings of the law-courts were suspended by war or internal trouble, yet there were also longer periods during which an action might have been brought. Cp. Thuc. VI. 91, where Alcibiades, urging the Spartans to occupy Deceleia, predicts that one of the results will be to stop the Athenian revenue from the law-courts (o(/sa a)po\ dikasthri/wn nu=n w)felou=ntai, — alluding to court-fees, prutanei=a, and to fines or confiscations). The prediction was fulfilled, since, as Thuc. VII. 28 says, all the citizens were required for military duty. This interruption fell within the period referred to here (412 — 400 B.C.). Cp. [Dem.] or. XLV. In Stephan. I. § 3 (about 351 B.C.), di/khn me\n ou)x oi(=o/s t' h)=n i)di/an laxei=n: ou) ga\r h)=san e)n tw=| to/te kairw=| di/kai, a)ll) a)neba/llesqe u(mei=s dia\ to\n po/lemon [the Social War, 357 — 355 B.C.].

dustuxhsa/shs, k.t.l. ‘Athens having suffered disaster [the defeat at Aegospotami, 405 B.C.], followed by the troubles of
faction [sta/sews, the oligarchical movement supported by Sparta, see Lys. In Agorat. §§ 6 ff., p. 78], and civil strife’ [a)gw=nos, the struggle which ended in the overthrow of the Tyrants and the restoration of the Democracy, 403 B.C.]. For a)gw=nos, cp. Isocr. Epist. III. § 2, p. 163, to\n a)gw=na to\n gegenhme/non, a euphemism for the struggle ended by the battle of Chaeroneia.

ou(tosi/ — h(mi=n — tou= qei/ou] ou(tosi/, Dicaeogenes III.: h(mi=n, the representatives of the four sisters, — viz. their sons (the speaker and his first-cousins): tou= qei/ou, their uncle Dicaeogenes II., the testator.

fa/skwn e)f) o(/lh|, k.t.l. ‘alleging that he had been adopted by our uncle as his sole heir’ (and not heir to one-third only). e)f' o(/lh|, sc. th=| ou)si/a|. § 12, poihqh=nai...ui(o\n e)pi\ panti\ tw=| klh/rw|. A childless Athenian citizen could, either during his life or by testament, adopt any Athenian citizen as his son and heir. Permission to execute a will is said to have been first given to Athenian citizens by the laws of Solon, but it was expressly restricted to those citizens who had no direct male descendants. The faculty of adoption was the germ of testamentary power, and was intended primarily to meet a case in which the head of a house left behind him, at his decease, no one duly qualified by nearness of blood to offer the sacrifices at the hearth and the grave. In the Hindoo system of succession the religious aspect of adoption is still the foremost one: (see the Tagore Law Lectures for 1870, Lect. IX. On the Rite of Adoption, pp. 208 f., by Mr Herbert Cowell). The Roman will of Cicero's time was already a true testament. The Athenian diaqh/kh belongs to an intermediate stage. While the religious continuity of the family is still nominally the first principle, the main object in practice is to enlarge the childless testator's choice of heirs. — Cp. Maine, Ancient Law, ch. VI. on ‘The Early History of Testamentary Succession’. Attic Orators, II. 315 f.

mai/nesqai...th=| lh/cei, k.t.l. ‘we thought that he was mad in bringing the action’. th=| lh/cei causal dat.,=o(/ti e)/laxe th
 di/khn. Cp. Antiph. De Caed. Her. § 3, toi=s a)lhqe/sin, note, p. 209. — h(gou/meqa, imperf.: cp. the imperf. diisxurizo/meqa, § 23. ou)k a)
 oi)o/menoi...do/cai,=ou)k oi)o/menoi a)

pollw=| plei/w, k.t.l. ‘though we had far the best of the argument, we were cheated of our verdict — not by the judges, but by Melas’. pollw=| plei/w kai\ dikaio/tera, lit. ‘a far greater
number of just pleas’, comparative of polla\ kai\ di/kaia, like polla\ kai\ a)gaqa/ (Ar. Thesm. 351), etc. — Schömann cp. [Dem.] or. LIX. In Neaer. § 5, tw=| ou)=n e)capath/santi tw=| lo/gw| tou\s dikasta\s di/kaion o)rgi/zesqai, ou) toi=s e)capathqei=si.
o( path/r The speaker's father Polyaratus, who had married one (apparently the eldest) of the four sisters of Dicaeogenes II.: § 5.

e)pecelqei=n...e)peskh/yato ‘before he had brought the action against those witnesses whom he had indicted for perjury’: martu/rwn, the witnesses brought by Dicaeogenes III. to prove the validity of the will under which he claimed the whole of the estate. e)pecelqei=n: cp. § 12, e)pech/|ei toi=s katamarturh/sasin. — e)peskh/yato, sc. yeudomarturiw=n, which is often omitted in this phrase: cp. § 17, e)piskhyame/nwn d' h(mw=n...h(...tw=n yeudomarturiw=n di/kh ei)sh/|ei.

*khfisofw=ntos Cephisophon had married one of the four sisters of the testator Dicaeogenes II. His daughter was therefore niece (a)delfidh=) of the latter, first-cousin to the speaker, and first-cousin once removed to Dicaeogenes III.
th\n *dhmok. gen. gunai=ka ‘her who had become the wife of Democles’. — a)delfo\s w)/n, her own brother; whereas Dicaeogenes III. was only first-cousin, a)neyio/s, of the testator.

*khfisodo/tou Cephisodotus was present, supporting his first-cousin, the speaker, who appeals to him at the beginning of the speech (§ 2) as being able to vouch for the truth of the affidavit (a)ntwmosi/a).

kai\ ga tou/twn ge...a)nti/dikos ‘For of these [tou/twn ge — Cephisodotus, his mother, and her other child or children, as opp. to the testator's other sisters and their children] he was at the same time guardian (e)pi/tropos), legal representative (ku/rios), and legal adversary (a)nti/dikos)’: i.e. Dicaeogenes III. was the protector and representative before the law (ku/rios), as her nearest male relative for this purpose, of the mother of Cephisodotus (since a son could not be the ku/rios of his mother). He was also guardian, e)pi/tropos, of Cephisodotus, who had a brother or brothers, a sister or sisters, as appears from o)rfanoi/ here, au)toi=s e)/dwken below, and pai/dwn o)/ntwn tou/twn in § 11. Every e)pi/tropos (guardian of a minor) was also ku/rios of his ward, but every ku/rios was not e)pi/tropos. The term ku/rios denotes esp. the legal control of a citizen over an unmarried woman or a widow, either as her nearest male relative or by delegation from the natural ku/rios: [Dem.] or. XLVI. In Stephan. II. § 18, e)a
 de\ mhdei\s h)=| tou/twn (i.e. if she has neither father, brother, nor paternal grandfather living) e)a
 me
 e)pi/klhro/s tis h)=| (if she be an heiress) to
 ku/rion e)/xein (her nearest
male kinsman shall marry her), e)a
 de\ mh\ h)=|, o(/tw| a)
 e)pitre/yh|, tou=ton ku/rion ei)=nai, but if she be not, then her natural ku/rios may delegate the duty to another. The ku/rios of a married woman was her husband: see Isae. or. III. De Pyrrh. Hered. § 2. The vulg. kai\ tou/twn te can be defended if te is connected with the kai\ before ou)de\ kata\ to\ e)la/xiston me/ros, k.t.l.: he was both their guardian, etc., and unkind. But I feel sure that Dobree's ge (better than Scheibe's toi) is right: we want just this emphasis on tou/twn.

ou)de\ kata\ to\ e)la/xiston me/ros ‘not the smallest fraction of their claim on his kindness or compassion was allowed by him’: lit. ‘not even in respect to the smallest part of the ties between them (oi)keio/ths — the double tie of kinsman and guardian) did they obtain pity’.

a(\ de\ o( pro\s mhtro\s...di/khs ‘and what their maternal uncle [the testator] and their grandfather [Menexenus I., their mother's father, see stemma] had given to them [to Cephisodotus and the other child or children], he [Dicaeogenes III.] took away on his own authority (au)to/s), before the case had been tried’.
pria/menos kai\ kataska/yas For the aor. part. pria/menos, cp. Andoc. De Pace § 37, p. 47, pei/santes — laqo/ntes — pria/menoi — biasa/menoi.
to\n kh=pon e)poih/sato Dobree would omit to/n: rather transpose it, reading kh=p. e)poih/s. to\n pro\s th=| au(tou= oi)ki/a|: or, retaining it here, repeat it before pro/s.
e)n a)/stei in Athens: the art. omitted as usu.: cp. Isocr. Antid. § 299, note, p. 307. So below, § 22, e)/cw tei/xous — e)n *pedi/w|, note.

kai\ lamba/nwn mi/sqwsin ‘And though he was receiving 80 minas [about £330] in rent from our uncle's property, he sent the latter's nephew to Corinth in the quality of servant to his brother Harmodius’: ei)s *ko/rinqon, i.e. on military service during the Corinthian War, which began in 394 B.C. (the date of the speech is 390 B.C.). In § 37 there is a reference to the capture of Lechaeum, the w. port of Corinth, by the Spartans in 393 B.C. — a)ko/louqos here=the Attic hoplite's servant, (usu. u(phre/ths, Thuc. III. 17,) the Spartan qera/pwn: Thuc. VII. 75, e)/feron kai\ oi( o(pli=tai kai\ oi( i(pph=s para\ to\ ei)wqo\s au)toi\ ta\ sfe/tera au)tw=n siti/a u(po\ toi=s o(/plois, oi( me\n a)pori/a| a)kolou/qwn, oi( de\ a)pisti/a| (distrust of their servants).

e)mba/das kai\ tribw/nia ‘brogues and frieze’. The e)mba/s was a sort of thick shoe (in Xen. Hipp. XII. § 10 e)mba/ths is a half-boot), worn by people who had rough out-door work to do, — the
ordinary u(po/dhma being merely a sandal bound under the foot; the sanda/lion had an upper leather across the toe; the krhpi/s was a half-shoe. Cp. Becker Charicl. Exc. XI. The tri/bwn was a short mantle of coarse stuff. Dem. or. LIV. In Conon. § 34, ‘men who are of a gloomy countenance, who affect the Spartan, who wear coarse cloaks (tri/bwnas) and single-soled sandals’ (a(pla=s u(pode/dentai). The Acharnian rustics wear the tri/bwn (Ar. Ach. 184), which seems to have been the ordinary dress of poor men. Socrates sometimes alludes to his ‘poor cloak’ (tri/bwn ou(tosi/, Protag. 335 D). Being the ordinary dress of philosophers, it afterwards came to be regarded, like the cowl, as a badge of austere life. (From my note on Theophrast. Char. XXII.=XXV. p. 255.) Scheibe reads tri/bwna with Cobet N. Lect. p. 155; but cp. Lysias or. XXXII. In Diogitona, § 16, — where the question is of similar harshness towards poor relations — e)kbalei=n tou/tous h)ci/wsas qugatridou=s o)/ntas e)k th=s oi)ki/as th=s au)tw=n e)n tribwni/ois, a)nupodh/tous, ou) meta\ a)kolou/qou, ou) meta\ strwma/twn, ou) meta\ i(mati/wn (the ordinary woollen cloak).

o(/qen a)pe/lipon=e)kei=qen o(/pou, ‘from the point at which I digressed’: i.e. from the end of § 9, when Dicaeogenes III. had seized the whole estate. Cp. Plat. Phaedo 78 B, o(/qen a)peli/pomen a)nala/bwmen au)=qis.

e)pech/|ei ‘proceeded to prosecute’, Attic imperf. of e)pece/rxomai, as the Att. fut. is e)pecie/nai. Cp. § 9, e)pecelqei=n. — toi=s katamarturh/s., ‘those who had borne false testimony against us [against the speaker and Cephisodotus], and against him’ [Menexenus, their cousin]: cp. § 9.

o(/nper...tou=ton] tou=ton, not, as usu., ‘the defendant here’, but emphatic after o(/nper prw=ton, as if *lu/kwna had not preceded: ‘convicted the very first man they brought before the court — Lycon’.
poihqh=nai, k.t.l. See on § 7.
to\n...pra/ttonta ‘who was acting’,=o(\s e)/pratte, in the prosecution of the witnesses.

ti/ poih=sai; k.t.l. ‘persuades him — to do what? to take for himself such a share of the estate as fell to him, and to throw over us for whom he was acting’. o(/ ti e)gi/gneto: such a fraction as was due to him (imperf.), on the supposition that two-thirds of the whole estate belonged to the sisters and their children. Cp. § 6, ui(o\s e)gi/gneto poihto/s, (under the will) he was to become adopted son, i.e. it directed that he should do so; and § 15. So § 16, a)ku/roin gignome/nain,=e)peidh\ e)gi/gnonto, as (by a logical necessity) both the wills now became, now must be, invalid: § 44, e)kei/nwn e)gi/gneto, ‘were due to them’.

a)fei=nai ‘to withdraw his charges against the witnesses who had not yet been convicted’: a)fei=nai, here, not of the jury who acquit the accused, but of the prosecutor who absolves him by allowing the proceedings to drop. Cp. § 1 of this speech, a)fh/kamen a)llh/lous tw=n e)gklhma/twn. [Dem.] or. XLV. In Stephan. I. § 40, w(s a)fe/ntos e)mou= tw=n e)gklhma/twn au)to/n. Harpocr. s.v. a)fei/s contrasts a)fei=nai, ‘to let off’ an accused person by withdrawing a charge, with a)palla/cai, ‘to get rid’ of an accuser by persuading him to do so: cp. § 28 of this speech, ou) du/natai a)palla/ssein tou\s xrh/stas, he cannot pay off his creditors.

kaqhgou/menoi Elsewhere in classical Greek kaqhgei=sqai is usually to ‘show the way’, ‘set an example’, ‘teach’: here Dobree conj. h(mei=s d' ou)ke/q' h(gou/menoi prosh/kein. Baiter, h(mei=s de\ a(/q' h(gou/menoi, Sauppe h(mei=s d' , w)= a)/ndres, h(gou/menoi. I believe that kaqhgou/menoi, though unattested in this sense, is right,=‘inferring’, (kata/ implying an unfavourable inference:) cp. Her. III. 27, pa/gxu sfe/as katado/cas e(wutou= kakw=s prh/cantos xarmo/suna tau=ta poie/ein.

kat' a)gxistei/an ‘we claim the whole estate [oi)/kou=klh/rou] from him on the ground of affinity’ — and no longer kata\ diaqh/khn, on the ground of the testament under which they had originally claimed two-thirds. a)gxistei/a, in the legal sense, was a degree of affinity (including, for legal purposes, consanguinity, sugge/neia) recognised by the law as constituting a claim to an inheritance in the absence of a special bequest which could legally divert it. To claim an estate under testamentary disposition was a)mfisbhtei=n kata\ diaqh/khn, or kata\ do/sin. (Schömann, Isae. p. 250, regards dido/nai, do/sis as the general terms for a bequest: diati/qesqai, diaqh/kh as terms strictly applicable only when the legatee was at the same time adopted as son by the testator. But in Isae. or. I. § 41 the defendants claim kata\ diaqh/khn, and it nowhere appears that they had been adopted. I believe rather that do/sis denoted the act, and diaqh/kh the instrument.) To claim on the ground of affinity (in the absence of a will) was a)mfisbhtei=n kat' a)gxistei/an, or kata\ ge/nos, or. IV. § 15. For the distinction between a)gxistei/a and sugge/neia, cp. Isae. or. XI. § 17, o(\ (the relationship of son to mother) suggene/staton me\n h)=n th=| fu/sei pa/ntwn, e)n de\ tai=s a)gxistei/ais o(mologoume/nws ou)k e)/stin: meaning that a mother could not inherit from her son, — although, by Attic law, an inheritance could ascend collaterally, as by an uncle inheriting.

o)rqw=s e)gnw/kamen ‘have decided rightly’ (to sue D. for the whole estate): the perf., because the resolve still exists, since the case has not been finally settled. The argument is briefly this. Dicaeogenes III. received one-third of the estate under
the will. He has set that will aside, and has taken the whole estate under another alleged will. We have shown that this alleged will is false. Therefore there is no will. And therefore the next of kin inherit.

h( me\n pa/lai pollw=|, h( d' u(/steron If pa/lai pollw=| stood alone, it certainly could not mean ‘very long ago’: that would be pa/nu pa/lai, as in Isae. or. VI. § 14, ou)/te a)ne/kdoton kai\ a)/paida ei)=nai, a)lla\ pa/nu pa/lai sunoikei=n (has long been married). But where pa/lai and u(/steron are contrasted in the same clause, pollw=| may stand with pa/lai in the sense, ‘old by a long interval as compared with the later date’. I therefore hesitate to adopt the obvious transposition, h( me\n pa/lai, h( d' u(/steron pollw=|.
*pro/cenos Proxenus, father of Dicaeogenes III., had produced the will under which his son inherited one-third of the estate of Dicaeogenes II.: § 6, diaqh/khn a)pe/fhne *pro/cenos. See the stemma.
e)gi/gneto Cp. § 13, note on ti/ poih=sai;...o)/ ti e)gi/gneto.
au)th/n redundant after h(/n: cp. § 12, *lu/kwna...tou=ton, note.
a)ku/roin gignome/nain ‘were by inference invalid’, a)/kuroi e)gi/gnonto; § 13, note.
kata\ do/sin...kat' a)gxist.] Cp. § 14, kat' a)gxistei/an, note.
dia\ de\ tau=ta If de/ is right, it has a resumptive force: ‘for these reasons, I say’: but dia\ dh\ tau=ta seems needed.

laxei=n tou= klh/rou — a)nto/mnusqai] laxei=n tou= klh/rou, sc. di/khn, ‘to claim the estate’, to obtain a hearing of one's legal claim: but laxei=n klh=ron, ‘to obtain the estate’: § 7, e)ke/kthto...e(/kastos a(\ e)/laxe. — a)nto/mnusqai, ‘when we were about to make our affidavit’ (a)ntwmosi/a), in the preliminary proceedings (a)na/krisis) before the archon.

diemartu/rhse...mh\ e)pi/dikon ei)=nai to
 klh=ron ‘entered a protest (diamarturi/a) to the effect that our claim was inadmissible’: i.e. that a diaqh/kh existed giving it to Dicaeogenes. Cp. Isae. or. VII. § 3, ei) me
 e(w/rwn u(ma=s ma=llon a)podexome/nous ta\s diamarturi/as h)\ ta\s eu)qudiki/as, ka)
 ma/rturas prou)balo/mhn mh\ e)pi/dikon ei)=nai to
 klh=ron: where a protest barring the claim is contrasted with a direct trial of the claim. Cp. § 6, e(ka/sth to\ me/ros e)pedika/sato (sc. tou= klh/rou), each claimed the estate in her due share.

e)piskhyame/nwn...ei)sh/|ei ‘We indicted Leochares; the action in claim of the estate was cancelled, and the charge of perjury came before the court’. e)piskhyame/nwn, sc. yeudomarturw=n: cp. § 9. — lh=cis, sc. th=s di/khs, tou= klh/rou, for claiming the estate. — diegra/fh: Ar. Nub. 773, oi)/m' w(s h(/domai | o(/ti penteta/-
lantos diage/graptai/ moi di/kh, ‘a suit in which I might have lost five talents is quashed’.

e)caireqeisw=n out of the two kadi/skoi, one for condemnation, the other for acquittal: cp. Lys. In Agor. § 37, note, p. 267. Dobree ingeniously but needlessly, e)cerasqeisw=n, ‘tumbled out’ (Ar. Ach. 341, tou\s li/qous...e)cera/sate).

a(\ me\n tw=n dikastw=n...le/gein ‘as to the entreaties which L. addressed to the judges and to us, and the penalties which we were entitled to obtain, I hardly know that I need speak’ (i.e. you can imagine them). Leochares having been convicted of perjury (yeudomarturiw=n), the accusers might have claimed any penalty up to a)timi/a, disfranchisement (cp. § 19, e)ggeno/menon h(mi=n au)to/n, e)peidh\ ei(/lomen yeudomarturiw=n, a)timw=sai), since it was a timhth\ di/kh, that is, one in which the accuser could tima=sqai, assess the penalty. — e)cege/neto, with pluperf. force, not, ‘was in our power’, but, ‘had (by the verdict) come into our power’. — diapra/casqai, not ‘exact’, but ‘obtain’ para\ tw=n dikastw=n.

mh\ sunariqmei=n, k.t.l. ‘not to count the votes, but to cancel the conviction’; i.e. when the votes were taken out, there was an evident majority against Leochares; but the accusers consented to refrain from registering the result, and to admit L. to a compromise before sentence was passed. sunariqmei=n to compare the number of votes for him with that against him: sugxe/ai, to mix up all the votes in a heap.

a)fi/stato...me/rh ‘Dicaeogenes (III.) offered [imperf.] to resign two-thirds of the estate to the sisters of Dicaeogenes (II.), and to agree that he should place these two-thirds in our hands without litigation’: a)namfisbh/thta, i.e. he promised that they should not be required a)mfisbhtei=n, to bring a law-suit, in order formally to establish their claim. In the sequel, however, they were obliged to do so, since D. had already transferred the ownership to others.

kai\ tau=ta h)ggua=to, k.t.l. ‘And in all this Leochares the defendant offered [imperf.] to be his surety, and to undertake that he (Dicaeogenes) should fulfil his agreement, — Mnesiptolemus of Plōtheia [a deme of the Aegeid tribe] being his colleague in the suretyship’. — h)ggua=to, not e)negua=to, in Attic, as Scheibe shows, Isae. praef. crit. IX. — kai\ w(molo/gei poih/sein: better w(s w(molo/gei kai\ poih/sein, ‘pledged himself that Dicaeogenes would do as he (D.) had agreed’. Cp. § 20, h)ggua=to au)to\n a(\ w(molo/ghse kai\ poih/sein: § 22, ou) pisteu/ontes au)tw=| a(\ w(molo/ghse [kai\ Reiske] poih/sein.
e)ggeno/menon...a)timw=sai ‘when it had come into our power...to disfranchise him’: § 17, note. For the accus. absol. cp. Antiph. Tetr. B. b. § 7, note, p. 205.

kai/toi ei) mh\...ou)k oi)=d' o(/ ti ‘If, however, in the face of the judges, five hundred in number, and of the bystanders, he had not offered [imperf.] to become surety, I do not know what he could have done’: i.e. there was no other hope for him: he would then and there have been disfranchised. ei) mh\ h)ggua=to, not h)gguh/sato, because the promise had never been fulfilled. — pentakosi/wn, the normal number of a dikasth/rion, — the 5000 h(liastai/ (exclusive of the reserved 1000) being divided into 10 such panels: cp. Isocr. Areopagit. § 54, note, p. 349.

ei) ga\r a)pe/sth mo/non...ei)=xen ‘For if (as he alleges) he merely withdrew his claim to the two-thirds, but did not covenant to place them in our hands without litigation, what loss was he incurring by resigning property of which he already had the equivalent in money?’ i.e. he had already transferred to others the ownership of the property which he was resigning. It was his duty to see that we got it without having to go to law (a)mfisbhtei=n) with these other persons, from whom he had received the value (timh/) of it. ti/ e)zhmiou=to; i.e. we were in a position to claim a concession, since we had convicted his witness of perjury. But this would have been no concession. Therefore his compact cannot have meant this.

ou)de\ ga\r pri\n h(tthqh=nai...qe/menoi ‘for even before he had been worsted in the law-suit [by the conviction of his witness Leochares], the property which we claim had passed from him to the purchasers and mortgagees’. oi( pria/menoi — those who had bought from him outright: oi( qe/menoi, ‘the mortgagees’ — those who lent him money on the security of property which he placed in their hands. Plato, Legg. 820 E, kei/sqw me/ntoi kaqa/per e)ne/xura lu/sima e)k th=s a)/llhs politei/as, e)a\n h)\ tou\s qe/ntas h(ma=s h)\ tou\s qeme/nous u(ma=s mhdamw=s filofronh=tai, ‘let these (studies) rest, however, as pledges which can be redeemed by provisions in other parts of our commonwealth, in case they prove utterly unsatisfactory to us who have given the pledges’ (qe/ntas, the mortgagers), ‘or to you who have accepted them’ (qeme/nous, the mortgagees). So u(potiqe/nai (opponere) oi)ki/an, to pledge or mortgage a house: u(poti/qesqai oi)ki/an, to accept the house as security for a loan.

e)n *pedi/w| in the Attic plain (to\ pedi/on, Thuc. II. 65), from which the party led by Lycurgus were called oi( e)k tou= pedi/ou, pediakoi/ or pediei=s, as opp. to the pa/raloi led by Megacles and the dia/krioi led by Peisistratus, Her. I. 59. The art. omitted, as with tei=xos, a)/stu, § 11. — e(ch/konta ple/qrwn, ‘covering 60 plethra’. The ple/qron was the ordinary Greek unit of land-measurement,=10,000 square feet, nearly=Roman actus, or half iugerum. — kekomi/smeqa, ‘have recovered’: cp. § 13, komisa/menon.

h(mei=s d' ou)k e)ca/gomen ‘And we refrain from ejecting’ [tou\s priame/nous kai\ qeme/nous, those to whom D. has transferred the property], ‘for we are afraid of incurring penalties at law’: di/kas, sc. e)cou/lhs, actions for forcible ejectment.

kai\ fa/skontos mh\ bebaiw/sein ‘For by ejecting Micion from the ownership of the bath-house, at the instance of D., and on his assurance that he would not confirm the other's title, we incurred a fine of 40 minae — thanks to Dicaeogenes, judges’. mh\ bebaiw/sein: i.e. Dicaeogenes promised to admit that Micion had bought the balanei=on with a bad title, since he, Dicaeogenes, was not its legal owner when he sold it.

h(gou/menoi ga...kaqeisth/kesan h(mi=n ‘For, believing that he [au)to/n, Dicaeogenes] would not confirm another claim to any part of the property which he had resigned in our favour before the law-court, we insisted on this point [diisxurizo/meqa, imperf.] against Micion before the judges, offering to suffer what they pleased if D. confirmed M.'s title to the tenement, — never dreaming that he [D.] would violate his agreement, — though our only ground for such a faith was the fact that sureties had been given to us’. a)
 bebaiw/sein: as in Thuc. II. 8 the mss. give a)
 prosxwrh/sein, v. 82 a)
 w)felh/sein, v. 66 a)
 luph/sein, VIII. 25 a)
 prosxwrh/sein, VIII. 71 a)
 h(suxa/sein. In VI. 66 the corr. a)
 luph/seian is probable: in the other places Classen (rightly, I think) keeps a)/n, with Herbst, instead of omitting it with Stahl. Cp. Goodwin § 41. 4. — ou)k a)
...oi)o/menoi ...pra=cai, cp. § 8, note. — ou) di' a)/ll' ou)de/n: i.e. the character of D. himself was no guarantee, but we believed that he would not expose his surety to an e)ggu/hs di/kh (like the present).

ou(/tw kai\ tosau=ta ‘in this manner and measure’ i.e. so badly and so little: referring to § 36, th=| me
 fulh=| ei)s *dionu/sia xorhgh/sas te/tartos e)ge/neto, tragwdoi=s de\ kai\ purrixistai=s u(/statos: i.e. he won only the fourth prize when he produced a chorus [probably of au)lhtai/, flute-players] at the great Dionysia, — and was last when he produced a tragic chorus and a chorus of Pyrrhic dancers (perhaps at the *lh/naia). He had also failed to contribute when ei)sforai/, special war-taxes, were being levied. Once, indeed, he had promised an e)pi/dosis or voluntary subscription, which however he had not paid, and had therefore been ‘posted’ as a defaulter at the statues of the Twelve Heroes [in the Agora], § 38: kai\ tou=to e)pe/dwken, ou)k ei)sh/negken, a)ll' e)p) ai)sxi/stw| e)pigra/mmati [‘with a most disgraceful qualification’ — that which follows] e)cete/qh au)tou= tou)/noma e)/mprosqen tw=n e)pwnu/mwn, o(/ti oi(/de ei)s swthri/an th=s po/lews u(posxo/menoi tw=| dh/mw| ei)soi/sein xrh/mata e)qelontai\ ou)k ei)sh/negkan. — ei)s th
 po/lin, (spent)
on the city: so § 43, poi= a)nalw/sas; ou)/te ga ei)s th
 po/lin ou)/te ei)s tou\s fi/lous fanero\s ei)= dapanhqei\s ou)de/n.
o(/ti mei=zon e)dunh/qh Schömann suggests o(/te, but with this we should expect h)du/nato: and o(/ti, ‘(merely) because’, condemns the act more strongly.

ei)s tou\s misqwtou\s i)o/ntas ‘and allowed others [of his relatives] to be reduced to the rank of hired labourers, for want of a bare livelihood’. Cp. [Dem.] or. XLIX. Adv. Timoth. § 51, ti/nes h)=san oi( e)ne/gkantes to
 xalko
 w(s to
 pate/ra to
 e)mo/n; misqwtoi\ h)\ oi)ke/tai; ‘hirelings or slaves?’ Theophr. Charact. IV. kai\ toi=s par' au)tw=| e)rgazome/nois misqwtoi=s e)n a)grw=| pa/nta ta\ a)po\ th=s e)kklhsi/as dihgei=sqai, ‘he will recount all the news from the Ecclesia to the hired labourers working on his land’. ‘Slavery did not altogether swamp the labour-market. Even men, chiefly foreigners, found employment as artisans, farm-labourers or domestics: see Plat. Rep. 371. Lysis, in Plato's dialogue, says that his father's chariot was driven at the games by a hired charioteer (Lys. p. 203 E), while the groom mentioned in the same passage is a slave. The shrine of Eurysaces in the market-place is mentioned as the place at which ‘those who ply for hire used to congregate’ (from my note on Theophr. l.c., p. 221).

e)n tw=| th=s *ei)leiqui/as i(erw=| kaqhme/nhn, as a suppliant, — in appeal to the goddess against an unnatural son. Pausanias I. 18. § 5, plhsi/on de\ (near the temple of Sarapis, s.w. of the Acropolis) w)|kodo/mhto nao\s *ei)leiqui/as, h(\n e)lqou=san e)c *(uperbore/wn ei)s *dh=lon gene/sqai bohqo\n tai=s *lhtou=s w)di=si, tou\s de\ a)/llous par' au)tw=n fasi th=s *ei)leiqui/as maqei=n to\ o)/noma: kai\ qu/ousi/ te *ei)leiqui/a| *dh/lioi kai\ u(/mnon a)/|dousin *)wlh=nos.

*me/lana ‘As to his intimate associates [in distinction from tou\s prosh/kontas, his relatives, § 39], he has robbed Melas, his friend from boyhood, of the money which he received from him, and is now his bitter enemy’: *me/lana, not *me/lani, because the emphasis is more on the act (a)posterh/sas) which led to the feud than on the feud itself (e)/xqisto/s e)sti).
ei) e)pidika/saito tou= klh/rou ‘if he should claim the estate’: cp. § 16, e)pi/dikon, note. He said, dw/sw, e)a\n e)pidika/swmai.
oi( h(me/teroi pro/gonoi i.e. the testator, Dicaeo genes II., his father Menexenus, and his grandfather, Dicaeogenes I. — oi( tau=ta kthsa/menoi, who acquired the property now under dispute.

pa/sas...xorhg. e)xorh/g.] ‘discharged the office of choregus in all its forms’, for tragikoi/, kwmikoi/, and mousikoi\ a)gw=nes. — ei)sh/negkan, i.e. by way of ei)sforai/: cp. on § 39. — trihrarxou=ntes:
see on Isocr. De Pace § 128, ta\s summori/as, p. 336. — die/lipon: Isocr. Aeginet. § 27, note, p. 356.

a)naqh/mata ‘votive offerings’, a general term for gifts (buildings, statues, tripods, etc.) dedicated to a god; a)na/qhma a)natiqe/nai, Her. II. 182. — e)k tw=n perio/ntwn, not, ‘from their abundance’, but, ‘from what remained’ after these costly leitourgi/ai had been discharged.

tri/podas A bronze tripod was awarded to a successful choregus, who usu. dedicated it in the temple of Dionysus. Plutarch says that Nicias had presented to the temple a shrine (new/s) on which these tripods were set (Nic. 3). In the course of the 4th century B.C. a fashion arose of placing the prizetripod in a small shrine built especially for it, either in the precincts of the Theatre or in the ‘Street of the Tripods’ (Paus. I. 20) on the E. side of the Acropolis. The existing monument of Lysicrates (choregus 335 B.C.) was such a shrine: and the site of another, dedicated in 320 B.C. by the choregus Thrasyllus (Paus. I. 21), is still marked by a cave on the s. side of the Acropolis. (See my note on Theophr. Char. XXII.=XXV., p. 251.) Cp. Plat. Gorg. 472 A, *niki/as kai\ oi( a)delfoi/, w(=n oi( tri/podes oi( e)fech=s e(stw=te/s ei)sin e)n tw=| *dionusi/w|.

e)n *puqi/ou i.e. e)n tw=| *)apo/llwnos *puqi/ou i(erw=|. In May, 1877, the site of the *pu/qion was identified by the discovery of an inscribed altar-stone on the right bank of the Ilissus, N. W. of the temple of Zeus Olympius. This stone belonged to the altar erected by Peisistratus (grandson of the tyrant), and mentioned by Thuc. (VI. 54) as bearing in letters which even then were ‘faint’, a)mudroi=s gra/mmasi, the couplet: —
mnh=ma to/d' h(=s a)rxh=s *peisi/stratos *(ippi/ou ui(o\s qh=ken *)apo/llwnos *puqi/ou e)n teme/nei.

a)parxa\s...to\ i(ero/n ‘On the Acropolis, again, [as well as in the *dionu/sion and the *pu/qion] ‘they have dedicated tributes (a)parxa/s) from their substance, and have adorned the temple [to\ i(ero/n=to\n *parqenw=na] with images (a)ga/lmasi) in bronze and stone, — considerable in number, if it be remembered that the donors were private persons’. — a)parxa/s, firstfruits, [in Thuc. VI. 20 tithes paid by occupiers to landlords,] then ‘tributes’: cp. Eur. Androm. 150, where Hermione speaks of her robes and golden ornaments as a)parxai/, ‘offerings’ made to her, as a bride, by her father. — polloi=s closely with w(s a)po\ i)di/as kth/sews: Thuc. VI. 20, po/leis...mega/las,...to/ te plh=qos, w(s e)n mia=| nh/sw|, polla\s ta\s *(ellhni/das: Soph. Phil. 584, drw=n a)ntipa/sxw xrhsta/ g' , oi(=) a)nh\r pe/nhs. — a)ga/lmasi, not=a)naqh/masi (§ 41), but ‘images’ or ‘statues’ of gods, as opp. to a)ndria/ntes, portrait-statues of men.
*dikaioge/nhs i.e. Dicaeogenes I.: see stemma.

h( e)n **(alieu=si ma/xh Having made a descent on the coast of Argolis, the Athenians were defeated by the Corinthians and Epidaurians at Halieis, Ol. 80. 4, 457 B.C.: Thuc. I. 104. (Attic Orators, II. 353.) — *(alieu=si is due to Dobree. The traditional reading is h( e)n *)eleusi=ni ma/xh, which has been referred (1) by Palmer ap. Schöm. 342 to Ol. 80. 4, 457 B.C., when there were hostilities in the Megarid between the Athenians and the Corinthians: (2) by Reiske to Ol. 83. 4, 445 B.C., when the Lacedaemonians, invading Attica under Pleistoanax, advanced to Eleusis; Thuc. I. 114. But on neither occasion is a battle at Eleusis recorded.

fularxw=n th=s **)olunqi/as e)n *spartw/lw| ‘when commanding the cavalry of his tribe at Spartolus in the territory of Olynthus’: in Ol. 87. 4, 429 B.C., when the Athenians were defeated by the Chalcidians at Spartolus on the Chalcidic peninsula: Thuc. II. 79. — Scheibe rightly follows Palmer in reading *)olunqi/as for the vulg. *)olusi/as, which Dobree took as formed from *)/olunqos (‘ut *trikoru/sios a *triko/runqos Arist. Lys. 1034’), while Sir W. Jones actually explained it, ‘of the destructive cohort’. Reiske conj. *)odrusi/as or *)odussei/as (the latter as the name of a cohort). — In 429 B.C. Spartolus belonged to the *bottiai=oi (Thuc. l.c.), but it had now come under the control of Olynthus: cp. Xen. Hellen. v. 2. 11 (Attic Orators, II. 354).

*dikaioge/nhs i.e. the testator, Dicaeog. II. — e)n *kni/dw|: in 412 B.C., when an Athenian force of less than 20 sail was defeated, with the loss of six ships, by the Lacedaemonian fleet under Astyochus, Thuc. VIII. 42. The Paralos is mentioned soon afterwards as being with the Athenian army at Samos, Thuc. VIII. 74 (411 B.C.).

e)cargurisa/menos ‘having converted it’ (to
 oi)=kon=to
 klh=ron, the estate) ‘into money, you now bewail your poverty; but on what have you spent the money?’ e)carguris., because he had sold or mortgaged the houses and lands (cp. § 21, oi( para\ tou/tou pria/menoi kai\ qe/menoi). In Thuc. VIII. 81, h)
 de/h| teleutw=nta th
 e(autou= strwmnh
 e)carguri/sai (convert into money), e)cargurw=sai is a v. l., wh. Classen adopts, following Etym. M. 246. 55, e)cargurw=sai, ou)k e)carguri/sai, *qoukudi/dhs. Her. VI. 86, e)cargurw/santa. In Dem. De Pace § 8, h(
...e)ke/kthto fanera
 ou)si/an (real property), tau/thn e)carguri/sas, the form is less doubtful.

a)lla\ mh\n ou)de\ kaqippotro/fhkas ‘But again, neither have you squandered it on keeping horses’. The keeping of horses, esp. for the great contests, was regarded as in some sort a duty
incumbent on the rich, for the credit of the state, — horses being in a special sense at Athens a)/galma th=s u(perplou/tou xlidh=s (Aesch. P.V. 474). [Dem.] or. XLII. Adv. Phaen. § 14: ‘In one thing only can the defendant be proved to have shown public spirit towards you (pefilotimhme/non ei)s u(ma=s), judges: his munificence takes the form of keeping fine horses’ (i(ppotro/fos a)gaqo/s e)sti kai\ filo/timos). Xen. Hipparch. I. 12, ‘(you may win over parents) by explaining this to them, — that their sons will be forced to keep horses, if not by you, by their fortune, but that...you will deter them from giving extravagant or mad (manikw=n) prices for horses’ (note on Theophr. Char. XXIII.= VI. p. 197). Cp. Lysias or. XIX. § 63, o(/te i(/ppeuen, ou) mo/non i(/ppous e)kth/sato lamprou\s a)lla\ kai\ a)qlhta/s, kai\ e)ni/khsen *)isqmoi= kai\ *neme/a|, k.t.l.
plei/onos a)/cion h)\ triw=n mnw=n=about £12. The koppati/as of Pheidippides (Ar. Clouds 23) cost about 12 minas, or £48; and the same is the value of a horse in [Lysias] or. VIII. § 10.

ou)de\ zeu=gos e)kth/sw, k.t.l. ‘You have never set up so much as a pair of mules [o)riko/n from o)/reus=h(mi/onos] on the strength of (e)pi/) your large estates and wealth. Nor, again, have you ransomed any one from the enemy’. Cp. Lys. In Eratosth. § 20, pollou\s d' *)aqhnai/wn e)k tw=n polemi/wn lusame/nous, note, p. 253.

ta\ a)naqh/mata...kulindei=tai ‘Nor, again, have you duly placed on the acropolis [th
 po/lin] the votive offerings which Menexenus had caused to be made, and which death prevented him from dedicating, but they are still knocking about in the stone cutters' shops’. — po/lin=a)kro/polin, Thuc. II. 15, kalei=tai de\ dia\ th
 palaia
 tau/th| katoi/khsin kai\ h( a)kro/polis me/xri tou=de e)/ti u(p' *)aqhnai/wn po/lis. — keko/mikas, not merely ‘carried’, but taken to their proper place. — kulindei=tai should, I think, be read here: Attic writers seem to use kulindei=sqai in the literal sense, kalindei=sqai in the figurative; cp. Isocr. Adv. Sophist. § 20, tw=n peri\ ta\s e)/ridas kalindoume/nwn, note, p. 298.
e)kei/nwn e)gi/gneto ‘were due to them’, ‘came to them by right’: see § 13, note, p. 369. a)ga/lmata in the proper sense, statues of gods as opp. to a)ndria/ntes, cp. § 42.
leitourgi/as...trihrarxw=n On the distinction between the ordinary leitourgi/ai and the trihrarxi/a, cp. Isocr. De Pace, § 128, note, p. 335.

pole/mou...*)olu/nqioi...nhsiw=tai The Corinthian War (394 — 387 B.C.), of which this (390) was the 5th year. Olynthus, as well as the insular allies, had doubtless furnished troops to Athens in the course of the war. If the year 372 B.C. were taken as the date of the speech, the notice might be
referred to the Olynthian War of 382 — 379 B.C., — when the Olynthians were, in a sense, fighting the battle of Athens. The mention of nhsiw=tai might then be explained by the fact that, when war was renewed between Athens and Sparta in 374 B.C., Corcyra became a centre of hostilities. But tosou/tou and toiou/tou pole/mou in § 46 can mean nothing but the Corinthian War; it could not, without straining, be applied to the whole intermittent struggle against Sparta. — See Attic Orators, II. 351.

to
 tu/rannon Hipparchus. Cp. Thuc. I. 20, *)aqhnai/wn gou=n to\ plh=qos *(/ipparxon oi)/ontai u(f' *(armodi/ou kai\ *)aristogei/tonos tu/rannon o)/nta a)poqanei=n, kai\ ou)k i)/sasin o(/ti *(ippi/as me
 presbu/tatos w)
 h)=rxe tw=n *peisistra/tou ui(e/wn, *(/ipparxos de\ kai\ *qessalo\s a)delfoi\ h)=san au)tou=. Herod. (v. 55) does not make this error. Nor need we suppose it here, since to
 tu/rannon implies merely a member of the ruling house; cp. Andoc. De Myst. § 106, nikh/santes tou\s tura/nnous [=tou\s *peisistrati/das] e)pi\ *pallhni/w|.

th
 e)n *prutanei/w| si/thsin, k.t.l. Cp. Andoc. De Myst. § 45, note on e)dei/pnei, p. 226. — proedriw=n, ‘places of honour’ at festivals, etc.: a)teleiw=n, exemptions from taxation. — *)aristogei/twn...kai\ *(armo/dios: cp. Dem. F. L. § 280, u(pomenei=te ...to
 a)f' *(armodi/ou kai\ tw=n ta\ me/gist' a)gaqa\ u(ma=s ei)rgasme/nwn, ou(\s no/mw| dia\ ta\s eu)ergesi/as...e)n a(/pasi toi=s i(eroi=s e)pi\ tai=s qusi/ais spondw=n kai\ krath/rwn koinwnou\s pepoi/hsqe kai\ a)/|dete kai\ tima=te e)c i)/sou toi=s h(/rwsi kai\ toi=s qeoi=s...th
 e)k tw=n no/mwn di/khn u(pesxhke/nai, ..., to
 de\ *)atromh/tou a)fh/sete; Deinarchus In Demosth. § 63, e)de/qh tw=n a)f' *(armodi/ou gegono/twn ei(=s kata\ to\ so
 pro/stagma, was imprisoned by your injunction. For e)kei=nos=ille, ‘the famous’, cp. Ar. Eq. 786, mw=n e)/kgonos ei)= tw=n *(armodi/ou tis e)kei/nwn;

div2.p: . [Or. XI.] — ‘On the Estate of Hagnias’. — Theopompus, the speaker and defendant, possesses the estate of Hagnias. Half of this estate is claimed from Theompompus on behalf of his own nephew, the son of Stratocles. The form of the prosecution is an Information for maltreatment (ei)saggeli/a kakw/sews); the son of Stratocles being considered as an orphan whom his uncle, Theopompus, has wronged. The date is 359 B.C. — Attic Orators, II. 354 — 8.
Theopompus had already, under a legal decision, taken this estate away from Phylomachè II. (see the stemma), daughter of his own second cousin Eubulides II.

The essential points are these: — (1) Theopompus and Hagnias were the sons of a)neyioi/, first-cousins, and were therefore second-cousins to each other: (2) Eubulides II., father of Phylomachè II., was first-cousin of Hagnias.

div3.p: Theopompus begins by reading the laws which regulate the succession of collateral kinsfolk to an estate; and shows that, by these, his nephew, the son of Stratocles, is excluded. There is no reason to suppose that the prooi/mion is lost. The ninth oration of Isaeus, peri\ tou= *)astufi/lou klh/rou (Attic Orators, II. 330), and the third, peri\ tou= *pu/rrou klh/rou (ib. 339), begin with similar abruptness.

§§ 1, 2. dia\ tau=q'...klhronomi/an] ‘I have read you the laws, because the plaintiff contends that, under the first of them, the boy [the son of Stratocles] is entitled to half the estate; but this is untrue. For Hagnias was not our brother [h(mi=n, Theopompus himself and the other second-cousins of Hagnias, § 10]; but the law, speaking of a brother's property, has given the inheritance —
(1) first, to brothers, being sons of the same father, and the children of such brothers; this is the first degree of kinship to the deceased: but failing these,
(2) secondly, the law calls to the succession sisters by the same father, and their children: failing these,
(3) in the third degree (tri/tw| ge/nei) it gives the preference to first cousins (a)neyioi=s) on the father's side, continuing it to their children (me/xri a)neyiw=n pai/dwn=me/xri a)neyiadw=n).

(4) Failing these also, the law reverts to the direct line [ei)s to\ ge/nos, the direct lineage on the maternal side, as opp. to collateral kinship on the paternal] and gives the ownership of the property [poiei= kuri/ous au)tw=n, sc. tw=n xrhma/twn] to the kinsmen of the deceased on the mother's side, under the same rules by which, in the first instance (e)c a)rxh=s), it called the paternal kinsfolk to the inheritance’.

The gist of the whole argument is that Theopompus, being the son of a first-cousin (a)neyiou= pai=s) is, under provision (3), in the succession on the paternal side, while his nephew, being the son of a second-cousin, is out of it.

tau/tas poiei= ta\s a)gxistei/as, k.t.l. ‘constitutes (recognises) these claims by kinship, and no others’: a)gxistei/a, a degree of nearness to the testator such as the law of inheritance recognises, opp. to sugge/neia, natural kinship, which may or may not be a)gxistei/a: see or. v. note on § 14, kat' a)gxistei/an. — suntomwte/rws: for the form, cp. Isocr. Panegyr. § 163, e)rrwmeneste/rws, note, p. 311. — tau/th|, ‘to this effect’.

prosh/kei th=| a)gxistei/a|...e)/cw th=s suggenei/as Schömann suggests prosh/kei th=| suggenei/a| — e)/cw th=s a)gxistei/as. But e)/cw
th=s suggenei/as, ‘outside of the kinship’,=outside of that kinship which the law recognises as constituting a)gxistei/a.

a)nabibasa/menos...u(panaginw/skwn ‘I will therefore call him up here and question him before you, reading the provisions of the law, clause by clause’. a)nabibasa/menos, to the bh=ma from which either party in a law-suit spoke, Lysias In Theomn. § 15, note, p. 275: for the e)rw/thsis, cp. Lysias In Eratosth. § 24, a)na/bhqi ou)=n moi kai\ a)po/krinai, k.t.l., p. 70. In u(panagignw/skwn, u(po/=leading him on gradually from point to point: cp. Xen. Anab. IV. 2. 16, *cenofw=n me\n su\n toi=s newta/tois a)ne/bainen e)pi\ to\ a)/kron, tou\s de\ a)/llous e)ke/leusen u(pa/gein, o(/pws oi( teleutai=oi lo/xoi prosmi/ceian, ordered the others to advance (only) gently, so that the rearmost companies might rejoin them.

a)delfidou=s...h)\ pro\s patro/s The son of Stratocles (pai=s) was not, of course any one of these things. He was, to Hagnias, second-cousin once removed, — Stratocles and Hagnias having been sons of a)neyioi/, first-cousins.
kai\ o(/pws mh\...e)rei=s ‘And take care that you do not say’. Xen. Cyr. I. 2. 18, o(/pws ou)=n mh\ a)polei= mastigou/menos. Goodwin § 46. 4.

ei)...h)mfisbh/tei...a)
 prosh/koi ‘If he were claiming my property [which he is doing], this would [on that supposition] be fitting’, etc.: but a)
 prosh=ken, ‘this would now be [as it is not] fitting’. Cp. Dem. De Cor. § 206, ei) me
 toi/nun tou=t' e)pexei/roun le/gein,...ou)k e)/sq' o(/stis ou)k a)
 ei)ko/tws e)pitimh/seie/ moi. Goodwin § 54.
th=s a)gxistei/as...to\ ge/nos ‘the degree of the relationship’: cp. § 2, tri/tw| ge/nei. So § 6, tou= ge/nous...marturi/as: § 17, to\ peri\ au)th=s ge/nos, note.

dio/mnusqai...i(/na ma=llon a)
 e)pisteu/eto ‘(it was his duty to make an affidavit (diwmosi/a)..., so that he might have had a better chance of being believed’. The addition of a)/n shows that i(/na...e)pisteu/eto is not only a final clause, but also an apodosis with a suppressed protasis: i.e. i(/na e)pisteu/eto, w(/sper e)pisteu/eto a)/n, ei) diw/mnuto. This is very rare: but cp. Plato Legg. 959 B, zw=nti e)/dei bohqei=n, o(/pws o(/ ti dikaio/tatos w)
 kai\ o(siw/tatos e)/zh te zw=n kai\ teleuth/sas a)timw/rhtos a)
 kakw=n a(marthma/twn e)gi/gneto,=o(/pws e)gi/gneto, w(/sper a)
 e)gi/gneto, ei) ou(/tws e)/zh. Goodwin § 44. 3, Note I.

e)mou= katagn. t. th\n ei)saggeli/an ‘to decide against me on this Information’: Theopompus being prosecuted under an ei)saggeli/a kakw/sews, an Information charging him with maltreatment of an orphan, viz. his nephew. This was a special form of the grafh\ kakw/sews. Any citizen might lay before the
archon an ei)saggeli/a regarding alleged wrong done to parents, women, or orphans, — might address the court without limit of time, — and, if defeated, suffer no fine. There was no fixed penalty, but, as it might be a)timi/a, Theopompus can speak of himself as kinduneu/wn u(pe\r tou= sw/matos, — as having his civic existence at stake, § 35. — See Attic Orators, II. 354.

e)gw\ ga/r, k.t.l. See the stemma of the family, and §§ 1, 2. Nothing is known as to the embassy of Hagnias (presbeu/swn) noticed here. — ou)k e)f' h(mi=n...kate/lipen, did not leave the property in our disposition,=ou) kuri/ous h(ma=s e)poi/hse tw=n o)/ntwn.

e)poih/sato qugate/ra ‘adopted a niece of his own as his daughter’. The adoption of a daughter was comparatively rare, since, unless a son was born to her, the continuance of the oi)=kos was not secured. But other instances occur, e.g. in this speech, § 41, and or. VII., peri\ tou= *)apollodw/rou klh/rou, § 4. Such exceptions illustrate the use of Attic adoption to gratify a personal preference, apart from the original object of perpetuating the family rites: see above on or. v. § 7, p. 366.

kata\ th\n diaqh/khn ‘under the will’ — whereas Glaucon would not have been entitled to it by nearness of kinship, if there had been no will. On kata\ diaqh/khn or kata\ do/sin as opp. to kat' a)gxistei/an or kata\ ge/nos, see or. v. § 14, note, p. 370.

h( d' *eu)bouli/dou quga/thr, k.t.l. ‘But the daughter of Eubulides [Phylomachè II. — see stemma], supported by her accomplices [meaning her ku/rios or male representative, or. v. § 10, note, p. 367], claims the estate at law, and obtains it, on defeating those who had claimed it under the will; — though she was not within the prescribed degrees, but had merely conceived the hope (it seems) that we [the kinsmen] would not oppose her, because we had not resisted the will either’. — lagxa/nei (di/khn) tou= klh/rou: or. v. § 16, note, p. 371.

h(mei=s de/...o( klh=ros ‘We,...since the claim on the estate had been opened to the next of kin, all prepared to bring our action’: i.e. the diaqh/kh which had given the estate to Glaucon had precluded all claims on the score of a)gxistei/a. Now, however, this will had been set aside in favour of Phylomachè's claim as a kinswoman. As against her, the other kinsfolk enter their claim, on the ground that their a)gxistei/a takes precedence of hers, e)gw\ kai\ *stra/tios k.t.l.... pareskeua/zonto: cp. Eur. Bacch. 974, o( nikh/swn d' e)gw\ | kai\ *bro/mios e)/stai.

mo/nos *tw=n pro\s patro\s w)\n a)neyiou= pai=s This is a quibble. Theopompus claims the inheritance under provision (3) of the law cited in §§ 1, 2, on the ground that he is the child of a first-
cousin on the father's side. But Theopompus was a)neyiou= pai=s only in respect to the father of Hagnias. In respect to Hagnias he was not a)neyiou= pai=s, a first-cousin once removed, but a second-cousin. Theopompus was not really in the a)gxistei=ai at all: still less, of course, was his nephew, the son of Stratocles. Phylomachè, as daughter of a paternal first-cousin of Hagnias, had a better claim than any living relative. If Phylomachè had died, then the next heir would have been Glaucon, who would have claimed under provision (4) as a brother of the testator by the same mother (though not o(mopa/trios). The decision by which Theopompus took the estate from Phylomachè was unjust.
e)gi/gneto ‘devolved’: cp. or. v. § 13, note, p. 369.

tw=| de\ gnw/sesqe...skepte/on e)sti/ ‘But where are you to find proof that I had an admissible claim of kinship, while their issue — this boy included — had none? The law itself will show. That the succession includes first-cousins on the father's side, and continues it to their children, is admitted on all hands: but whether, after us [i.e. children of firstcousins], the law gives it to our children — that is the question’. toi=s e)c e)kei/nwn gegono/sin, viz. the offspring of Stratius and Stratocles, who, like Theopompus, were really second-cousins of Hagnias: see last note.
a)lla\ a)pe/dwke ‘but has assigned the inheritance to the kin of the deceased on the mother's side’, — under provision (4) of the law cited in §§ 1, 2, where see note.

kata\ tau)ta\...u(peirhme/non ‘on the same terms which were indicated in the first instance’, viz., in the case of the kinsfolk pro\s patro/s. Cp. § 2, kata\ tau)ta\ kaqa/per toi=s pro\s patro\s e)c a)rxh=s e)di/dou. — u(peirhme/non, said by way of preliminary definition: see Dem. In Aristocr. § 53, dido/ntos ga tou= no/mou safw=s ou(twsi\ kai\ le/gontos e)f' oi(=s e)cei=nai ktei=nai, ou(=tos a(/panta parei=de tau=ta, kai\ ge/grafen, ou)de
 u(peipw/n, o(/pws a)/n tis a)poktei/nh|, th
 timwri/an: i.e. though the law specifies some cases (of involuntary homicide) as exempted from the penalty, this man has set down the penalty without any preliminary reservation (ou)de
 u(peipw/n), no matter what the circumstances of the homicide may be. Cp. Dem. De Cor. § 60, tau=ta a)namnh/sw kai\ tou/twn u(fe/cw, tosou=ton u(peipw/n, ‘with only this much of preface’.

oi(=s de\ mhd' ei) *kai\ teteleuthkw\s h)=n e)gw/ ‘But how can they to whom, even if I were dead, the law does not grant the inheritance, suppose that the succession is theirs while I live and am in legal possession?’ [under the verdict which took the estate from Phylomachè, § 18]. The mss., mhd' ei) teteleuthko/tes w)=sin, w(s e)gw/: Scheibe, following Reiske (with the
change of ei) to e)a/n), mhd' e)a\n teteleuthkw\s w)= e)gw/: but ei) should be retained, reading, with Dobree, h)=n for w)=.

kai\ ga\r o( tou/tou path\r...e)kei/nois ‘For the boy's father (Stratocles) was related [to Hagnias] only in their degree’: o(moi/ws e)kei/nois, only in the same degree with those who were cousin's sons, like Theopompus himself and Stratius: e)kei=noi denoting that class or grade of kinsmen, just as below § 18 e)kei/nas is similarly used. Dobree is not right then, I think, in accounting for e)kei/nois by the disappearance of words alluding to the children of Stratius (§ 15): the text is sound.

toutoni\...kaqista/nai ‘that this man [the speaker on behalf of the pai=s] should resort to vexatious proceedings, and that, though he did not think fit to contest the case or to lodge a rival claim [parakataba/llein] when I was going to law for the estate — the proper moment for the decision of any issue that he had to raise on such points — he should now make this boy a pretext for annoying me with litigation, and bring my civil existence into peril’. The parakatabolh/ was a deposit made (to be forfeited on defeat) by one who claimed the whole of an inheritance from another. Thus, when Theopompus e)/laxe tou= klh/rou against Phylomachè (§ 15), it was necessary for him to make such a deposit, as the estate was already hers. If the son of Stratocles had claimed the whole estate from Theopompus, then he too, must have proceeded by parakatabolh/: but, in fact, he claimed only the half, h(miklh/rion (§ 1). — epi\ tou= paido\s o)no/mati, ‘in the boy's name’, not as meaning, ‘on the boy's behalf’ (u(pe\r tou= paido/s), but, ‘making him a pretext’. Better e)pi\ tw=| tou= p. o)no/mati. Cp. Dem. Adv. Leptin. § 126, tau=t' e)pi\ tw=| tw=n qew=n o)no/mati poiei=n zhtou=sin...to\ tw=n leitourgiw=n o)/noma e)pi\ to\ tw=n i(erw=n metafe/rontes e)capata=n zhtou=si. — peri\ tw=n megi/stwn, because he might incur a)timi/a: § 35, kinduneu/wn u(pe\r tw=n sw/matos. Cp. § 6, note.

tw=n o(mologoume/nwn ei)=nai tou= paido/s, k.t.l. ‘the unquestioned property of the boy’, viz. the patrimony left to him by his father Stratocles. Theopompus was guardian, e)pi/tropos, of his nephew: see § 27, th=s de\ pro\s e)me\ lh/cews e)mpodw\n ei)=nai tou\s no/mous: ou) ga\r ei)=nai toi=s o)rfanoi=s kata\ tw=n e)pitro/pwn. Hence diw/|koun here. — w(/sper ou(=tos, meaning that the speaker was (by this law-suit) injuring the interests of his client, the boy.

e)ma\ ei)=nai e)yhfi/sasqe alluding to the verdict of the court which took the estate from Phylomachè and gave it to Theopompus, § 18. do/ntes, ‘after allowing anyone who pleased to dispute it’, in reference to the claim put in also by the mother of Hagnias, ib.

e)pi\ tou/tois...a)gw=nas paraskeua/zein ‘get up such law-suits for this property’: cp. Lysias In Agor. § 12, p. 79, e)kei/nw|... dikasth/rion paraskeua/santes. — e)pi\ tou/tois, not strictly ‘with a view to’, but ‘on the ground of’, as just before, e)f' oi(=s... kri/nesqai.

ou)de\ kata\ mikro/n ne paululum quidem, ‘not in the slightest degree’. Cp. or. v. § 10, p. 168, ou)de\ kata\ to\ e)la/xiston me/ros. But in Ar. Vesp. 702, e)nsta/zousin kata\ mikro\n a)ei/, paulatim, ‘little by little, gradually’: Xen. An. VII. 3. 22, a)/rtous die/kla kata\ mikro/n, minutim, ‘in little bits’.

maqh/sesqai...a)kou/santas ‘But I think that you will understand the case [peri\ au)tw=n neut.] still more exactly in the light of further comments [kai\ e)k tw=n a)/llwn opp. to e)k tw=n h)/dh ei)rhme/nwn], when you have heard the history of my action in claim of the estate’: join maqh/sesqai peri\ au)tw=n, a)kou/santas th\n e)mh\n e)pidikasi/an w(s ge/gonen.

o( nu=n e)me\ ei)sagge/llwn, k.t.l. ‘who now lays the Information against me’, the ei)saggeli/a kakw/sews: see on § 6. — parakataba/llein u(pe\r tou= paido/s, ‘to institute a claim on the boy's behalf’: see on § 13.

*ou)de
 di' a)/llo <h)\ o(/ti> ou)de
 au(toi=s e)no/mizon prosh/kein] [they abstained from going to law] ‘for no other reason than because they thought that they had no claim to this property’. Cp. § 16, ei)do/tes o(/ti e)/cw h)=san th=s a)gxistei/as. I prefer this to Scheibe's conjecture, ou)de
 a)/llo h)\ ou)de
 au(toi=s nomi/zontes prosh/kein, ‘simply because they thought’, etc. Reiske suggests, ou)/te (oi( a)/lloi) ou)de/n, or ou)/te (kata\ ge/nos ou)/te kata\ diaqh/khn) ou)/te di' a)/llo ou)de/n.

e)pei\ ou)d' a)\n ou(=tos, k.t.l. ‘since even the prosecutor would not be vexing me now, if I allowed him to plunder the boy's property and did not thwart him’: i.e. as on the former occasion the sons of Stratius refrained from litigation, so the son of Stratocles would refrain now, did not this pettifogger instigate him, out of spite, because I (as e)pi/tropos of the boy) protect my ward's property from his designs.
oi(...pra/ttontes Cp. § 9, tw=n au)th=| sumpratto/ntwn, ‘her accomplices’, note.

tw=| *strati/ou paidi/ ‘whose relationship (to Hagnias) was properly [dikai/ws, as opp. to her allegation] only the same as that of the son of Stratius’. For tw=| *strati/ou paidi/ we must read, either with Schömann, tw=| *stratokle/ous paidi/, (the nephew of Theopompus,) which seems best: or with Baiter, toi=s *strati/ou paisi/. — The assertion made here is false: see stemma. Eubulides, the father of Phylomachè, was the first-cousin of
Hagnias. Stratius, Stratocles and Theopompus were only his second-cousins. See on § 10, pro\s patro\s w)\n a)neyiou= pai=s.
oi( ku/rioi th=s *(a. mhtro/s ‘the legal representatives of the mother of Hagnias’: see or. v. § 10, note, p. 367.

h)=san oi(=oi/ te ‘were capable’=e)to/lmhsan: cp. Dem. In Mid. § 85, oi(=o/s t' h)=n pei/qein au)to/n, h(\n katededih|th/kei, tau/thn a)podedih|thme/nhn a)pofai/nein, ‘he was capable of pressing the arbitrator to return the award given against him as if it had been an award in his favour’. a)ntidikei=n oi(=oi (Scheibe), without te, would mean merely, ‘the kind of men likely to contend’, and is unsuitable here. See or. VIII. § 21, p. 192, komi/zein oi(=os h)=n, ‘I felt inclined to carry him away’.

o(/ ti a)ntigra/ywntai peri\ th=s a)gx ‘what plea of kinship they should oppose to mine’: a)ntigr., deliberative subj., vivid for o(/ ti a)ntigra/yainto. — a)ntigrafh/, the plea put in against his e)pidikasi/a (§ 15) or claim.

h( me\n...e)/xousa...tolmh/santes ‘the possessor of the estate [Phylomachè, daughter of Eubulides], and those who set forth her claim in kinship, as they misrepresented the matter, were easily convicted by me, then and there, of having audaciously framed a statement devoid of truth’. to\ peri\ au)th=s ge/nos, lit. ‘the degree of relationship which concerned her’, i.e. on which her claim rested: see § 5, to\ ge/nos th=s a)gxistei/as, note. — to/te, at the time, — finally disposing of her claim, whereas the mother's claim was revived in a new form. — gra/yai, not=the technical a)ntigraya/menoi, but simply of a statement in writing. Dobree conj. ou)k a)lhqh= gra/yai, but ou)k a)lhqe/s ti=ou)d' o(tiou=n a)lhqe/s. Cp. § 18, au)tw=n ou)k i)/sxuse/ ti.

ge/nei me/n, k.t.l. ‘Since, though her collateral kinship [with her son Hagnias] was the same as my own, (for she was the sister of Stratius,) she was excluded by the law which gives the preference to males, they dropped that plea [of cousinship], and, thinking to get the better of me, described her as mother of the deceased’. — Polemon, father of Hagnias, had married the daughter of his own first-cousin. Hence the mother of Hagnias was at the same time the second-cousin of her son. Her claim was, on this score, the same as that of Theopompus: his was better only because males were preferred to females.
suggene/staton...a)gxistei/ais See or. v. § 14, note, p. 370. — h)=n= ‘is, as I granted’: Goodwin § 11, note 6.

ei)=ta *graya/shs a)neyiou= *paido\s ei)=nai...e)ch/legca ‘Next, when she described herself as the daughter of a firstcousin [and no longer mother of Hagnias], I proved that daughters of first-cousins, too, were not in the succession [since
a first-cousin's son existed]. Thus I established my claim (e)pedikasa/mhn) before you’, etc. — e)kei/nas: see on e)kei/nois, § 13. — Scheibe proposed to read, gra/yas a)neyiou= pai=s (Sauppe pai=da/ me) ei)=nai, ka)kei/nas e)cele/gcas...ou(/tws e)pedikasa/mhn. But there was no occasion for him to describe himself anew as a)neyiou= pai=s, since that was the quality in which he had claimed from the first.

kai\ au)tw=n ou)k i)/sxuse/ ti ‘and of these pleas not one proved valid; — for the possessor of the estate, it availed not that she had already got a verdict against the claimants under the will [i.e. against Glaucon, § 9]; for the other, it availed not that she was the mother of the testator’. — ou)k i)/sxuse/ ti: cp. ou)k a)lhqe/s ti, § 17, note.
e)moi\...th\n yh=fon h)/negkan ‘gave their vote in my favour’. Cp. Dem. In Mid. § 51, tou/tois a)cioi= dou=nai th\n yh=fon u(ma=s.

a)ntidikh=sai tw=| paidi\ tou= h(miklhri/ou ‘to claim the moiety of the estate on behalf of the boy’, = u(pe\r tou= paido/s. After a)ntidikei=n, the adversary is usually designated by pro/s tina, not tini/ (cp. § 16, pro\s e)me/): in Dem. or. XLI. Adv. Spudiam, § 13, pw=s a)\n tai=s tou/twn diabolai=s a)ntidikoi/hn, the figurative sense (=‘contend against’) explains the dat.

div2.p: . [Or. VIII.] ‘On the Estate of Ciron’. — Ciron married his first-cousin, by whom he had one daughter. This daughter was married, first, to Nausimenes; secondly, to another husband by whom she had two sons, of whom the eldest is the speaker.
After the death of his first wife, Ciron married the sister of one Diocles, and had by her two sons, both of whom died young.

At the death of Ciron, his estate was claimed by his daughter's eldest son. But the son of Ciron's brother, instigated by Diocles, set up a counter-claim on two distinct grounds: 1. That Ciron's grandson is illegitimate: 2. That, supposing him legitimate, a brother's son has a better claim than a daughter's son.
This speech is the defendant's answer.

The only indication of the date is that the speaker and his brother were born after the archonship of Eucleides, Ol. 94. 2, 403 B.C. (§ 43, met' *eu)klei/dhn ga\r a)/rxonta gego/namen). The speech cannot, then, be put before 383 B.C. On the other hand, the speaker's plea of ‘utter inexperience’ (§ 5) implies youthfulness. Now, if he was a young man, the date cannot be much below 383, since otherwise it would have been superfluous for him to tell the judges that he was born after
403. The date is probably about 375 B.C. — Attic Orators, II. 327 f.

This speech exhibits the powers of Isaeus perhaps at their best, in its combination of the old plainness with the modern force, of artistic narrative with trenchant proof. It is here given in full, with the exception of four sections at the end (43 — 46).

div3.p: e)pi\ toi=s toiou/tois ‘Indignation must necessarily be felt, judges, in a case where men not only dare to claim the property of others, but also hope by their own assertions to abolish the privileges which the laws confer’: i.e. not only does the claimant seek to deprive me of property which in fact is mine, but he also mis-states the law on the subject. The first clause refers to the claimant's statement that the speaker's mother was not the legitimate daughter of Ciron: the second, to his statement that a brother's son inherits before a daughter's son.
ou(=toi viz. the nephew of Ciron, and Diocles, the brother of Ciron's second wife, who abetted the nephew: cp. § 3.

w(s ou)k...o)/ntas, *ou)de\ genome/nhs ‘alleging that we are not the sons of his daughter, and that he never had a daughter at all’: genome/nhs, gen. absol. to which w(s belongs as well as to o)/ntas. — ou)de/, Reiske for the mss. ou)/te.
au)tou/s...tou/twn] tou/twn referring to the same persons as au)tou/s: cp. Andoc. De Myst. § 64, au)toi=s followed by e)kei/nois, p. 41.
to/ <te> plh=qos mss. to\ plh=qos: Baiter and Sauppe, to/ te plh=qos. Scheibe, with Schömann, kai\ to\ plh=qos.
e)/xousi...kratou=si ‘have taken by force, and (still) hold in their grasp’.

th\n me\n ou)=n kri/sin, k.t.l. ‘Now you must not suppose that in this trial my real adversary is the man who has instituted the claim; it is Diocles of Phlya, surnamed Orestes. For it is he who has suborned (paraskeua/sas) the claimant to vex us with these proceedings, because he himself is withholding (a)posterw=n) from us the property which our grandfather bequeathed’. — Isaeus wrote two speeches, now lost, againt this man, kata\ *diokle/ous u(/brews (perh. in the grafh/ noticed below, § 41) and pro\s *diokle/a peri\ xwri/ou, fragg. VIII. IX. Sauppe O. A. II. 230. — *)ore/sthn: a nickname for any violent character, borrowed from the robber mentioned by Aristophanes (with an allusion to the orestes of Eurip.), Acharn. 1166, ei)=ta kata/ceie/ tis au)tou= mequ/wn th=s kefalh=s *)ore/sths maino/menos. (Attic Orators, II. 328.)

w(/sper kai\ to\ di/kaio/n e)sti ‘even as justice prescribes’, stronger than di/kaio/n e)stin: cp. Plat. Legg. 630 E, w(/sper to/ te a)lhqe/s, oi)=mai, kai\ to\ di/kaion u(pe/r ge qei/as (a)reth=s) dialegome/nous le/gein, as truth and justice prescribe that we should speak in discussing superhuman excellence: Laches 181 c, w(/sper to\ di/kaion, as right enjoins.

pro\s paraskeua\s lo/gwn kai\ ma/rturas, k.t.l. ‘against fabricated statements and witnesses whose depositions are false’; cp. Dem. Adv. Onet. I. § 3, oi)=da me
 ou)=n, w)= a)/ndres dikastai/, o(/ti moi pro\s paraskeua\s lo/gwn kai\ ma/rturas ou) ta)lhqh= marturh/sontas o( a)gw/n e)stin. And so, too, the phrase here, e)/sti me
 ou)=n xalepo/n, w)= a)/ndres,...ei)s a)gw=na kaqi/stasqai peri\ thlikou/twn, has an echo in Dem. Adv. Aphob. I. § 2, oi)=da me
 ou)=n, w)= a)/ndres dikastai/, o(/ti pro\s a)/ndras kai\ le/gein i(kanou\s kai\ paraskeua/sasqai duname/nous xalepo/n e)stin ei)s a)gw=na kaqi/stasqai peri\ tw=n o)/ntwn a(pa/ntwn. Demosthenes was doubtless aided by the counsel of Isaeus in preparing for the contests with Aphobus and Onetor, though these earliest speeches of Demosthenes have a thoroughly original stamp: see Attic Orators, II. 267 — 269.

ou) mh\n a)lla\...prosdokw/menon ‘At the same time, I have strong hopes that you will ratify my just claims, and also that in stating these claims — if in nothing else — my own part will be duly done, — unless some such mischance befall as I apprehend just now’ [where ‘just’ will render tugxa/nei]: alluding,
apparently, either to an indisposition from which the speaker was suffering, or to some interruption or annoyance which he anticipated from his opponents. In either case, the clause a)\n mh/ ti sumbh=|, k.t.l. is evidently an appeal bespeaking the sympathy of the judges.

bohqh=sai/ moi ta\ di/kaia=bohqh=sai/ moi th\n dikai/an boh/qeian, ‘to give me your righteous aid’, concise for bohqou=ntas a)podou=nai/ moi ta\ di/kaia: so Isae. or. IV. § 4, de/omai u(mw=n...bohqei=n moi ta\ di/kaia. Cp. Lysias or. XXXIV. § 10, pisteu/ontas me\n toi=s qeoi=s kai\ e)lpi/zontas to\ di/kaion meta\ tw=n a)dikoume/nwn e)/sesqai, note, p. 242.

lo/gwn a)koh=| kai\ martu/rwn...toi=s ei)do/si xr. ma/rtusin ‘(I will prove this to you), in regard to the events further back, by statements at second-hand, vouched for by those who heard them (lo/gwn a)koh=| kai\ martu/rwn); in regard to events within living memory, by witnesses personally cognizant of the facts (toi=s ei)do/si xrw/menos ma/rtusi)’. — lo/gwn a)koh=| kai\ martu/rwn: lit. ‘by the hearing of reports (object. gen.) and the hearing (thereof) by witnesses (subject. gen.)’: i.e. I will bring witnesses who can vouch for a)koh\ lo/gwn, things which are not, indeed, within their personal knowledge, but which they know from hearsay. Cp. Thuc. I. 73, ta\ pa/nu palaia\ ti/ dei= le/gein; w(=n a)koai\ ma=llon lo/gwn ma/rtures (for which the evidences are rather hearsay reports) h)\ o)/yis tw=n a)kousome/nwn. So below, § 29, tw=n me\n palaiw=n (neut.) a)koh\n marturou/ntwn parexo/menos, tw=n de\ e)/ti zw/ntwn (masc.) tou\s ei)do/tas e(/kasta tou/twn.

e)/ti de\ tekmhri/ois ‘and, further, by positive proofs’: tekmhri/ois, here, logical inferences from established facts, as opp. to marturi/ai, allegations tending to establish facts: cp. Antiph. De Caed. Her. § 81, note, p. 215.

o(/qen ou)=n h)/rcanto...dida/skein ‘Starting, then, from the point at which they [the claimants] began their account of the matter, [au)tw=n=tw=n xrhma/twn, the history of the bequest,] I will endeavour to give you my version of it’.

th
 e)mh
 th/qhn, k.t.l. The first wife of Ciron was also his first-cousin (a)neyia/), and was the grandmother (th/qh) of the speaker. — au)th
 gegenhme/nhn: au)th/n is not, I think, redundant (as in Isae. or. III. § 73, th
 qugate/ra th
