 e)k tau/ths a)pofanqei=san ei)=nai — e)pi/dikon katalipei=n au)th/n), but=ipsam, emphatic, in symmetry with au(tou=, ‘herself the child of his own mother's sister’ — a way of marking, on the speaker's part, that he and his brother, the children of the first marriage, had an additional tie with the house of Ciron which was not shared by the connexions (such as Diocles) through the second marriage.

meta\ e)niautou\s *te/ttaras mss. tria/konta, which cannot
stand, since the words could not mean ‘after a life of 30 years’. Dobree conj. te/ssaras, supposing l/ to have been written by mistake for d/.
e)gigne/sqhn ‘were born in due course’ (imperf.): gigne/sqhn A, whence Bekker gi/gnesqon.

kai\ e)kei/nhn te e)/trefe, k.t.l. i.e. e)/trefe/ te e)kei/nhn,...e)kdi/dwsi/ te. For the place of te, cp. Antiph. Tetr. B. b. § 1, tolma=n ta/ te a)/lla, note, p. 203. — sunoikei=n ei)=xen h(liki/an: cp. Lysias or. VII. § 29, ou)/t' e)pimelhth\s h(|rhme/nos ou)/q' h(liki/an e)/xwn ei)de/nai peri\ tou/twn. — *xolargei=: of the deme *xolargo/s.

su\n i(mati/ois...e)pidou/s ‘with a dowry, including (su/n) clothes or jewels, of 25 minas’. Cp. Isae. or. XI. § 42, kate/lipe pe/nte tala/ntwn ou)si/an kai\ trisxili/wn draxmw=n su\n toi=s e(autou= patrw/|ois. — e)pidou/s: e)pi/=‘with’ the bride: cp. Lys. Pro Mant. § 10, note, p. 244.

o( de\ pa/ppos, k.t.l. ‘Our grandfather’ [her father, Ciron] ‘took her to his home; and, without withdrawing the dowry (large as it was) which he had given on account of the embarrassed circumstances of Nausimenes, bestows her hand in a second marriage on my father’, etc.

tauti\ dh\ pa/nta...e)chu=ron ‘How, then, is one to place the truth of all these facts beyond dispute, in face of the charges which the claimants are making now? [nu=n, after so long an interval]. I sought, and I discovered, a way’. — ai)ti/as, the imputations cast on the genuineness of the speaker's descent. For the rhetorical e)rw/thsis, cp. or. XI. § 11, p. 181, tw=| de\ gnw/sesqe tou=q' , o(/ti e)moi\ me\n a)gxisteu/ein, toi=s d' e)c e)kei/nwn gegono/sin ou)k h)=n...; au)to\s o( no/mos dhlw/sei.

a)na/gkh th
 e)mh
 mhte/ra, k.t.l. ‘The question whether my mother was, or was not, the daughter of Ciron, — the fact that she lived, or did not live, in his house — the question whether he gave a marriage-feast for her once only, or twice — all this must be known to the male and female slaves of his household’. The difference of form made by the alternation of mh/ — ou) — mh/ is roughly represented by the alternation of ‘question’ and ‘fact’ in such a version as the above. The only practical difference here is that the clause in which ou) is used refers to that point which a member of the household could at once affirm or deny in the most positive manner, — viz., whether she had, or had not, been a resident member of the family. See on Antiph. De Caed. Her. § 14, h)\ mh/...h)\ ou)/, p. 211. Cp. Dem. Adv. Lept. § 83, ou)x o( no/mos kri/netai, po/tero/n e)stin e)pith/deios h)\ ou)/, a)ll' u(mei=s dokima/zesqe, ei)/t' e)pith/deioi pa/sxein e)ste\ eu)= to
 loipo
 xro/non ei)/te mh/.

boulo/menos ou)=n, k.t.l. ‘Wishing, then, in addition to the witnesses whom I had already, to procure proof of the facts from depositions made under torture, — in order that you might believe [pisteu/hte, vivid for pisteu/oite] my witnesses (au)toi=s) the more, when this ordeal for their veracity was past and not prospective — I required the claimants (tou/tous) to give up their male and female slaves for the question, both on these points, and on all others of which they were cognizant’. He proposed to examine the slaves under torture on the same matters to which the depositions of his witnesses referred. If the slaves confirmed the statements of the witnesses, then the witnesses would come into court with a presumption already established in favour of their truthfulness: whereas, if they had not been tested in this way, the court might always suspect that the evidence of the household, could it be obtained, would contradict them. Cp. Lycurg. In Leocrat. § 28, oi)=mai dei=n... tou\s ma/rturas mh\ dw/sontas e)/legxon marturei=n a)lla\ dedwko/tas. parekalesa/mhn ga\r au)tou/s, pro/klhsin u(pe\r tou/twn a(pa/ntwn gra/yas, kai\ a)ciw=n basani/zein tou\s tou/twn oi)ke/tas: i.e. ‘I think witnesses should pass the ordeal of veracity before, and not after, they depone in court. Now I invited their attendance [at the ba/sanos, or examination of the slaves], after drawing up a challenge [pro/klhsin, to surrender slaves] referring to all these points, and claiming to put the defendant's slaves to the question’.

kai\ i)di/a| kai\ dhmosi/a|, k.t.l. ‘Both in private and in public matters’: i)di/a|, as in di/kai, etc.: dhmosi/a|, as e.g. when the Hermae were mutilated. This whole passage, from u(mei=s me
 toi/nun kai\ i)di/a| to e)k tw=n basa/nwn ei)po/ntes recurs nearly verbatim in Dem. Adv. Onet. I. § 37. Cp. Isocr. or. XVII. § 54, o(rw= de\ u(ma=s kai\ peri\ tw=n i)di/wn kai\ peri\ tw=n dhmosi/wn ou)de
 pisto/teron ou)d' a)lhqe/steron basa/nou nomi/zontas, kai\ ma/rturas me
 h(goume/nous ei)=nai kai\ tw=n mh\ gegenhme/nwn paraskeua/sasqai, ta\s de\ basa/nous fanerw=s e)pideiknu/nai o(po/teroi ta)lhqh= le/gousi, k.t.l. Cic. Topica XX. § 74, nam et verberibus, tormentis, igni fatigati quae dicunt, ea videtur veritas ipsa dicere. It must be remembered that under Greek and Roman law citizens were ordinarily protected from torture, and that it is citizens who pronounce these astounding panegyrics on the services of torture to truth. Cp. Andoc. De Myst. § 43, note, p. 226.

ou)de/nes pw/pote e)chle/gxqhsan The rhetorical theory of tor ture — whether anyone believed it or not — was that a person under torture will tell the truth because it is his interest to tell the truth: see the *(rhtorikh\ pro\s *)ale/candron, XV. § 1, pisto/tero/n e)sti ba/sanos martu/rwn: toi=s me\n ga\r ma/rtusi sumfe/rei polla/kis yeu/desqai, toi=s de\ basanizome/nois lusitelei= ta)lhqh= le/gein. A
good commentary on this assumption will be found in Antiphon De Caed. Herod. §§ 31 — 33, — a passage which deserves to be placed beside this of Isaeus: — ‘The slave, to whom the prosecutors had doubtless promised freedom, and whose release from agony likewise depended upon them, was probably induced to calumniate me on both grounds — in the hope of winning his freedom, and in the desire of deliverance from anguish at the moment. Now I fancy you all know this, — that the party in whose hands the chief conduct of the examination rests have the examined on their side, and ready to say anything that will please them: for in the torturers is the hope of the tortured, especially if the slandered persons happen not to be present. Had it been I who gave the order to rack the slave as speaking falsely, that very threat would probably have deterred him from bearing false witness against me. As it was, the prosecutors were at once presidents of the inquisition and protectors of their own interest. So long, therefore, as the slave felt that his prospects in slandering me were hopeful, he was obstinate in the calumny; but when he saw that he was to die, then at last he told the truth, and said that he had been persuaded by the prosecutors to slander me’.
a)ll' ou)x h(mei=s sc. feu/gomen to\n e)/legxon. — a)ciw/santes — feu/gontos, ou(/tws: ‘since we claimed,...while he refused,... under these circumstances (ou(/tws) we shall demand’, etc.

a)koh/n ‘what they have heard’. ou(=toi, the witnesses who have just given their testimony, are not, I think, the persons who were intimate with Ciron, oi(\ e)xrw=nto tw=| pa/ppw| (for they would be said ei)de/nai), but oi( para\ tw=n xrwme/nwn a)kou/santes. See on § 6.

tou\s e)gguhsame/nous, k.t.l. ‘those to whom my mother was betrothed and those who were present with them when she was betrothed to them’. tou\s e)gguhsame/nous= her first husband, Nausimenes, and her second husband, the speaker's father. Both are dead, but the relatives of both (oi( e)kei/nois paro/ntes) are witnesses. The formal e)ggu/hsis was necessary to the validity of a marriage: see the no/mos ap. [Dem.] In Stephan. II. § 18, h(
 a)
 e)gguh/sh| e)pi\ dikai/ois (shall solemnly affiance) da/marta ei)=nai h)\ path h)\ a)delfo\s o(mopa/twr h)\ pa/ppos o( pro\s patro/s, e)k tau/ths ei)=nai pai=das gnhsi/ous. The act. e)gguw= was said of the relative, or his representative before the law (ku/rios, or. v. § 10, n. p. 367), who bestows the hand of the bride, but the midd. e)gguw=mai of the bridegroom: cp. Her. VI. 130, e)gguw= pai=da th
 e)mh
... fame/nou de\ e)ggua=sqai *megakle/os (the future husband). So [Dem.] or. LVII. Adv. Eubul. § 41, e)ggua=tai o( path th
 mhte/ra th
 e)mh/n.

ti/nes de\ oi( trefome/nhn...*ki/rwnos ‘And who are they who
know that she lived in the family and was the true-born daughter of Ciron?’ The answer to this question would naturally be, oi( oi)ke/tai kai\ ai( qera/painai: see § 10. But their evidence had been excluded by the refusal of the claimants to give them up for torture: and the speaker turns this to account by saying, ‘The present claimants practically (e)/rgw|) bear clear testimony that these facts are so, by withholding their slaves from the question’.
*a(\ <maqo/ntes> gnw/sesqe] The traditional reading is i(/na gnw/sesqe. But i(/na with fut. indic. is unexampled in classical Greek: see Goodwin § 44, 1. Cp. the note on the text.

pai/dwn *o)/ntwn ‘as we were children’. This (Sauppe's) conjecture is at least more prob. than o)/ntwn ui(e/wn. The vulgate, pai/dwn ui(e/wn, is unintelligible. Reiske, from the Aldine pa/ppou ui(e/wn, gives pa/ppon ui(e/wn. I suspect, however, that the fault lies deeper, and that ui(e/wn referred to the two sons, now dead, borne to Ciron by his second wife (§ 7, e)c h(=s au)tw=| e)gigne/sqhn ui(ei=s du/o). The general sense would then have been, oi(=a ga\r ei)ko/s, [au)tw=| me\n ou)k o)/ntwn] ui(e/wn [h(mw=n de\] pai/dwn e)c e(autou= qugatro/s, k.t.l.

ei)s *dionu/sia ei)s a)gro/n The ‘Lesser’ or ‘Rural’ Dionysia, the Vintage Feast, was kept in Dec.; the Lenaea, in Jan.; the Anthesteria in Feb., and the great Dionysia in March. — ta\ kat' a)grou\s *dionu/sia, with its rustic sports (chief of which was the a)skwliasmo/s, or dancing on a)skoi/, wine-skins inflated and greased, Pollux IX. 121), was essentially a family festival, — hence the point of its mention here: see Harpocration 143, ta\ kata\ dh/mous *dionu/sia *qeoi/nia e)le/geto, e)n oi(=s oi( gennh=tai e)pe/quon, in which members of the same ge/nos offered sacrifice together (30 ge/nh made a fratri/a, and three fratri/ai a fulh/).

kai\ met' e)kei/nou te e)qewrou=men, k.t.l. ‘and we were his companions at public spectacles [in the Theatre], where he would set us at his side [par' au)to/n, not par' au)tw=|], and for every festive celebration we came to his house [par' e)kei=non]’: for au)to
...e)kei=non cp. Andoc. De Myst. § 64, note, p. 230. Cp. Isocrates or. XIX. § 10, e(/ws me
 ga pai=des h)=men, peri\ ple/onos h(ma=s au)tou\s h(gou/meqa h)\ tou\s a)delfou/s, kai\ ou)/te qusi/an ou)/te qewri/an (public spectacle) ou)/t' a)/llhn e(orth
 ou)demi/an xwri\s a)llh/lwn h)/gomen.

tw=| *dii/ te qu/wn, k.t.l. ‘And when he sacrificed to Zeus Ktêsios, — a festival which he kept with especial reverence, and in which he associated no stranger, slave or free, but did everything by the hands of his own household (au)to\s di' e(autou=), — we participated in that celebration, assisted in the service of the
altar, laid our offerings on it along with his own (sunepeti/qemen), and aided in all else; and he used to pray the god to give us health and wealth, as a grandfather would pray’. — *zeu\s *kth/sios was one of the group of deities (e)fe/stioi, mu/xioi, e(rkei=oi) who were regarded as protecting the family and its possessions: Harpocr. 179, *kth/sion *di/a e)n toi=s tamiei/ois (store rooms) i(dru/onto: the Doric name of this Zeus was *pa/sios, Ross Inscr. III. 52. Small images (shmei=a) of *zeu\s *kth/sios were kept in little cases or shrines, which were especially called kadi/skoi (a)ggei=on d' e)sti
 e)n w(=| tou\s *kthsi/ous *di/as e)gkaqidru/ousin, Athen. XI. p. 473, with Casaubon's note ap. Schweigh.). — sunepeti/qemen, Scheibe for mss. suneti/qemen, a necessary corr., I think. For e)pitiqe/nai, cp. Ar. Nub. 426, ou)d' a)
 qu/saim), ou)d' a)
 spei/saim), ou)d' e)piqei/hn libanwto/n. Cp. e)pe/quon ap. Harpocr. in note on ei)s *dionu/sia, § 15.
mo/nous e)kgo/nous...kataleleimme/nous His two sons being dead, § 7. Dobree would bracket kataleleimme/nous: Schömann compares Lucian Auct. Vit. 27, ti/s loipo\s h(mi=n katalei/petai.

*ou(=tos paradou=nai] ou(=tos is Dobree's conjecture. The mss. au)to\s could only mean — ‘It is his own fault (and not mine) that I cannot produce the slaves in support of these statements’. Cp. § 14 ti/nes de\ oi( trefome/nhn...feu/gontes th\n ba/sanon, note.

ai( gunai=kes ai( tw=n dhmotw=n ‘The wives of the demesmen’ are the women of the deme to which Ciron belonged. On his daughter's marriage, they chose her as one of the two presidents of the *qesmofo/ria, the three days' festival of *dhmh/thr *qesmofo/ros, the Law-giver, which was annually celebrated about the end of Oct. by the women of each Attic deme. It seems to have been customary for a rich man, on his marriage, to defray the cost of a banquet at the next Thesmophoria: cp. Isae. or. III. § 80, kai\ e)n tw=| dh/mw| kekthme/nos to\n trita/lanton oi)=kon, ei) h)=n gegamhkw/s, h)nagka/zeto a)\n u(pe\r th=s gameth=s kai\ *qesmofo/ria e(stia=n ta\s gunai=kas [entertain them at the Thesmoph.] kai\ ta)/lla o(/sa prosh=ke leitourgei=n e)n tw=| dh/mw| u(pe\r th=s gunaiko\s a)po/ ge ou)si/as thlikau/ths.

ga/mous ei(sti/ase...toi=s te fra/torsi gamhli/an ei)sh/negke ‘gave a marriage-feast’ [on bringing the bride home, as her father did on her leaving his house, § 9]...‘provided a wedding-festival for his clansmen’. gamhli/an, sc. qusi/an, Pollux III. 42, dei=pnon o(\ toi=s fra/torsin e)poi/ei o( gamw=n: a sacrifice, with a banquet, given by the husband on the introduction (ei)sagwgh/) of the bride into his fratri/a, while the entertainment denoted by ga/mous e(stia=n was of a more private character.

tou= *pitqe/ws or *piqe/ws, of the deme of Pitthos or
Pithos, belonging to the Cecropid tribe. This Diocles is a distinct person from Ciron's brother-in-law, Diocles o( *flueu/s, of Phlya, § 3.

ei)s tou\s fra/toras...ei)sh/gagen Cp. Dem. or. XXXIX. Adv. Boeot. de nom. § 4, e)ggra/fei toi=s *)apatouri/ois toutoni\ *boiwto\n ei)s tou\s fra/toras. This was done on the third day of the Apaturia, called kourew=tis (the first day being dorpei/a, the supper, — the second, a)na/rrusis, the sacrifice): and the ceremony — here represented as occurring soon after birth — was seldom deferred beyond the third or fourth year: Herm. Ant. I. § 99. 2. 10. Cp. Ar. Ranae 418, o(\s e(pte/ths w)\n ou)k e)/fuse fra/toras.

e)c a)sth=s kai\ e)gguhth=s ‘the child of an Attic mother, born in wedlock’: e)gguhth=s, betrothed with the consent of her father or his legal substitute: see note on § 14, e)gguhsame/nous Cp. [Dem.] or. LVII. Adv. Eubul. § 66, a)lla\ mh
 o( path au)to\s zw=n, o)mo/sas to
 no/mimon toi=s fra/torsin o(/rkon, ei)sh/gagen e)me\ a)sto
 e)c a)sth=s e)gguhth=s au)tw=| gegenhme/non ei)dw/s.

kai/toi mh\ oi)/esq' a)/n...gnhsi/an *ki/rwnos The a)/n after oi)/esqe belongs to ei)senegkei=n and a)pokru/yasqai, being repeated after mh/te: with ai(rei=sqai and with e)pitre/pein it is again repeated. In the direct discourse, the form would be: ei) toiau/th tis h)=n, ou)/t' a)
 ei)sh/negkan, a)ll) a)pekru/yanto (a)/n)...ou)/q' h(rou=nto a)
 au)th
 sunieropoiei=n kai\ kuri/an e)poi/oun, a)ll) e(te/ra| a)
 e)pe/trepon,...ou)/te a)
 ei)sede/xonto a)lla\ kathgo/roun kai\ e)ch/legxon (a)/n): where the imperfects, which might refer to present time, refer to a continued act in past time, ‘would not have proceeded to choose’, etc.: Goodwin § 49. 2. The number of clauses in the apodosis leads to the protasis, ei)...h)=n, being re-stated in a different form at the end — ei) mh\ pa/ntoqen h)=n o(mologou/menon, k.t.l.

nu=n de\ th=| perifanei/a|...toiou=ton ou)de/n ‘But as it was, owing to the notoriety of the matter [tou= pra/gmatos, her legitimacy] and the fact that so many persons were aware of it, no such objection was raised from any quarter’. th=| perif., tw=| suneide/nai, causal datives: cp. Antiph. De Caed. Her. § 3, toi=s a)lhqe/sin, note, p. 209.

komiou/menos au)to/n ‘to obtain the body, intending that the funeral should take place from my own house’: komiou/menos, as being his proper charge: but active komi/zein below, of simply carrying. — e)k th=s oi)ki/as: i.e. the laying out (pro/qesis) should take place there, and the e)kfora/ to the grave (mnh=ma, § 27) set out thence. Cp. e)nteu=qen, § 22: Lysias, In Eratosth. § 18, triw=n h(mi=n oi)kiw=n ou)sw=n ou)demia=s ei)/asan e)cenexqh=nai, note, p. 253.

komi/zein oi(=os h)=n ‘I was disposed to remove the body’. For
the distinction between oi(=os and oi(=o/s te with infin., see above, or. XI. § 16, h)=san oi(=oi/ te, note, p. 387.

summetaxeiri/zesqai...kosmh=sai ‘help in tending’,... ‘dress’ (for the pro/qesis). Soph. El. 1139, ou)/t' e)n fi/laisi xersi\n h( ta/lain) e)gw\ | loutroi=s s' e)ko/smhs) ...a)ll) e)n ce/naisi xersi\ khdeuqei\s ta/las, k.t.l. Ant. 903, to\ so\n | de/mas periste/llousa: so componere. Here summetaxeiri/z. refers esp. to the washing of the corpse: Lucian *peri\ pe/nqous, 11, lou/santes...mu/rw| xri/santes...kai\ stefanw/santes toi=s w(rai/ois a)/nqesi, proti/qentai, lamprw=s a)mfie/santes.

a)lla\ kai\ e)wnh=sqai...tou\s labo/ntas ‘but alleging that he had actually (kai/) purchased part of the requisites of the funeral, and had given earnest-money for the rest, Diocles claimed these sums from me; and came to an agreement that he should be reimbursed for his purchases, while, as to the alleged deposits of earnest-money, he was to produce those who had received it’. — a)rrabw/n: a small sum paid in advance as caution-money. Arist. Polit. I. 11. § 9, fasi
 au)to
... a)rrabw=nas diadou=nai tw=n e)laiourgi/wn...o)li/gou misqwsa/menon a(/t' ou)deno\s e)piba/llontos, paid earnest-money all over the country (diadou=nai) for the hire of the oil-presses, — getting them at a low rent, as no one bid against him. — susth=sai: ‘to introduce’, ‘present’ to the speaker the persons who had received the a)rrabw/n: cp. Dem. or. XLI. § 6, o)fei/lein w(molo/gei moi *polu/euktos kai\ to
 *lewkra/th sune/sthse, and presented L. to me (in proof of transactions between L. and himself).

eu)qu\s ou)=n...parefqe/ggeto ‘Well, then, — he immediately remarked in a casual way that Ciron had left nothing at all behind him, — though I had not yet touched on the subject of Ciron's property’. parefqe/gg., threw in the observation carelessly, as if it were not the thing uppermost in his thoughts. Cp. Hypereides Pro Euxenippo XLII., kai\ to\ pa/ntwn deino/taton tw=n e)n tw=| lo/gw| legome/nwn u(po\ sou=, o(\ su\ w)/|ou lanqa/nein w(=n e(/neka le/geis, ou) lanqa/nwn, o(po/te parafqe/ggoio e)n tw=| lo/gw| polla/kis w(s plou/sio/s e)stin *eu)ce/nippos.
su\ de\ ti/s ei)=;] ‘Now who are you?’ The de/ marks that the speaker's attention is suddenly turned on the intruder. Her. I. 115, w)= de/spota, e)gw\ de\ tau=ta e)poi/hsa.

ou) mh\ *ei)/sei ‘You shall not enter’. The only practical distinction which can be drawn between ou) mh\ ei)/sei and ou) mh\ ei)se/lqh|s is that ou) mh\ ei)/sei states the negative future fact in a more direct and positive manner. This direct and positive negation, addressed to a person or persons, may of course, as here, be equivalent to a prohibition: Ar. Nub. 367, ou) mh\ lalh/seis, ‘You shall not prate’. On the other hand, unless
the mss. are altered, ou) mh\ poih/sete (e.g.) is sometimes merely a rougher and stronger ou) mh\ poih/shte: Aeschin. In Ctes. § 177, tou\s...ga\r ponhrou\s ou) mh/ pote belti/ous poih/sete. Elmsley's view that ou) mh\ ei)/sei (e.g.) meant ‘will you not not-enter?’ appears to be decisively negatived by such passages as Ar. Nub. 296, ou) mh\ skw/yei mhde\ poih/seis [v. l. skw/yh|s — poih/sh|s] a(/per oi( trugodai/mones ou(=toi, | a)ll' eu)fh/mei [not eu)fhmh/seis]. Cp. Goodwin § 89.

ei)s e(/w de\...ei)senegkei=n ‘but requested me to place the money in his hands early the next morning’. e)ke/leuon usu. = ‘I requested’ or ‘invited’, e)ke/leusa, ‘I commanded’, though the distinction cannot always, of course, be sharply drawn. In Xen. Anab. VII. 1 most mss. have the milder e)ke/leue in § 38, and the more peremptory e)ke/leuse in § 39 — rightly, I think: though G. Sauppe adopts in § 39 the v. l. e)ke/leue. On the other hand e)ke/leue is preferable to the vulg. e)ke/leuse in such places as Anab. II. 5. 3, IV. 3. 13.

ou) toi/nun e)kei=nos...ei)=pen ou)de/n ‘Now it was not Diocles alone who was silent; the present claimant of the estate said nothing to such a purport either [ou)de\n toiou=ton, nothing implying that I was not the lawful heir]; it is Diocles who has suborned him to contend’: i.e. ou) mo/nos e)kei=nos ou)de\n ei)=pen, a)ll' ou)de\ o( nu=n a)mfisbhtw=n (ei)=pen o(tiou=n): the awkwardness arising from the postponement of ei)=pen ou)de/n, which leaves ou)de/ with no corresponding negative before it, since ou) belongs only to mo/nos. All would be clear if ou)de/ were kai/, and ei)=pen ou)de/n were e)si/ghsen.

ka)kei/nou...a)nalwma/twn ‘And although Diocles (e)kei/nou) refused to receive in payment (a)polabei=n, as § 23, tw=n h)gorasme/nwn timh\n a)polabei=n) the money which I tendered, and alleged next day [when I brought it, ei)s e(/w § 24] that he had received it in full from the claimant (tou/tou), yet I was not prevented from attending the funeral, but took part in the ceremony throughout: not that the claimant or Diocles bore the cost; the charges of the burial were defrayed out of the property left by the deceased’. ou)x o(/pws: i.e. ou) (le/gw) o(/pws (sune/qapton) tou=de a)nali/skontos (gen. absol.).

kai/toi kai\ tou/tw| ‘The claimant too, however, [i.e. even if Diocles had remained passive] was bound to repulse me (w)qei=n), — to repudiate me (e)kba/llein) — to forbid my presence at the funeral’. w)qei=n, to repel advances: e)kba/llein, stronger, to eject from the company of the relatives.

ou)de\n ga\r o(/moion h)=n moi pro\s tou=ton ‘For my attitude towards him was utterly different [from his towards me]’: i.e. I, claiming to be the grandson and heir, still recognised him
as a nephew of Ciron: but he, on his own theory, was bound to regard me as an impostor. ou)de\n ga\r o(/moion h)=n moi pro\s tou=ton [kai\ tou/tw| pro\s e)me/], is an answer to the possible objection: ‘If, as you say, he ought to have excluded you from the funeral rites, why did you not exclude him?’ — hence ga/r.

e)pi\ tou= *mnh/matos ‘at the tomb’. Schömann's emend. of bh/matos. Dem. De Cor. § 208, tou\s e)n toi=s dhmosi/ois mnh/masi keime/nous. — e)pi\ tou= mnh/matos, like e)pi\ tou= dikasthri/ou, before the court. But the phrase is strange, and the supposed conduct stranger still. If bh/matos is right, it prob. means the tribune from which the speaker addressed a law-court, when claiming the inheritance in some proceedings previous to this case. Cp. § 37. — a)posterw=n, ‘withholding’; cp. § 3.

po/qen de\ tou\s ma/rturas; ou)k e)k tw=n basa/nwn; k.t.l. ‘And how is the credibility of witnesses to be tested? How but by statements made under torture?’ [by slaves examined on the same points]: see §§ 10 f., boulo/menos...pro\s toi=s u(pa/rxousi ma/rtusin e)/legxon e)k basa/nwn poih/sasqai peri\ au)tw=n, k.t.l., and notes.

po/qen d' a)pistei=n...tou\s e)le/gxous;] ‘And how are we entitled to disbelieve the statements of the claimants? How, but by their shrinking from the ordeals of proof?’ [by refusing to permit the examination of their slaves: § 13].

§§ 28, 29. tw=s ou)=n a)/n tis...h)/|desan; k.t.l.] ‘How could one prove the case more clearly than by offering a proof of this kind, — producing, for the earlier part of the story, hearsay evidence (a)koh/n) vouched for by witnesses, and for matters within living memory [lit., from among men still living] those who know the several facts, — who were cognizant of her living in Ciron's house, being acknowledged as his daughter, having been twice betrothed and twice married: then further, proving that the claimants have shrunk from applying the question, on all these points, to slaves who knew the whole’. The complexity of this sentence is studied, and the subtlety is Isaean. The really weak point in the speaker's case obviously is that, for the principal facts, he has nothing but a)koh/, hearsay evidence, by way of proof. He tries to get over this by a persistent assumption that the slaves who had personal knowledge of the facts would have confirmed this hearsay evidence if only he could have examined them. By his way of introducing tou\s ei)do/tas in this sentence he makes it depend on parexo/menos, suggesting that he had actually produced witnesses who had personal knowledge (tou\s ei)do/tas), whereas, at most, he had only tried to produce them. Then tou/tous after e)/ti de\ peri\ pa/ntwn depends on e)pideiknu/s, supplied kat' e)/nnoian from pare-
xo/menos. — On a)koh/ see § 6, note. For marturou/ntwn I should prefer marturou=ntas.

fe/re dh/, k.t.l. His first point has now been made — viz. that his mother was the true-born daughter of Ciron. Here he comes to his second point. Briefly it is this. Descent in the direct line (ge/nos) gives a better claim to succession than collateral kinship (sugge/neia). Descendants (e)/kgonoi) have a right to inherit before collateral relations (suggenei=s). And therefore a grandson before a nephew.

kai\ nomi/zw me\n a(plw=s...dida/comen ‘Now I suppose that, as a general proposition (a(plw=s), it is already as clear to you as to me [kai\ u(mi=n] that Ciron's collateral relatives (oi( met' e)kei/nou fu/ntes) are not nearer to the legal succession than his lineal descendants (oi( e)c e)kei/nou gegono/tes). Of course they are not; we call the former merely his “kinsfolk”, the latter his “issue”. Nevertheless, since even under these circumstances the claimants have the hardihood to dispute my right, I will prove the point more in detail from the laws themselves’. oi( meta/ tinos fu/ntes, kinsmen in the same generation with him, brothers, sisters, or cousins. Dobree's a)/llws for a(plw=s is needless: a(plw=s is opp. to a)kribe/steron.

sunoikh=sai me\n a)/n, k.t.l....e)pi\ di/etes h(/bhsan ‘would be entitled to marry her [i.e. his own niece], but would not be entitled to the property, which would go to their children, when these had come of age’: e)pi\ di/etes h(/bhsan, ‘had been e)/fhboi for two years’, i.e. had completed their 20th year. — o(po/te h(/bhsan, not h(bh/seian, because the fact is present as definite and past: cp. § 37, o(po/te o( pa/ppos e)teleu/thsen, where teleuth/seien would be admissible, but the indic. is used because the speaker is looking back on the historical fact of the decease.

e)k tou= peri\ th=s kakw/sews no/mou ‘Now this appears, not only from the foregoing consideration, but also from the law which deals with breaches of natural duty’. An ei)saggeli/a kakw/sews might be laid against (1) a son, on behalf of his parents — or, acc. to this passage, his grand-parents: (2) a husband, on behalf of his wife, she being an e)pi/klhros [the phrase is always tai=s e)piklh/rois]: (3) a guardian, e)pi/tropos, on behalf of his ward, — as in reference to the estate of Hagnias (or. XI., introd. p. 379). In cases of ka/kwsis the accuser could speak a)/neu u(/datos, without limit of time (Harpocr. 161), and was not liable to the e)pwbeli/a (or fine in 1/6th of the damages laid) if he failed to gain a fifth of the votes. — For the term gonei=s extended to pro/gonoi, cp. Her. I. 91, *kroi=sos de\ pe/mptou gone/os (i.e. of Gyges) th\n a(marta/da e)ce/plhse.

pro\s e(/na de\...e)rwth/sw ‘I will illustrate my meaning by a particular case of collateral kinship, — the nearest, — and will ask you to compare with it the several degrees of lineal descent’. prosa/cw, sc. to\n e)/kgonon, I will compare (the lineal descendant) with one — the first, nearest — of collateral kinsmen (suggenw=n), viz. a brother: and will question you, tou= ge/nous kaq' e(/kaston, on the details of lineal descent (ge/nos) as distinguished from sugge/neia: i.e. I will first take a daughter, then, descending, a daughter's child, etc. If it appears that even a daughter's son is nearer than a brother, a fortiori he is nearer than a brother's son: and I, therefore, Ciron's grandson, inherit before his nephew.

pa/ntes ga\r u(mei=s...a)nepi/dikon ‘You all inherit the property of your fathers, grandfathers, or remoter ancestors in virtue of a lineal descent (ge/nous) which guarantees your succession against dispute’: your a)gxistei/a, legal nearness or right to inherit, is a)nepi/dikos, not to be contested: that is, no one can, as against lineal heirs, e)pidika/zesqai tou= klh/rou, claim the estate at law; nor have you to assert your right by an e)pidikasi/a. A person who entered on possession of an undisputed inheritance was said e)mbateu/ein ei)s to\n klh=ron. Cp. [Dem.] or. XXXIII. § 6.

*fluh=si Phlya, of which the exact site is doubtful, a deme of the mesogai/a, or district S.E. of the Attic Plain, seems to have been a place of some note, with several temples: Paus. I. 31 § 4, IV. 1 § 5.

misqoforou=san...eu(ri/skousan ‘one house, — which is let, — near the temple of Dionysus in Limnae, — worth 2000 drachmas’ (about £80): eu(ri/skousan, acc. to Schömann (comparing Boeckh Pub. Econ. 67), not of the annual rent, misqo/s, but of the sum which the house would fetch if it were sold: and as the value of the other house is represented by triw=n kai\ de/ka mnw=n, (about £52,) this seems probable. Cp. Isae. or. XI. § 49, *xaire/lews... xwri/on kate/lipen o(\ ple/on ou)k a)
 eu(/roi tria/konta mnw=n. Xen. Mem. II. 5. 5, o(/tan tis oi)ke/thn ponhro
 pwlh=| kai\ a)podidw=tai tou= eu(ro/ntos,=tou/tou o(\ a)
 eu(/rh|, strictly, ‘for that which will bring him gain’, i.e. ‘for any price the slave will fetch’.

qerapai/nas kai\ paidi/skhn The qera/paina was an ordinary domestic slave: th=| gunaiki\...mh\ pri/asqai qera/painan, a)lla\ misqou=sqai ei)s ta\s e)co/dous e)k th=s gunaikei/as to\ paidi/on to\ sunakolou/qhson, of the a)neleu/qeros or mean man, Theophr. Char. XXII. (=XXV. in my ed., where see note, p. 255). — paidi/skh, ‘girl’, might be merely a synonym for qera/paina, as in Lysias or. I. §§ 11 — 12, where qera/paina and paidi/skh seem to designate one and the same person. Schömann, however, would dis
tinguish them both there and here, regarding paidi/skh as one who was exempt from menial work.

o(/sa fanera\ h)=n ‘all the real property’ (land, houses, etc., as opp. to money), — here including the slaves, who are considered as furniture of the houses: cp. [Dem.] or. XXXVIII. § 7, th\n ou)si/an...a(/pasan xre/a kate/leipon kai\ fanera\n e)ke/kthnto mikra/n tina, ‘left all their fortune in debts, and had possessed only some small amount of real property’.

e)kei/nhn me\n ga\r...ei)spoih/saito ui(o/n ‘For Diocles abstained from finding another husband for his sister, though she was still capable of bearing children in another marriage, lest, if she were separated from Ciron, the latter should form the proper resolve regarding his own property [i.e. should adopt my brother and me as his heirs], but persuaded her to remain with him’. Diocles is the subject to e)cedi/dou and e)/peiqe, but Ciron to bouleu/saito.

diafqei/rein sc. to\ e)/mbruon, de abortu: so diafqorh/ (ionice) Hippocrates Epidem. VII. 48,=a)pofqei/rein: ib. IV. 2, 5, e)camblou=sqai. — prospoioume/nhn diafqei/r. a)/kousan, i.e. o(/ti die/fqeiren a)/kousa (‘had been’ doing so hitherto). — As this passage shows, a childless union could be dissolved at the instance of the wife's relatives: cp. Isae. or. III. § 64, polloi\ sunoikou=ntes h)/dh a)fh/|rhntai ta\s e(autw=n gunai=kas.
ei)spoih/saito ui(o/n ‘adopt as his son’, like poih/saito: but § 40, act., au(to\n tw=| patri\ ei)spoih/sas, of one who forges a will for his own adoption.

ta/ te ou)=n xre/a...di' au(tou= poiei=sqai ‘So Diocles gradually persuaded Ciron to place under his control (di' au(tou= poiei=sqai) all the monies (xre/a) that were owing to him, with the interest upon them, and also the real property’ (ta\ fanera/). — ta/ te xre/a corresponds with ta/ te fanera/ (‘both’... ‘and’): the kai\ before to/kous merely connects it with ta\ xre/a,=su\n toi=s to/kois. — di' au(tou= poiei=sqai: cp. Isae. or. VI. § 35, e)sko/poun e(/pws kai\ teleuth/santos e)kei/nou di' au(tw=n e)/soito h( ou)si/a, ‘should be in their hands’. [Dem.] or. XLVIII. § 15, kai\ to\ a)rgu/rion tou=q' a(/pan ei)=xen au)to\s di' e(autou= o( a)/nqrwpos, had under his exclusive control. Cp. above § 16, au)to\s di' e(autou= pa/nt' e)poi/ei, note.

o(po/te...e)teleu/thsen ‘when my grandfather had died’. At that time he had not died: but e)teleu/thsen, not teleuth/seien, is used, because the speaker is now looking back on the death as a past event. See § 31, o(po/te...h(/bhsan, note.

pareskeu/aze, k.t.l. Cp. § 3, o( tou=ton paraskeua/sas: § 25, u(po\ tou/tou paraskeuasqei/s: § 27, tou=ton pe/peiken a)mfisbhtei=n. —
me/ros pollosto\n...metadidou/s, ‘offering (pres.) to give him a small fraction if he succeeded’: he said, metadi/dwmi, e)a\n katorqw/sh|s. — ou)de\ pro\s tou=ton o(mologw=n, ‘admitting not even to [i.e. in conversation with] him’: cp. Isocr. Evag. § 50, prosomologh/seien, note, p. 292.

kai\ e)peidh\...to\n pa/ppon ‘And immediately on Ciron's death, having made his preparations for the funeral beforehand, Diocles requested me, indeed, to bring the money;...but then pretended to have received the whole amount from the claimant, and withdrew his consent to take it from me, — thus quietly setting me aside (u(poparwqw=n), in order that the claimant, and not I, should appear to celebrate my grandfather's obsequies’. — ta\ e)nta/fia, here=ta\ ei)s th\n tafh/n, § 23, all requisites for the pro/qesis and the e)kfora/. — to\ a)rgu/rion: see § 24.

a)mfisbhtou=ntos...gignome/nwn ‘As the claimant disputed my possession of that house [tau/ths, the house in which Ciron died] as well as of the other property left by Ciron, and alleged that he had left nothing behind him, I did not think it proper, under such inopportune circumstances, to use force in removing my grandfather's corpse, — and my friends approved of this decision; but I took part in the rites of burial, the charges being defrayed by the property which my grandfather left’. Cp. §§ 21 — 22: the entreaties of Diocles' sister induced him to refrain from removing the body. — a)kairi/ais: for the plur. see Isocr. Antid. § 283, note, p. 303. — sunepoi/oun: for poiei=n, of sacred rites, cp. §§ 16, 25. — tw=n a)nalwm...gign.: the same point as in § 25, ou)x o(/pws tou=de a)nali/skontos, k.t.l.

to\n e)chghth\n...e)ph/negka ‘I consulted the interpreter of the sacred law, and, under his directions, rendered at my own charges the ninth-day offerings to the dead’. Cp. [Dem.] or. XLVII. § 68, e)peidh\ toi/nun e)teleu/thsen, h)=lqon w(s tou\s e)chghta/s, i(/na ei)dei/hn o(/ ti me xrh\ poiei=n peri\ tou/twn. The office of e)chghth/s was usually hereditary in Eupatrid houses who possessed the unwritten lore of religious tradition: cp. [Lys.] In Andoc. § 10, mh\ mo/non xrh=sqai toi=s gegramme/nois peri\ au)tw=n no/mois a)lla\ kai\ toi=s a)gra/fois kaq' ou(\s *eu)molpi/dai e)chgou=ntai. In later times there are references to a written lore in such matters, e.g. a ritual of purification for suppliants, i(ketw=n ka/qarsis, Athen. IX. 78. — ta\ e)/nata, novendialia, as tri/ta, Ar. Lysist. 613, offerings at the grave on the third day after death: yearly offerings are mentioned in Isae. or. II. § 46, e)nagi/zh| au)tw=| kaq' e(/kaston e)niauto/n. Herm. Ant. III. § 39.

i(/na...e)kko/yaimi ‘that I might disconcert this sacrilegious scheme of theirs’: i(erosuli/an, i.e. their usurpation of my right (as nearest kinsman) to honour the dead. — e)kko/yaimi, ‘knock
out’ of its course, baffle: cp. Lysias or. XXVIII. § 6, i(/na au)tw=n e)kko/yh|s ta\s sukofanti/as: Deinarchus In Aristogit. § 4, kai\ ta\s profa/seis kai\ tou\s fenakismou\s e)kko/yate au)tou=.
sxedo/n ti tau=t' e)sti/n ‘are substantially these’. Cp. Soph. El. 609, sxedo/n ti...ou) kataisxu/nw, it may be said that I do not...: Ant. 466, sxedo/n ti mw/rw| mwri/an o)fliska/nw.

th/n ou)si/an...diaqh/khn ‘Diocles holds the property, which supports his present splendour, by an act of usurpation (a)llotri/an). Three sisters, children of the same mother, were left heiresses to the estate; but he contrived to represent himself as their father's adopted son, though the father had made no will recognising such adoption’. As Diocles became guardian (§ 42) to the son of one of these sisters, they were probably his own half-sisters on the maternal side (cp. th\n a)delfh/n, § 41), — their mother having previously or subsequently married the father of Diocles. — ei)spoih/sas, by forging a diaqh/kh: without which, the testator's own children would have inherited (by a)gxistei/a) before a child born by his wife to another husband. Diocles was driven to this device because an a)delfh\ o(momh/trios could not marry her half-brother, and therefore he could not obtain any part of the property by marriage with one of the e)pi/klhroi. — Cp. § 36, where the middle ei)spoih/saito is said of the adopting father.

*toi=n d' a)delfai=n...di/khn de/dwke] ‘when the property was claimed on behalf of two of the sisters by their husbands, he contrived to make the husband of the elder sister his prisoner, and then subjected him to gross contumely. An indictment for outrage has been laid against him, but he has not yet expiated this offence’. toi=n duoi=n: the third sister was apparently unmarried, or no longer alive: we are to understand that Diocles seized her share unopposed. katoikodomh/sas=kataklei/sas ei)s oi)/khma (Harpocrat. s.v.), having shut him up in a house or room from which he could not escape: cp. Thuc. I. 134, thrh/santes au)to\n kai\ a)polabo/ntes ei)/sw a)pw|kodo/mhsan, ‘walled him in’. — e)pibouleu/sas following katoikod. is a prwqu/steron, since the ‘plot’ is that which led to the capture. h)ti/mwse: usu. taken here as=h)ti/mase, ‘dishonoured’, referring to some personal assault or outrage such as u(/bris indicates: cp. Aesch. Suppl. 644, a)timw/santes (=a)tima/santes) e)/rin gunaikw=n. Elsewhere in prose a)timo/w usu. = to deprive of civic rights. If this is the true sense here, Diocles must have subsequently charged his captive with some offence which would entail a)timi/a. — grafh\n u(/brews: the same prob. for which Isaeus wrote his speech kata\ *diokle/ous u(/brews: see on § 3, and Sauppe Or. Att. II. 230 f.

th=s de\ met' e)kei/nhn...e)kei/nw| de/dwke ‘As to the younger
sister, he employed a slave to murder her husband, — got the man [e)kei=non=to\n oi)ke/thn] out of the country, — threw the guilt on his sister, — and, having crushed her by his villanies, has further deprived her son — whose guardian he had become — of his property, — keeping the land, and giving his ward a piece of stony ground’. — kataplh/cas refers less to a judicial condemnation than to the helplessness of a cowed and broken spirit: cp. Dem. or. XXXVII. § 43, h(li/kon e)sti\ pleone/kthma (ironical) to\ katapeplh=xqai to\n bi/on. — *felli/a: vulg. felle/a de\ xwri/a a)/tta. But felle/a is acc. sing. of felleu/s, stony ground. Dobree thinks that xwri/a a)/tta arose from a scholion on felle/a, — xwri/on a)ttikw=s. It may be that we should read felli/a a)/tta, some pieces of stony ground: cp. Xen. Cyneg. v. 18, o(/tan tou\s li/qous, ta\ o)/rh, ta\ felli/a [ta\ fe/llia G. Sauppe], ta\ dase/a a)poxwrw=si ‘when (the hares) take refuge among stones, or on the hill-side, or on rough ground (ta\ felli/a), or in underwood’: the contemptuous force of a)/tta is certainly appropriate.

dedi/asi me\n au)to/n, i)/sws d' a)/n moi kai\ marturh=sai e)qelh/seian = kai/per dedio/tes au)to/n, i)/sws a)/n...e)qelh/seian. For the parenthesis with finite verb (dedi/asi me\n au)to/n), cp. Anthol. Palat. 7. 664, *)arxi/loxon kai\ sth=qi kai\ ei)/side (=sta\s ei)/side), and my note on Soph. Ant. 537.
